headline: Dirt Biker Dies After Colliding With Fire Truck In Baltimore
summary: Police are on investigating a fatal dirt bike crash in West Baltimore.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police are on investigating a fatal dirt bike crash in West Baltimore.   According to reports, crews responded to the intersection of West Pratt Street and South Payson Street for a reported crash. On the scene, they found a victim trapped.   Police said a fire truck was responding to a fire with lights and sirens on when it collided with a man on a dirt bike. The driver of the bike was pronounced dead on the scene.   Stay with WJZ on this developing story. To get breaking news alerts, download our app now     Police say a fire truck was responding to a fire with lights and sirens on when it collided with a man on a dirt bike. The driver of the bike died at the scene. Witnesses say they saw the truck drag the man halfway down the block because he was stuck  @wjz   ‚Äî Kelsey Kushner (@KelseyKushnerTV)  October 22, 2021       Media Staging @ S. Payton & W. headline: Diana Toebbe Ordered To Remain In Custody On Espionage Charges
summary: An Annapolis woman accused of conspiring with her husband to sell military secrets to a foreign government must remain in federal custody while awaiting trial on espionage charges, a judge ruled Thursday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  An Annapolis woman accused of conspiring with her husband to sell military secrets to a foreign government must remain in custody while awaiting trial on espionage charges, a judge ruled Thursday. U.S. Magistrate Judge Robert Trumble granted the government‚Äôs motion to detain Diana Toebbe, calling her a flight risk and national security threat if released. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúAlthough Defendant has no prior criminal history, the nature and circumstances of the charges against her and her actions demonstrate that Defendant is a danger to every community and to our national security,‚Äù Trumble wrote. Toebbe, 45, and her husband, Jonathan, 42, were named Tuesday in a three-count indictment  charging the couple with one count of conspiracy to communicate restricted data and two counts of communication of restricted data . The couple is accused of  hatching a plot to sell classified data , which Toebbe‚Äôs husband allegedly stole from his workplace for the U.S. Navy‚Äôs nuclear program, to an unnamed foreign government in exchange for cryptocurrency. Authorities say Toebbe acted as a lookout for her husband when they crossed state lines several times to drop off batches of sensitive submarine data for someone they thought was a foreign agent but was in fact an undercover FBI agent. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The couple was arrested Oct. 9 in West Virginia, where they‚Äôve remained in custody while their case winds its way through the legal system. During a Wednesday detention hearing, Toebbe‚Äôs attorneys insisted their client was innocent and unaware of ‚Äúwhat her husband was up to.‚Äù They said Toebbe, a school teacher, was not a threat or flight risk and could be freed under special conditions. Prosecutors argued that she was complicit in the plot. They pointed to her presence at three of four ‚Äúdead drops,‚Äù and noted several messages the couple allegedly authored, in which they discussed plans to leave the country. In issuing his ruling, Trumble cited the government‚Äôs evidence, which included surveillances images, messages attributed to the couple and signals that they had the means and desire to escape. ‚ÄúDefense counsel presented no evidence or testimony but argued that electronic monitoring, a third-party custodian, and no computer or internet access would suffice to prevent Defendant from fleeing. The Court is unconvinced,‚Äù the judge wrote. ‚ÄúNo bond conditions can be set to reasonable ensure the appearance of Defendant and the safety of the community.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Both have pleaded not guilty to the charges, each of which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison, a $100,000 fine and five years of supervised release.

headline: Annapolis, Columbia & Frederick Among ‚ÄòTop 100 Best Places To Live In America‚Äô
summary: Chances are you already know Maryland‚Äôs a great place to live. But did you know that Annapolis, Columbia and Frederick are among the top 100 best places to live in the U.S.?
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Chances are you already know Maryland‚Äôs a great place to live. But did you know that Annapolis, Columbia and Frederick are among the top 100 best places to live in the U.S.? That‚Äôs according to a new study compiled by Livability.com, which  ranked the nation‚Äôs best cities based on a wide range of criteria  including their economies, health, housing, infrastructure, and education. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Besides those factors, the study‚Äôs authors analyzed each city‚Äôs remote readiness, or how prepared it is to accommodate a workforce that works from home. RELATED:  ‚ÄòBest Small Cities In America‚Äô: Nearly 40 Maryland Cities Appear On 2021 List Coming in at No. 4 was Frederick, which was lauded for its blend of ‚Äúold meets new‚Äù and scored well in the amenities, remote-ready, demographics, civics, education, economy, and housing categories. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Next up was Columbia at No. 15. Known for its high quality of life and open spaces, the city sandwiched between Baltimore and D.C. stood out for its civics, demographics, economy, and health scores. Last but certainly not least was Annapolis at No. 38. Maryland‚Äôs capital city received high marks for its civics and remote readiness. So, what about the top 3? Those honors belong to Madison, Wisconsin; Ann Arbor, Michigan; and Overland Park, Kansas. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Rounding out the top 100 list was none other than Anchorage, Alaska.

headline: Gaming Commission Forwards Sports Wagering Applications From Hollywood Casino, Ocean Downs; No Date Set For State Approval
summary: The Maryland Lottery and Gaming Control Commission on Thursday announced it was forwarding the sports wagering applications of Hollywood Casino in Perryville and Ocean Downs Casino in Berlin to a state commission for final approval. But it's not yet clear when the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission, which awards licenses for sportsbooks, is going to meet nex
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî The Maryland Lottery and Gaming Control Commission on Thursday announced it was forwarding the sports wagering applications of Hollywood Casino in Perryville and Ocean Downs Casino in Berlin to a state commission for final approval. But it‚Äôs not yet clear when the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission, which awards licenses for sportsbooks, is going to meet next. The group postponed an Oct. 14 meeting and has not yet scheduled a new date, the gaming commission said. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Earlier this month the gaming commission  forwarded the applications  of the state‚Äôs three largest casinos‚ÄìHorseshoe Casino in Baltimore, Live! Casino and Hotel in Hanover and MGM National Harbor in Oxon Hill‚Äìfor final approval. The gaming commission previously said all three applications were to be considered at the Oct. 14 meeting. Gov. Larry Hogan released a statement saying he expects the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission to ‚Äúswiftly approve these licenses‚Äù with the NFL season underway and March Madness around the corner. Maryland Lottery and Gaming Director John Martin said his organization will continue forwarding licenses with the expectation sports wagering can launch in late fall. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what the public wants and expects, and we‚Äôre doing everything we can to deliver it,‚Äù he said. All five casinos were named in the law to legalize sports wagering as potential sites for sports books, along with 12 other entities. The qualifications of each business have to be reviewed. In August, SWARC voted unanimously that the gaming commission‚Äôs qualification standards are sufficient for determining how to award sports wagering licenses. Maryland‚Äôs one other casino, the Rocky Gap Casino Resort, was also named in the bill, as were FedEx Field, M&T Bank Stadium, Oriole Park at Camden Yards, Laurel Park and Pimlico Race Course. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Maryland‚Äôs six casinos brought in $165.4 million in revenue last month, according to the most recent data from the gaming commission.

headline: Baltimore County Eagle Scout Makes A Difference One Step At A Time
summary: A Baltimore County Eagle Scout is getting recognized for a community project that's making it easier for people to get around.
bodytext: BALTIMORE COUNTY, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Baltimore County Eagle Scout is getting recognized for a community project that makes it easier for people to get around. Ethan Earle and fellow members of Boy Scout Troop 732 built a 50-foot stairway on the Indian Rock Park‚Äôs Northeast Trail in Nottingham, not far from Perry Hall High School. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The goal of the project, Earle told WJZ, was to make the path easier for people to negotiate. ‚ÄúI took (the project) up because it was something a little bit different,‚Äù Earle told WJZ.   Here‚Äôs what the trail looked like before and how it looks now.   Before the stairway was built, a stretch of the trail was muddy and the terrain wasn‚Äôt the easiest for people to use. ‚ÄúOnce I found that and the fact that there are actual students going through this messy, muddy hill, I decided, ‚ÄòWhy not improve it and make it a more accessible area for the community?'‚Äù Earle said. The troop cut pieces of lumber and assembled them into individual steps, then placed them along the path. Once that was complete, they filled in the steps with gravel. The finished product became an instant hit with the community. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúI‚Äôve also seen an uptick in community members using it as well because now it‚Äôs easier access,‚Äù resident Patty Warren said. The stairway also earned Earle some well-deserved recognition from his peers. In fact, the Baltimore Area Council of the Boy Scouts America named the stairwell its Eagle Project of the Year, setting it apart from hundreds of other submissions. Earle will be honored Thursday evening at the Boy Scouts‚Äô annual Gathering of the Eagles dinner, a networking opportunity that brings together hundreds of Eagle Scouts. The teen‚Äôs troop leader is among those who are proud of Earle‚Äôs accomplishment. ‚ÄúTo me, it means that the boys are working hard,‚Äù Boy Scout Troop 732 Scout Master Bob Jones said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre out volunteering in the community and they‚Äôre doing projects that are worthwhile and help people in the community, as Ethan has done.‚Äù Earle, who said he was humbled by the honor, said the skills he‚Äôs acquired as a scout are helping him prepare for life as an adult. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúIt also shows that you‚Äôre willing to put in everything that you‚Äôve got, shows you have determination and will,‚Äù he said.

headline: Key Takeaways From President Joe Biden‚Äôs CNN Town Hall
summary: During the CNN town hall, moderated by Anderson Cooper, the president touched on several issues including infrastructure, his domestic agenda, his "Build Back Better" plan, spending proposals, tax rates, supply chain issues and Covid during the 90-minute event.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  President Joe Biden has been taking his ‚Äú Build Back Better ‚Äù plan on the road to the American people. His latest stop was here in Baltimore. During the  CNN town hall , moderated by Anderson Cooper, the president touched on several issues including infrastructure, his domestic agenda, his ‚ÄúBuild Back Better‚Äù plan, spending proposals, tax rates, supply chain issues and Covid during the 90-minute event. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School One of the first issues addressed was President Biden‚Äôs Build Back Better plan. Anderson Cooper:  ‚ÄúAre you close to a done deal?‚Äù President Joe Biden:  ‚ÄúThis is a big deal. We have two plans. One is the infrastructure plan, roads, highway, bridges, buses, trains, etc. And the other one is what I call the care economy. It has a lot of money in there for environmental remediation as well as care economy. For example, you know, we want to get the economy moving but millions of women can‚Äôt go to work because they don‚Äôt have any child care. That kind of thing. So there‚Äôs a lot of pieces in there. There‚Äôs a lot that people don‚Äôt understand. And by the way, all this paid for. Every single penny. It‚Äôs not going to raise one single cent.‚Äù President Biden also expressed optimism on two key spending proposals. He said he believes divided lawmakers are close to an agreement and urged to focus on compromising in regards to the legislation. Biden:  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all about compromise,‚Äù said Biden. ‚ÄúYou know, compromise has become a dirty word, but bipartisanship and compromise still has to be possible.‚Äù TAXES The president also said that corporations need to pay their fair share of taxes when asked about tax rates. Biden added that corporate leaders know they should be paying more in taxes. Ben Frederick, realtor : ‚ÄúI hear you repeatedly say that the wealthy are not paying their fair share of income taxes. What is the percentage of income that you believe is fair?‚Äù Biden:  ‚ÄúI come from the corporate state of the world: Delaware. More corporations in Delaware than every other state in the union combined. Okay? Now, here‚Äôs the deal, though. You have 55 corporations, for example, in the United States of America making over $40 billion, don‚Äôt pay a cent. Not a single little red cent. Now, I don‚Äôt care. I‚Äôm a capitalist. I hope you can be a millionaire or billionaire. But at least pay your fair share. Chip in a little bit.‚Äù The corporate tax rate was 35 point, 37 percent. Barack and I thought it should come down. We thought it should come down to 28 percent. In the process, it came down to 21 percent under Trump. Which even the corporate leaders, and you know if you‚Äôre in real estate, major real estate, ask them. They know they should be paying a little more than 21 percent because the idea that if you‚Äôre a school teacher and a firefighter you‚Äôre paying at a higher tax rate than they are as a percentage of your taxes.‚Äù SUPPLY CHAIN ISSUES When asked about the supply chain issues, President Biden said he is prepared to call the National Guard to help. Biden:  ‚ÄúThe answer is, ‚Äòyes,‚Äô if we can‚Äôt move, increase the number of truckers, which we are in a process of doing.‚Äù The president also addressed the increase in gas prices and said it‚Äôs likely that they will remain high until 2022. Biden:  ‚ÄúMy guess is you‚Äôll start to see gas prices come down as we get into next year, 2022. I don‚Äôt see anything that‚Äôs going to happen in the meantime that‚Äôs going to significantly reduce gas prices.‚Äù COVID The president was also asked what he would say to struggling Americans affected by COVID-19 and the economy. He said that as things improve within the country, spirits will be lifted. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Biden:  ‚ÄúA lot of it has to do with us getting back on our feet. Getting back on our feet, in terms of our attitudes about what the future looks like for us.‚Äù He also added,¬† ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs plenty of help. Being down, having some problem, in terms of needing some advice, if you have a broken spirit, it‚Äôs no different than a broken arm. They shouldn‚Äôt be ashamed of it. They should seek the help. There is a lot of people who can help.‚Äù The White House is gearing up to roll out COVID-19 shots for children ages five to 11 and the plans were released on  Wednesday.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre completing the operational planning to ensure vaccinations for kids ages five to 11 are available, easy and convenient,‚Äù White House COVID-19 coordinator Jeff Zients said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to be ready, pending the FDA and CDC decision.‚Äù Biden said his administration has ‚Äúsecured enough vaccine supply to vaccinate the 28 million children who would become eligible.‚Äù Biden:  ‚ÄúThe expectations are, they should be ready in the near term.‚Äù He also added, ‚ÄúI want to make it clear, unlike past administrations, science will dictate this.‚Äù Biden also addressed first responders who refuse to get vaccinated. He said he believes that they should ‚Äúbe forced to stay home or let go.‚Äù He also said he believes that mandates are working. Biden:  ‚ÄúI waited until July to talk about mandating. I tried everything else possible. The mandates are working.‚Äù FILLIBUSTER When asked about the filibuster, Biden said a debate over it right now will cost him votes on his economic agenda. Biden:  ‚ÄúHere is the deal, if, in fact, I get myself into at this moment the debate on the filibuster, I lose at least three votes right now to get what I have to get done on the economic side of the equation, foreign policy side of the equation.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúIt used to be the filibuster the way it worked and we have ten times as many more than that, times the filibuster has been used since 1978, it used to be you had to stand on the floor and exhaust everything you had and when you gave up the floor and someone else sought the floor, they had to talk until they finished. You‚Äôre only allowed to do it a second time. After that, it‚Äôs over. You vote. Someone moves for the vote. I propose we bring that back now, immediately.‚Äù US SOUTHERN BORDER CRISIS Biden said he has not visited the Southern Border but will consider it in the future. He said he has not had a ‚Äúwhole lot of time to visit.‚Äù Biden:  ‚ÄúI guess I should go down, but the whole point of it is I have not had a whole lot of time to get down.‚Äù The president also stressed that the US is not sending children back and defended his decision to uphold  Title 42. ‚ÄúWe have maintained that because of the continued extent of Covid in those countries from which people are coming. It is very, high. So, we maintained the policy.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúWe are not sending back children, we send back adults, and we send back large families but we don‚Äôt send back children in that circumstance.‚Äù Get alerts from WJZ first!  Follow WJZ on Facebook ¬†  download the app. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night‚Äôs Town Hall
summary: When President Joe Biden's motorcade pulled up at Baltimore Center Stage Thursday night, both supporters and protesters were there to make some noise.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  When President Joe Biden‚Äôs motorcade pulled up at Baltimore Center Stage Thursday night, both supporters and protesters were there to make some noise. ‚ÄúWe are here reminding the president that there are over eight million undocumented community members that are counting on him, that are waiting on him to ensure a pathway to citizenship,‚Äù said Lydia Walther-Rodriguez, CASA. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Inside the theater,¬† Marylanders rattled off questions to the president on a wide range of topics like free college tuition. He admitted it may not happen right now. ‚ÄúI promise you, I guarantee you, we are going to get free community college in the next several years,‚Äù said President Joe Biden. When it comes to his trillion-dollar infrastructure bill, the president reminded the audience that the bill could evolve and become better over time. ‚ÄúSo I am prepared to do the things that can get done now. That can begin to change the lives of ordinary Americans to give them  a fighting chance,‚Äù said Biden. Here in Baltimore, where city leaders are facing a challenge from workers‚Äô unions who are pushing back against vaccine mandates, the president said he has tried everything possible.¬†‚ÄúI waited until July to talk about mandates because I tried everything else possible. The mandates are working.‚Äù READ MORE:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized This was the president‚Äôs first visit to the city since taking office. He met with city leaders who are also touting his agenda. ‚ÄúIt showcases that Baltimore is a city that‚Äôs coming back and the president is coming to highlight the ‚ÄòBuild Back Better‚Äô agenda and what better place to do that than the city that is going to be the best come back story of any city,‚Äù said Mayor Brandon Scott. For some of the hundreds of people who got a seat inside the theater, this was their only chance to hear from the president in the same room. ‚ÄúI think it was really great to have a lot of students and engage some younger democrats in the conversation,‚Äù said Sydney Brooke. ‚ÄúI was very impressed, I think he knows, he has an objective and he knows what he wants,‚Äù Patrick Armstrong added. MORE NEWS:  Dirt Biker Dies After Colliding With Fire Truck In Baltimore The president also took a question from a student about the shipping backlog that‚Äôs driving up prices. He said he‚Äôs willing to activate the National Guard to help alleviate some of those problems.

headline: Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized
summary: Right now, seven children in Maryland are hospitalized with Covid-19 including three in intensive care, and the push is on to vaccinate more adolescents aged 12 and older.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Right now, seven children in Maryland are hospitalized with Covid-19 including three in intensive care, and the push is on to vaccinate more adolescents aged 12 and older. Dr. Kawsar Taalat from Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health said Thursday that the FDA could approve vaccines for those aged five to 11 years old as soon as early November. The FDA will meet to discuss vaccines for children next week. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The rollout will not look like it did with adults‚Äîwith smaller vaccine clinics instead of mass vaccination sites. The doses will also be administered using smaller needles. Health officials will rely on trusted pediatricians, pharmacies and school clinics to get shots into arms. Dr. Tamar Mendelson, also with Johns Hopkins, said treating covid vaccinations like any normal visit to the doctor will reduce anxiety among children over the shot. On Thursday, a mobile vaccine clinic was set up outside Cherry Hill Elementary-Middle School where an outbreak hit last month. Three new cases have been reported in the last 10 days. The city‚Äôs public schools have reported 193 total infections in that same period. Janae Stanley has a daughter at the school. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs frightening because this covid is killing people, and I care about my child‚Äôs safety,‚Äù she told WJZ Investigator Mike Hellgren. ‚ÄúMy sister is terrified. She has a young infant, and she doesn‚Äôt want that stuff to come to her home.‚Äù The good news: Outbreaks in Maryland schools are down 15 percent overall compared to last week according to the governor‚Äôs office. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Here are the largest in our area according to the Maryland Department of Health: 41 cases at Friends School in Baltimore City, 40 at Chesapeake High in Anne Arundel County and 39 at Saint Ursula Catholic in Baltimore County. The biggest outbreak in the state is at Margaret Brent Middle School in St. Mary‚Äôs County with 89 infections. Leonardtown High School, also in St Mary‚Äôs County, has 72 cases. You can see the entire statewide list  here. In Baltimore City Public Schools, Baltimore International Academy Elementary Middle has the most cases at 24. You can access the school system‚Äôs dashboard  here. Anne Arundel County reports more than 1,400 students and staff are currently in quarantine. You can see their latest numbers  here.¬† Back in Cherry Hill, community leader Crystal Branch told Hellgren it can be a challenge just battling misinformation among those already eligible for the vaccine. ‚ÄúWe are making sure you have the literature so you have the information as well so you don‚Äôt hear from word of mouth, ‚ÄòIf I get the vaccine, I‚Äôm going to turn into a robot or they‚Äôre trying to make zombies or I might die if I get the vaccine,‚Äô‚Äù said Branch, the president of the Cherry Hill Tenant Council. ‚ÄúI say to them, ‚ÄòWhat about protecting your child? What about setting an example as the head of your household? Why not protect your kids 12 and over.‚Äô Come with them, make vaccination a family thing.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Dirt Biker Dies After Colliding With Fire Truck In Baltimore ¬†

headline: Supply Chain Issues: ‚ÄòThere Really Are Problems Everywhere,‚Äô Even For Small Companies
summary: Extensive slowdowns all along the supply chain are preventing consumers from buying what they want when they want, suggesting broader problems across the economy.
bodytext: ( CBS Baltimore ) ‚Äî  Why are the shelves at the local grocery store always partly empty? Why do deliveries take so much longer than they used to? Why is everything more expensive? The short answer is  supply chain  issues. The long answer is not that simple. It goes without saying that the once-in-a-lifetime COVID pandemic has exacerbated existing issues. That includes a shortage of workers along the path that products take from the factory to a consumer‚Äôs doorstep, creating multiple bottlenecks in a system that depends on timeliness to function, just as demand has drastically increased for those products. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Even that more complicated explanation doesn‚Äôt fully explain why consumers can‚Äôt buy what they want when they want. That‚Äôs because there are no easy answers and no easy fixes. What Is The Supply Chain? The supply chain is the series of steps that brings a product to a customer.  Martin Dresner , Professor and Chair of the Logistics, Business and Public Policy Department at the R.H. Smith School of Business at the University of Maryland, describes it as the¬†‚Äúnetwork of manufacturers, their suppliers, distributors, retailers that are responsible for getting products from point of origin to the final customer.‚Äù The network for any given company can start with suppliers of raw materials and other inputs, and include shipping those supplies to a manufacturing facility. Once inputs are transformed into a finished product, it is moved to a warehouse or a store and then ultimately to the final customer. Various agents, brokers, vendors, transportation companies, and distribution centers can play key roles along the way in ensuring a product gets made and reaches its final destination. A supply chain for large company can get very complicated very fast. Dresner describes just how complicated in an example of a typical packaged goods company: ‚ÄúA packaged goods manufacturer has many suppliers, and those suppliers will be supplying raw materials for use in the production process. And that could be farmers, or farmers can sell through distributors. Or the product used by the manufacturer might be manufactured themselves, so they may have other components suppliers. ‚ÄúWe think of the suppliers that sell directly to Procter & Gamble or Kellogg‚Äôs as first-tier suppliers,‚Äù he continues. ‚ÄúBut then there are people who supply them, and we would call those second-tier suppliers. And there could be third-tier, fourth-tier suppliers as well, all the way back to where the components of the product originate. That manufacturer also may not do all the manufacturing themselves. They contract out some manufacturing. Those contract manufacturers are also suppliers to packaged good manufacturers. And they have their own supply chains.‚Äù Once a product is produced, it must find its way to the consumer. ‚ÄúManufacturers will often not sell directly to customers, but they will sell through distributors,‚Äù Dresner further explains. ‚ÄúDistributors may sell to retailers, and manufacturers may sell directly to retailers. There can be other companies involved in the sale and distributions of products. There can be agents or brokers, transporters. There are all sorts of companies that need to be involved in getting the product to their eventual end user. All these companies, they‚Äôre a part of that focal firm, that packaged goods manufacturer‚Äôs supply chain.‚Äù So many steps along the way leave plenty of opportunities for slowdowns. And those slowdowns build upon each other to create growing delays for a company. Multiple Elements Are Making Matters Worse Now imagine that every company that produces and/or sells a physical product has its own unique supply chain. Some are more complicated, some are less complicated. But all of them have some basic elements in common. And all leverage the same regional, national and global systems to (hopefully) deliver their product to their consumer in a timely manner. This broader global pipeline of goods is the ‚Äúsupply chain‚Äù that‚Äôs garnering headlines for all the causing delays and pushing up prices. Cargo ships carrying as many as half a million  shipping containers  filled with goods from various countries in Asia await offloading at the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach. Once they are offloaded, a  shortage of truck drivers  prevents those loads from moving out of ports in a timely manner.  Railroad terminals , where trucks deliver goods for the next leg of the journey, are backed up with containers awaiting further transport, which, in turn, also block inbound trains. Should those goods somehow make it to a warehouse, worker shortages are limiting their timely processing. And, as if all that weren‚Äôt enough, the  United States Postal Service  has recently slowed its delivery times. The ¬†COVID pandemic is certainly to blame for this cascading array of problems in the supply chain. But it isn‚Äôt the only culprit. A global microchip shortage, exacerbated by  Texas winter storms  that affected domestic production, is slowing the production of cars and various electronic devices. China, where many consumer goods destined for America are produced, is suffering through an  ongoing energy crisis  that‚Äôs curtailing manufacturing. And manufacturers in many other countries with lower rates of vaccination have endured shutdowns and worker shortages brought on by the spread of the Delta variant. One Small Company Suffering Big Supply Chain Problems The  Unemployed Philosophers Guild  (UPG) is one of the many companies navigating the supply chain issues affecting the entire marketplace. The Brooklyn-based gift company specializes in creating and selling smart and funny gifts for smart and funny people or, as their website puts it,¬†‚Äúfulfilling the people‚Äôs needs for finger puppets, warm slippers, coffee cups, and cracking up at stuff.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Finger puppets of famous people, known as  magnetic personalities , are among its most popular gifts, according to UPG Director of Sales, Trudi Bartow. Current bestsellers include former Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsberg, former painter and television host Bob Ross, and President Biden‚Äôs Chief Medical Advisor, Anthony Fauci. ‚ÄúWe partner with the manufacturer to physically make that product,‚Äù according to Bartow. ‚ÄúI would say that 65 percent of our products are made overseas, which is a little bit different than if they‚Äôre made in the United States. Supply chain issues for the most part right now are overseas issues, so I‚Äôll focus on that. Once our manufacturer has made the product, then we load it onto a container, load that container onto a boat. We ship that boat to the U.S. It goes to a port. It gets taken off the boat. The container is put on a rail. The rail goes into our warehouse. Our warehouse takes the container and puts it all on the shelf and marks it all as in stock. And then we sell it to physical stores or to online stores, doesn‚Äôt really matter. And that product is then taken out of the warehouse, put on a truck, shipped to the store, and then put on that store‚Äôs shelves, either physically, so someone can walk in and remove it and purchase it, or in some online store purchase it and then it is shipped to them.‚Äù Those finger puppets, like many of UPG‚Äôs other products and goods across the marketplace in general, are taking longer to get to market. ‚ÄúWe are not unique, as is any gift manufacturer or any manufacturer of any product,‚Äù says Bartow. ‚ÄúThere are pretty much issues throughout the entire process, throughout the entire supply chain‚Ä¶ There really are problems everywhere.‚Äù Where Are The Problems? The United States is the world‚Äôs largest economy, with the purchases of individual consumers accounting for over two-thirds of the economic activity. Some of those purchases are services, like dry-cleaning or a stay at a fancy hotel. Some of those purchases are goods, which could be anything from an Anthony Fauci finger puppet to a $45,000 SUV. Around  90 percent  of goods produced travel across an ocean to reach a consumer. For a magnetic finger puppet, destined to be displayed on your neighbor‚Äôs refrigerator, that trip begins at a manufacturing plant in China alongside thousands of other little finger puppets. And that manufacturing plant is likely experiencing problems. According to Bartow, ‚Äúit can start at the factory overseas, rising costs of goods, an increase in electric fees on the Chinese power grid particularly, COVID cases shutting down warehouses, while they do cleanings. Keeping distance on the manufacturing floor has created delays there.‚Äù Once that little Anthony Fauci is created, it must find its way to a port, where a boat can take it across the Pacific Ocean. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs physically a lack of drivers everywhere, so getting containers to ports is tricky, because now there‚Äôs a backlog,‚Äù Bartow explains. ‚ÄúThen things are sitting on ports for extra long time, because there‚Äôs delays in seafarers and boats. So now instead of sitting there for a week or two, you could sit there for multiple weeks waiting to even get a booking. And once you get a booking, there‚Äôs even more delays with dock workers getting your stuff onto boats.‚Äù The time for that Anthony Fauci finger puppet to cross the ocean hasn‚Äôt changed. But the time for him to transfer to the next leg of the trip has. ‚ÄúNow you‚Äôve arrived at, say, the Port of LA,‚Äù Bartow continues. ‚ÄúAnd instead of taking a week to clear and get off, it could be two, three weeks maybe even more, because there‚Äôs a long queue in the Port of LA. Once again these are all restrictions on the supply chain. There‚Äôs not enough dock workers. The dock workers that are there are under safety restrictions. There are shutdowns for COVID. There‚Äôs increased or decreased hours depending on labor. So that adds delay.‚Äù Eventually the Anthony Fauci finger puppet and all his finger puppet friends find their way into the Port of Los Angeles and off the boat. But the delays continue. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a  shortage of drivers . There‚Äôs a shortage of trucks. There‚Äôs a shortage of physical containers to move things back and forth.‚Äù After a long road trip from the port, the finger puppets arrive at the warehouse. ‚ÄúThe warehouse is subject to the same hurdles as everywhere else,‚Äù Bartow points out. ‚ÄúThe shortage of labor causing a shortage in packing containers. Containers can sit outside a warehouse for one to three weeks.‚Äù But the trip still isn‚Äôt over. When an online or physical retailer places an order for 100 Anthony Fauci magnetic personalities, a box is sent to the store. Once there, a customer can buy the finger puppet in person or online. At that point, the U.S. mail system takes over. The  U.S. Postal Service  has started slowing deliveries in an effort to cut costs. The inevitable result for the consumers will be more delays in the last leg of that finger puppet‚Äôs journey. With problems all along the supply chain, consumers are experiencing increasing shortages, higher prices, and delivery showdowns for a wide range of goods across the economy. That could mean wine from northern California, as producers try to  procure bottles  and the paper for labels. That could also mean food items at the local  grocery store , as retailers struggle to stock shelves. It could even mean  artificial Christmas trees  and decorations, which are currently stuck in ports around the country. All the supply chain issues don‚Äôt bode well for the upcoming holiday season. Expect extensive delays as potential gifts, move slowly across oceans, through ports, along highways and railroad tracks to warehouses and stores. So if you‚Äôre expecting to give an Anthony Fauci finger puppet to remind friends and loved ones to wear a mask, ordering early is probably a good idea. (Note: The author‚Äôs wife works at the Unemployed Philosophers Guild.) headline: Adhir Kalyan And Parker Young On ‚ÄòUnited States Of Al‚Äôs Last Minute Season 2 Rewrite: ‚ÄòArt Really Imitated Life‚Äô
summary: Adhir Kalyan and Parker Young discuss season 2 of 'United States Of Al' on CBS.
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì¬† United States Of Al  is back tonight at 8:30PM ET/PT on CBS and available to stream with Paramount+. Tonight‚Äôs episode ‚ÄúMo/Masoud‚Äù sees Al trying to find an Afghan-American bachelor to set up with his sister while Riley and Freddy challenge each other to a bowling match. CBS‚Äô Matt Weiss spoke to series stars Adhir Kilyan and Parker Young about the incredible backstory behind their season two premiere and the authenticity behind the show as a whole. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School MW-  Adhir, Parker nice to see you both again. Second season of  United States Of Al  underway, congratulations right off the bat. How does it feel to be back for season two? AK-  Oh gosh, I mean what a thrill this is. The fact that we get to come back and shoot a second season was just a real treat, we feel lucky. MW-  What were some of the big differences in shooting season two compared to season one? AK-  Well, I think with the second season the biggest difference has been that we had to address what was happening in Afghanistan. When the writers came together to begin writing season two none of what happened was unfolding. As Kabul fell into the hands of the Taliban and we began to see the United States withdrawing from Afghanistan our writers had no choice but to scrap what we had and go back to the writer‚Äôs room. PY-  Yeah, I think this scenario unfolding was something that we were somewhat aware of and then the worst case scenario really unfolded. No one anticipated it unfolding as quickly as it did. AK-  We had already begun shooting season two and we had an entirely different premiere episode and we had to pivot. We had to adjust and address what had happened. We didn‚Äôt know what that story was or what the new premier would be or even what the season was going to look like moving forward. PY-  What we did know was that we had to help our Afghan colleagues get their loved ones out of Afghanistan, or at least do everything in our power to assist them in that in that process. So we literally put everything on hold and we were on the phone for days on end trying to get ahold of loved ones. We were essentially conducting a rescue operation and through that rescue operation the premiere episode really revealed itself. Our art really imitated life. AK-  I think you know the opening episode of the season was incredibly strong. We certainly feel like it was authentic because it was. It was a reflection of the real-life experiences people were facing. Everyone really banded together to not only serve the story but to also be a source of support for real people. We will continue to track the stories of these characters against the backdrop of everything that‚Äôs unfolding as the season progresses. We will also begin to see these characters truly develop their relationships. I think the outline gets even stronger as the season evolves. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall We‚Äôll get to learn more about Riley‚Äôs readjustment to civilian life and the steps that he‚Äôs taking to get himself into a better headspace. We‚Äôll learn more about how his family and we have some really, really funny episodes on the way. I think our writers and Mr. Chuck Lorre have done a remarkable job of really trying to shed a spotlight on some very serious issues but doing so in a heartfelt sincere way, in a way that‚Äôs also quite touching. PY-  Yeah, it was obviously incredibly emotional for everyone. Everything felt so heightened at the time because it was. What we will endeavor to do on the show is to tell stories as truthful and as honest as possible whilst at the same time keeping audiences entertained. This is ultimately a family show and you know we really want the show to reflect not only the lives of these characters but to offer something for everyone. MW-  Sounds like you went through a very real-life situation while making this season. How much work goes into making the show as authentic as possible with feedback from people you have behind the scenes? AK-  How lucky are we that we have such a wealth of experience and insight to be able to draw upon. Whether it‚Äôs our truth, or Afghan colleagues or veterans on staff or we have an incredible military consultant as well. They really are able to bring their own life experiences to the show. I think certainly from the responses we‚Äôve gotten from the Afghan community and the military, they really feel that there‚Äôs a degree of authenticity that the show is bringing to the table. PY-  Absolutely, yeah these are true stories. I think that everybody is really endeavoring to make the show as great as possible, to honor our veterans. We‚Äôre taking this very serious subject matter but we‚Äôre making it fun and palatable and hope that everybody enjoys it as much as we‚Äôre enjoying making it. AK-  It‚Äôs such a great privilege that we have been working with such an amazing team of writers and producers and Mr. Chuck Lorre. They are all so incredibly adept at taking things that might not look like there are going to be funny when you look at them on a page but they just make things really heartfelt. We just hope these stories will continue to resonate with viewers MW-  Absolutely, thank you both so much for the time and all the best moving forward! AK-  Thanks, Matt! PY-  Thank you, man. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Tune in for new episodes of  United States Of Al  at 8:30 PM ET/PT on CBS and available to stream with  Paramount+ . Check your local listings for more information.

headline: HBCU‚Äôs Howard, Morgan State To Play At NBA All-Star Weekend
summary: The NBA plans to generate exposure for historically Black colleges and universities at the All-Star weekend again this season.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (AP) ‚Äî  Among those likely playing at the NBA All-Star weekend this season are Kevin Durant, LeBron James and Stephen Curry. Also playing at All-Star weekend: the men‚Äôs teams from Howard and Morgan State. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The NBA plans to generate exposure for historically Black colleges and universities at the All-Star weekend again this season, announcing Thursday the matchup for the inaugural NBA HBCU Classic on Feb. 19. Howard was scheduled to play Morgan State that day at home in Washington; instead, at the NBA‚Äôs request, the teams will meet in Cleveland on the Saturday of All-Star weekend. Howard athletic director Kery Davis wasn‚Äôt sure how his basketball coach, Kenny Blakeney, would like the idea of giving up a home Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference game against a rival. Turns out, Blakeney didn‚Äôt need any convincing. ‚ÄúThis is great for everybody,‚Äù Davis said. ‚ÄúA rising tide lifts all boats and this is a great opportunity for all HBCUs and for us individually in terms of exposing people to our university and our university‚Äôs history, traditions and excellence, quite frankly. So, he got it right away.‚Äù Some details are still being worked out. The NBA said the game will be nationally televised from the Wolstein Center in Cleveland, the arena that will play host to some All-Star weekend events. The home of the Cleveland Cavaliers, Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse, will be the site of the biggest events of the weekend, such as All-Star Saturday Night and the All-Star Game itself on Sunday. There are no shortage of NBA players who have worked to raise the exposure of HBCUs in recent years, James, Curry and Chris Paul among them. The league said at All-Star weekend last season that it would do its part as well. On Thursday, in addition to announcing plans for the game, it revealed the start of a paid fellowship program that will place HBCU students in jobs with the league office and with NBA and WNBA teams. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúThe NBA should be commended for the foresight and willingness to address important issues surrounding diversity, equity and inclusion,‚Äù Morgan State athletic director and vice president Ed Scott said. Last season‚Äôs All-Star Game in Atlanta generated at least $3 million for HBCUs ¬†through donations to scholarship funds ‚Äî and the exposure those schools got during the game was worth even more. The court was designed by artists from HBCUs; the pregame featured bands from Grambling State, Florida A&M and Clark Atlanta; and¬† even the trio of referees assigned to the game ¬†by the NBA were all HBCU graduates. Howard‚Äôs history is rich, with the school dating back to 1867 and a list of alumni that includes Vice President Kamala Harris, Elijah Cummings, Thurgood Marshall, Toni Morrison and countless other people prominent in their fields. But when Davis travels the country, he said, he‚Äôs routinely asked where Howard is and if it‚Äôs a Division I institution. After All-Star weekend, he hopes, more people will know the answer to those questions. ‚ÄúI think it gives us an opportunity to connect with an audience who potentially don‚Äôt know much about us,‚Äù Davis said. ‚ÄúBut also, not only does it give an opportunity to get exposure to the universities, it also gives an opportunity to tell the story of the universities ‚Äî which is even more important.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized (¬© Copyright 2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: Customs & Border Protection Warns Shoppers To Be Diligent While Shopping For Toys Online This Holiday Season
summary: Officials want to remind consumers to be extra diligent while shopping online this holiday season after Baltimore Customs and Border Protection officers seized a shipment of toys coated in unsafe levels of lead, cadmium and barium.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Officials want to remind consumers to be extra diligent while shopping online this holiday season after Baltimore Customs and Border Protection officers seized a shipment of toys coated in unsafe levels of lead, cadmium and barium. Officials said that the toys were initially inspected on July 16 and included seven boxes with 295 packages from China. The contents included Lagori 7 Stones, a popular children‚Äôs game in India. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The shipment was detained on Aug. 24 and nine samples were sent to the lab for analysis. Lab results revealed that the toys were coated in lead, cadmium and barium that exceeded safe levels for consumer products. As a result, the remaining shipment was also seized on Oct. 4. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Officials said the toys were destined to an address in Fairfax County, Virginia. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúThe health and safety of our nation‚Äôs children remains a priority concern for Customs and Border Protection, CPSC and all of our consumer safety partners,‚Äù said Adam Rottman, CBP‚Äôs Area Port Director for the Area Port of Baltimore. ‚ÄúWe hope that seizures like this helps to raise consumer awareness about the very real threats posed by seemingly safe children‚Äôs toys and we urge consumers to conduct their due diligence when purchasing holiday gifts online this year.‚Äù

headline: Health Officials Share Ways To Keep Children Safe This Holiday Season
summary: Halloween is right around the corner and before you know it the holidays will be here. Plenty of families are getting travel plans ready but the big question many have is how do u keep kids safe who are still unvaccinated?
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Halloween is right around the corner and before you know it the holidays will be here. Plenty of families are getting travel plans ready but the big question many have is how do u keep kids safe who are still unvaccinated? It‚Äôs never too soon to start making those holiday plans. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúFor Thanksgiving, we will stay local,‚Äù said Raina Crawford. But this year, the big question is: will it be safe for unvaccinated kids? ‚ÄúFor us, last year was about keeping the grandparents safe. This year is now about keeping our kids safe,‚Äù said Crawford. Raina Crawford has two kids under the age of nine. She says when it comes to making holiday plans this year, safety is a top priority. ‚ÄúI really miss seeing the extended families but just kind of the domino effects. It‚Äôs not worth it, plus I don‚Äôt want my kids to get covid, ‚Äú said Crawford. Right now only the Pfizer shot is approved for kids over 12 but an FDA advisory committee is set to meet next week to consider allowing the shot for kids five to 11. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Until a vaccine is approved, it‚Äôs putting a pause on holiday planning. ‚ÄúLast Christmas, we did nothing. So this Christmas, they are asking to do things and go over family members‚Äô houses and I‚Äôm like mhm maybe. We might but I have to make sure everyone is vaccinated,‚Äù Kendra McCoy. Doctors say there is a way to keep kids safe this holiday season and it all starts with knowing the risks. ‚ÄúThe best thing to know is where you‚Äôre going how you‚Äôre getting there and who‚Äôs going to be there, ‚Äú said Dr. Scott Krugman at Sinai Hospital. Dr. Krugman says if you‚Äôre having a large family gathering, encourage eligible family members to get vaccinated or to quarantine before the gathering. If you‚Äôre planning to fly, he says airlines have been doing a good job making sure travelers are masked up. ‚ÄúThe safest thing is to test yourself 72 hours before going, ‚Äú said Dr. Krugman. He added you can always get the family tested. ‚ÄúMake sure you‚Äôre negative and if everybody does that you can be pretty safe and not worry about the kids.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The CDC says wearing a mask indoors is important, no matter your vaccination status. Another option is to always bring the party outside.

headline: ‚ÄòYou Could Never Be Mad At This Guy‚Äô: Little Italy Community Mourning The Loss Of Beloved Server
summary: Those who knew him said Marco Osorio had a profound impact on the community there and now life won‚Äôt be the same without him.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Members of the Little Italy community are mourning the loss of a server who was killed in a car crash on Monday. Those who knew him said Marco Osorio had a profound impact on the community there and now life won‚Äôt be the same without him. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúIt was devastating,‚Äù said Chesley Patterson, general manager of La Scala Ristorante Italiano. ‚ÄúHe had a massive impact on everybody.‚Äù Twenty-six-year-old Marco Osorio was on his way to work on his motorcycle when he was struck by a pickup truck making a right turn onto Brookview Road in Dundalk. He was then taken to the hospital where he later died, leaving colleagues and friends at La Scala Ristorante where he worked, devastated. ‚ÄúThere is a massive hole here,‚Äù said Patterson. Marco worked at the restaurant for 11 years first as a busboy and then as a server where he was known for his beaming personality, sense of humor and infectious charisma. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúThey all loved him he was so funny, he joked with them,‚Äù Patterson added. ‚ÄúYou could never be mad at this guy,‚Äù said Jose Torres, bartender and server at La Scala Ristorante Italiano. He leaves behind his six-year-old daughter, Delainey, who the restaurant has pledged to support with the help of a  gofundme.¬† ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to take care of Delainey and that‚Äôs for sure,‚Äù said Torres. Services for Marco are below: MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Studies Show COVID-19 Worsens Pregnancy Complication Risk
summary: Only a third of people who are pregnant are fully vaccinated against Covid-19, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî  Pregnant women who develop  Covid-19 symptoms  risk emergency complications and other problems with their pregnancies, according to two new studies. The disease also puts their children at risk. The first study showed that pregnant women with symptomatic Covid-19 had a higher percentage of emergency complications when compared to those who tested positive but didn‚Äôt have symptoms. This research was part of a presentation given to the Anesthesiology 2021 Annual meeting over the weekend. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Of the 100 Covid-positive mothers who delivered babies between March and September of last year at one hospital in Texas, 58% of those with symptomatic infections delivered in emergency circumstances, the study, which has yet to be peer reviewed, found. For those with an asymptomatic case, 46% did. The mothers with symptoms were more likely have emergency complications that were a danger to the baby. More babies were born breech, there was more likely to be decreased fetal movement, and some had too little amniotic fluid. The study also found that babies born to these symptomatic mothers were much more likely to need oxygen support and more likely to be admitted to the intensive care unit. Plus, babies born to these symptomatic mothers were much more likely to need oxygen support and more likely to be admitted to the intensive care unit. ‚ÄúCOVID-19 has severe systemic effects on the body, especially symptomatic patients,‚Äù said Kristine Lane, a medical student at the University of Texas Medical Branch, in Galveston, Texas, who helped lead the study. ‚ÄúIt is possible that these effects are amplified in pregnant mothers, who have increased fetal and maternal oxygen demands.‚Äù There‚Äôs also a possibility, she said, that the doctors caring for the symptomatic patients were being cautious because of the virus and proactively recommend a cesarean delivery. Dr. Gil Mor, a reproductive immunologist who did not work on the study but reviewed the work, said it‚Äôs also possible that the problems could be related to chronic inflammation caused by Covid-19. ‚ÄúInflammation is extremely dangerous for both the mother and the development of the fetus. A chronic inflammation is now a fight for the survival of the mother and the fetus, and in every fight, they pay they pay a price,‚Äù said Mor, who leads a research lab at Wayne State University that studies the immune system during pregnancy and the impact of pathogens. ‚ÄúWe need to do everything in our hands in order to prevent the chronic inflammation.‚Äù The  other study  was peer reviewed and was published Sunday in The Journal of Maternal-Fetal & Neonatal Medicine. This research looked at the impact Covid-19 had on women in the third trimester of their pregnancies. Scientists looked at the records for more than 2,400 women at one hospital in Israel between March and September of last year and saw significant health differences between the women who had Covid-19 and those who did not. Of the Covid-19 positive patients, 67% were asymptomatic. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The women who had symptomatic Covid-19 had the most trouble, Dr. Elior Eliasi of the Mayanei Hayeshua Medical Center and colleagues found. They had higher rates of gestational diabetes, a lower white blood cell count, and experienced heavier bleeding during their delivery. Their babies also experienced more breathing problems. The increased risk of problems was nearly 20% higher for women who had Covid-19 symptoms, and 14% higher for people with asymptomatic Covid-19. Unlike the other research, this study did not find symptomatic women were significantly more likely to deliver early. The study has limitations as it only looked at women in one hospital, so its findings may not be true for all people who are pregnant. These new studies add to a growing body of evidence that Covid-19, particularly symptomatic Covid-19, is a real threat to people who are pregnant and provides more evidence that the risks of Covid-19 far outweigh the risks to pregnant women of getting vaccinated, said Dr. Denise Jamieson, who did not work on this study. Only a third of people who are pregnant are fully vaccinated against Covid-19, according to the  US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.  Vaccines can protect pregnant women from getting Covid-19 and if they have a breakthrough case, a vaccinated person is much more likely to have mild symptoms, if any at all. The protection that comes from a vaccine is also passed along to the newborn. ‚ÄúThese studies fit into an overall emerging pattern of what we have seen with other research,‚Äù said Jamieson, chair of the department of gynecology and obstetrics at the Emory University School of Medicine and a member of the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology‚Äôs Covid-19 expert group. ‚ÄúCovid impacts pregnancies and can cause severe illness in pregnant persons and their babies, this is clear.‚Äù Jamieson said it is important for doctors to urge their pregnant patients to get the Covid-19 vaccine as soon as possible. Initially the CDC guidance said that women could get the vaccine but it did not recommend it. That‚Äôs because the initial vaccine studies did not intentionally include pregnant women, although there were woman who became pregnant during the studies. After more research, the CDC sent out an  urgent plea  in September that strongly recommended pregnant women get vaccinated right away. ‚ÄúI know pregnant persons can be reluctant to take medications or receive vaccines during their pregnancy and they really want to do everything possible to protect their baby, and they make sacrifices in pregnancies, but I think it has to be balanced with the risks of not getting vaccinated,‚Äù Jamieson said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important for all persons to get vaccinated, but in particular for pregnant persons to get vaccinated in order to protect themselves and to protect their babies.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The-CNN-Wire  ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2021 Cable News Network, Inc., a WarnerMedia Company. All rights reserved.

headline: Five Lawmakers Want Three Western Maryland Counties To Join West Virginia
summary: Five Republican lawmakers from Maryland's three westernmost counties have sent letters to West Virginia legislative leaders asking if the state would consider adding their jurisdictions.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ)  ‚Äî Five Republican lawmakers from Maryland‚Äôs three westernmost counties have sent letters to West Virginia legislative leaders asking if the state would consider adding their jurisdictions. Lawmakers from Allegany, Garrett and Washington counties, all bordering West Virginia, signed the letters, which both say that seceding from Maryland and joining West Virginia would be ‚Äúmutually beneficial for both states and for our local constituencies.‚Äù READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School In a news release with the letters, Washington County Del. William Wivell‚Äôs office said, ‚ÄúThis letter is generated as a result of various constituent requests over the years.‚Äù Dels. Wivell (District 2A) and Mike McKay (District 1C) signed one letter on behalf of Washington County, and Dels. Jason Buckel (District 1B), Wendell Beitzel (District 1A) and McKay, and Sen. George Edwards (District 1), signed another letter on behalf of Allegany and Garrett counties. None of the signatories immediately returned a request for comment from WJZ. Both letters were sent to West Virginia Senate President Craig Blair (R) and House Speaker Roger Hanshaw (R). A spokesperson for Hanshaw confirmed the speaker had received both copies. ‚ÄúThe speaker has said this is an introductory step in what would be a somewhat lengthy process,‚Äù said Ann Ali, director of communications for Hanshaw. ‚ÄúHe also has said he would recognize any border counties that recognize West Virginia‚Äôs role in the growing part of our nation‚Äôs economy and that we have the greatest quality of life in the country.‚Äù In response to questions from WJZ, Blair released a statement saying he would welcome the three Maryland counties into West Virginia. Citing a  declining unemployment rate , a  growing GDP  and a recent  $1 billion investment in broadband , Blair touted West Virginia‚Äôs growth. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúThis request is recognition of the work we have done to transform the state, and I welcome my friends and neighbors across the border in Maryland to join us as we keep moving forward,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWith everything we offer, who wouldn‚Äôt want to live here?‚Äù In 2020, West Virginia Gov. Jim Justice (R) made a pitch to conservative counties in Virginia to break away and join his state, according  to  The Washington Post . ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a loving, good people. Faith-based people. People that really know the difference between right and wrong. ‚Ä¶ If you‚Äôre not truly happy where you are, we stand with open arms to take you from Virginia,‚Äù Justice said last year. The state is not without its issues. According to the most recent Census, West Virginia  saw the steepest population  drop in the country. West Virginia has one of the highest poverty rates in the country, with 1 in 5 children living in poverty, according to  2019 data compiled by the USDA . County-level secession movements are not a novel idea. In fact, those three Maryland counties were named in a previous secessionist effort nearly a decade ago. As WTOP reports, a grassroots secessionist group rallied support for an unsuccessful plan that would have seen  Allegany, Carroll, Frederick, Garrett and Washington counties leave Maryland to form a new state , which would‚Äôve been dubbed Western Maryland. Rural counties in Oregon  have pitched the idea  of becoming part of Idaho, and a group of counties in Colorado  wants to join up  with Wyoming. West Virginia was in fact founded by counties that broke away from Virginia after it seceded from the Union at the outset of the Civil War. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized According to Article IV, Section 3, of  the U.S. Constitution , no new state can be formed within the jurisdiction of another state, or by joining parts of states, ‚Äúwithout the Consent of the Legislatures of the States concerned as well as of the Congress.‚Äù

headline: Take Common Sense Precautions As Maryland Black Bears Prepare For Hibernation, Officials Say
summary: The department said motorists traveling in western Maryland should also watch for bears crossing roads in search of food.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  State officials are asking residents and visitors of western Maryland to watch out for increased black bear activity this fall season. Autumn is the time black bears start a period of increased feeding ahead of winter hibernation, and they‚Äôre not shy of human food. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The Maryland Department of Natural Resources said the state‚Äôs ‚Äúbear country‚Äù is Allegany, Frederick, Garrett, and Washington counties. The department wants to remind residents to take common-sense precautions to avoid close encounters with the animals. ‚ÄúKeeping food sources like bird feeders, pet food, and trash in a place where bears can‚Äôt get to them is the best way to avoid problems,‚Äù¬† Wildlife and Heritage Service ¬†Director Paul Peditto said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The DNR says to never feed bears because they‚Äôll come back looking for more. If you encounter a bear, officials said to keep calm and leave the area immediately. The department said motorists traveling in western Maryland should also watch for bears crossing roads in search of food. The department provided these pointers to minimize bear problems on property:   Reduce garbage odors. Rinse food cans and wrappers before disposal.   Compost vegetable scraps properly away from house.   Keep meat scraps in the freezer until garbage pickup day.   Wash garbage cans regularly and use lime to cut odors.   Keep garbage cans in a bear-proof container or in an enclosed building until trash pickup. ‚Äã   Remove bird feeders in the spring. If you persist in feeding during summer, remove seed, suet and hummingbird feeders at night.   Keep pet food inside.   Keep barbecue grills and picnic tables clean.   Use an energized fence to keep bears out of beehives, sweet corn, fruit trees and berry patches. (An energized fence is powered by a low-impedance, high‚Äìvoltage energizer that provides a short-duration, high-energy impulse.)   Barking dogs, bright lights and noisemakers will sometimes discourage bears from coming into an area.   MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized For more information on living around black bears,  visit the department‚Äôs website.

headline: ‚ÄòYou Are Not Seeing Double‚Äô: 2-Headed Turtle Hatches On Cape Cod
summary: Do not adjust your screen. A turtle that hatched recently on Cape Cod does indeed have two heads.
bodytext: BARNSTABLE, Mass. (CBS) ‚Äì ¬†A turtle that hatched recently on Cape Cod is making headlines ‚Äî because it has two heads.¬†The turtle, which hatched from a protected nesting site in Barnstable, has a condition called bicephaly, which can occur from genetic and environmental factors.   ‚ÄúNo you are not seeing double!‚Äù the Cape Wildlife Center posted, sharing a photo of a diamondback terrapin hatchling.   According to experts, the condition is similar to conjoined human twins. The turtles share parts of their body, but also have independent parts as well. This turtle has two heads and six legs.   A turtle with two heads hatched in Barnstable. (Image Credit: New England Wildlife Center Cape Cod Branch)   Though animals with bicephaly don‚Äôt always survive or live long lives, Cape Wildlife Center said ‚Äúthese two have given us reason to be optimistic‚Äù after two weeks of care. The turtles are eating, swimming, and gaining weight.   ‚ÄúIt is impossible to get inside the heads of these two, but it appears that they work together to navigate their environment,‚Äù the center said.   The center is taking the case day-by-day, and is hoping to learn as much from the turtles as possible.

headline: Baltimore Man Charged With Murder In Cherry Hill Shooting
summary: Jones is currently being held at Central Booking.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Baltimore man is charged with first-degree murder in a fatal Cherry Hill shooting that happened months ago, police said Tuesday.   Officers responded midday on September 7 to the 600 block of Cherry Hill Road, where they found 31-year-old Seth Tunstall shot multiple times. He was pronounced dead on the scene.   Homicide detectives developed the suspect as 35-year-old Maurice Timothy Jones. He was arrested and formally charged October 6.   Jones is currently being held at Central Booking.

headline: COVID-19 In Maryland: 20 Hospitalized, 27 Deaths Reported In Last 24 Hours
summary: Maryland reported 411 new COVID-19 cases and 27 new deaths, according to state health department data released Tuesday morning.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland reported 411 new COVID-19 cases and 27 new deaths, according to state health department data released Tuesday morning. The percentage of people testing positive increased slightly by 0.16% to 3.88%. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Doctors say the new cases are fueled by dangerous strains targeting the unvaccinated. During an August press conference, Gov. Larry Hogan said the Delta variant, a strain that is reportedly two to four times more contagious than the original virus strain, accounts for nearly every new confirmed case in Maryland. ‚ÄúThe vaccines are without a doubt our single most effective tool to mitigate the threat of COVID-19 and the surging Delta variant, and Maryland‚Äôs vaccination rate continues to outpace the nation,‚Äù Hogan said. More than 3.9 million Maryland adults are fully vaccinated. Hospitalizations increased by 20 to 765. Of those hospitalized, 561 remain in acute care and 195 are in the ICU. Since the pandemic began, there were 545,439 total confirmed cases and 10,397 deaths. There are 3,938,200 Marylanders fully vaccinated. The state has administered 8,108,425 doses. Of those, 3,996,427 are first doses with 2,777 administered in the past 24 hours. They have given out 3,634,316 second doses, 2,317 in the last day. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of people who have rolled up their sleeves, Maryland continues to be one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan of the eight million milestone mark. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù The state began to administer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine again in April after the CDC and FDA lifted their pause on the vaccine due to a rare blood clot found in some women. A total of 306,378 Marylanders have received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 177 in the last day. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall On September 24, after the CDC granted final approval for Pfizer‚Äôs booster, Gov. Hogan announced the immediate authorization of the booster shot for Marylanders who have received their second Pfizer shot at least six months ago. Hogan  had already approved use  for vulnerable populations in early September. The state has administered 171,304 additional or booster vaccine doses, 5,281 in the last day. The state reported 84.6% of all adults in Maryland have received at least one dose of the vaccine. In August, the state launched a post-vaccination infections dashboard that is updated every Wednesday. There have been 18,243 total cases among fully vaccinated Marylanders as of last Wednesday, Sept. 22. Of those cases, 1,331 vaccinated Marylanders were hospitalized, representing 8.73% of all Covid cases hospitalized in the state. One hundred fifty-six fully vaccinated Marylanders have died, representing 8.36% of lab-confirmed Covid deaths in the state.
