headline: Baltimore Symphony Orchestra Relocates Another Show Citing Strathmore Labor Dispute
summary: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra is relocating yet another show due to a labor dispute between management and the union representing employees in the ticket office at the Music Center at Strathmore.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra is relocating yet another show due to a labor dispute between management at the Music Center at Strathmore and the union representing employees in the ticket office. The orchestra announced Tuesday it is moving the Oct. 23 performance of Marin Conducts Rachmaninoff to the Joseph Meyerhoff Symphony Hall and offering ticket-holders comparable seats and either free parking or a shuttle from Montgomery County. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School On Sept. 15, the BSO  said it was moving two concerts  from the North Bethesda venue while management continued negotiations with I.A.T.S.E. Local 868, the union representing ticket office workers. The next week, the orchestra  announced  the cancellation of two October concerts at the venue and relocation of another. The union has  said ¬†Strathmore is using the pandemic to eliminate full-time jobs in the ticket office and reduce hours for part-time employees. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Strathmore has previously expressed hopes in finalizing an agreement with the venue‚Äôs two dozen full- and part-time ticket sellers, but also said the pandemic has caused management ‚Äúto rethink what ticket-buying will look like in the future.‚Äù In  a Sept. 16 update , the venue said it ‚Äúimplemented‚Äù a final offer for three full-time and 10 part-time ticket sellers that doesn‚Äôt reduce wages and benefits, provides more training and creates flexible work schedules based on demand. Separately, the BSO and Strathmore have yet to finalize an annual licensing agreement for the 2021-2022 season that complies with the contracts between the orchestra and the unions representing the musicians and stagehands. In response, Strathmore said the Concert Hall is now open to other performers on dates when the BSO has relocated performances. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Tonya McBride Robles, BSO vice president and chief operating officer, said in a statement on Sept. 24: ‚ÄúWe have provided Strathmore with a signed license agreement that contains the same provisions included in previous years regarding staffing and collective bargaining units, and we have engaged in efforts to help steer Strathmore and IATSE Local 868 towards mediation. We remain hopeful that a resolution of their underlying labor dispute will help to resolve the connected issues with our license agreement and enable the return of the BSO to our beloved second home.‚Äù

headline: Maryland To Receive Over $3.6M In Grants For Chesapeake Bay Restoration
summary: An additional 31 projects were announced out of the state for watershed restoration for a total of $10 million in grants.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS (WJZ) ‚Äî  The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday announced over $3.6 million in grants for projects to help restore Maryland‚Äôs portion of the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. The federal-state Chesapeake Bay Program said the 18 grants will generate $4,334,707 in matching contributions for a total of more than $8 million. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School An additional 31 projects were announced out of the state for watershed restoration for a total of $10 million in grants. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúEPA is pleased to support projects that improve the quality of local waters and habitat and help restore the Chesapeake Bay,‚Äù said Diana Esher, EPA Mid-Atlantic acting regional administrator. ‚ÄúIt is a priority for EPA to support local actions that move us closer to our restoration goals.¬† We applaud the grantees for their commitment to cleaner water and healthier watersheds.‚Äù The program said some of the grant recipients include:   Future Harvest, Inc. ¬† ($302,750): The project will work with 12 grain farms on Maryland‚Äôs Eastern Shore to demonstrate the agronomic and environmental benefits of cover crop planning.   Greater Grace World Outreach, Inc.¬† ($200,785): Funding will implement components of the organization‚Äôs green infrastructure plan, including the planting of 100 community trees, two micro-retention areas and one bioretention system.   Shorerivers, Inc. ¬†($79,886): Engagement of three underserved communities across the Choptank watershed to prioritize community restoration projects will activate a diverse network of stewards.   MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The grants come from the Small Watershed Grants Program, part of the NFWF Chesapeake Bay Stewardship Fund. For more information on the grants, visit  the fund‚Äôs website.

headline: Batwoman Star Javicia Leslie Says ‚ÄòI‚Äôm Really Excited For The Villains‚Äô
summary: Javicia Leslie stars as Ryan Wilder aka Batwoman, and Robin Givens joins the cast as Jada Jet, the CEO of Jet Industries for Season 3, debuting October 13.
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äî   Batwoman  returns October 13th for season three on The CW. The series stars Javicia Leslie as Ryan Wilder aka Batwoman. Robin Givens joins the cast as Jada Jet, the CEO of Jet Industries. CBS‚Äôs Katie Johnston (KJ) caught up with Leslie (JL) and Givens (RG) to chat about the evolution of the show with Givens‚Äô new character. The two also talk about paying homage to Batman and what it‚Äôs like to work on the show READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School KJ ‚Äî Joining me today to talk all about the action-packed upcoming season, Batwoman herself, Javicia Leslie, and a strong woman off-screen, but who plays a powerful business mogul in the series, Robin Givens. Thank you so much for hanging out with me today! Robin, starting with your new character ‚ÄòJada Jet,‚Äô what do you love about her? And what can fans expect to see from her contributions to the season? RG ‚Äî I‚Äôm in love with her. I just absolutely love her. She is so powerful, like you mentioned. She runs a major company in Gotham City. The fact that Robin, I get to be a part of Gotham City is really fantastic. I love trying to bring her to life in a special way in the sense that she is a powerful woman, but she‚Äôs basically just a mom also. Her Achilles heel, if she has one, would be her children ‚Äî her two children. Ryan hasn‚Äôt grown up with her mom in her life, which was a major cliff-hanger in the last season. I‚Äôm not sure Jada is really ready to have a relationship with Ryan. But we see a lot of guilt there; we see a lot of love there. We see‚Äîat first‚Äîkeeping her at bay. The dynamic of their relationship is a special one. She‚Äôs willing to do anything to protect her children and I mean anything. KJ ‚Äî You mention how exciting it was to be a part of the Gotham world. Were you guys both DC Comics fans growing up? Were you a fan of Batwoman? JL ‚Äî I was a huge, huge Batman fan‚Äîlike‚Äîexcessively huge Batman fan. So enter the world of Batwoman in this kind of way and‚Äîespecially Season 3‚Äîbe able to play homage to Batman through having the Batman Villain Trophies in Gotham and those trophies influencing new villains. So you‚Äôre talking about villains influenced by the Mad Hatter, Killer Croc, and by Victor Fries. To be a part of that storytelling is so much fun. I literally feel like a child just doing this imaginary make-believe world, but influenced obviously by a make-believe world I grew up watching and creating in my mind. KJ ‚Äî What about you, Robin? RG ‚Äî We get to live in it. We get to live in this world. Sometimes we‚Äôre doing a scene and you‚Äôre saying these words and you‚Äôre inside this world and it‚Äôs just really cool. It‚Äôs so much fun to be able to experience it from inside Gotham City. KJ ‚Äî I do want to ask you, Robin, stepping into this character, who is a new character this season. What has the chemistry been like on set for you? How would you describe your relationship with cast and crew? RG ‚Äî I am happy, Katie, that you asked that question. It‚Äôs so‚Äîokay, Javicia. Turn your ears off. I know you‚Äôre tired of hearing it. For a second. She has such a major role. She‚Äôs Batwoman, she‚Äôs the leader on screen, but she‚Äôs also the leader off-screen. Whatever the chemistry is on set, it‚Äôs so magnificent. We laugh so much. To be able to go to work, and we all know this, to want to go to work and to have fun. Sometimes in scenes we‚Äôre crying. The other day we were doing this major scene and Javicia made me break and I‚Äôm cracking up with tears rolling down my eyes. It is just such a pleasure, and I think so much of that comes from her. We have Caroline Dries who is our show runner and writer‚Äîruns this amazing team, gives us these fantastic words. The chemistry is fantastic. Right now I just don‚Äôt want it to end. KJ ‚Äî I remember watching an interview with you, Javicia, when you first joined this role, how you felt like it was a family, and you‚Äôve never been more welcomed than this role. That seems still true today. JL ‚Äî Yes, yes! And it‚Äôs so cool to get new members of our family joining. You guys have all been amazing additions to this family. We all have so much fun together that even when we do Zoom press calls and we‚Äôre all there, we‚Äôre constantly cracking jokes and remembering thing that happened. It‚Äôs a really positive energy and a positive vibe. It does make coming to work fun, but it also makes coming to work easy. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall KJ ‚Äî Javicia, with the introduction of your character last season, what does it mean to you to come back to this show this season and continue the legacy of Batwoman? JL ‚Äî It‚Äôs amazing! It‚Äôs fun! This is the show‚Äôs third season, but my second season. They‚Äôre all like, ‚ÄòOkay, we‚Äôre doing this again.‚Äô And I‚Äôm like‚Äîahh we‚Äôre doing this again! This is really cool, this is really fun, this is really epic. I‚Äôm just so excited about this season. This season is so much fun. Like I said earlier, every episode could stand alone. They‚Äôre full and they‚Äôre colorful and they‚Äôre Gotham, so they‚Äôre dark and creepy. It‚Äôs funny because I‚Äôll see little snippets of movies and it will be a really gory scene of someone‚Äôs face getting cut off and I‚Äôll be like‚Äî‚Äôwe did that first.‚Äô I‚Äôm proud! We did that creepy thing first. Just to be a part of a show that is so groundbreaking and everyone that is a part of it is so committed to the story and so committed to every element of the story‚Äîit just makes it so much fun. KJ ‚Äî You definitely get a sense of that when I watched a preview for this season and scenes from episodes that haven‚Äôt been released yet. It‚Äôs just incredible the connection you guys have on set and everything you‚Äôve been able to do with the show. Is there anything else I haven‚Äôt asked you about the upcoming season that you want to include? JL ‚Äî I know I‚Äôm really excited for the villains. That‚Äôs one of my favorite things because, when it comes to anything that has to do with Batman, I love the villains. I‚Äôve actually loved the villains more than anything. And then I‚Äôm really excited for this journey Ryan is going on with her mom. I don‚Äôt even know what‚Äôs going to happen. Robin knows this about me. I can only read the episode that is the episode coming up. I can‚Äôt read any further than that because then I start getting confused and making character decisions that aren‚Äôt even applying to this episode. So they all may know what‚Äôs happening in episode 9 and I only know what‚Äôs happening in this current episode that I‚Äôm on. I have no idea what‚Äôs going to happen with Ryan and Jada. Then, to top it off, we did a scene the other day and Jada did some real crazy thing. I‚Äôm looking at whatever happened, and I come back and I look at Jada and I think to myself‚ÄîI think this as Javicia and I think Ryan thought this too‚Äî‚ÄôDo I really want to be a part of this family? They are crazy! RG ‚Äî Katie! You should‚Äôve seen it. She turns back around and goes‚Äî‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know!‚Äô KJ ‚Äî I love that you‚Äôve been able to incorporate that! RG ‚Äî She‚Äôs willing to do anything and I mean anything! But, Javicia‚Äîjust so you know‚Äîwe have some other history that‚Äôs going to be made when you speak of villains in a way. We can‚Äôt give it away, don‚Äôt you give it away! JL ‚Äî I know I‚Äôm bad about that. RG ‚Äî I think the world will be really excited to see. JL ‚Äî I give a lot of‚Äîwhat are they called? RG ‚Äî Spoilers! MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized JL ‚Äî I give a lot of spoilers so I have to kind of like, reel it in.

headline: Baltimore County‚Äôs First Free Circulator, Towson Loop, Opens For Service
summary: Stops include staples like Towson Town Center, the Shops at Kenilworth and local universities.
bodytext: TOWSON, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  The Towson Loop is officially in service and it can take you to work, class or out on the town all for free. The circulator is Baltimore County‚Äôs first free public transit service, and it begins its first route Tuesday at noon. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The circulator aims to ease the congestion so common in the Towson area, making it easier for residents, students and other commuters to get around without adding to traffic and parking headaches. There will be 12 buses in circulation which come every 15 minutes, and these new routes are incorporated into the existing MTA bus routes. The multi-million dollar service is paid for by county funds and a federal grant. Baltimore County Executive Johnny Olszewski said the circulator fulfills a major campaign promise. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúWhether you‚Äôre going to work at GBMC or Towson Place, heading to class at Towson or Goucher, or dining or shopping around downtown Towson, you can get around,‚Äù said Olszewski at a celebration Tuesday morning. The Towson Loop, consisting of the blue and orange routes, is the first of numerous free circulators planned in the area as part of the Baltimore County Loop. For more information about its run times and various routes, head to the  Baltimore County Loop website.  baltcoloop.Com. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Father And Son Shot And Killed In Rosedale, Police Investigating
summary: Baltimore County Police are investigating a shooting Monday night in Rosedale that left a father and son dead.
bodytext: ROSEDALE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Baltimore County Police are investigating a shooting Monday night in Rosedale that left a father and son dead. Officers were called to a shooting in the 7400 block of Plainview Road shortly after 9 p.m. There they found 55-year-old Christopher Walker and his 24-year-old son, Justin, shot. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Both men were pronounced dead at the scene. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The circumstances that lead up to the shooting remain unclear. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Detectives with the Baltimore County Police Department‚Äôs Homicide Unit request anyone with information to contact 410-307-2020. headline: Nine Amazing Lamar Jackson Stats Following Monday Night‚Äôs Ravens Win
summary: Lamar Jackson's dazzling final line in the 31-25 overtime win: 37-for-43 for 442 yards and 4 touchdowns, along with 62 yards on the ground. But that only scratches the surface.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Leading the Baltimore Ravens back from a 22-3 deficit against the Indianapolis Colts, quarterback Lamar Jackson put on what head coach John Harbaugh described as ‚Äúone of the greatest performances I‚Äôve ever seen.‚Äù Jackson‚Äôs dazzling final line in the 31-25 overtime win: 37-for-43 for 442 yards and 4 touchdowns, along with 62 yards on the ground. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School But that only scratches the surface of how epic Jackson‚Äôs night was, and how amazing he‚Äôs been through the first five games of the 2021 season. Here are nine stats that paint a more complete picture. Jackson‚Äôs 442 passing yards set a Ravens record for most in a single game .   Lamar Jackson threw for 442 yards, a new Ravens franchise record.   ‚Äî Ryan Mink (@ryanmink)  October 12, 2021 The Ravens had 528 yards of total offense on Monday night. Jackson was responsible for 504 of them.   Lamar Jackson was responsible for 96% of the  #Ravens  total yards.    You read that correctly ü§Øüé±  pic.twitter.com/3j0nxgFvT3   ‚Äî PFF BAL Ravens (@PFF_Ravens)  October 12, 2021 Of the 4,017 NFL games where a quarterback has thrown the ball 40 times, Jackson has the highest completion percentage, at 86%.   There have been 4,017 individual games of 40+ pass attempts in NFL history.     Lamar Jackson (86.0%) now has the highest completion percentage in any of those games.   H/T  @EliasSports   pic.twitter.com/u8oSBaJGUH   ‚Äî ESPN Stats & Info (@ESPNStatsInfo)  October 12, 2021 He also has the highest completion percentage for any quarterback who‚Äôs passed for 400 yards or more.   On Monday night vs. the Colts, Ravens‚Äô QB Lamar Jackson overcame the largest deficit of his NFL career (19 points) and set the NFL record for completion percentage (86%) in both a 400-yard passing game and a 40-attempt passing game.  pic.twitter.com/E5ju49kUWH   ‚Äî Adam Schefter (@AdamSchefter)  October 12, 2021 READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Jackson is the first player in league history to pass for 1,500 yards and rush for 300 yards in a five-game span.   ÔøºLamar Jackson has been beating teams through the air and on the ground beyond last night.   Jackson is the first player with 1,500 passing yards and 300 rushing yards in a 5-game span in NFL history, according to  @EliasSports   ‚Äî Jamison Hensley (@jamisonhensley)  October 12, 2021 With the win, Jackson tied Miami Dolphins quarterback Dan Marino for the most wins by a quarterback before age 25. The Ravens still have 12 more games to play and Jackson doesn‚Äôt turn 25 until January.   LAMAR JACKSON IS HISTORICALLY GREAT PASS IT ON  pic.twitter.com/Amu3mPCOj9   ‚Äî The Exit 52 Podcast (@Exit52Podcast)  October 12, 2021 On the season, Jackson is fifth in passing yards. Not bad for a running back. Jackson has 1,519 passing yards so far this year, putting him ahead of highly regarded signal callers such as Patrick Mahomes, Josh Allen and Dak Prescott. Even more incredible, he is the eighth best rusher in the entire league With 341 rushing yards on the year, Jackson has been better on the ground than many team‚Äôs starting running backs, a list that includes Colts back Jonathan Taylor, Washington‚Äôs Antonio Gibson and Green Bay‚Äôs Aaron Jones. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Put that together, and Jackson‚Äôs 1,860 yards of production is better than 18 teams. Yes, 18 NFL teams have put up fewer yards than Jackson as an individual.   Lamar Jackson has more total yards than 18 teams ü§Ø  pic.twitter.com/ZhxVKj52Ir   ‚Äî B/R Gridiron (@brgridiron)  October 12, 2021

headline: Baltimore County Agrees To $6.5 Million Settlement With Family Of Eric Sopp, Man Fatally Shot By Police In 2019
summary: Baltimore County has agreed to a $6.5 million settlement with the family of Eric Sopp, the man who was fatally shot by Baltimore County police in November 2019 during a mental health crisis, the law firm Brown, Goldstein & Levy announced
bodytext: TOWSON, Md. (WJZ)  ‚Äî Baltimore County has agreed to a $6.5 million settlement with the family of Eric Sopp, the man who was fatally shot by a police officer in November 2019 during a mental health crisis, the law firm Brown, Goldstein & Levy announced. In a statement released Tuesday by the law firm, Sopp‚Äôs mother, Catherine, said she hopes the county reevaluates crisis intervention training for police officers. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúMy son lost his life due to one officer‚Äôs egregious actions,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúJustice for Eric has always meant that the County must take whatever steps are necessary to prevent a tragedy like this in the future.‚Äù Sopp‚Äôs family  filed a lawsuit  against the county and Officer Gregory Page in October 2020, alleging county police routinely use excessive force against peopl¬† with mental health disabilities and those experiencing mental health crises, and that Page violated Sopp‚Äôs civil rights as well as federal laws prohibiting disability discrimination. On the night of November 26, 2019, Sopp, who suffered from mental health issues, took off after threatening to kill himself with an ice pick but left the pick at home, his family said at the time. Catherine Sopp called police and warned a dispatcher he was driving drunk and suicidal. ‚ÄúThere needs to be someone out there looking for his car before he hurts himself,‚Äù she told a dispatcher according to audio of the 911 call released by police. Officers pulled Sopp over between the Mount Carmel and Belfast Road exits. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Body-worn camera footage released by the the police department  showed Page approaching the passenger side window of Sopp‚Äôs Toyota Camry with his gun drawn and knocking on the window multiple times. The officer repeatedly ordered Sopp to turn off the car and show his hands. Sopp said he wouldn‚Äôt turn off the car. About a minute later, Sopp got out of the car and Page opened fire. At the time, police said they did not find a weapon on Sopp but declined to say if one was found in the car. The lawsuit claimed Sopp was unarmed. ‚ÄúWhen I called 911 that evening, I was seeking assistance to protect both Eric and other drivers,‚Äù Catherine Sopp said today. ‚ÄúI never dreamed that a police officer would kill my unarmed son.‚Äù One of the family‚Äôs attorneys, Chelsea J. Crawford, said the county needs to practice de-escalation with people in distress. ‚ÄúMeaningful change will only occur if the County strengthens its crisis intervention programs, provides mandatory training for all police officers, and hires additional crisis intervention personnel,‚Äù Crawford said. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Sean Narron, a spokesperson for Baltimore County Executive Johnny Olszewski Jr, said, ‚ÄúThe County considers this matter resolved and has no further comment at this time.‚Äù

headline: Man Dies Of Injuries After Southwest Baltimore Shooting, Police Say
summary: A Tuesday afternoon shooting in Southwest Baltimore left one man dead, authorities said.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Tuesday afternoon shooting in Southwest Baltimore left one man dead, authorities said.   Patrol officers were called to a shooting in the 2600 block of Dulany Street about 1:50 p.m., according to the Baltimore Police Department.   Upon arrival, officers found a man suffering from a gunshot wound. He was taken to the hospital but did not survive.   Anyone with information about this case is asked to call police at 410-396-2100 or Metro Crime Stoppers at 1-866-7LOCKUP.

headline: Southwest Cancels Hundreds More Flights; Passengers Stranded
summary: The sales director for a consulting company said he flies Southwest dozens of times a year but had ‚Äúnever been in a situation like that.‚Äù
bodytext: DALLAS (AP) ‚Äî  Southwest Airlines canceled more than 350 flights Monday following a¬†weekend of major disruptions¬†that it blamed on bad weather and air traffic control issues. The pilots union accused the company of a botched response to what it said would have been a minor challenge for other airlines.       The third straight day of canceled and delayed flights left passengers stranded and steaming from California to the East Coast.   ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt really relax when you‚Äôre just sitting there waiting for your next flight to be canceled,‚Äù said Vanessa Wheeler, who was biding her time at the San Jose, California, airport. She said Southwest canceled six consecutive flights on her over three days before she eventually decided to book a flight home to Las Vegas with Delta Air Lines. She vowed to never fly Southwest again.   Monday‚Äôs cancellations amounted to 10% of Southwest‚Äôs schedule, and at least 1,400 other flights, or roughly 40%, were delayed, according to the FlightAware tracking service. Shares of Southwest Airlines Co. fell 4.2%.   The widespread disruptions began shortly after the Southwest Airlines Pilots Association, representing 9,000 pilots, asked a federal court on Friday to block the airline‚Äôs order that all employees get vaccinated. The union argued that Southwest must negotiate over the issue because it could involve sick leave or disability if pilots have a reaction to the vaccine.     If your travel was affected, please explore self-service rebooking options by checking your flight status on  https://t.co/GiF91yLJcx . (2/2)   ‚Äî Southwest Airlines (@SouthwestAir)  October 9, 2021     ¬†   ‚ÄúWe are not anti-vaccination at all, but our pilots are extremely worried about how their medicals are going to be handled‚Äù if they are unable to fly, union president Casey Murray told The Associated Press. Murray said pilots had not staged a sickout because of the vaccine mandate.   He instead blamed the chaos of the past few days on Southwest‚Äôs operation, which he said has become ‚Äúbrittle‚Äù and ‚Äúcracks under the slightest pressure.‚Äù He said the airline uses antiquated crew-scheduling technology that leads to cascading disruptions when flights are canceled in one part of its network.   Unions at both Southwest and American have also argued that management has been too slow to bring pilots back from leaves of absence that the airlines persuaded them to take during the pandemic, leaving them short-handed.   In a video for employees, Southwest Chief Operating Officer Mike Van de Ven said that despite ‚Äúa very aggressive hiring plan ‚Ä¶ we are still not where we want to be with staffing,‚Äù especially pilots.   The staffing shortage is leading to fewer flights. After massive delays this summer, Southwest trimmed its fall schedule, which Van de Ven said had helped reduce delays in the past month. He said Southwest has already made significant cuts in its original schedules for November and December, ‚Äúand if we think we need to do more, we will.‚Äù   There is a risk to fewer flights, however: It leaves Southwest with fewer options to accommodate stranded passengers.   Meanwhile, the Federal Aviation Administration acknowledged delays in part of Florida on Friday but pushed back against Southwest‚Äôs air-traffic control explanation. The FAA said Sunday that ‚Äúsome airlines‚Äù were experiencing problems because of planes and crews being out of position. Southwest was the only airline to report such a large percentage of canceled and delayed flights over the weekend.   Southwest spokeswoman Brandy King said there was no evidence that would indicate the disruptions were caused by any sort of employee protest over vaccinations.   Some passengers were frustrated not just by flight delays but also the lack of a clear reason for them.   ‚ÄúMy concern is we had no explanation really that was, I feel, very legitimate or believable,‚Äù said Brian Gesch of Cedar Grove, Wisconsin, who was traveling through Reagan Washington National Airport with his wife. He doubted that weather and air traffic controllers were the real issue. ‚ÄúSo we are frustrated and missing a day of work.‚Äù   Others were just concerned about getting home ‚Äî any way they could.   Kent Moddelmog ended up driving 700 miles (1,127 kilometers) with his 14-year-old son from Phoenix to Dublin, California, after Southwest canceled their flight and he couldn‚Äôt find a flight on a competing airline that wasn‚Äôt exorbitantly priced. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt going to drop $3,000 to get back,‚Äù Moddelmog said.   The sales director for a consulting company said he flies Southwest dozens of times a year but had ‚Äúnever been in a situation like that.‚Äù   Savanthi Syth, an airlines analyst for Raymond James, said the weekend problems will increase Southwest‚Äôs costs and worsen the company‚Äôs strained relations with unions.   Southwest has¬† struggled all summer ¬†with high numbers of delayed and canceled flights. In August, it announced it was trimming its September schedule by 27 flights a day, or less than 1%, and 162 flights a day, or 4.5% of the schedule, from early October through Nov. 5.   The White House has pushed airlines to adopt vaccine mandates because they are federal contractors ‚Äî they get paid by the Defense Department to operate flights, including those that carried Afghanistan refugees to the U.S. this summer.   United Airlines was the first major U.S. carrier to announce a vaccination requirement. Southwest had remained silent even after President Joe Biden announced his order for federal contractors and large employers. Finally last week, Southwest told employees they must be fully vaccinated by Dec. 8 to keep their jobs. Workers can ask to skip the shots for medical or religious reasons.

headline: Maryland Awarded $144K EPA Grant To Enhance Wetlands With ‚ÄòLiving Shoreline‚Äô
summary: The Maryland Department of the Environment on Tuesday received an EPA grant to enhance state wetlands with a "living shoreline" approach, placing plants, stones and other materials to restore coastal habitats.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî The Maryland Department of the Environment on Tuesday received an EPA grant to enhance state wetlands with a ‚Äúliving shoreline‚Äù approach, placing plants, stones and other materials to restore coastal habitats.   The state was awarded $144,202 through the EPA‚Äôs Wetland Program Development Grant program.   ‚ÄúWetlands are a primary component of Maryland‚Äôs environment, which contribute greatly to the state‚Äôs ability to protect water quality and natural resources,‚Äù said EPA Mid-Atlantic Acting Regional Administrator Diana Esher. ‚ÄúThis award focuses on improving shoreline stabilization to help protect Maryland‚Äôs 3,000 miles of coastlines that are vulnerable to climate change.‚Äù   On its website, the EPA  says living shorelines  can reduce erosion and, compared to physical structures such as bulkheads and sea walls, improve the ecosystem. Restoring wetlands can also reduce wave heights in coastal areas that are susceptible to climate change, the agency says.

headline: Texas Man Federally Charged With Threatening Former Baltimore Health Commissioner Dr. Leana Wen
summary: A Texas man has been federally charged with threatening Dr. Leana Wen, a former Baltimore City Health Commissioner and current medical analyst with CNN, over her support of the COVID-19 vaccine.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî A Texas man has been federally charged with threatening Dr. Leana Wen, a former Baltimore City Health Commissioner and current medical analyst with CNN, over her support of the COVID-19 vaccine, according to an indictment unsealed Tuesday. Scott Eli Harris allegedly sent Wen a message in July and threatened she would be shot, claiming he was an Army veteran and sniper. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait for the shooting to start,‚Äù he allegedly wrote, later asking, ‚Äúwhere‚Äôs your f‚Äîing office?‚Äù Harris also allegedly told Wen he was never going to take ‚Äúyour wonder drug,‚Äù adding ‚ÄúMy 12 gauge promises I won‚Äôt.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The message also allegedly references Wen‚Äôs background as a Chinese immigrant and uses other offensive, threatening language. Harris is charged with one count of threats transmitted by interstate communication. If convicted, Harris would face a maximum sentence of five years in federal prison and a fine of up to $250,000. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The indictment was originally returned on Sept. 29 and unsealed Tuesday after Harris was arrested. He is scheduled to make an initial appearance on Wednesday, Oct. 13 in U.S. District Court in Plano, Texas.

headline: Parent Backs Raises For Anne Arundel County School Bus Drivers: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs An Essential Job‚Äô
summary: There‚Äôs no question that bus drivers play a key role in every school district. They make sure students make it to school on time and back home safely after the bell rings.
bodytext: BROOKLYN, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  There‚Äôs no question that bus drivers play a key role in every school district. They make sure students make it to school on time and back home safely after the bell rings. It‚Äôs for those reasons that Anne Arundel County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. George Arlotto came up with a  $7.4 million plan to raise pay for all its school bus drivers and attendants by $5 an hour . READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The  Board of Education signed off on Dr. Arlotto‚Äôs plan  at its meeting Monday evening. It couldn‚Äôt have come at a better time ‚Äì  drivers with one bus company went on strike last week , calling for higher wages to match a more demanding workload brought about by a nationwide shortage. The need isn‚Äôt lost on parents, like Patrick Broadbent, whose daughter attends an Anne Arundel County elementary school. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an essential job, bus drivers, and I think it‚Äôs something they need to get compensated for,‚Äù he said. Broadbent acknowledged that ferrying around other people‚Äôs children isn‚Äôt something he‚Äôs cut out for. That‚Äôs why he recognizes how important it is to hire and retain school bus drivers. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve got a (Commercial Driver‚Äôs License), would you rather drive a truck for Pepsi or Coke or something, or would you rather drive around a bunch of kids?‚Äù he wondered aloud. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Broadbent said his daughter takes the bus to and from school. This year, he said, has been different. ‚ÄúHer kindergarten year she had the same bus driver every day,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis year it fluctuates like she‚Äôll have one bus driver for one week and then a different bus driver.‚Äù Melissa Ellis, president of the Anne Arundel County Board of Education, said the board wants to increase bus drivers‚Äô pay not only as a show of appreciation but also to give students and parents stability. ‚ÄúIt is a critical role,‚Äù Ellis said. Besides giving drivers and attendants pay raises, Superintendent Arlotto has also proposed setting aside federal funds to add $2,000 signing bonuses for new hires. as well as retention bonuses for existing drivers. The board‚Äôs request is subject to approval from County Executive Steuart Pittman. While the bonus pay requires a green light from the County Council, the bonuses could be approved immediately. The district maintains a database of reported issues with bus routes throughout the county.  Click here to check it out. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: New Attorney General‚Äôs Unit Investigating Baltimore County Police Shooting
summary: A new division of the Maryland Attorney General's Office is among the agencies investigating Monday's police-involved shooting in Baltimore County.
bodytext: WOODLAWN, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A new division of the Maryland Attorney General‚Äôs Office is among the agencies investigating this week‚Äôs  police-involved shooting in Baltimore County . The Attorney General‚Äôs Office‚Äôs Independent Investigations Division was formed in response to several police reform bills passed by the Maryland General Assembly earlier this year. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School That unit and the Maryland State Police are now tasked with investigating the shooting that unfolded Monday morning while police pursued a pair of armed robbery suspects. ‚ÄòIf you think about it, it makes sense,‚Äù said Dana Mulhauser, chief of the Independent Investigations Division.¬†‚ÄúIndividuals shouldn‚Äôt be investigating people that they know if there is a way to avoid it, right?‚Äù According to Baltimore County Police, officers were initially called about 2 a.m. Monday for an armed robbery at a 7-Eleven in Windsor Mill. The two suspects were trying to get away from police when their vehicle was involved in a hit-and-run crash, and they bailed out, according to police. An officer encountered one of the suspects near Englewood Avenue and Gilmore Street, and a shootout ensued. Police said K-9 units found the suspect dead nearby¬† a short time later. A firearm was recovered from the scene. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The officer, who was hurt but not shot during the exchange of gunfire, was taken to an area hospital for treatment. The flurry of police activity and a sprawling crime scene had some residents concerned, neighbors told WJZ. ‚ÄúThe neighbors were in fear,‚Äù Woodlawn resident Rodney Booth said. ‚ÄúThey were in shock.‚Äù While Baltimore County Police are investigating the robbery, the new unit with the Attorney General‚Äôs Office will review the officer-involved shooting. Based on preliminary details released by police, it‚Äôs believed that only one officer fired his agency weapon during Monday morning‚Äôs pursuit. The officer, whose name has not been released, was placed on paid administrative leave, which is standard operating procedure for officer-involved shootings. The Independent Investigations Division and MSP will compile a report based on their findings, which will be provided to the Baltimore County State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs Office. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúWe think that this is better for everyone,‚Äù Mulhauser said. ‚ÄúYou know, our job is not to target or to headhunt. Our job is to investigate police officers in the same way that everyone else gets investigated, right, with fairness.‚Äù

headline: Was Your Heart Racing During Monday Night‚Äôs Ravens Game? It‚Äôs A Common Reaction, One Health Expert Says
summary: The stress that comes with watching sports is natural, but with our Ravens, it just feels like your heart skips a beat.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî The stress that comes with watching sports is natural, but with our Ravens, it just feels like your heart skips a beat. All across social media, Ravens fans mentioned heart palpitations during Monday‚Äôs overtime win versus Indianapolis. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School From Brandi: ‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt have heart palpitations during the 4th quarter of a Ravens game, did the Ravens even play a game?‚Äù Even NFL agent Samantha Sankovich said, ‚ÄúThis season could easily give me heart palpitations.‚Äù Dr. Drew Pate with LifeBridge Health said sudden adrenaline is related to the fight or flight response, genetically programmed from our ancestors. ‚ÄúIf you watch an entire game, and you‚Äôre a really avid Ravens fan, and it‚Äôs a close game back and forth, then your blood pressure and your heart rate will be elevated just like you‚Äôre out walking or doing a lighter form of exercise,‚Äù he said. A  study by The Canadian Journal of Cardiology  said people‚Äôs heart rates increased by 75% when they watched a hockey game on TV and by 110% in person. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The comeback win was one for the ages, and when Rodrigo Blankenship missed the field goal at the end of regulation, Baltimore went NUTS. Ray and Trent Lepriol traveled from Bradenton, Florida to see the game. ‚ÄúI was ready to go home crying if we lost that thing. Mixed emotions,‚Äù Trent said. ‚ÄúI was ready to cuss out the guy who got the penalty who gave them into field goal range but he missed it and God gave us a shot.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe excitement, the jubilation, the joy we felt was just incredible. Speechless,‚Äù Ray told WJZ. Dr. Pate added more. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúThat kind of intensity can be viewed in a positive community way,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt really shows an investment into our community, and those who represent our community, which is really what the Ravens and the Orioles and all the other professional teams represent.‚Äù

headline: DeShon Elliott Puts Jack Doyle On Notice After Cheap Shot On Tavon Young
summary: Count Baltimore Ravens safety DeShon Elliott among those who weren't fans of the cheap shot Indianapolis Colts tight end Jack Doyle took at Tavon Young late in Monday night's game.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî¬† Count Baltimore Ravens safety DeShon Elliott among those who weren‚Äôt fans of the cheap shot Indianapolis Colts tight end Jack Doyle took at Tavon Young late in Monday night‚Äôs game. ‚ÄúJack Doyle don‚Äôt let me see you again brah, don‚Äôt disrespect Tay like that,‚Äù Elliott tweeted Tuesday. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Elliott, who was inactive Monday, was referring to the moment Doyle pushed his teammate‚Äôs helmet into the turf while getting to his feet following a play late in the fourth quarter. Young got up and retaliated by shoving Doyle, who sold the shove with a flop worthy of an Oscars nod. Young was flagged for unnecessary roughness, resulting in a 15-yard penalty that gave Indianapolis a new set of downs with 18 seconds left in regulation. Fortunately for Baltimore, the Colts couldn‚Äôt capitalize and the game went to overtime. And, well, you know the rest.   Jack Doyle don‚Äôt let me see you again brah, don‚Äôt disrespect Tay like that.   ‚Äî DeShon Elliott (@OfficialShon_4)  October 12, 2021 READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall If Elliott‚Äôs name rings a bell for Doyle, it‚Äôs because it was the Ravens safety who knocked him out of the game with a jarring hit the last time the teams played each other. The tight end got a concussion and Elliott received a $4,200 fine. Elliott wasn‚Äôt the only one who took offense to Doyle‚Äôs cheap shot, either. Ravens fans had a field day ‚Äî with one user calling him a ‚Äúmarked man‚Äù in Baltimore and others calling him a variety of names we probably shouldn‚Äôt repeat here. For his part, Young took the whole thing in stride and accepted responsibility for the penalty. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúDumb penalty by me got to keep my cool that‚Äôs on me, other than great win keep stacking and I love my team,‚Äù Young tweeted, later adding: ‚ÄúLol ya going crazy in my mentions Relax.‚Äù   Dumb penalty by me got to keep my cool that‚Äôs on me, Other than great win keep stacking and I love my team ‚úåüèæ   ‚Äî Tavon Young (@TY_Real1)  October 12, 2021

bodytext: POOLESVILLE, Md. The man killed was identified as 34-year-old Harry Trueman Powell of Washington, D.C. headline: BARCS To Close Intake Of New Cats Due To Feline Panleukopenia Outbreak, Effective Immediately
summary: The closure is effective immediately and will remain in place for at least two weeks when the situation will be reevaluated.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  BARCS announced that they will be closing their intake of new cats into the shelter due to a feline panleukopenia outbreak, officials announced Tuesday. The closure is effective immediately and will remain in place for at least two weeks when the situation will be reevaluated. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Last week, BARCS received  133 cats from a single home  in Baltimore. Today, some of the cats from that case tested positive for panleukopenia. Panleukopenia is a highly contagious virus that mostly affects unvaccinated kittens. Panleukopenia spreads through fecal matter, urine and nasal secretions. It does not affect people or other animals. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The remaining cats from this case are being quarantined along with any other cats exposed to them. ¬† MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Fans Get Married At Halftime Of Ravens, Colts Game At M&T Bank Stadium
summary: The Ravens said congrats Tuesday, directed mostly to the groom who won twice last night.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî¬† Monday night‚Äôs  nailbiter between the Ravens and Colts  was punctuated with a touching moment at halftime: a Colts fan and Ravens fan got married in the stands.   The Colts had a 10-3 lead at halftime after a relatively uneventful first half, but we just hope the newlyweds stuck around for Baltimore‚Äôs explosive overtime win. Let‚Äôs hope the bride isn‚Äôt too sore about the Colt‚Äôs loss.     Congrats to the happy couple who got married during halftime of last night's game!   (But, mostly the groom üòÇ)  pic.twitter.com/SMbzKYfmxI   ‚Äî Baltimore Ravens (@Ravens)  October 12, 2021     The Ravens said congrats Tuesday, directed mostly to the groom who won twice last night.   The union wasn‚Äôt the only tearjerker at halftime. The Ravens also inducted DT  Haloti Ngata  into their Ring of Honor. He played nine seasons with the Ravens and helped the team to its victory in the 2013 Super Bowl.

headline: Two Critically Injured In Columbia Shooting

bodytext: COLUMBIA, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police are investigating a shooting in Columbia that left two people critically injured Tuesday evening. Officers responded to the 10600 block of Gramercy Place just before 6 p.m. There, they found a man suffering from gunshot wounds near an apartment complex. About half a mile away, near Hickory Ridge Road and Martin Road, police found a second man suffering from gunshot wounds. Anyone with information is asked to call 911.

headline: Covid-19 Vaccine Boosters Are ‚ÄòImmoral‚Äô And ‚ÄòUnfair‚Äô, Says WHO Chief
summary: Distributing Covid-19 vaccine booster shots in some countries while inoculations across Africa lag is "immoral," according to the director-general of the World Health Organization (WHO).
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî  Distributing Covid-19 vaccine booster shots in some countries while inoculations across Africa lag is ‚Äúimmoral,‚Äù according to the director-general of the World Health Organization (WHO). The increasing use of boosters is ‚Äúimmoral, unfair and unjust and it has to stop,‚Äù WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus told CNN‚Äôs Becky Anderson on Tuesday. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúTo start boosters is really the worst we can do as a global community. It is unjust and also unfair because we will not stop the pandemic by ignoring a whole continent, and the continent that doesn‚Äôt have any manufacturing capacity of other means,‚Äù he said. The WHO has recommended an additional vaccine dose for immunocompromised people, but strongly opposes the widespread use of booster shots until more of the world gets vaccinated with a first round of Covid-19 shots. South America, North America, Europe, Asia, Oceania have all administered a single vaccine dose to more than 50% of their populations, whereas only 7% of the population of Africa has received a dose, Tedros said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall In September, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) authorized booster doses of Pfizer‚Äôs vaccine for certain people. In addition the European Medicine Agency (EMA) has directed European Union nations to issue ‚Äúofficial recommendations on the use of booster doses, taking into account emerging effectiveness data and the limited safety data.‚Äù The EMA says that people for people with normal immune systems, booster doses of BioNTech/Pfizer ‚Äúmay be considered at least 6 months after the second dose for people aged 18 years and older.‚Äù The agency is currently evaluating data to support a booster dose for the Moderna vaccine, as well. headline: Baltimore Schools Monitor Student Laptops For Suicide Signs
summary: Baltimore public schools are using software that alerts officials when a student using one of the system‚Äôs laptops might be considering suicide.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (AP) ‚Äî  Baltimore public schools are using software that alerts officials when a student using one of the system‚Äôs laptops might be considering suicide. Since March, GoGuardian‚Äôs Beacon software has identified nine students as having a severe mental health crisis. All were taken to an emergency room, Stacey Davis, the city schools coordinator of media and instructional technology, told The Baltimore Sun. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School But the practice, which came about as the system loaned out laptops for students‚Äô home use during the pandemic, is raising questions about privacy and equity. Two recent reports warn that such technology could be used for disciplinary purposes, unintentionally out LGBTQ students or squash student expression. They also note that economically disadvantaged students may be tracked more frequently since school-owned laptops may be their only devices. ‚ÄúPrivacy and equity was not being considered as much as it needs to be,‚Äù said Elizabeth Laird, director of equity in civic technology at the Center for Democracy and Technology in Washington and co-author of one of the reports. ‚ÄúStudent activity monitoring is quite widespread.‚Äù When there‚Äôs an alert on weekends and at night, when school psychologists or social workers aren‚Äôt available, a school police dispatcher tries to call the family. If there‚Äôs no answer, an officer goes to the home to talk to the family, Davis said. Officers show parents a copy of the alert and what their child typed, then ask to see the student, school police Chief Akil Hamm said. Only once have officers taken a student to the emergency room, and it was at the parents‚Äô request, Hamm said. Baltimore schools have gotten 786 alerts from Beacon since March. Of those, clinicians responded 401 times and school police went to homes 12 times. In addition to the nine students referred to an emergency room, 12 students were referred to a crisis response center. Having school police arrive at a family‚Äôs home could look unsupportive and punitive, said Larry Simmons, president of the system‚Äôs Parent Community Advisory Board. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúSchool police are not social workers,‚Äù he said. The monitoring doesn‚Äôt concern Baltimore City Council of PTAs President Deborah Demery. ‚ÄúAs far as being concerned personally, I feel much better they are monitoring and they are able to get those kids the help. It is a safeguard and it is working,‚Äù Demery said. Society has to balance the risks of invading privacy and the loss of privacy for the common good, said Sharon A. Hoover, co-director of the National Center for School Mental Health at the University of Maryland. Hoover, who is also a professor of child and adolescent psychiatry, said she believes there are good intentions behind the technology ‚Äúand at the same time, they are raising questions and concerns around privacy.‚Äù ‚ÄúDo I think there is some positive potential in protecting students from suicide? Yes, I do,‚Äù she said. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized (¬© Copyright 2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: Kennedy Krieger Clinic Treats Young Patients With ‚ÄòLong COVID‚Äô Who Are Still Dealing With Effects From The Virus
summary: Kennedy Krieger has one of the only clinics in the country that treats children and young adults dealing with what‚Äôs known as "long COVID," when some suffer from symptoms long after the initial infection.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Months after getting COVID-19 last November, Hannah Larson was still dealing with long-term effects from the virus. ‚ÄúI was either passing out or I was really confused and kind of delirious I didn‚Äôt know what was going on I started having problems walking,‚Äù she said. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School She had to take the semester off from school and tried to figure out what was wrong but was not getting far. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt getting better, so I found out about Kennedy Krieger because they opened up their post-COVID clinic,‚Äù Larson said. Kennedy Krieger has one of the only clinics in the country that treats children and young adults dealing with what‚Äôs known as ‚Äúlong COVID,‚Äù when some suffer from symptoms long after the initial infection. ‚ÄúLonger COVID syndrome is a problem that happens after that and has a very complex number of symptoms such as fatigue, dizziness, headaches, weakness, also things like brain fog,‚Äù said Dr. Suzanne Rybczynski, Associate Chief Medical Officer at Kennedy Krieger. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The clinic helps patients through physical therapy and connects them with neurologists and physiologists to help them get better. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a multi-disciplinary clinic so it‚Äôs not just one doctor seeing one kid,‚Äù said Rybczynski. And doctors at the clinic have seen more cases of ‚Äúlong COVID‚Äù as many have started going back to school. But many don‚Äôt about it, and that‚Äôs why Kennedy Krieger is now trying to get the word out about it in schools. ‚ÄúWe have a program that reaches out to school nursing so and provides that education so that there can be that bridge between parents kids and the school,‚Äù said Rybczynski. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized If you have any symptoms of ‚Äúlong COVID‚Äù or suspect anything, doctors at Kennedy Kreiger recommend reaching out to your child‚Äôs pediatrician to see if they can start to help out your child and figure out if they might be experiencing ‚Äúlong COVID.‚Äù

headline: FEMA Denies Disaster Declaration For Damage From Ida; Pittman Calls On Hogan To Declare State Of Emergency
summary: It's another direct hit, but this time to the wallets of people impacted by the rare tornado.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ)  ‚Äî FEMA has denied a request for money to help the dozens of home and business owners impacted by the  EF-2 tornado  that hit parts of Anne Arundel County last month and local leaders are now calling on the governor to step in. It‚Äôs another direct hit, but this time to the wallets of  people  impacted by the rare tornado. READ MORE:  Cleanup Continues After EF-2 Ravages Parole Neighborhood ‚ÄúThey need to do something about it people are still cleaning up the aftermath,‚Äù said neighbor, Wonda Day. FEMA denied a request for a major disaster declaration which would have given people like Wonda Day access to federal money to rebuild. ‚ÄúThese people‚Äôs roofs are still looking horrible and it‚Äôs not a justice for them at all,‚Äù said Day. The powerful twister was spawned by the remnants of Hurricane Ida. Winds up to 125 miles per hour ripped through homes, uprooted trees and left dozens of homes damaged with no help in sight. Now, Anne Arundel County Executive Steuart Pittman is stepping in. ‚ÄúThey do not believe that the storm was such severity and magnitude as to be beyond the capabilities of the state,‚Äù said Pittman. READ MORE:  ‚ÄòLike A Bomb‚Äô Annapolis Neighborhoods Reeling From EF-2 Tornado With 125mph Winds In a letter to the governor, Pittman urged Hogan to declare a State of Emergency to help homeowners and businesses get the funds they need to make repairs. ‚ÄúWe need to be able to activate all of the state resources that we can both for the businesses and for residents who have damage as a result of this tornado,‚Äù said Pittman Pittman says nearly $4 million was lost in businesses revenue. While dozens of families and now left underinsured, Annapolis Mayor Gavin Buckley says helping them out is a top priority. ‚ÄúWe promised that community we would be there for them and we wouldn‚Äôt abandon them,‚Äù said Buckley. Tarps spotted on homes and windows are still boarded up. Neighbors like Day say something needs to be done. ‚ÄúI feel like they are doing them an injustice and it‚Äôs sad,‚Äù said Day. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Suburb Comes Together To Clean Up Damage Left By EF-2 Tornado The Governors‚Äô Office did send out a tweet today saying that while FEMA‚Äôs decision is disappointing, the Maryland Emergency Management Agency will meet with both Anne Arundel County and Annapolis to discuss other options.

headline: Doctors Say Trick-Or-Treating Is Safe For Children This Halloween
summary: With COVID-19 hospitalizations and deaths dropping nationwide, doctors say trick-or-treating is one of the activities this fall that we can really engage in with lots of layers of protection against COVID-19.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  With COVID-19 hospitalizations and deaths dropping nationwide, doctors say trick-or-treating is one of the activities this fall that we can really engage in with lots of layers of protection against the virus. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve grown in our science since last year, but the most important thing is we have a vaccine,‚Äù said Dr. Keri Althoff, associate professor of epidemiology at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School They say it‚Äôs an encouraging sign as we continue to fight to get to the other side of this pandemic. ‚ÄúDefinitely get out there with your kids and trick or treat, be outside, that‚Äôs the best place for you,‚Äù said Althoff. There is a catch, Dr. Althoff says there‚Äôs a right way to do it safely. ‚ÄúI think being outside for these gatherings is really going to be key,‚Äù said Althoff. She recommends staying in small groups for any activities, keeping your distance and properly incorporating a mask into your costume. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre wearing a holiday mask that is a part of your costume that does not cover your mouth and nose properly, that‚Äôs not giving you the protection you need,‚Äù said Althoff. Proper face coverings are especially important for kids under the age of 12 who can‚Äôt get vaccinated just yet. For those handing out goodies, doctors say the treats will be just as sweet, even with less physical contact. ‚ÄúYou can put a bowl of candy, even a few feet from you and tell the guests to take a few pieces and you can sit there with your mask on,‚Äù said Althoff. Most importantly, parents can look forward to making Halloween memories with their loved ones again. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Health officials say they‚Äôre going to be monitoring COVID-19 cases following Halloween, and hopes this serves as a reminder for people to get vaccinated ahead of the holiday season so we can enjoy them safely.

bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A man shot in the head and body had to flag down a Baltimore Police patrol officer on Greenmount Avenue early Wednesday morning, police said. The 31-year-old man is hospitalized in critical condition. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Police said a patrol officer was approached by the man around 5:17 a.m. He was transported to the hospital where he is now in critical but stable condition. headline: Is My Immunity Waning? Doctors Advise Pfizer Vaccine Recipients Not To Worry
summary: How can protection wane against mild or asymptomatic infection while staying strong against severe disease?
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî  There‚Äôs little doubt now ‚Äî study after study, in real life and in lab dishes, in the US and elsewhere ‚Äî that people‚Äôs immunity starts to wane just months after they finish the two-dose series of Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine. While getting two doses of vaccine creates a strong immune response that reduces the risk of severe disease by more than 90%, the protection against milder and asymptomatic infections drops off gradually. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School That‚Äôs why Pfizer has asked for and received US Food and Drug Administration authorization to add boosters for many people who are six months out from vaccination. But should others be seeking boosters, too? How much should people be worrying? ‚ÄúI think that we expect that immunity will slowly wane, over time, but it‚Äôs not a reason for people to panic,‚Äù said Dr. Ann Falsey, a specialist in viral respiratory diseases at the University of Rochester School of Medicine. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like suddenly one day you‚Äôre completely susceptible, like you were before you were vaccinated,‚Äù added Falsey, who is helping lead clinical trials of Covid-19 vaccines. ‚ÄúThe vaccines are all standing up pretty well ‚Äî Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson ‚Äî for severe disease,‚Äù Falsey told CNN. ‚ÄúNow, that‚Äôs not to say that we might not eventually get to a point where we really need people to get boosters to prevent more severe illness. But, really, the majority of the breakthrough infections are colds, maybe flu-like illness ‚Äî not the scary illnesses that we were facing before,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúSo my main message is, don‚Äôt panic. You‚Äôre going to be okay.‚Äù That hasn‚Äôt stopped Americans from flocking to get boosters. This past week more people were getting booster shots than were getting their first round of a coronavirus vaccine. By Friday, more than 7 million Americans had received either booster shots or the third round of vaccines authorized for people with immunocompromising conditions who likely did not get adequate responses to the first two shots. This week,  two more studies  added to the growing evidence that immunity from Pfizer‚Äôs vaccine drops off. One study from Israel covered 4,800 health care workers and showed antibody levels wane rapidly after two doses of vaccine, ‚Äúespecially among men, among persons 65 years of age or older, and among persons with immunosuppression.‚Äù A second study from Qatar showed protection from the Pfizer vaccine peaked in the first month after vaccination and then began to wane. ‚ÄúThese findings suggest that a large proportion of the vaccinated population could lose its protection against infection in the coming months, perhaps increasing the potential for new epidemic waves,‚Äù the team wrote in a report published in the New England Journal of Medicine. How can protection wane against mild or asymptomatic infection while staying strong against severe disease? It‚Äôs because the human immune system is complex. Antibodies form the first line of defense, stopping a virus from getting into some cells in the body. This is the protection that starts to wear off after time. But there‚Äôs a second line of defense ‚Äî cell-based immunity. Cells called B cells and T cells can take longer to generate than antibodies, but they provide a longer-lived, broader defense against infection and are responsible for decreases in severe infections. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall So while people may be susceptible to mild illness after they‚Äôve been vaccinated, they‚Äôre much less likely to get really sick, end up in the hospital or die. ‚ÄúBut there‚Äôs a lot of reasons people don‚Äôt want to get sick. They don‚Äôt want to pass it to loved ones. People don‚Äôt want to pass it to young children that can‚Äôt get vaccinated yet,‚Äù Falsey said. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has been saying for months that‚Äôs why even fully vaccinated people need to continue taking precautions against infection ‚Äî wearing masks when around a lot of other people who may or may not be vaccinated, especially indoors, and making sure rooms are well ventilated. The FDA is considering applications later this month from both Moderna  and Johnson & Johnson  to authorize booster doses of their vaccines. Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, has said he thinks a third dose of vaccine will become part of the standard regimen for Covid-19. ‚ÄúThey just don‚Äôt need to storm the pharmacies and panic.‚Äù The people getting boosters now should have been among the first to have been vaccinated ‚Äî in January, February and March. They include people 65 and older, adults with conditions putting them at risk of severe disease and people in occupations or living conditions that put them at higher than average risk of infection. Everyone else should cool it for now. ‚ÄúThey just don‚Äôt need to storm the pharmacies and panic,‚Äù Falsey said. People should not go ahead and get booster doses if it hasn‚Äôt been six months since their last dose of Pfizer vaccine, because they will not get the best immune response, Fauci said in a White House briefing last month. ‚ÄúThere will be temptations, for example, for people who recently got vaccinated to not wait for the six month period of time,‚Äù Fauci said. But waiting for several months after the initial immunization to boost helps produce a stronger response. Immune system cells that help restore waning immunity respond more robustly if they are allowed to go into a resting state after the first round of vaccination. That said, most people should eventually plan on getting boosters, Falsey said. ‚ÄúProbably it‚Äôs going to be true of any of the vaccines, not just Pfizer ‚Äî we‚Äôll benefit from boosting immunity. That‚Äôs not the same thing as saying it‚Äôs critically necessary,‚Äù she said. While people who have recovered from an infection have some protection, they‚Äôre even more protected if they get vaccinated, too. ‚ÄúI think that, depending on your own natural immunity because you feel like you‚Äôre a strong person is like playing Russian roulette,‚Äù Falsey said. Even young, seemingly healthy people have become seriously ill from Covid-19 and have died from it. ‚ÄúI would never depend only on my natural immunity to weather this virus. It‚Äôs a very, very bad actor,‚Äù Falsey said. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The-CNN-Wire  ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2021 Cable News Network, Inc., a WarnerMedia Company. All rights reserved.

headline: Annapolis Couple Could Face Life In Prison If Convicted Of Espionage Charges
summary: A Navy nuclear engineer and his wife could both face life in prison if convicted of espionage charges related to a plot to sell military secrets to a foreign government.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Navy nuclear engineer and his wife could both face life in prison if convicted of  espionage charges related to a plot to sell military secrets to a foreign government. Jonathan Toebbe, 42, and his wife, Diana, 45, both of Annapolis, appeared Tuesday in federal court in West Virginia to face charges of conspiracy to communicate restricted data and communication of restricted data in violation of the Atomic Energy Act. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The couple were ordered to remain in the custody of the U.S. Marshals Service pending the outcomes of their detention hearings on Friday morning. Each of the charges carries a maximum sentence of life in prison, a $100,000 fine and a five-year term of supervised release, U.S.¬†Magistrate Judge Robert¬†W.¬†Trumble told the couple. ‚ÄúThe consequences here are monumental. They are seeking monumental consequences‚Äù said University of Maryland School of Law professor Michael Greenberger, who has no ties to the case. The charges stem from a federal complaint that accuses the couple of trying to sell confidential information, including nuclear submarine schematics, to an unnamed foreign power. According to the complaint, the plot began with an unsolicited package Jonathan Toebbe sent to a foreign government in April 2020, a package that was later handed over to the FBI. ‚ÄúI apologize for this poor translation into your language. Please forward this letter to your military intelligence agency. I believe this information will be of great value to your nation. This is not a hoax,‚Äù Toebbe allegedly wrote. But instead of making contact with foreign military intelligence, Toebbe was put in touch with the FBI, which set up a sting operation using an undercover agent who posed as a foreign contact. Authorities say after working out details for payment and delivery of the data, Toebbe crossed state lines on multiple occasions to drop off memory cards containing sensitive data as part of the arrangement. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall According to the complaint, the memory cards were concealed inside ordinary items that included everything from a peanut butter sandwich to a pack of gum. At times, the complaint said, Diana Toebbe acted as a lookout for her husband. The year-long investigation resulted in the couple‚Äôs arrests Saturday in Jefferson County, West Virginia. Greenberger, the law professor, said there are expectations in place when someone, such as Toebbe, is granted multiple high-level security clearances. ‚ÄúOne expects, quite rightly, the people handling this information are loyal to the United States government,‚Äù Greenberger said. Based on financial affidavits detailing the couple‚Äôs income, assets and debts, they will be assigned court-appointed attorneys to represent them in court. Notably, Diana Toebbe hedged somewhat when asked if the court documents accurately represented the couple‚Äôs finances. ‚ÄúTo the best of my knowledge, which is limited,‚Äù she said. The Toebbes are due in court Friday for detention hearings. The judge also set preliminary examination hearings for Oct. 20 to determine if probable cause exists for the couple‚Äôs charges. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Baby Cereal Sold At Walmart Recalled Over Arsenic Levels
summary: Have the product in your pantry? Check the best if used by date and product numbers to determine if you've purchased from the recalled lots.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  The company that manufactures a baby cereal sold exclusively at Walmart issued a voluntary recall Friday for three lots of the product, the Food and Drug Administration announced. A routine sampling by the FDA found that three lots of Parent‚Äôs Choice Rice Baby Cereal, made by Maple Island Inc., tested above the guidance for naturally occurring inorganic arsenic. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Walmart has pulled the baby food off its shelves and has taken measures to prevent further sales. No illnesses related to the product lots have been reported and no other production lots or Parent‚Äôs Choice products are affected by the recall, the FDA said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Have the product in your pantry? Check the best if used by date and product numbers to determine if you‚Äôve purchased from the recalled lots. Here are the best if used by date and product numbers of the recalled lots:   Lot 21083 with UPC Code #00681131082907 with a best if used by date of JUN 24 2022.   Lot 21084 with UPC Code #00681131082907 with a best if used by date of JUN 25 2022   Lot 21242 with UPC Code #00681131082907 with a best if used by date of NOV 30 2022   If you have the recalled product, throw it away or return it to Walmart for a full refund. For more information,  visit the FDA announcement. headline: COVID-19 In Maryland: Over 1,100 Cases Reported, 16 New Deaths
summary: Maryland reported 1,113 new COVID-19 cases and 16 new deaths, according to state health department data released Wednesday morning.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland reported 1,113 new COVID-19 cases and 16 new deaths, according to state health department data released Wednesday morning. The percentage of people testing positive decreased slightly by 0.03% to 3.85%. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Doctors say the new cases are fueled by dangerous strains targeting the unvaccinated. During an August press conference, Gov. Larry Hogan said the Delta variant, a strain that is reportedly two to four times more contagious than the original virus strain, accounts for nearly every new confirmed case in Maryland. ‚ÄúThe vaccines are without a doubt our single most effective tool to mitigate the threat of COVID-19 and the surging Delta variant, and Maryland‚Äôs vaccination rate continues to outpace the nation,‚Äù Hogan said. More than 3.9 million Maryland adults are fully vaccinated. Hospitalizations decreased by 3 to 762. Of those hospitalized, 558 remain in acute care and 192 are in the ICU. Since the pandemic began, there were 546,552 total confirmed cases and 10,413 deaths. There are 3,945,098 Marylanders fully vaccinated. The state has administered 8,127,860 doses. Of those, 4,001,501 are first doses with 5,074 administered in the past 24 hours. They have given out 3,638,404 second doses, 4,088 in the last day. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of people who have rolled up their sleeves, Maryland continues to be one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan of the eight million milestone mark. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù The state began to administer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine again in April after the CDC and FDA lifted their pause on the vaccine due to a rare blood clot found in some women. A total of 306,694 Marylanders have received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 316 in the last day. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall On September 24, after the CDC granted final approval for Pfizer‚Äôs booster, Gov. Hogan announced the immediate authorization of the booster shot for Marylanders who have received their second Pfizer shot at least six months ago. Hogan  had already approved use  for vulnerable populations in early September. The state has administered 181,261 additional or booster vaccine doses, 9,957 in the last day. The state reported 84.7% of all adults in Maryland have received at least one dose of the vaccine. In August, the state launched a post-vaccination infections dashboard that is updated every Wednesday. There have been 25,476 total cases among fully vaccinated Marylanders as of last Wednesday, October 13. Less than 0.71% of fully vaccinated Marylanders have later tested positive. Of those cases, 1,842 vaccinated Marylanders were hospitalized, representing 10.8% of all Covid cases hospitalized in the state. 233 fully vaccinated Marylanders have died, representing 8.36% of lab-confirmed Covid deaths in the state.
