headline: Child Tax Credit: How To Opt Out Of Monthly Payments
summary: The next Child Tax Credit payment is due October 15, but some parents may prefer a lump-sum payment at tax time.
bodytext: ( CBS Detroit ) ‚Äî  Most parents will receive their next Child Tax Credit payment on  October 15 . The monthly checks of up to $300 per child will continue through the end of 2021. And up to $1,800 more per child will arrive at tax time next year. The amount of each parent‚Äôs total deposit depends on their annual income, the number of children and the ages of those children. When added together, the money may add up to more than any of the first three stimulus checks. But what if a parent wants to opt out of these advance payments in favor of a one-time payment? Qualifying For The Updated Credit The updated Child Tax Credit is based on parents‚Äô modified adjusted gross income (AGI), as reflected on their 2020 tax filing. (AGI is the sum of one‚Äôs wages, interest, dividends, alimony, retirement distributions and other sources of income minus certain deductions, such as student loan interest, alimony payments and retirement contributions.) The amount  phases out  at a rate of $50 for every $1,000 of annual income beyond $75,000 for an individual and beyond $150,000 for a married couple. The benefit is fully refundable, meaning it does not depend on the recipient‚Äôs current tax burden. Qualifying families receive the full amount, regardless of what they owe in taxes. There is no limit to the number of dependents that can be claimed. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The IRS is paying $3,600 per child to parents of children up to age five. That changes to $3,000 total for each child ages six through 17. Half of the total is being paid as six monthly payments and half as a 2021 tax credit. The IRS has made a one-time payment of $500 for dependents age 18 or full-time college students up through age 24.   #IRSTaxTip : Non-traditional families may qualify for advance  #ChildTaxCredit  payments. Check out the  #IRS  eligibility guidelines and see if your family qualifies:  https://t.co/9J5HB58rqX *Thanks for sharing your artwork, Kayleigh*  pic.twitter.com/QklAjdqPjp   ‚Äî IRSnews (@IRSnews)  October 13, 2021 As an example, suppose a married couple has a four-year-old child and an eight-year-old child and showed an annual joint income of $120,000 on their 2020 taxes. The IRS would send them a monthly check for $550 starting in July. That‚Äôs $300 per month ($3,600 / 12) for the younger child and $250 per month ($3,000 / 12) for the older child. Those checks would last through December. The couple would then receive the $3,300 balance ‚Äî $1,800 ($300 X 6) for the younger child and $1,500 ($250 X 6) for the older child ‚Äî as part of their 2021 tax refund. Parents of a child who ages out of an age bracket are being paid the lesser amount. That means if a five-year-old turns six in 2021, the parents are receiving a total credit of $3,000 for the year, not $3,600. Likewise, if a 17-year-old turns 18 in 2021, the parents have received $500, not $3,000. An income increase in 2021 to an amount above the $75,000 ($150,000) threshold could lower a household‚Äôs Child Tax Credit. The IRS has confirmed that they‚Äôll soon allow claimants to adjust their income and custodial information online, thus lowering their payments. Failure to do so could increase one‚Äôs tax bill or reduce one‚Äôs tax refund once 2021 taxes are filed. Eligibility requires that a dependent be part of the household for at least half of the year and be at least half supported by the taxpayer. A taxpayer who makes above $95,000 ($170,000) ‚Äî where the income limits phase out ‚Äî will  not be eligible  for the expanded credit. But they can still claim the existing $2,000 credit per child. Opting Out Of Advance Payments Parents who filed taxes in 2019 and/or 2020 and meet the income requirements automatically started receiving advance Child Tax Credit payments back in July. But some parents may prefer a lump-sum payment at tax time rather than monthly payments and a smaller tax credit. The deadline to opt out before the October 15 payment has already passed. But the deadline to opt out of the November 15 payment is November 1. (Subsequent opt-out deadlines for payments going forward will occur three days before the first Thursday of the month being opted out of.) The  Child Tax Credit Update Portal  allows users to make sure they are registered to receive advance payments, update bank account information for direct deposit, and change an address. It also lets recipients view their payment history and unenroll from advance payments in favor of a one-time credit when filing their 2021 taxes. Updating dependents and changing income are other features coming to the portal. To access this portal, users need an IRS username or an ID.me account. ID.me is a sign-in service used by various government agencies, including the IRS, Social Security Administration and Treasury Department, to authenticate users. Users need valid photo identification to create an account. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall From the portal page, a user should click the ‚ÄúManage Advance Payments‚Äù button. Log into your account on the next page, or create an account. Once logged in, a user can view their eligibility and change how the Credit will be received. Reasons To Opt Out Of Advance Payments Every household‚Äôs financial circumstances are unique. Every family handles their finances in the way that works best for them. And then there are simple matters of preference. For these and other reasons, the default scenario of advance monthly payments followed by a lump-sum credit may not be ideal. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an advance payment based off of your estimated benefit, given what your income is going to be in 2021, based off of what your income was 2020 or 2019,‚Äù says Stephen Nu√±ez, the Lead Researcher on Guaranteed Income at the Jain Family Institute, an applied research organization in the social sciences. (Nu√±ez studies cash welfare policy, that includes field work to answer policy-relevant questions about the social safety net.) ‚ÄúSo there is a possibility, of course, that your income changes from year to year, so that the estimate is actually fairly far off from what your actual income is.‚Äù Given the decline of the economy in 2020 as compared to its surge in 2021, drastic income changes seem plausible if not expected. A parent who lost her job in March of 2020 and found a new one in January of 2021 could earn more money this year than last year. However, the IRS will base her monthly Child Tax Credit payments on her 2020 income. If the new job pushes her above the income threshold, the IRS will overpay her. ‚ÄúImagine a world where based off of your income in 2020, they give you $3,000,‚Äù Nu√±ez suggested. ‚ÄúIt turns out that based off your income in 2021, you actually only were supposed to receive only $2,400. Well then at tax time, there would be a claw-back. They will say, sorry, we overpaid you, because our guess was incorrect. So you need to pay us back $600.‚Äù The IRS will be holding half of the overall Child Tax Credit in reserve. So, using Nu√±ez‚Äôs example, that $600 wouldn‚Äôt have to be repaid per se. It would simply be deducted from the other half of the credit. This parent would receive a $900 credit at tax time next year, rather than the $1,500 balance. For families navigating a divorce or child custody issues, advance payments of the Child Tax Credit could create additional difficulties. A divorce will break a household into multiple households. The $150,000 threshold for a married couple becomes $112,500 for each head of the new household. That could create complications based on individual incomes and who has custody of the children. As Nu√±ez puts it, ‚Äúif you‚Äôve had a change in household composition. Imagine you got divorced, or you no longer have a child, and they‚Äôre sending you $3,000 for a child that you don‚Äôt have in your life. That money, you‚Äôre going to have to pay it back.‚Äù Opting out of advance monthly payments in favor of a lump-sum payment at tax time would simplify the process of reorganizing a household into multiple households. It also could make financial planning easier. The choice depends on individual circumstances. Monthly payments help people smooth out income volatility month to month and handle unforeseen expenses, like a car repair. A onetime payment lets people be certain they will have money for a bigger purchase without setting that money aside themselves. It‚Äôs a sort of induced savings plan. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Nu√±ez related the situation to research on the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC), which is paid as a lump sum at tax time. ‚ÄúPart of it is that some people really like the idea of receiving all that money at once,‚Äù Nu√±ez said. ‚ÄúIt helps them plan for big purchases, for down payments on cars, for buying a refrigerator, whatever. And that‚Äôs just the way that they would prefer to receive their money. They may also, to be honest, they may feel like if they get the money on a monthly basis, they‚Äôre going to have trouble setting aside money, calculating how much money to set aside or perhaps they may feel like it‚Äôs a temptation to spend it, rather than to save it.‚Äù

headline: ‚ÄòKeep Striving For Greatness‚Äô: Lamar Jackson Appears On Steve Harvey‚Äôs Show To Encourage A 12-Year-Old Boy Helping Single Parents Get Diapers
summary: Fresh off his incredible performance against the Indianapolis Colts, Ravens quarterback Lamar Jackson appeared on Steve Harvey's talk show Wednesday to encourage a young boy who has raised more than $45,000 to help his community.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Fresh off his  incredible performance  against the Indianapolis Colts, Ravens quarterback Lamar Jackson appeared on Steve Harvey‚Äôs talk show Wednesday to encourage a young boy who has raised more than $45,000 to help his community. Harvey had 12-year-old Cartier Carey on ‚Äú STEVE On Watch ‚Äù to highlight the boy‚Äôs efforts with  Kids 4 Change 757 , a nonprofit Carey started to sell lemonade and use the proceeds to buy and distribute diapers to single parents in the Newport News, Virginia area. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School After Carey listed Jackson, Tom Brady and Michael Vick among his favorite NFL players, Harvey had the boy turn around for a surprise video message from the Ravens signal-caller. ‚ÄúI want you to keep going, man,‚Äù Jackson told Carey. ‚ÄúKeep striving for greatness, to be the best person you could be.‚Äù   . @Lj_era8  teamed up with  @IAmSteveHarvey  to surprise a young man who's making a big difference in his community!  #SteveOnWatch     Catch the full episode:  https://t.co/ksjsdLjdOB   pic.twitter.com/KFa5CpcMd6   ‚Äî Baltimore Ravens (@Ravens)  October 13, 2021 READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall In addition to charity work, Jackson told Carey to keep pursuing football, basketball and rapping. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do the rapping part, you know? But I can do a little something on the court, throw a football here and there with you,‚Äù said Jackson. Carey laughed with joy at the end of the video and said, ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt expecting that.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The Ravens and Jackson presented the Carey family with four tickets to the¬† Oct. 17 home game against the Los Angeles Chargers.

headline: Hey, EA Sports: Lamar Jackson Is Ready To Be In Madden‚Äôs 99 Club
summary: "Man, I feel like we should have been in the 99 Club," Lamar Jackson joked. "Man, I don't know what's up with Madden."
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Baltimore Ravens quarterback Lamar Jackson makes plays on the field that don‚Äôt seem possible, be it with his arm or his legs. Jackson‚Äôs coach at Boynton Beach Community High, Rick Swain, used to call him ‚ÄúMr. Video Game.‚Äù READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúHe stood apart from everybody else. It looked like you were playing Madden or something,‚Äù Swain  told ESPN  in 2019. ‚ÄúYou had the supercharged guy.‚Äù Jackson filled up the stat sheet in the Ravens‚Äô 31-25 overtime win against the Indianapolis Colts. In case you need a reminder, he went 37-for-43 with 442 passing yards and 4 touchdowns, and rushed for 62 yards. On Wednesday, a reporter asked Jackson about Madden, the long-running NFL video game franchise. Friends were texting him about the quarterback‚Äôs 85% completion percentage against the Colts and saying, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt even do that in Madden,‚Äù the reporter said. ‚ÄúI can do that in Madden,‚Äù Jackson quickly replied with a smile. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall So is it time for the quarterback to be in the  99 Club , a select group of players with the game‚Äôs highest overall ranking of 99 overall? ‚ÄúMan, I feel like we should have  been  in the 99 Club,‚Äù Jackson joked. ‚ÄúMan, I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs up with Madden.‚Äù   . @EAMaddenNFL ,  @Lj_era8  would like a word üòÇüòÇ  pic.twitter.com/nVs6zhtAcd   ‚Äî Baltimore Ravens (@Ravens)  October 13, 2021 And then he pretended to wave off the question. ‚ÄúWe ain‚Äôt even talking about that one,‚Äù he said. Madden 22 has Jackson has a 92 overall, according to  rankings  from the game‚Äôs developer, EA Sports. His elite speed is represented with a 96 speed rating and a 96 acceleration rating, and EA Sports even seems to recognize Jackson‚Äôs cannon arm with a 92 throwing power ranking. But they ding the Ravens quarterback for his accuracy, with ratings on short, medium and deep passes being no higher than 89. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Maybe they will make the necessary changes after watching a replay of that Colts game.

headline: Baltimore Man Identified As Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Police Shootout
summary: The robbery suspect and Baltimore County officer involved in a shootout in Woodlawn Monday were identified by the Maryland Attorney General's Office Wednesday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî ¬†The robbery suspect and Baltimore County officer involved in a shootout in Woodlawn Monday were identified by the Maryland Attorney General‚Äôs Office Wednesday. The suspect, identified as 36-year-old Jovan Lewis Singleton, was found dead shortly after the exchange of gunfire. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The officer was identified only as Lt. Meade,¬†a 25-year veteran of the Baltimore County Police Department Meade was hurt during the shootout, but his injury was not a gunshot wound. He was taken to an area hospital for treatment. The sequence of events began shortly after 2 a.m. as officers investigated an armed robbery reported at a 7-Eleven convenience store on Windsor Mill Road near Woodlawn Drive, according to Baltimore County Police. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Police said two suspects were trying to lose police when their vehicle was involved in a hit-and-crash crash near Dogwood Road and Gwynn Oak Avenue. That‚Äôs when police believe the suspects bailed out. An officer came across one of the suspects near the corner of Englewood Avenue and Gilmore Street and the pair traded gunfire, according to police. Police said K-9 units found one of the suspects dead nearby a short time later. It wasn‚Äôt immediately clear how the suspect died. A firearm believed to be linked to the case was recovered from the scene. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Based on a preliminary investigation, police believe only one officer fired his agency-issued firearm during the exchange of gunfire.

headline: Judge Orders Baltimore To Allow ‚ÄòChurch Militant‚Äô Rally Featuring Far Right Speakers, Legal Analyst Weighs In On Ruling
summary: St. Michaels Media -- also known as Church Militant -- plans to make their voices heard on the Catholic Church's sexual abuse scandal in November, when Catholic bishops from around the country gather in Baltimore for a conference.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A federal judge ruled Baltimore City can‚Äôt reject the request on behalf of the Catholic conservative group, Saint Michael‚Äôs Media, to rent out the MECU Pavilion. But the mayor‚Äôs office said it intends to appeal the judge‚Äôs ruling, saying it‚Äôs a matter of public safety. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not allowed as a government to make decisions about which messages and which viewpoint are going to have the opportunity to be expressed,‚Äù said Adam Ruther, Partner at Rosenberg Martin Greenberg, LLP, in an interview with WJZ Wednesday. St. Michaels Media ‚Äî also known as Church Militant ‚Äî plans to make their voices heard on the Catholic Church‚Äôs sexual abuse scandal in November, when Catholic bishops from around the country gather in Baltimore for a conference. The group tried to rent the city-owned MECU Pavilion at Pier Six, even putting down a deposit. But city leaders rejected that request. Church Militant then sued, claiming its First Amendment rights were being violated. U.S. District Judge Ellen Hollander ruled late Tuesday that Church Militant is likely to succeed on its argument that the city violated its free speech rights and is discriminating against the group based on its political views. ‚ÄúThey saw a concern that the message that they thought was going to be expressed might cause problems in the community, there might be counter-protests, there might even be, God forbid, some degree of violence,‚Äù said Ruther. But Ruther said that crosses a  constitutional line , echoing what U.S. District Judge Ellen Hollander ruled. He said the right to free speech means ‚Äúpeople who express even unfavorable or dangerous ideas should be allowed to have their moment to express them.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúWe are disappointed by the Court‚Äôs decision and potential threat to public safety if this event ensues,‚Äù a spokesperson for Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott said in a statement to WJZ. ‚ÄúThe proposed rally is slated to take place on Baltimore City property, and we have a responsibility to protect our property and fellow citizens. We remain committed to this charge and will appeal this decision.‚Äù The city fears violence in the expected crowd of 3,000 people and cites incendiary speakers who are expected to attend‚Äîincluding Steve Bannon, the former Chief Strategist for President Trump, and  Milo Yiannopoulos,  a right-wing provocateur. A  2017 appearance  by Yiannapoulos led to violence in Berkeley, California. Bannon called for the beheading of  Dr. Anthony Fauci  on his podcast last year. Until the conclusion of the litigation, no city officials or employees can prohibit the group from entering into a contract with the pavilion‚Äôs manager, Hollander said. The judge did not set any expectations on the terms of the contract. Hollander said in her decision she ‚Äúanticipates good faith negotiations, but expresses no opinion on the terms of a contract.‚Äù Church Militant said there was no violence during a similar protest at the bishops‚Äô conference in Baltimore three years ago. That event drew about 1,000 people. This year‚Äôs rally, planned for Nov. 16, has an expected crowd of 3,000 people. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: A ‚ÄòTwindemic‚Äô Of Flu & COVID-19 Can Be Dulled With Vaccines, Expert Says
summary: Though the side effects of the flu are similar, sometimes identical to those of COVID-19, Dr. Thompson said they are indeed two very different viruses and therefore need their own protective vaccine.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A local biology expert said health officials fear a ‚Äòtwindemic‚Äô this year with sickness plaguing Americans, whether it be coronavirus or influenza. ‚ÄúMany places have hospitals that are already overrun with Covid cases so if we add all those flu cases to that it could be a huge problem for the economy, for communities, for doctors, for hospitals everywhere,‚Äù said Dr. Christopher Thompson, Assoc. Professor of Biology at Loyola University READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Right now, he said Maryland hospitals are doing OK, but other parts of the country are feeling overwhelmed. Dr. Thompson suggests people get vaccinated against both viruses. ‚ÄúIt does seem odd that we have all these vaccines for things that attack our lungs and give us fevers and coughs and some similar symptoms, but they are very different viruses,‚Äù Dr. Thompson said. Though the side effects of the flu are similar, sometimes identical to those of COVID-19, Dr. Thompson said they are indeed two very different viruses and therefore need their own protective vaccine. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúThey are two very different things they both attack our lungs but they caused different diseases,‚Äù Dr. Thompson said. ‚ÄúNormally the flu kills about 36,000 people a year.‚Äù You might have noticed that last year‚Äôs flu numbers were extremely low, but Dr. Thompson said much of that can be attributed to the restrictions in place. Americans were more careful, he said, wearing masks, social distancing, washing hands. Dr. Thompson said now that more and more people are back to work the flu season might be more severe than last year. Statistically mild flu seasons are followed by more severe ones, and people often get sick between October and March. ‚ÄúVirologists refer to the flu as the worst Christmas gift you could ever get, we tend to see it peak right after Christmas time,‚Äù Dr. Thompson said. Darian Nolin, who works at Total Health Care in Baltimore, said people can even get both shots at once; ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs available right here, now. I can get both and it is safe to receive both at the same time, so individuals are looking for that as a convenient thing.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Shameka McFadden, who lives in Baltimore, stopped into a clinic Thursday; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here for my Covid vaccine,‚Äù she told WJZ. She said, ‚Äò‚ÄùI got my flu shot two months ago with my son and then my Covid shot, this is my first one.‚Äù

headline: Neurologist Shares Insight On Traumatic Brain Injuries In Wake Of Elijah Gorham‚Äôs Death
summary: The medical examiner revealed the cause of death for the beloved high school football player, Elijah Gorham.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  The medical examiner revealed the cause of death for the beloved high school football player,  Elijah Gorham. In an email to WJZ on Tuesday, the office revealed that the 17-year-old‚Äôs cause of death was cardiac arrest, multi-system organ failure, accidental trauma, and a traumatic brain injury. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúThese cases are very unfortunate and they remind us of the severity of this injury,‚Äù said Dr. Kevin Crutchfield, a neurologist who helped to write Maryland‚Äôs concussion protocol laws. Dr. Crutchfield does not know the specifics of Gorham‚Äôs case but described what happens in the body when an athlete gets a traumatic brain injury. ‚ÄúIf the body stops suddenly, the brain can still shift around inside the skull and bang up against the inside of the skull. And it‚Äôs the transfer of that force into the tissue of the brain that has energy that leads to chemical changes and that is a traumatic brain injury. It can either cause bruising, bleeding,‚Äù said Dr. Crutchfield. Dr. Crutchfield said traumatic brain injuries (TBI) are more severe than concussions. He describes concussions as a self-resolving process, whereas TBI improves, but does not fully resolve. Gorham was a senior at Mergenthaler Vocational-Technical High School. He was injured during a game back in September and died a few weeks later. In a statement to WJZ, Baltimore City Schools said: READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall During interscholastic football games, such as this one, City Schools arranges for a medic to be on the scene. The medic administered care while waiting for an ambulance to arrive. Additionally, all coaches are trained in student care and injury prevention. The medic ensures that the district Athletic Department receives information regarding any injury that requires medical attention. Gorham‚Äôs mother, Shantres Shaw told WJZ the team was like family. ‚ÄúIt was a brotherhood to him, he loved his team members his coaches, his family and he was just amazing,‚Äù said Shaw. Even at a teenager, Elijah‚Äôs positive impact was unmistakable. His coach called him a silent leader. ‚ÄúJust a wonderful young man so caring so giving so genuine, can‚Äôt say enough positive things about him,‚Äù sid Patrick Nixon, head football coach and athletic director at Mervo. Coach Nixon said there will be a vigil on the football field Thursday at 7 p.m. in Elijah‚Äôs honor. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized A GoFundMe has been organized to establish a scholarship in Gorham‚Äôs memory. To donate or learn more,  click here.

headline: ‚ÄòTis The Season To Start Shopping Early‚Äô: Experts Encourage Consumers To Start Holiday Shopping Early
summary: Americans are expected to be in the mood to spend this holiday season but this isn't the year to procrastinate and experts say you may be taking a gamble by waiting for a discount.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)¬† ‚Äî  Americans are expected to be in the mood to spend this holiday season but this isn‚Äôt the year to procrastinate and experts say you may be taking a gamble by waiting for a discount. ‚ÄúThis holiday season will be much different, it will be much longer,‚Äù said Tinglong Dai, Professor at Johns Hopkins University Carey Business School. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Local business analytics expert Tinglong Sai said supply chain and labor issues from the start of the pandemic are creating a major backlog and just about every industry is seeing the impact. ‚ÄúSo overall we have enough supply, we have basically a stable demand. Its in the middle, a lot of things, lots of kinks that need to be worked out,‚Äù said Dai. ‚ÄúIf we can get more people to work, I think that‚Äôs really the key to solve this ongoing trouble.‚Äù As container ships continue to sit outside the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach with a shortage of truck drivers and warehouse workers, experts say small retailers will be hit the hardest. ‚ÄúWe started hearing from vendors. Shoes that we‚Äôre supposed [to be] delivered in August or September were getting pushed to October, November, even some December,‚Äù said Mary Kate Donahue, Brand Manager and Assistant Buyer at Sassanova. That‚Äôs why at Sassanova, a local clothing boutique, the staff has already worked to stay ahead of the disruptions. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúWhen it came time for us to really front-load all of our holiday gifts, around June, July, we just decided to get everything in as soon as we could,‚Äù said Donahue. Some local shoppers are also not taking any chances. ‚ÄúI already stocked up on my food. Already did my Thanksgiving shopping,‚Äù said Joana Straughter-Diallo. ‚ÄúI¬†already put down my holiday shopping and my special shopping‚Äù But experts say there‚Äôs no need to start panic buying. Instead, just plan ahead and learn to adapt to the changes. ‚ÄúConsumers should expect to see less discount to be offered, also less variety and in certain cases, you have to settle with what‚Äôs available rather than what you desire,‚Äù Dai added. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just reminding customers that if you see it and you don‚Äôt buy it there‚Äôs a very high chance that it‚Äôs not going to be here when you come back,‚Äù Donahue said. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Dai said he expects things to start dwindling back to normal and back up to speed sometime early next year. In the meantime, he said now is a good time to support local businesses.

headline: Baltimore Rock Opera Society And Maryland Zoo Partner On ‚ÄòMonster World: Zoo Quest‚Äô Interactive Fundraiser
summary: The Baltimore Rock Opera Society and Maryland Zoo are partnering on "Monster World: Zoo Quest," a fundraiser that takes attendees through an interactive tour of the zoo grounds to see monsters from previous rock operas in their "natural habitat."
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Think Disney‚Äôs Jungle Cruise ride with a spooky twist, and put it right here in Baltimore. The Baltimore Rock Opera Society and Maryland Zoo are partnering on ‚ÄúMonster World: Zoo Quest,‚Äù a fundraiser that takes attendees through an interactive tour of the zoo grounds to see monsters from previous rock operas in their ‚Äúnatural habitat.‚Äù READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Guests will follow the scripted story both on foot and on the zoo‚Äôs tram, passing by monster puppets and costumed performers. Over at the Waterfowl Pavilion, there will be a Halloween party with drinks, carnival games, a costume contest, a photo booth and live music. BROS executive director Aran Keating said the outdoor event will allow the organization to hold a COVID-safe fundraiser and have something akin to its own theme park. ‚ÄúIndoor parties are great, but Monster World is going to be a huge evolution in terms of the type of events that BROS conducts,‚Äù Keating said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The event is scheduled for two nights, Oct. 28 and 29, from 5-10 p.m. Tickets are on sale now at  baltimorerockopera.org  and cost $60 for both the party and the tour. A VIP option with a swag bag and access to an exclusive party area is available for an additional $15. Guests who just want to attend the party can get tickets for $25. As for entertainment, punk group Cowabunga Pizza Time is scheduled to perform on Oct. 28 and indie group PLRLS is set to take the stage on Oct. 29. On both nights, funk group The Jonathan Gilmore Project will play, with DJ Landis Expandis spinning between sets. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: ‚ÄòI Get Scared To Go To School‚Äô: Uptick In Violence In Baltimore County Schools Has Students Fearful & Parents Concerned
summary: There's a major uptick in violence in Baltimore County Schools.
bodytext: TOWSON, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  There‚Äôs a major uptick in violence in Baltimore County Schools. ‚ÄúI get scared to go to school,‚Äù said Baltimore County School student, Ileana Nazario. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Videos from Dundalk High School are circulating online showing students fighting each other in the parking lot. ‚ÄúThey tackle each other to the ground. They fistfight and bleeding everywhere,‚Äù said Nazario. And students like Ileana Nazario say it‚Äôs happening across the county. ‚ÄúKids getting slammed into walls getting slammed into lockers. I just get sick and tired of it. It‚Äôs horrible, really horrible,‚Äù said Nazario. Wednesday, school leaders met with parents for a virtual town hall hoping to ease concerns over safety. ‚ÄúFighting among students is a problem that usually starts with unresolved conflicts. We know adults are key in helping students understand appropriate ways to deal with conflict,‚Äù said April Lewis, Executive Director of School Climate and Safety. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The superintendent says this problem goes far beyond the county as students return to the classroom after more than 18 months of virtual learning. ‚ÄúSchools across the country seeing an uptick in disruptive behaviors, stress the pandemic placed on children,‚Äù said Superintendent Darryl L. Williams. School officials say they have resources available for students like mental health counseling and social-emotional learning. They also have a comprehensive safety plan to prevent, respond to, and mitigate any violent behavior at every school campus. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only getting worse,‚Äù said former Baltimore County Public Schools employee, Hayden Borkowicz. But some people say right now, it‚Äôs not working. ‚ÄúThey just get all uptight and they start arguing back and forth and there‚Äôs no authority figure to say ‚Äòhey stop it knock it off‚Äô and there‚Äôs no consequences,‚Äù said Borowicz. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized When it comes to consequences, school officials say administrations handle these on a case-by-case basis and give the consequence they see fit including detention or suspension.

headline: Leak Of Military Secrets Could Cause ‚ÄòGrave Damage‚Äô To U.S., Defense Expert Warns
summary: Days after the arrests of an Annapolis couple accused of trying to sell military secrets to a foreign intelligence agency, a defense expert is weighing in on the significance of the data at the center of the case.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Days after the arrests of an Annapolis couple  accused of trying to sell military secrets to a foreign intelligence agency , a defense expert is weighing in on the significance of the data at the center of the case. Jonathan Toebbe, 42, a Navy nuclear engineer, and his wife, Diana, 45, are charged with conspiracy to communicate restricted data and communication of restricted data. Each of them could  face life in prison if convicted of those charges . READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The charges stem from what‚Äôs described in a federal complaint as a  plot to trade sensitive data on U.S. nuclear submarines to an unnamed foreign government  in exchange for cryptocurrency. David Luckey, a senior defense researcher for the RAND Corporation, told WJZ it‚Äôs critical that information like this doesn‚Äôt fall into the wrong hands because leaks can cause ‚Äúexceptionally grave damage‚Äù to the country. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want [to give] our adversaries, or potential adversaries, information on how to defeat our technologies,‚Äù Luckey said. ‚ÄúWe also don‚Äôt want our technologies to fall into the hands of our potential adversaries for them to defeat us.‚Äù According to charging documents, the plot began in April 2020 when Toebbe sent an unsolicited package containing sensitive data to a foreign intelligence agency. The package was later handed over to the FBI, which set up a sting operation using an undercover agent posing as a foreign intelligence officer. Over several months, Toebbe arranged to deliver batches of data to his contact by hiding memory cards inside ordinary objects ‚Äî a sandwich, a pack of gum, a bandage ‚Äî and dropping them off at several ocations in Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia, the documents state. The data involved included sensitive design and schematic information on the Navy‚Äôs Virginia-class, nuclear-powered attack submarines. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Federal surveillance teams monitoring the ‚Äúdead drop‚Äù locations saw Toebbe making the drop-offs, at times accompanied by his wife who appeared to be acting as a lookout for her husband, according to the complaint. Throughout the course of the sting, Toebbe was paid $100,000 in cryptocurrency, a fraction of the $5 million sum that court documents suggest he was seeking. The investigation culminated in the couple‚Äôs arrests Saturday in West Virginia. News of the Toebbes‚Äô arrests stunned those who live in the couple‚Äôs Annapolis neighborhood, which was swarming with federal agents over the weekend. ‚ÄúEverybody felt bad because we knew they had kids,‚Äù said neighbor Jennifer McCormick. ‚ÄúThat was everybody‚Äôs first concern.‚Äù Diana Toebbe, a teacher at the Key School, was suspended indefinitely from her job pending the outcome of the federal case. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The Toebbes are scheduled to appear in federal court on Friday for a detention hearing to determine whether they‚Äôll remain in custody while awaiting trial.

headline: Weekend Weather: Cool Down Incoming, Hello Fall!
summary: This cold front will be more than capable of completely shifting the airmass in place from a warm and moist one to a dry and chilly one.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  It might be hard to imagine with the low 80s we‚Äôre experiencing today but sweater weather is right around the corner! Before we can get to that dramatic temperature drop, we have a high of 84¬∞ on deck for Friday and then a warm and humid Saturday with highs near 80¬∞. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Saturday is when this cold front arrives so that does mean a good chance for showers and a few embedded thunderstorms during the second half of the day. As far as the severe threat, we‚Äôre expecting a marginal risk for severe storms. The primary threat will be wind gusts above 50 MPH. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall This system could bring a few isolated downpours but most of us will pick up less than half an inch of rain. This cold front will be more than capable of completely shifting the airmass in place from a warm and moist one to a dry and chilly one. Highs on Sunday will only be in the mid-60s! Factor in a gusty north wind and the warmest it will actually feel is around 63¬∞! That‚Äôs a 20¬∞ drop from how it will feel the day before. Hello fall! MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized A large zone of high pressure will hold firm for most of the following work week, keeping things mostly to partly sunny and seasonably cool. Highs will range from the mid-60s into the low 70s.

headline: Report: Stewart Bainum Jr. Plans To Launch ‚ÄòThe Baltimore Banner,‚Äô An All-Digital News Outlet
summary: Stewart W. Bainum Jr., the hotel magnate who launched a failed bid to acquire The Sun and the rest of the newspapers owned by Tribune Publishing, plans to open a new nonprofit, all-digital publication called The Baltimore Banner, according to a new report in The Atlantic.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Stewart W. Bainum Jr., the hotel magnate who launched a failed bid to acquire  The Sun  and the rest of the newspapers owned by Tribune Publishing, plans to open a new nonprofit, all-digital publication called  The Baltimore Banner , according to  a new report in  The Atlantic . Bainum, chairman of Choice Hotels International, told the magazine the organization will start with an annual operating budget of $15 million and a staff of 50 journalists. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School In preparation for the launch, Bainum met with local news start-ups around the country to learn best practices and came away thinking all of them needed more funding to bulk up operations. ‚ÄúYou need real capital to move the needle,‚Äù he told the magazine. If his plan to start a new outlet in Baltimore proves successful, he hopes it can be replicated in other markets where local newspapers have suffered years of staff cuts. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no industry that I can think of more integral to a working democracy than the local-news business,‚Äù he said. Faced with the prospect of being acquired by Alden Global Capital, a hedge fund dubbed ‚Äú the grim reaper of American newspapers ‚Äù by  Vanity Fair , a group of  Baltimore Sun  journalists in 2020 launched the Save Our Sun campaign and lobbied for local ownership to turn the newspaper into a nonprofit. Other Tribune papers soon followed suit. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Bainum came forward as an interested buyer of  The Sun , and  reportedly reached a deal  to purchase the newspaper for $65 million once Alden Global Capital acquired Tribune Publishing. But Alden added a licensing deal that would have added millions to the price, according to the  Atlantic  article, so Bainum tried to line up other backers to put in a bid for Tribune Publishing as a whole. Tribune shareholders approved Alden Global Capital‚Äôs bid last May, not long after Swiss billionaire Hansj√∂rg Wyss  reportedly dropped  his support for the rival bid. Bainum reached out to one of Alden Global Capital‚Äôs co-founders, Heath Freeman, after the purchase was completed to inquire about buying  The Sun  separately but never got a response, according to the  Atlantic  article. In the story, Freeman defended Alden‚Äôs cost-cutting practices. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúPrior to the acquisition of the Tribune Company, we purchased substantially all of our newspapers out of bankruptcy or close to liquidation,‚Äù he told the magazine. ‚ÄúThese papers were in many cases left for dead by local families not willing to make the tough but appropriate decisions to get these news organizations to sustainability. These papers would have been liquidated if not for us stepping up.‚Äù

headline: Maryland Man Charged With Assault & Kidnapping Of University Of Delaware Student
summary: A Maryland man has been charged with assault and kidnapping after Newark Police say he attacked a female student at an off-campus apartment near the University of Delaware.
bodytext: NEWARK, Del. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Maryland man has been charged with assault and kidnapping after Newark Police say he attacked a female student at an off-campus apartment near the University of Delaware. Brandon Freyre, 20, is also a student at the school. He has been charged with assault, kidnapping and strangulation. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Officials said the incident occurred on Oct. 8. Charging documents state that the suspect was jealous that the victim, who is also his ex-girlfriend, attended a fraternity party on campus the night before. Freyre is a member of a different organization. Authorities said they two began arguing before the victim assaulted her and eventually choking her unconscious. He spray-painted her eyes and held her captive for four hours. Freyre also threatened to kill her so ‚Äúshe wouldn‚Äôt be able to call the police and ruin his life.‚Äù The victim was able to escape after being thrown down a flight of stairs without shoes, her wallet, keys, or phone. She walked back to her apartment and immediately called the police. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall According to  CBS Philly , the suspect has been suspended and banned from the University of Delaware. He faces expulsion if convicted on the charges. The university says Freyre was a member of the Kappa Delta Rho fraternity but has since had his membership revoked. Freyre was released on bail Wednesday. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Surveillance Video Shows Drive-By Shooting That Wounded 12-Year-Old Maryland Girl
summary: Police released surveillance footage Thursday in hopes the public can help identify a suspect who shot a 12-year-old girl in Capitol Heights last week.
bodytext: CAPITOL HEIGHTS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police released surveillance footage Thursday in hopes the public can help identify a suspect who shot a 12-year-old girl in Capitol Heights last week. The drive-by shooting happened about 6:35 p.m. Friday in the 5200 block of Marlboro Pike, injuring a girl who was waiting for food inside a nearby restaurant, according to Prince George‚Äôs County Police. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Police said the 12-year-old victim, who is not believed to be the shooter‚Äôs intended target, was rushed to an area hospital where she‚Äôs listed in critical condition.   Please take a moment to view this video. Our detectives are looking to identify the vehicle (possibly an Infiniti) and suspect(s) who shot and critically injured a 12-year-old Friday. A  @PGCrimeSolvers  CA$H reward is being offered in this case. Read more:  https://t.co/XHUIdwRQJz   pic.twitter.com/PAs3GvRBZL   ‚Äî PGPDNEWS (@PGPDNews)  October 14, 2021 The 41-second clip shows someone wearing a blue hooded sweatshirt standing out of the sunroof of a dark-colored sedan, opening fire toward businesses in a strip mall. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The shooter‚Äôs vehicle, described as possibly an Infiniti with tinted windows and chrome trim, was last seen heading toward Brooks Drive, police said. Police are offering a reward of up to $2,500 for credible tips that lead to an arrest in the case. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Anyone with information is asked to call detectives at 301-516-200. Those who wish to remain anonymous can call Crime Solvers at 1-866-411-TIPS (8477).

headline: Jackson‚Äôs Passing Has Rejuvenated Ravens‚Äô Offense
summary: The quarterback who has faced questions about his passing ability finished 37 of 43 in that department, leading Baltimore to a victory on a night when its running game wasn't up to its usual standard.
bodytext: OWINGS MILLS, Md. (AP) ‚Äî  Colts owner Jim Irsay was so impressed with Lamar Jackson that¬† he took to Twitter ¬†the next day ‚Äî and said the Baltimore quarterback‚Äôs performance against Indianapolis might have been the best in NFL history. And Irsay, as he explained in his tweet, was at Wrigley Field the day Gale Sayers scored six touchdowns. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The superlatives keep rolling in for Jackson, who threw for 442 yards and four touchdowns in¬† a 31-25 overtime win ¬†over Indianapolis on Monday night. It wasn‚Äôt quite a perfect night for Jackson, who fumbled near the goal line, but after that turnover the Ravens scored touchdowns on their final four possessions. The quarterback who has faced questions about his passing ability finished 37 of 43 in that department, leading Baltimore to a victory on a night when its running game wasn‚Äôt up to its usual standard. ‚ÄúMan, it‚Äôs special. He‚Äôs just scratching the surface on how good he can be,‚Äù Ravens defensive lineman Calais Campbell said. ‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs still 24 years old. I mean, this is crazy ‚Äî what he‚Äôs capable of doing. I know he‚Äôs notorious for what he can do with his legs, and I feel like he got a lot of disrespect on his arm talent, and I think a lot of people are eating their words right now.‚Äù Jackson won MVP honors two seasons ago, and it‚Äôs been clear for a while that his blend of passing and running can be really difficult to defend. In truth, he‚Äôs been pretty efficient throwing the ball throughout his career, completing 64.5% of his passes with 76 touchdowns and 21 interceptions. Still, it was fair to point out that Jackson hasn‚Äôt attempted more than 401 passes in a season ‚Äî in a league where top quarterbacks routinely surpass 500. If you added Jackson‚Äôs passing and rushing yardage, he accounted for 4,333 yards in his MVP season but just 3,762 last season. The Ravens finished first in the NFL in rushing and last in passing in 2020 ‚Äî and that added up to a No. 19 ranking in total offense. This season the Ravens are No. 1 in total offense. Jackson‚Äôs passing and rushing adds up to 1,860 yards ‚Äî also the best mark in the league. That should make any remaining critics of Jackson‚Äôs passing ability a little quieter. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if they‚Äôre going to stop talking about it. I don‚Äôt really know,‚Äù Jackson said. ‚ÄúAll I know is my focus is on winning.‚Äù Whether by design or necessity ‚Äî Baltimore‚Äôs top two running backs went down with season-ending injuries ‚Äî Jackson is throwing more, and he‚Äôs handling it impressively. He‚Äôs averaging 33 pass attempts per game, up from 25 last season. ‚ÄúLook at the last couple of games, he‚Äôs just calm, composed, and he‚Äôs a leader, man,‚Äù tight end Mark Andrews said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what we all look to. There were mistakes. There were a couple mistakes that were made, but he just keeps on coming.‚Äù Jackson is also doing this without all the targets he was expecting to play with. Rookie receiver Rashod Bateman hasn‚Äôt played yet because of groin problems, and newcomer Sammy Watkins left Monday‚Äôs game with a hamstring injury. Jackson ended up targeting Andrews and Marquise Brown a combined 23 times against the Colts. They caught 20 passes for 272 yards and all four Baltimore touchdowns. Jackson‚Äôs big game came on a night when the Ravens had their streak of 43 consecutive 100-yard rushing games snapped. After sputtering through the first half, Baltimore unleashed Jackson in the second. He threw for 335 yards after halftime. ‚ÄúHe definitely went to another level in that game. That level was pretty impressive I would say, and it was awesome to watch,‚Äù coach John Harbaugh said. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm not surprised.‚Äù This coming week, Jackson faces Justin Herbert and the Los Angeles Chargers in a matchup of division leaders. It‚Äôs now clear that the Chargers ‚Äî and the rest of Baltimore‚Äôs opponents ‚Äî need to respect the Ravens‚Äô previously maligned passing game. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been believing in myself. The Ravens‚Äô organization has been believing in me,‚Äù Jackson said. ‚ÄúI really haven‚Äôt seen my peak yet. It‚Äôs still early in the season.‚Äù

bodytext: PIKESVILLE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî ¬† Pikesville Middle School is dismissing class at 10 a.m. Thursday for a gas leak, Baltimore County Schools announced.   The gas leak was found by the Baltimore County Fire Department in a kitchen. Afternoon activities are also canceled.
