headline: Winter Heating Bills Poised To Spike As Inflation Hits Home
summary: With prices surging worldwide for heating oil, natural gas and other fuels, the U.S. government said Wednesday it expects households to see their heating bills jump as much as 54% compared to last winter.
bodytext: NEW YORK (AP) ‚Äî  Get ready to pay sharply higher bills for heating this winter, along with seemingly everything else. With prices surging worldwide for heating oil, natural gas and other fuels, the U.S. government said Wednesday it expects households to see their heating bills jump as much as 54% compared to last winter. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Nearly half the homes in the U.S. use natural gas for heat, and they could pay an average $746 this winter, 30% more than a year ago. Those in the Midwest could get particularly pinched, with bills up an estimated 49%, and this could be the most expensive winter for natural-gas heated homes since 2008-2009. The second-most used heating source for homes is electricity, making up 41% of the country, and those households could see a more modest 6% increase to $1,268. Homes using heating oil, which make up 4% of the country, could see a 43% increase ‚Äî more than $500 ‚Äî to $1,734. The sharpest increases are likely for homes that use propane, which account for 5% of U.S. households. This winter is forecast to be slightly colder across the country than last year. That means people will likely be burning more fuel to keep warm, on top of paying more for each bit of it. If the winter ends up being even colder than forecast, heating bills could be higher than estimated, and vice-versa. The forecast from the U.S. Energy Information Administration is the latest reminder of the higher inflation ripping across the global economy. Earlier Wednesday, the government released a separate report showing that prices were 5.4% higher for U.S. consumers in September than a year ago. That matches the hottest inflation rate since 2008, as a reawakening economy and snarled supply chains push up prices for everything from cars to groceries. The higher prices hit everyone, with pay raises for most workers so far failing to keep up with inflation. But they hurt low-income households in particular. ‚ÄúAfter the beating that people have taken in the pandemic, it‚Äôs like: What‚Äôs next?‚Äù said Carol Hardison, chief executive officer at Crisis Assistance Ministry, which helps people in Charlotte, North Carolina, who are facing financial hardship. She said households coming in for assistance recently have had unpaid bills that are roughly twice as big as they were before the pandemic. They‚Äôre contending with more expensive housing, higher medical bills and sometimes a reduction in their hours worked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what we know about this pandemic: It‚Äôs hit the same people that were already struggling with wages not keeping up with the cost of living,‚Äù she said. To make ends meet, families are cutting deeply. Nearly 22% of Americans had to reduce or forego expenses for basic necessities, such as medicine or food, to pay an energy bill in at least one of the last 12 months, according to a September survey by the U.S. Census Bureau. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúThis is going to create significant hardship for people in the bottom third of the country,‚Äù said Mark Wolfe, executive director of the National Energy Assistance Directors‚Äô Association. ‚ÄúYou can tell them to cut back and try to turn down the heat at night, but many low-income families already do that. Energy was already unaffordable to them.‚Äù Many of those families are just now getting through a hot summer where they faced high air-conditioning bills. Congress apportions some money to energy assistance programs for low-income households, but directors of those programs are now watching their purchasing power shrink as fuel costs keep climbing, Wolfe said. The biggest reason for this winter‚Äôs higher heating bills is the recent surge in prices for energy commodities after they dropped to multi-year lows in 2020. Demand has simply grown faster than production as the economy roars back to life following shutdowns caused by the coronavirus. Natural gas in the United States, for example, has climbed to its highest price since 2014 and is up roughly 90% over the last year. The wholesale price of heating oil, meanwhile, has more than doubled in the last 12 months. Another reason for the rise is how global the market for fuels has become. In Europe, strong demand and limited supplies have sent natural gas prices up more than 350% this year. That‚Äôs pushing some of the natural gas produced in the United States to head for ships bound for other countries, adding upward pressure on domestic prices as well. The amount of natural gas in storage inventories is relatively low, according to Barclays analyst Amarpreet Singh. That means there‚Äôs less of a cushion heading into winter heating season. Heating oil prices, meanwhile, are tied closely to the price of crude oil, which has climbed more than 60% this year. Homes affected by those increases are primarily in the Northeast, where the percentage of homes using heating oil has dropped to 18% from 27% over the past decade. ___ AP Writer David Sharp contributed from Portland, Maine. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized (¬©¬† Copyright ¬†2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: University System of Maryland Appoints Search Committee For New UMBC President
summary: Jay A. Perman, chancellor of the University System of Maryland, on Thursday appointed a search committee to select a new president of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Jay A. Perman, chancellor of the University System of Maryland, on Thursday appointed a search committee to select a new president of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Dr. Freeman Hrabowski, who served as president of UMBC for three decades and helped turn the university into a nationally renowned institution,  announced his retirement  in August. His final day in office is June 30, 2022. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Perman‚Äôs committee was approved the University System of Maryland Board of Regents, with Regent Michelle Gourdine serving as chair. In a release, the system said it is looking for a successor who will continue Hrabowski‚Äôs commitment to affordability, diversity, research and community service. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúWe know UMBC was transformed under Dr. Hrabowski, establishing itself as a leader in teaching, research, and equity‚Äîin student achievement and community engagement,‚Äù Perman said. ‚ÄúSo we know we need a president who can harness the scholarly firepower of UMBC‚Äôs people, who can harness untapped potential, to keep that national‚Äîand international‚Äîprominence rising.‚Äù The committee includes UMBC student leaders, school faculty and administrators. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The committee will work with recruiting firm Isaacson, Miller and eventually submit finalists to the chancellor and the Board of Regents for consideration.

headline: Jairus ‚ÄúJD‚Äù Robinson Shares Why He Kept Giving Shan His Extra ‚ÄòSurvivor‚Äô Vote: ‚ÄòMy Only Play Was To Suck Up To The People In Power‚Äô
summary: Jairus "JD" Robinson discusses his time on 'Survivor 41.'
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì  The monster that is  Survivor 41  claimed another victim last night as Jairus ‚ÄúJD‚Äù Robinson was sent home after another tribal council blindside. CBS‚Äô Matt Weiss spoke with JD about his time on the island, getting to go on reward and his sudden blindside at tribal council. READ MORE:  Survivor‚Äôs Brad Reese Says He Could Have ‚ÄòOutran That Monster‚Äô With A Few More Power Ups MW-  JD, excited to talk to you today man, hope all‚Äôs going well. We‚Äôll get into everything that went down during your time in the game but before that, as a fan of  Survivor , take me back to that moment when you first stepped foot on the island. JR-  Yeah, so as soon as I hit the big boat, your heart is pounding. It‚Äôs so real and I‚Äôm like ‚Äòoh my gosh, like, this is what I dreamed of.‚Äô Like Adam said this is what dreams are made of. I‚Äôm standing here and then getting to touch the sand and to see our tribe flag, everything was so cool. I was just so happy to be there. MW-  That‚Äôs awesome. Now once the game begins your tribe just starts getting picked off one by one. There‚Äôs always a healthy amount of paranoia that you need to play  Survivor  but as you see more and more of your tribe leaving what‚Äôs going through your head? JR-  Well, I saw most of my tribe leaving but I was also a target who could have gone home. So in that way it was really scary. Like yes, my tribe was getting picked off, but all these people getting picked off were voting for me to go home. It was terrifying, you know. MW-  So how did that change the way you went about playing the game? JR-  I saw that we were losing and that people were going home. I knew that I wanted to flip the game but I was in the bottom rung of the whole tribe with Shan and Ricard. There are so many times that I wanted to flip the game on its head. I wanted to work with Brad and Genie and I wanted to vote out Ricard. But Brad wanted to vote out me for some reason, even though I saved him at tribal council. They wanted to work with the people who want to vote Brad out and to this day I don‚Äôt understand it. I wanted to put myself in a position of power. The problem was I didn‚Äôt have people who wanted to do it with me. My only play was to suck up to the people in power and try to get in good with them so that they‚Äôll take me with them. That‚Äôs why I gave Shan my extra vote and not Ricard. That‚Äôs why I gained Shan my extra vote again because I‚Äôm trying to find a space. There were no other options I only had two votes and so, yeah, there was really nothing else I could do. MW-  It seemed like the tension was really building for Ua but then when you all got reward it seemed like things started to ease up a little bit. I know the game ended quicker than you would have liked but you did get to go on a reward and have that experience at least. What was that like? JR-  Reward was awesome, shout out to Nathan he was my bro! He taught me so much stuff out there. There‚Äôs so many different types of coconuts and he‚Äôs trying to teach me climbing techniques. I was always climbing trees trying to get coconuts. He‚Äôs an amazing man, like the dude is not human. He swims like a fish, he climbs like a spider, he could just crack a coconut in half like it‚Äôs nothing. He‚Äôs awesome. READ MORE:  Sara Wilson Reacts To ‚ÄòWorst Case Scenario‚Äô After Early Survivor Elimination: ‚ÄòGiven Me So Much Fire On The Inside‚Äô MW-  The reward challenge went great for you, immunity did not. What went wrong for Ua? JR-  You know, I think a lot of people will blame me for the fact that we didn‚Äôt win that immunity challenge but I was the only one who landed it! I don‚Äôt know why they didn‚Äôt show that we switched but we switched other people in. The only thing I‚Äôd change is maybe saying money and actually making it. That‚Äôs the only thing I‚Äôd change. MW-  I feel bad bringing this up, but was there any extra salt in the wound afterwards knowing that Deshawn and Danny were trying to lose? JR-  That hurts so bad. I was like I landed two rings, like that wasn‚Äôt that bad, right? Then it‚Äôs like dude is re-tying knots and both Ua and Yase are not even close to done. They were throwing the challenge and we weren‚Äôt even close. That just goes to show how much of a beast Naseer. He was basically going against Deshawn and Danny and still won. MW-  Now at tribal council, obviously you got blindsided. As you said you were trying to build trust with Shan so you have up your extra vote. Walk me through everything that unfolded there. JR-  As tribal council unfolds I couldn‚Äôt make it live and try to make a move because I didn‚Äôt have my extra vote. That was a mistake that I already made and I was like, dang. So the best thing that I can do at tribal council is show them that Genie is not with them and that I am just in case they haven‚Äôt made up their minds. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm said Genie don‚Äôt play your shot in the dark and then I wink at Ricard and Shan to say I‚Äôm with you guys, she‚Äôs not, she doesn‚Äôt even believe you right now. That‚Äôs what I was trying to do at tribal and it didn‚Äôt work but I went for it, made a bad move. MW-  That‚Äôs what  Survivor  is all about, taking your shot. Although it didn‚Äôt work for you this time, would you take another shot down the road at  Survivor ? JR-  110,000,000%, I would do anything to be back out there. The biggest thing for me going back out there is that in pregame a lot of people were high on me. People were saying how this dude did Toastmasters and he‚Äôs athletic and he talks to all these different people and he works with kids; everyone thought I would do well. I feel like I didn‚Äôt show what kind of player I can really be. So I would love to go back and I just want to prove to them that it‚Äôs in me. I promise it‚Äôs in me to be that great survivor player. I couldn‚Äôt execute, I fumbled a lot but now I know a little more about the game and how it‚Äôs actually truly played. That‚Äôs my biggest thing I want to go back so bad. MW-  Hopefully we see you with that second chance but for now congrats on getting on the show at least and thank you for the time today JD! JR-  Thanks bro! MORE NEWS:  David Voce Compares ‚ÄòSurvivor‚Äô Adventure To A Drug: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs Going To Rock You To Your Core‚Äô Tune in for new episodes of  Survivor 41 , Wednesdays at 8:00PM ET/PT on CBS or available to stream with  Paramount+ . Check your local listings for more information.

headline: Young Siblings Make $35K Monthly By Mining Cryptocurrency. Here‚Äôs How They Do It
summary: Ishaan Thakur, 14, and his sister Aanya, 9, are making more than $35,000 a month mining mainly for the cryptocurrency, Ethereum.
bodytext: FRISCO, Texas (CBSDFW.COM)  ‚Äì Ishaan Thakur, 14, and his sister Aanya, 9, make it sound easy.¬†Eight months ago, the Texas siblings converted their gaming computer into a cryptocurrency mining machine.   ‚ÄúI went online, watched a couple YouTube tutorials, and I just learned it,‚Äù Ishaan explained to KTVT-TV in Dallas. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs possible for anyone to do it if they put their mind to it.‚Äù   Ishaan Thakur (CBS 11)   On their first day of mining, the siblings made $3.¬†Now they are making more than  $35,000 a month  mining mainly for the cryptocurrency, Ethereum.   ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt know much about it at first,‚Äù said Aanya. ‚ÄúBut our dad told us stories about how much the prices were going up so we wanted to find out about it. That‚Äôs how we got started.‚Äù   Aanya Thakur (CBS 11)   The way mining works is whenever someone buys or sells cryptocurrency a new unique digital coin needs to be made to ensure security. To do that, computers around the world race to solve a complex math problem. The computer that does it first wins and produces the new coin. That computer is then rewarded with cryptocurrency for themselves.   The odds of any one computer winning are slim, so the key is to have lots of computer servers.¬†With the help of a loan from their father, the Thakur siblings have invested tens of thousands of dollars into their operation.¬†This included buying 145 graphic cards ‚Äì each costing more than $3000.   Most their operation is also no longer in their garage. Instead, the majority of their computer rigs are now located at a secure climate-controlled data center in Dallas.   Mining computers create heat and potential home hazard   To be successful mining for cryptocurrency, you need several high-powered computers running 24 hours a day.¬†These computers get hot ‚Äì sometimes too hot.   Last year, Fort Worth firefighters responded to a house fire on Bamberg Lane on the north side of the city.¬†No one was home at the time as the fire gutted most of the two-story home.¬†When searching through the charred debris in the garage, fire investigators noted finding boxes of graphic cards, the type often used to mine for cryptocurrency.   According to the investigation report, investigators concluded the electrical fire started from a computer server rack in the garage. The renter told firefighters the server rack ‚Äúmined for cryptocurrency.‚Äù   At-home Bitcoin miners struggle to compete with professional operations   When mining for cryptocurrency, at-home miners often must compete against large well-funded mining operations.¬†This is why many at-home miners don‚Äôt mine for Bitcoin and instead mine for less valuable cryptocurrencies, such as Ethereum.   The Whinstone facility in Rockdale, Texas is the largest Bitcoin mining operation in North America. The 100-acre facility has more than 115,000 computer servers mining for Bitcoin. Whinstone goes to great lengths to keep their servers from over-heating.   RELATED:  Will The Texas Electric Grid Be Able To Handle State‚Äôs Bitcoin Mining Rush?   The company built a high-tech cooling system in their buildings that sends cold water running through the outside walls, while heat generated from the computers is sucked out through ceiling vents.¬†‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs what a lot of people don‚Äôt realize is the amount of investment that goes into buildings like this,‚Äù said Whinstone CEO Chard Harris.   Whinstone in Rockdale, Texas (CBS 11)   Without major equipment investment, most at-home miners usually make small profits   Because it is hard to compete against the large cryptocurrency miners without major investment, most at-home miners experience to similar to Noah Jost‚Äôs.   When the 10-year-old Bedford student is not playing Fortnight on his computer, he switches his computer over to mine for Ethereum.   Noah Jost (CBS 11)   In the past year, Noah has learned a lot about the cryptocurrency market along with a lesson on striking it rich.¬†‚ÄúI‚Äôve made about $230 total in eight months,‚Äù he said.   Noah said he plans to save his earnings to buy a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù computer so he can ‚Äúearn more money mining.‚Äù

headline: ‚ÄòSurvivor 41‚Äô Episode 4 Recap: A Blindside Strikes!
summary: Survivor¬†is back with another suspenseful episode! A castaway didn't just get voted out¬†‚Äì¬†they got completely blindsided! Who was it? Well, here's how it all went down...
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì  Survivor ¬†is back with another suspenseful episode! A castaway didn‚Äôt just get voted out¬†‚Äì¬†they got completely blindsided! Who was it? Well, here‚Äôs how it all went down‚Ä¶   Photo Courtesy of CBS   READ MORE:  ‚ÄòSurvivor 41‚Äô Episode 3 Recap: Advantages Galore Reward Challenge  The first Reward Challenge of the season was a tough one! Four members of each tribe had to compete in a series of obstacles to win an epic day with a native Fijian. The winning tribe would learn the ins and outs of living off the land in Fiji ‚Äì a crucial reward to win in this game! The second tribe would also win a reward, not quite a day with a native Fijian ‚Äì¬†but a big ol‚Äô fish instead. Still good, just not as epic. The challenge itself involved each tribe racing through a series of physically draining obstacles. So draining, in fact, one tribe member, in particular, couldn‚Äôt even finish the first leg of the course. Heather on the Luvu tribe couldn‚Äôt complete her task early on in this challenge. Even though she was struggling, she didn‚Äôt give up ‚Äì and that itself was impressive. Her tribe thought the same and immediately rooted her on even though she eventually let the tribe down. This resulted in the Ua tribe winning the main reward, followed by the Yase tribe winning the fish dinner.   This is what real sportsmanship looks like. ü•∫  #Survivor   pic.twitter.com/NfDRNYpTsu   ‚Äî SURVIVOR (@survivorcbs)  October 14, 2021 Ua Tribe  Before the Reward Challenge, Genie came back from the last Tribal Council completely shocked that her closest ally, Brad, was voted out. She was pissed. Genie then tells her tribe how she feels betrayed. While sharing how she feels like ‚Äúthe mom‚Äù of the tribe and has constantly fed them all, she finally says she‚Äôs ‚Äúdone‚Äù with preparing and providing their food‚Ä¶ But then, the reward came. The Fijian, Nathan, who visited their camp, gave them all sorts of necessary survival skills to live off the land of Fiji. Watching this guy on TV was nuts¬†‚Äì climbing trees like Spiderman, and showing how he‚Äôs clearly an expert at his craft. All this knowledge the tribe gained got Ricard thinking‚Ä¶ maybe they don‚Äôt need Genie taking care of them after all?   Photo Courtesy of CBS   Yase Tribe  The Yase tribe is on a roll with winning! After starting the season on an embarrassing losing streak, the solid four are proving they have what it takes to get far. After reflecting on how they‚Äôve struggled, they realize there‚Äôs now, literally and metaphorically, a reward after it all. While enjoying their big fish, they even see their metaphor in the flesh.   Gotta love an animal metaphor. Yase = Sea Turtles. üê¢üí™üèΩ  #Survivor   pic.twitter.com/NzjjysQSCK   ‚Äî SURVIVOR (@survivorcbs)  October 14, 2021 The tribe compared themselves to the tiny baby sea turtles they saw pushing through the sand at their camp. I mean, it couldn‚Äôt possibly be¬† Survivor ¬†without a few metaphors, can it?! Luvu Tribe  Meanwhile, the Luvu tribe is unbeatable. This tribe still has yet to go to Tribal Council! After being six castaways strong, now at Day 8, things are finally beginning to crack‚Ä¶ Erika, who we don‚Äôt even know yet this season, gets some much-needed screentime. She explains her approach to the game and even says she‚Äôs a ‚Äúlion dressed as a lamb.‚Äù She‚Äôs ready to pounce and get this game started. Her first prey is Sydney. Erika wants to get her out because she thinks she is emotionally unstable, which could potentially cause trouble later in the game. Erika shares this plan with her closest ally, Deshawn. Now, as Deshawn‚Äôs listening to this master plan of hers, he starts to get a little apprehensive about Erika herself. He even calls her ‚Äúsus.‚Äù He thinks she‚Äôs playing hard ‚Äì because she is. He‚Äôs nervous about her sneakiness, and he now wants to cut the ‚Äúhead off the snake‚Äù (or should I say lion?) and get her out next instead. While trying to come up with a plan to vote Erika out, Deshawn approaches Danny with a scenario we‚Äôve all seen before in the game of¬† Survivor¬† ‚Äì throwing the Immunity Challenge. Yep. Deshawn is ready to throw it. He proposes to Danny how purposely losing could work in their favor because Erika is too sneaky and needs to be gone asap. Being an ex-NFL player, Danny feels like¬†this is all against his values of athleticism, but he decides to entertain the idea and get on with throwing this next Immunity Challenge anyway. READ MORE:  Survivor‚Äôs Brad Reese Says He Could Have ‚ÄòOutran That Monster‚Äô With A Few More Power Ups Immunity Challenge  Immunity is up for grabs! The first two tribes who finish their exhausting water-based obstacles win Immunity and are safe from Tribal Council. The three tribes began in the ocean and had to make their way to shore while untying bags of logs on the way. As always, these challenges are tough. But, let‚Äôs not forget how Deshawn and Danny want to milk every exhausting moment, as they‚Äôre trying to lose on purpose. While the rest of Luvu was pushing hard through the water, Deshawn was taking his sweet time. Meanwhile, as they compete against the Ua and Yase tribe, they notice that Yase is still slower than them! It was pretty comical. Deshawn narrated this Immunity Challenge explaining how he took every moment he could to throw it, yet the Yase tribe was still falling behind. It wasn‚Äôt until the last leg of the challenge where each tribe was even with one another (yes, Yase finally caught up). To finish this challenge, each tribe had to toss three rings onto their pegs. While Deshawn was terribly throwing his rings while (terribly) throwing the challenge, it was Naseer who stepped in. Naseer simply didn‚Äôt want to see his tribe lose for the first time. And, in the end, it didn‚Äôt matter that Deshawn and Danny were moving slow. That‚Äôs because Naseer won it for them! After the Yase tribe made a sweet victory of coming in first, (surprisingly?!) it was between Luvu and Ua for second place. JD on the Ua tribe failed to complete the last obstacle and lost it for his tribe.   Photo Courtesy of CBS   Tribal Council  With only four people left on the Ua tribe, at this point, Genie is certain she‚Äôs the next one to go. She even teases the fact that she‚Äôs ready to give the new¬† Survivor ¬†‚Äúshot in the dark‚Äù twist a-go. The shot in the dark would allow her to risk her vote but have a one-in-four shot at gaining Immunity at Tribal Council. The question for her was, does she want to risk losing her vote? Meanwhile, Shan is still running the show on this tribe. She‚Äôs playing her cards well. Ricard, her closest ally, has proven he will vote with her as long as he‚Äôs in this game. JD, though, has been questionable. Last week, he kept a vital secret from her as she eventually caught him in the lie. JD kept his ‚Äúsecret vote‚Äù advantage from her and Ricard, which has left her skeptical about him since. Now JD knows their trust in him is somewhat broken. Even though he‚Äôs teasing Genie that he‚Äôd work with her, JD knows he owes both Shan and Ricard his loyalty. So much so, Shan feels like this is the perfect opportunity to manipulate him. She knows how to play this game ‚Äì and to be quite frank,¬† Survivo r is all about backstabbing and being manipulative to get ahead. And, it was just that. Shan put on an act to JD. She acts ‚Äúparanoid‚Äù and tells JD she‚Äôs afraid he will vote against her. JD, who‚Äôs young, and I suppose, a bit naive in this case, then solidifies his trust (once again) and gives her his extra-vote advantage to hold! He did this once, and now he does it again! But this time, his risk did not pay off. JD was completely blindsided as Genie, as well as both Shan and Ricard, voted him out. And now, Shan is sitting with his advantage in her pocket!   Photo Courtesy of CBS   Wow. Even though we didn‚Äôt see too many game-changing twists in this episode, this week was just as wild, with an even wilder and unexpected Tribal Council! What‚Äôd you think of this week‚Äôs episode? Personally, I‚Äôm happy Genie is still in this game ‚Äì she‚Äôs pretty cool, plus, she‚Äôs my castaway in my family‚Äôs¬† Survivor ¬†pool!  Tweet me¬† @mick_cloudy , and let‚Äôs talk¬† Survivor! MORE NEWS:  Jairus "JD" Robinson Shares Why He Kept Giving Shan His Extra 'Survivor' Vote: 'My Only Play Was To Suck Up To The People In Power' Don‚Äôt miss¬† Survivor 41 , Wednesdays at 8/7c on CBS, as well as streaming live and on-demand with¬† Paramount+ ¬†or the CBS App!

headline: ‚ÄòJust A Wonderful Young Man‚Äô: Loved Ones Remember Mervo High School Senior Elijah Gorham
summary: A "phenomenal young man" is how Mergenthaler Vocational-Technical high school senior, Elijah Gorham is being described.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A ‚Äúphenomenal young man‚Äù is how Mergenthaler Vocational-Technical high school senior Elijah Gorham is being described. Gorham, a 17-year-old student-athlete who played wide receiver for the Mustangs, died earlier this week. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Head football coach and athletic director, Patrick Nixon, said Elijah Gorham was a silent leader on the Mervo football team and was a silent leader who was a steady presence for his teammates and even the adults. RELATED:  Vigil Planned For Mervo High School‚Äôs Elijah Gorham ‚ÄúJust a wonderful young man. So caring, so giving, so genuine, can‚Äôt say enough positive things about him,‚Äù said Coach Nixon. ‚ÄúElijah would be one somebody to pick my day up. Elijah would always run up to me and say ‚Äòhey coach, how‚Äôs your day?‚Äô and offer a hug.‚Äù Gorham suffered a brain injury during a game Sept. 18,  according to his GoFundMe page.  He had been in the hospital since that injury until word came out Monday that he passed away. His mother, Shantres Shaw, spoke with WJZ over the phone Tuesday. ‚ÄúHe was amazing, he loved the game, he loved to play football, he was a team player, a loyal team player, it was a brotherhood to him,‚Äù Shaw said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The Mervo football program lamented the teen‚Äôs passing with a tweet Monday. ‚ÄúOur hearts are heavy today as we mourn the passing of our fellow brother, and teammate Elijah Gorham,‚Äù the tweet said.   Our hearts are heavy today as we mourn the passing of our fellow brother, and teammate Elijah Gorham.   We ask that our football community continue to uplift Elijah‚Äôs family, teammates and friends in prayer.  #„ÄΩÔ∏èustang‚ìñang #„ÄΩÔ∏èervoprideüêé #7strong #LLEG   ‚Äî Mervo H.S. Football (@MustangGang410)  October 11, 2021 ‚ÄúHe was a young man full of promise with an infectious spirit. Elijah‚Äôs passing is an unspeakable tragedy,‚Äù added Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott, a Mervo alum.   Elijah Gorham was more than a  @HighMervo  student athlete. He was a young man full of promise with an infectious spirit. Elijah‚Äôs passing is an unspeakable tragedy. My heart goes out to his family and our  @MustangGang410  community.  #7strong   #mustangpride  üíôüíõ  https://t.co/g3YUQvzMyA   pic.twitter.com/ZrV6ojAuNW   ‚Äî Brandon M. Scott (@MayorBMScott)  October 11, 2021 Thursday‚Äôs football game may be postponed as the team remembers a young man whose light will continue to glow. ‚ÄúHe means a lot, there was no player on the team that didn‚Äôt know and love and respect him,‚Äù said Coach Nixon. Coach Nixon said  there will be a vigil on the football field Thursday at 7 p.m. in Elijah‚Äôs honor . MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The GoFundMe, meanwhile, has been organized to establish a scholarship in Gorham‚Äôs memory. To donate or learn more,  click here.

headline: Butterball Recalls Ground Turkey Products For Possible Plastic Contamination
summary: If you have the recalled product, toss the turkey or return it to the place of purchase.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Butterball, LLC is recalling just over 14,000 pounds of ground turkey products that may be contaminated with blue plastic, the U.S. Department of Agriculture‚Äôs Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) announced Thursday. The FSIS said these products produced on September 28 are recalled:   2.5-lb. trays containing ‚Äúfarm to family BUTTERBALL all natural Ground Turkey‚Äù with the case code 50211271, a sell or freeze by date of 10/18/2021, and timestamps from 2123 through 2302 printed on the packaging.   3-lb. tray containing ‚ÄúKroger GROUND TURKEY‚Äù with the case code 50211271, a sell or freeze by date of 10/17/2021, and timestamps from 2314 through 2351 printed on the packaging.   READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Anyone who has purchased these products is urged to check their case codes and sell by dates. The products were shipped to stores nationwide, the service said. The company learned of the mistake after customers called complaining about the plastic. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall There have been no reported injuries from eating the product, but the FSIS said it is concerned about customers who have the contaminated product in their kitchens. If you have the recalled product, toss the turkey or return it to the place of purchase. headline: Baltimore Man, 33, Charged With First-Degree Murder In Deadly Shooting
summary: A 33-year-old man faces a murder charge in a deadly shooting last month in Southeast Baltimore, authorities said Thursday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A 33-year-old man faces a murder charge in a deadly shooting last month in Southeast Baltimore, authorities said Thursday. Paul Hunter, Jr., was arrested Wednesday and booked into the Central Intake Facility on a charge of first-degree murder, according to the Baltimore Police Department. headline: Fantasy Football Start Or Sit Week 6: Will Darrel Williams Get Enough Touches For The Chiefs?
summary: Darrel Williams will take over for the injured Clyde Edwards-Helaire in the Chiefs backfield, but will he see the football enough to make a difference?
bodytext: ( CBS Boston ) ‚Äî  Having one of the Kansas City Chiefs‚Äô offensive skill players in your fantasy lineup can certainly help your scoring output. But that hasn‚Äôt necessarily been a guarantee this season. While Patrick Mahomes has generally been consistent (turnover issues not withstanding), other players have had off-weeks. It‚Äôs been feast or famine with receiver Tyreek Hill. Travis Kelce picked up just two points against the Philadelphia Eagles. And running back Clyde Edwards-Helaire sometimes seemed to disappear from the offense. Edwards-Helaire is now on injured reserve with a knee injury. Darrel Williams is set to take over the starting spot. Is he in for a big game against a Washington Football Team defense that can‚Äôt seem to stop anyone this season? Or will he struggle to get touches with so much other talent on the field? headline: Woman Burned By Hot Coffee Sues Dunkin‚Äô Store Owner, Says ‚ÄòCruel‚Äô Employees Mocked Her
summary: A woman burned by "scalding" hot coffee in a Dunkin' drive-thru is suing the local owner of the store and two employees there who allegedly mocked her injuries.
bodytext: BROCKTON, Mass. (CBS Boston) ‚Äî  A woman burned by ‚Äúscalding‚Äù hot coffee at a Massachusetts Dunkin‚Äô location is suing the local owner of the store and two employees who allegedly mocked her injuries. Angela Barbosa filed the lawsuit in Plymouth Superior Court earlier in October. She said she was in the passenger‚Äôs seat of her sister‚Äôs car in June of 2020 when they pulled up to the Dunkin‚Äô drive-thru at night and ordered three hot coffees.¬†She claims an employee handed her sister coffee cups that were not placed firmly in a tray, and that the hot drinks were not properly capped. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School They came loose and tipped over onto Barbosa, burning her legs and buttocks. ‚ÄúScreaming in pain, the Plaintiff was forced to rip off her leggings in the parking lot, exposing herself in full view of the Dunkin Donuts employees,‚Äù the lawsuit states. ‚ÄúSeeing this, the employees were pointing, laughing, and mocking the plaintiff.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The coffee spill resulted in serious burns and nerve damage, the lawsuit states, as well as permanent scars.¬†Barbosa is suing for negligence and emotional distress.¬†‚ÄúThe defendants‚Äô actions were extreme and outrageous, beyond all possible bounds of decency and utterly intolerable in a civilized community,‚Äù the lawsuit states. The Dunkin‚Äô location in question is owned by Pembroke-based Cadete Enterprises, according to the lawsuit. WBZ-TV in Boston has reached out to them for comment. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The website  for Cadete Enterprises says their brands include Dunkin‚Äô, Anytime Fitness and Meineke Car Care Centers. They say they are ‚Äúcommitted to providing the highest quality in products and services to our guests throughout Massachusetts while maintaining the highest levels of standards.

headline: Southwest Issues Apology For Thousands Of Canceled Flights
summary: Southwest Airlines issued an apology Thursday for the thousands of flights it has canceled since last Friday, disrupting travel plans across the country.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Southwest Airlines issued an apology Thursday for the thousands of flights it has canceled since last Friday, disrupting travel plans across the country. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot to say about what happened over the last several days, but we‚Äôll start with the most important message: we‚Äôre sorry,‚Äù the airline tweeted.   There‚Äôs a lot to say about what happened over the last several days, but we‚Äôll start with the most important message: we‚Äôre sorry. Cancelling thousands of flights & displacing Customers isn‚Äôt what we want for you, nor is it what you should expect from us.  https://t.co/NSBotfqdkm   pic.twitter.com/pM9TINNq0Q   ‚Äî Southwest Airlines (@SouthwestAir)  October 14, 2021 READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Attached was  a letter  from¬†Southwest Airlines President & COO Mike Van de Ven. He said the disruption was initially created by weather and air traffic constraints in Florida. Because of Southwest‚Äôs ‚Äúpoint-to-point‚Äù flying system, 40-50% of Southwest‚Äôs planes fly through Florida each day, so the displacement to aircraft and crews reportedly kicked off an avalanche of issues. ‚ÄúIt took us several days to re-set our network after the initial challenges,‚Äù said Van de Ven. The disruptions came shortly after the¬†pilot‚Äôs union tried to block Southwest‚Äôs new¬†COVID-19 vaccine mandate, spurring speculation that there was a sort of strike. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Captain Cassey Murray, president of the Southwest pilots‚Äô union,  told CBS News  the disruptions were not caused by pilots protesting the pending vaccine mandate. Van de Ven waved off the rumors in his announcement as well. ‚ÄúDespite widespread rumors and speculation, the weekend challenges were  not  a result of unusual Southwest Employee activity, and there simply is nothing in our data that indicates that particular reason,‚Äù he said. BWI was no exception to Southwest‚Äôs impact. Dozens of customers were  stranded at the airport  Sunday from last-minute cancellations. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: NYPD Officer Accused Of Fatally Shooting Her Ex-Girlfriend‚Äôs New Lover, Wounding Ex
summary: An NYPD officer is facing murder charges after police say a love triangle turned deadly.
bodytext: NEW YORK (CBSNewYork)  ‚Äî An  NYPD  officer is facing murder charges after police say a love triangle turned deadly. Police said 31-year-old Yvonne Wu, a five-year veteran of the force,  was lying in wait at her ex-girlfriend‚Äôs home  in Brooklyn when she shot her ex and the ex‚Äôs new lover, CBS2‚Äôs Jessica Moore reported Thursday. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School New video shows the chaos triggered when police say a scorned lover snapped. ‚ÄúIt was two shots and I have never ever in all the years I‚Äôve lived here seen anything like this in my life,‚Äù neighbor Pat Santi said. Cellphone video shows Wu being frisked by fellow police officers Wednesday evening. Wu was off-duty when she allegedly shot and wounded her ex-girlfriend and killed 24-year-old Jamie Liang, her ex‚Äôs new girlfriend, according to detectives.¬†Multiple 911 calls came in reporting shots fired inside a house at the corner of 19th Avenue and 79th Street in Bensonhurst,  Brooklyn  at around 5 p.m. Wednesday. The deadly encounter has the community on edge.¬†‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe it. It‚Äôs awful,‚Äù one woman told Moore. WCBS-TV learned Wu and her ex broke up last month.¬†‚ÄúI saw them all the time together,‚Äù said Jeanette Vargas, a neighbor. ‚ÄúJust like anyone else, you can come home and find your lover or someone with someone else and you snap. So I don‚Äôt think it had nothing to do that she was a police officer.‚Äù ‚ÄúHow many breakups have you had in your lifetime? You gonna go and kill the person? You‚Äôd like to, but you don‚Äôt take a 9mm and shoot them,‚Äù added Santi. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Valerie Wades said she watched as paramedics tried desperately, but unsuccessfully, to save Liang.¬†‚ÄúThe ambulances came and took two victims out and they were doing mad chest compressions,‚Äù Wades said. Police sources told WCBS-TV‚Äôs John Dias that the deadly encounter may have been premeditated.¬†Sources said Wu waited inside her ex-girlfriend‚Äôs home, which they shared at one time. When she returned with Liang, Wu allegedly fired off multiple rounds. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very good chance it is her service weapon,‚Äù said NYPD Assistant Chief Michael Kemper.. ‚ÄúOne female, a 24-year-old, was found lying in the living room area and the second female, a 23-year-old, was found lying on the floor in the bedroom.‚Äù Police said Wu admitted to the shooting right away.¬†‚ÄúI would describe her as calm and collective and very forthcoming,‚Äù said Kemper. ‚ÄúNever in a million years did I think it was a cop who was the shooter. She just seemed so detached. Everyone else was in hyper-drive and she was just so calm,‚Äù Wades said. Police said Wu‚Äôs ex-girlfriend is in stable condition, but her injuries are serious. Sources said Wu and her ex had remained in touch, but their post-relationship communication was ‚Äúconfrontational.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The state Attorney General‚Äôs Office is handling the case since it is considered a police-involved shooting.

headline: Child Tax Credit: When Will Your October Payment Show Up?
summary: The next advance Child Tax Credit payment goes out Friday, with direct deposits arriving almost immediately and mailed checks taking a little longer.
bodytext: ( CBS Detroit ) ‚Äî  The fourth Child Tax Credit payment from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) goes out tomorrow. But many parents want to know when exactly the money will be deposited. Last month‚Äôs checks started arriving the morning of September 15 for those with direct deposit, or soon after for those who received it through the mail. This month‚Äôs payment will be sent on Friday, October 15. Advance payments will continue next month and the following month, thanks to the American Rescue Plan passed back in March. While another stimulus check seems unlikely at this point, Democratic lawmakers are looking to extend the advance Child Tax Credit through 2025. Families can use the Child Tax Credit money however they like. That means the extra $250 or $300 per child can be put toward essentials like food or rent. It may also be spent on school supplies or a new computer, should COVID push students back into remote learning. Other households may apply the money toward piano lessons, daycare or even diapers. Regardless, the money comes at a time when much of the other pandemic aid ‚Äî¬† most recently the extra unemployment insurance ‚Äî has ended. Knowing that additional income is coming allows for a measure of security and flexibility in a world that‚Äôs full of surprises. How Much Should Your Check Be? READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The IRS is paying $3,600 total per child to parents of children up to five years of age. That drops to $3,000 for each child ages six through 17. Half of the total is being paid as six monthly payments and half as a 2021 tax credit. So each month through December parents of a younger child are receiving $300, and parents of an older child are receiving $250. The IRS has also made a one-time payment of $500 for dependents age 18 or full-time college students up through age 24.   DYK, foster parents, grandparents or other relatives may be eligible to receive advance  #ChildTaxCredit  payments? Read this  #IRSTaxTip :  https://t.co/9J5HB58rqX   #IRS   pic.twitter.com/831CpGNTfx   ‚Äî IRSnews (@IRSnews)  October 14, 2021 The updated Child Tax Credit is based on parents‚Äô modified adjusted gross income (AGI), as reflected on their 2020 tax filing. (AGI is the sum of one‚Äôs wages, interest, dividends, alimony, retirement distributions and other sources of income minus certain deductions, such as student loan interest, alimony payments and retirement contributions.) The amount  phases out  at a rate of $50 for every $1,000 of annual income beyond $75,000 for an individual and beyond $150,000 for a married couple. The benefit is fully refundable, meaning it does not depend on the recipient‚Äôs current tax burden. Qualifying families receive the full amount, regardless of what they owe in taxes. There is no limit to the number of dependents that can be claimed. For example, suppose a married couple has a three-year-old child and a seven-year-old child and showed an annual joint income of $120,000 on their 2020 taxes. The IRS is sending them $550 per month. That‚Äôs $300 per month ($3,600 / 12) for the younger child and $250 per month ($3,000 / 12) for the older child. Those payments will last through December. The couple would then receive the $3,300 balance ‚Äî $1,800 ($300 X 6) for the younger child and $1,500 ($250 X 6) for the older child ‚Äî as part of their 2021 tax refund. Parents of a child who ages out of an age bracket are paid the lesser amount. That means if a five-year-old turns six in 2021, the parents will receive a total credit of $3,000 for the year, not $3,600. Likewise, if a 17-year-old turns 18 in 2021, the parents are receiving $500, not $3,000. An income increase in 2021 to an amount above the $75,000 ($150,000) threshold could lower a household‚Äôs Child Tax Credit. The IRS has confirmed that they‚Äôll soon allow claimants to adjust their income and custodial information online, thus lowering their payments. Failure to do so could increase one‚Äôs tax bill or reduce one‚Äôs tax refund once 2021 taxes are filed. Eligibility requires that the dependent be a part of the household for at least half of the year and be at least half supported by the taxpayer. A taxpayer who makes above $95,000 ($170,000) ‚Äî where the Credit phases out entirely ‚Äî will not be eligible for the expanded credit. But they can still claim the existing $2,000 credit per child. How Do You Make Changes For Future Payments? The IRS has three different tools to help recipients and potential recipients update their information on file, register and check eligibility. Child Tax Credit Update Portal READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The  Child Tax Credit Update Portal  allows users to make sure they are registered to receive advance payments. It also lets  recipients unenroll  from advance payments in favor of a one-time credit when filing their 2021 taxes. The deadline for the next payment was October 4. (Subsequent opt-out deadlines for future payments will occur three days before the first Thursday of the month from which a person is opting out.) Here are the remaining opt-out deadlines:   Payment Date: November 15 / Opt-Out Deadline: November 1   Payment Date: December 15 / Opt-Out Deadline: November 29   The tool also allows users to add or modify bank account information for direct deposit, view their payment history, and update their mailing address. Other features coming to the portal include changing one‚Äôs income and dependents. To access this portal, users need an IRS username or an ID.me account. ID.me is a sign-in service used by various government agencies, including the IRS, Social Security Administration and Treasury Department, to authenticate users. Users need valid photo identification to create an account.   An  #IRS  tool now enables families to quickly and easily unenroll from receiving monthly payments of the  #ChildTaxCredit , if they so choose.  https://t.co/Qt9TAuwjvv   pic.twitter.com/JNrVfKUkvt   ‚Äî IRSnews (@IRSnews)  October 12, 2021 Child Tax Credit Non-Filer Sign-Up Tool The  Child Tax Credit Non-Filer Sign-Up Tool  is to help parents of children born before 2021 who don‚Äôt typically file taxes but qualify for advance Child Tax Credit payments. That means parents who have not filed their 2020 taxes, are not required to file, and don‚Äôt plan to file. (Parents who claimed their dependents on their 2019 tax return should not use this tool.) Users enter their personal information, including their name, mailing address, email address, date of birth, relevant social security numbers, bank account information, and identity protection PIN. The IRS uses the information to check eligibility and, once confirmed, will begin making payments. The IRS and experts advise using the tool on a desktop or laptop computer rather than a mobile device. Child Tax Credit Eligibility Assistant The  Child Tax Credit Eligibility Assistant  lets parents check if they are eligible to receive advance Child Tax Credit payments. Users will need a copy of their 2020 tax return or, barring that, their 2019 tax return. It‚Äôs also fine to estimate income and expenses from the appropriate tax year, though the result may not be accurate. The assistant asks multiple questions to determine eligibility, but does not ask for sensitive information. No entries are recorded. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Originally published Friday, August 6 at 5:01 p.m. ET.

headline: Man Fatally Shot In Annapolis Thursday Afternoon
summary: Police in Annapolis are investigating after a man was fatally shot Thursday afternoon.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police in Annapolis are investigating after a man was fatally shot Thursday afternoon.   Officers responded to the unit block of Pleasent Street for a reported shooting. On the scene, they found a man suffering from gunshot wounds.   He was taken to an area hospital where he later died.   Detectives are investigating and anyone with information about this incident to contact at 410-260-3439. You can also call Metro Crime Stoppers at 1-866-7LOCKUP and submit an anonymous tip. If your tip leads to an arrest or indictment you may be eligible for a cash reward of up to $2,000.

headline: Former Raven Bart Scott Thinks WR Marquise Brown Wouldn‚Äôt Start On Most Top Teams. Brown Calls It ‚ÄòFoolishness‚Äô
summary: There's a family fight going on in Ravens Nation. Former linebacker Bart Scott thinks Marquise Brown isn't good enough to start on the NFL's top teams. Brown calls that "foolishness."
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî There‚Äôs a family fight going on in Ravens Nation. Appearing on ESPN‚Äôs ‚ÄúFirst Take‚Äù Wednesday, former Ravens linebacker Bart Scott took a few shots at third-year player Marquise Brown, arguing the wide receiver wouldn‚Äôt start for some of the league‚Äôs top teams such as the Buffalo Bills, Kansas City Chiefs and Green Bay Packers. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Brown shot back on Twitter: ‚ÄúHis name Bart what you expect.‚Äù   ü§£ü§£ His name Bart what you expect  https://t.co/sbhvfgePCW   ‚Äî Hollywood Brown (@Primetime_jet)  October 13, 2021 Brown went a little more in-depth during his appearance on WJZ‚Äôs ‚ÄúPurple Playbook.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat was pretty disrespectful, I‚Äôm not gonna lie,‚Äù he told Mark Viviano. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt usually respond to people but if I see Bart in person, we got words.‚Äù   Bmore loves  @BartScott57  but his take that  @Primetime_jet  wouldn‚Äôt be a starter w KC, GB or BUF? ü§î  Marquise on  @wjz : ‚ÄúThat was pretty disrespectful, I‚Äôm not gonna lie. I don‚Äôt usually respond to people but if I see Bart in person, we got words.‚Äù  See ‚ÄúPurple Playbook‚Äù this wknd  pic.twitter.com/HAbtOKeL0R   ‚Äî Mark Viviano (@MarkWJZ)  October 14, 2021 On the season Brown has 451 receiving yards‚Äìgood for 8th in the league‚Äìand five touchdowns. Asked about it again on Thursday, Brown reportedly  labeled  Scott‚Äôs comments as ‚Äúfoolishness.‚Äù It didn‚Äôt end there. Taking exception to Brown‚Äôs Twitter clapback, Scott on Thursday afternoon posted a clip from his radio show talking about his Baltimore credentials after playing with the Ravens from 2002 to 2008, telling Brown to find his poster inside the Ravens complex.   Just gonna leave this here.  pic.twitter.com/mY0JhJMVxj   ‚Äî Bart Scott #CantWait üèà (@BartScott57)  October 14, 2021 ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs talk about blood in the soil, DNA, you know what I‚Äôm saying? I built bricks. I added bricks to that legacy over there,‚Äù Scott said. ‚ÄúSo don‚Äôt ever come at me, bro.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall During his time in Baltimore, Scott played in 109 games and recorded 448 tackles and 16 sacks. He said his comments were about quarterback Lamar Jackson‚Äôs incredible play, then added a dollop of shade. ‚ÄúWhat I was really talking about was Lamar Jackson and his greatness, not the fact that you aren‚Äôt a No. 1, which you aren‚Äôt,‚Äù Scott said. The Ravens‚Äô selection of wide receiver Rashod Bateman in the draft ‚Äúlets you know they‚Äôre not sold on you as a No. 1,‚Äù Scott argued. Scott then doubled down on his argument that Brown wouldn‚Äôt start for some of the NFL‚Äôs contenders, listing off teams and their receiving units. (Some of his examples are not all that convincing.)   Showing my work  pic.twitter.com/8MWoCiTHpV   ‚Äî Bart Scott #CantWait üèà (@BartScott57)  October 14, 2021 There was something of an apology. ‚ÄúListen, I didn‚Äôt mean to hurt your feelings,‚Äù Scott said. ‚ÄúWhat I was trying to do was build up a Lamar Jackson.‚Äù But he followed it up with a defense of the name Bartholomew while taking a few digs at Marquise. Yes, really. ‚ÄúBartholomew will get an interview anywhere,‚Äù Scott said. ‚Äú‚ÄòMarkweese‚Äô, Marquise, mmmmm, you might not get called back sometimes, bro.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Two former Ravens, quarterback Robert Griffin III and running back Mark Ingram, came to Brown‚Äôs defense on Twitter.   Marquise ‚ÄúHollywood‚Äù Brown is a starter on every team in the league this year and there is nothing wrong with his name.   ‚Äî Robert Griffin III (@RGIII)  October 14, 2021   Good stuff RG3 idk why these dudes be feeling the need to hate and bring another brother down for no reason smh ü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è   ‚Äî Mark Ingram II (@markingramII)  October 14, 2021

headline: Baltimore County Residents Outraged After Losing Running Water For 48 Hours
summary: Residents in the Belmont South Community in Nottingham are furious because they went without water for days.
bodytext: NOTTINGHAM, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Residents in the Belmont South Community in Nottingham are furious because they went without water for days. The water went out early Tuesday morning. There was no water for the entire day Tuesday and Wednesday. But on Thursday, more than 48 hours later, contractors arrived in the community. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just been a nightmare,‚Äù resident Mia Bogy said. ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs the first time it looks like they are actually working on it. Hopefully today we will have water.‚Äù The problem stems from the fact that it wasn‚Äôt immediately clear who was responsible for repairing the broken service line. The leak was on Mitnick Road and an individual with the property management initially told residents that it was up to Baltimore County‚Äôs Department of Public Works to make the fix. The public agency disagreed. ‚ÄúI called 311, they told me it would be on yesterday but it never came on,‚Äù said Aletha Carey, who has lived in the community for years. In a statement to WJZ, the Department of Public Works said the leak occurred on the side of the line that‚Äôs private property: ‚ÄúThis was a leak on the private side of the service line. The community (homeowners association) asked DPW to cut off the water in order for the repair to be made. DPW complied and will turn it on as soon as they are asked.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Residents who felt like they‚Äôve been getting the run around over the past few days confronted the property manager when he visited the community. Then on Thursday, residents received a new letter signed by the property manager. ‚ÄúBarring any unforeseen issues, the water should be back later this evening,‚Äù it said in part. Throughout this ordeal, neighbors purchased water to help each other with the basic necessities such as showering, cooking and flushing toilets. ‚ÄúIt takes a gallon to flush the toilet,‚Äù Bogey said. We can‚Äôt shower. Thankfully we have family and friends, we could go shower.‚Äù WJZ received this statement from the Belmont South Community Board of Directors: ¬† The DWP began their investigation of the leak on Tuesday afternoon and determined Wednesday afternoon that the water break was somewhere on association property. Upon that determination, the Board worked with property management tohire a contractor to find the leak within the community. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized

headline: Rose McIver And Utkarsh Ambudkar Talk ‚ÄòGhosts‚Äô On CBS: ‚ÄòWe Got A Hit Baby!‚Äô
summary: Last week saw the big premiere of 'Ghosts'¬†on CBS. Rose McIver and Utkarsh Ambudkar star in this American adaptation of the hit British series.
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì  Last week saw the big premiere of  Ghosts ¬† on CBS. Rose McIver and Utkarsh Ambudkar star in this American adaptation of the hit British series where Samantha (McIver) and Jay (Ambudkar) throw caution to the wind when they convert their recently inherited country estate into a bed-and-breakfast. Not only is the place falling apart, but it‚Äôs also inhabited by spirits of previous residents ‚Äî whom only Samantha can see and hear. CBS‚Äô Matt Weiss spoke to McIver and Ambudkar about tonight‚Äôs new episode, their favorite co-stars and their early impression of the show (spoiler, it‚Äôs a hit). READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School MW-  hey there Rose, Utkarsh! Congratulations on episode one last week finally hitting the air waves in America but of course this is actually an adaptation of the British program by the same name. Were either of you familiar with the original? RM-  I didn‚Äôt know about the original until I saw it after we had already booked  Ghosts , but once I did, I was like this thing is brilliant. It‚Äôs really no wonder it‚Äôs a huge success and they deserve so much credit. We‚Äôre just excited to be part of their family. they‚Äôve been so welcoming to us as we reimagine the show with an American take. UA-  I watched five minutes of the BBC one and I was like ‚Äòoh yeah I would do this show.‚Äô The script came to me and then I watched what they‚Äôve done ‚Äúacross the pond‚Äù and it‚Äôs just so funny and charming. The premise just works. It‚Äôs a showcase for a lot of different kinds of actors to do some really funny and engaging work. MW-  Now that episode one has aired, I imagine it has to be such a good feel that this thing you‚Äôve been working on is finally out there. What‚Äôs your reaction been like the last week? UA-  We got a hit baby! No, I‚Äôm just so happy I mean this has been like our vortex for so long. We were going to go with this project back in March right before we went into the global pandemic. I‚Äôm just happy that now it‚Äôs not just the cast talking to each other anymore but we we have a whole audience to interact with and the people at home can enjoy it too. RM-  Yeah, the goal is to give people a television show with a lot of love and heart and comedy and humor and they can sort of release. l certainly feel a little bit of relief and it feels really good that folks are actually enjoying and engaging with it. MW-  Obviously, the show has quite a cast of characters. Outside of each other, who are your favorite characters to interact with so far? READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall RM-  You trying to make us enemies on set [Laughs]? Well, character wise, THIS week, it‚Äôs Thorfinn. He is really the centerpiece of tonight‚Äôs episode and he gets to shine so he‚Äôs the favorite child this week. UA-  I have a least favorite‚Ä¶and you know who you are. [Laughs] MW-  [Laughs] We‚Äôll just leave that there. Last question before we go, what‚Äôs in store for episode two tonight? RM-  So tonight, Jay and Samantha discover some bones on their property. Actually their fantastic contractor played by Tristen Lalla, a new father and supremely talented actor, he discovered some Viking bones on the property and Samantha and Jay you have to decide whether or not to sell these bones and make a bunch of money or to give Thorfinn the Viking funeral that he had longed for, for over 1000 years. It becomes a situation where they have to decide whether to put their family before themselves or not. It is a big dysfunctional family comedy. It‚Äôs not the family they signed up for but they love them! MW-  We‚Äôll all have to tune in tonight to see which way you decide to go. Thank you both so much for your time and all the best, take care! RM-  Thank you so much, man! UA-  Thanks, Matt! MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Ghosts  airs Thursdays at 9:00PM ET/PT on CBS or available to stream with  Paramount+ . Check your local listings for more information.

headline: First Responders Say Many MD Drivers Do Not Move Over Or Slow Down For Vehicles Offering Roadside Assistance
summary: Maryland law requires that drivers move over for vehicles providing roadside assistance or slow down if it is not safe to change lanes, but an overwhelming majority of first responders said motorists are not following the rule, according to a new survey.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Maryland law requires that drivers move over for vehicles providing roadside assistance or slow down if it is not safe to change lanes, but an overwhelming majority of first responders say motorists are not following the rule, according to a new survey released by AAA Mid-Atlantic. Almost 75% of respondents in Maryland, a group that includes police, emergency medical services personnel, tow truck drivers and roadside workers, said drivers do not move over or slow down for people working on the side of the road. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School More than 90% said they have nearly been hit by a vehicle or had their life threatened because a driver failed to move over. As a result, 65% of first responders said they do not feel safe even with the law in place. Maryland drivers don‚Äôt seem to know there‚Äôs a problem. According to a survey AAA Mid-Atlantic released last month, 90% of drivers said they follow the law. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall State officials and representatives from AAA gathered at an I-95 rest stop in Laurel on Thursday to mark the anniversary of the law and remind motorists to move over or slowdown for first responders on the side of the road. ‚ÄúThe men and women who work every day along our roadways ‚Äì law enforcement officers, emergency responders and highway crews ‚Äì are there to serve the public and are often performing their duties within inches of fast-moving traffic,‚Äù Maryland Department of Transportation Secretary Greg Slater said. ‚ÄúAs we work together to eliminate excessive speed and distracted, impaired and aggressive driving, we must also remember our responsibility as motorists to move over and slow down for emergency vehicles and work crews.‚Äù The law, first enacted in 2010, required drivers to move over or slow down for law enforcement, emergency responders and state highway crews. In 2014, it was expanded to include tow trucks. Four years later, waste and recycling trucks and other service vehicles were added. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Between 2014 and 2019, 53 people were killed and more than 4,000 people were injured in work zone crashes in Maryland, according to the Maryland Department of Transportation.

headline: Baltimore City DOT Announces Locations Of 7 New Speed, Red Light Cameras
summary: The Baltimore City Department of Transportation on Wednesday announced the locations of four new automated speed cameras and three new red light cameras.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî The Baltimore City Department of Transportation on Wednesday announced the locations of four new automated speed cameras and three new red light cameras. The department‚Äôs Automated Traffic Violation Enforcement System program uses automated cameras to measure vehicle speed, assess the heights of commercial vehicles and determine if vehicles run red lights to assess fines. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Starting on or about Oct. 25, four new speed cameras will be placed in the area of city schools. The locations are:   200-5400 blocks Cedonia Avenue (northbound and southbound) ‚Äì Hazelwood Elementary/Middle School   600-1000 blocks N. Fulton Avenue (northbound and southbound) ‚Äì Harlem Park Elementary/Middle School, Augusta Fells Savage Institute of Visual Arts   3100-3500 blocks Hillsdale Road ‚Äì Calvin Rodwell Elementary School   4500-5300 blocks Walther Avenue ‚Äì Arts & Ideas Sudbury School   Speed cameras in school zones operate Monday through Friday from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. Fines are $40. Starting on or about Oct. 25, there will be three new red light cameras at the following intersections:   Patterson Park Avenue at Orleans Street   Ellwood Avenue at E. Fayette Street   Huntingdon Avenue at 28th Street   READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Red light camera are on 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Fines are $75. Additionally, the agency announced the location of two new monitoring systems for commercial vehicles. When a truck is detected in a restricted area, photos and video are taken of the vehicle. There are  designated truck routes  throughout the city. On or about Oct. 25, commercial vehicle monitoring will begin at:   1700 block of E. Preston Street   1000 block of Milton Avenue   Vehicle height monitoring system cameras are on 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. A warning is issued for a first offense. Fines are $125 for the second offense and $250 for subsequent offenses. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized A full map of automated cameras in the city can be found  here .

headline: Girl, 8, Beats Deadly Condition Tied to COVID-19 At Johns Hopkins Children‚Äôs Center
summary: MIS-C is a serious medical condition that can cause inflammation in major organs like the lungs, kidney and brain.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚ÄìMorgan Deitz is known for her spunky and social personality, but in September, the eight-year-old didn‚Äôt feel like herself. ‚ÄúI just felt awful and I just felt blah,‚Äù she recalled. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School She got COVID-19 over the summer. She recovered and thought she was in the clear, until she started feeling sick again. She learned she had MIS-C, or multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children. ‚ÄúIt was affecting her stomach,‚Äù said Morgan‚Äôs mom, Lauren Deitz. ‚ÄúShe had pain throughout her entire body. Her eyes were bloodshot. Even as we were sitting in the ER with her, the rash was spreading to her stomach, to her feet.‚Äù It‚Äôs a serious medical condition that can cause inflammation in major organs like the lungs, kidney and brain. In some cases MIS-C can shut down the organs and lead to death. Morgan was treated at Johns Hopkins Children‚Äôs Center. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Her mother said it was touch-and-go at times. ‚ÄúThey push the code button and tons of people come running into the room trying to work on her. It was just so incredibly scary and that happened twice,‚Äù said Lauren Deitz. MIS-C is a new condition that started affecting children during the pandemic. According to the CDC, there have been 5,000 cases and about 40 deaths since May of last year. ‚ÄúWe are not used to kids getting sick from a new phenomenon that we don‚Äôt have the level of expertise and knowledge about to necessarily know what the best or right treatments are at this point, and so that‚Äôs difficult,‚Äù said Julia Shalen, a pediatric rheumatologist at Johns Hopkins Children‚Äôs Center. Morgan‚Äôs doctor says the only way to prevent MIS-C right now is for anyone who can get a vaccine to get one, since children like Morgan can‚Äôt be vaccinated yet. ‚ÄúEverybody wants to go back to their normal lives,‚Äù said Lauren Deitz. ‚ÄúWe want to just as much as the next family, and the only way to do that is to protect each other by getting the vaccine.‚Äù Morgan will continue to be monitored to make sure the MIS-C does not come back. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized She will be getting vaccinated as soon as she is eligible.

headline: FDA Panel Endorses Lower-Dose Moderna COVID-19 Shot For Booster
summary: The recommendation is non-binding but it‚Äôs a key step toward expanding the U.S. booster campaign to millions more Americans. Many people who got their initial Pfizer shots at least six months ago are already getting a booster after the FDA authorized their use last month.
bodytext: (AP) ‚Äî  U.S. health advisers said Thursday that some Americans who received Moderna‚Äôs COVID-19 vaccine should get a half-dose booster to bolster protection against the virus. The panel of advisers to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously to recommend a booster shot for seniors, adults with other health problems, jobs or living situations that put them at increased risk for COVID-19. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The recommendation is non-binding but it‚Äôs a key step toward expanding the U.S. booster campaign to millions more Americans. Many people who got their initial Pfizer shots at least six months ago are already getting a booster after the FDA authorized their use last month. As for the dose, initial Moderna vaccination consists of two 100-microgram shots. But Moderna says a single 50-microgram shot should be enough for a booster. The agency convened its experts Thursday and Friday to weigh-in on who should get boosters and when for people that received the Moderna and Johnson & Johnson shots earlier this year. The FDA will use its advisers‚Äô recommendations in making final decisions for boosters from both companies. Assuming a positive decision, there‚Äôs still another hurdle: Next week, a panel convened by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will offer more specifics on who should get one. THIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP‚Äôs earlier story follows below. U.S. health advisers are debating if millions of Americans who received Moderna vaccinations should get a booster shot ‚Äî this time, using half the original dose. Already millions who got their initial Pfizer shots at least six months ago are getting a booster of that brand. Thursday, advisers to the Food and Drug Administration evaluated the evidence that Moderna boosters should be offered, too ‚Äî and on Friday, they‚Äôll tackle the same question for those who got Johnson & Johnson‚Äôs vaccine. U.S. officials stress that the priority is to get shots to the 66 million unvaccinated Americans who are eligible for immunization ‚Äî those most at risk as the extra-contagious delta variant of the coronavirus has burned across the country. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to remember that the vaccines still provide strong protection against serious outcomes‚Äù such as hospitalization and death from COVID-19, said FDA vaccine chief Dr. Peter Marks. But Marks said it‚Äôs also become clear there is some waning of protection against milder infections with all three of the coronavirus vaccines used in the U.S. And he encouraged the advisory panel to consider if the evidence backs similar booster recommendations for all of them as well, since that would ‚Äúcreate the least confusion‚Äù for the public. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Moderna is seeking FDA clearance for a booster used just like Pfizer‚Äôs: For people 65 and older, or adults with other health problems, jobs or living situations that put them at increased risk of serious coronavirus ‚Äî once they are at least six months past their last dose. The FDA will use its advisers‚Äô recommendations in deciding whether to authorize Moderna boosters. If it does, there‚Äôs still another hurdle: Next week, a panel convened by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will offer more specifics on who should get one. What‚Äôs the evidence that the Moderna vaccine‚Äôs protection is waning? As the delta variant surged in July and August, people who were more recently vaccinated had a 36% lower rate of ‚Äúbreakthrough‚Äù infections compared with those vaccinated longer ago, Moderna‚Äôs Dr. Jacqueline Miller told FDA‚Äôs advisers. As for the dose, initial Moderna vaccination consists of two 100-microgram shots. But Moderna says a single 50-microgram shot should be enough for a booster. The company said that would trigger fewer uncomfortable shot reactions such as fever and achiness while also leaving more vaccine available for the global supply. A study of 344 people found the booster shot six months after initial vaccinations restored virus-fighting antibodies to levels seen after recipients‚Äô last dose ‚Äî and that included large jumps in antibodies able to target the delta variant, Miller said. One very rare side effect of both the Moderna and Pfizer vaccines is heart inflammation, particularly among young men soon after the second dose ‚Äî and one lingering question is whether another dose could spark more cases. Moderna‚Äôs booster study wasn‚Äôt large enough to spot such a rare risk. But Israel began offering Pfizer boosters sooner than the U.S. and to more of its population. Thursday, Dr. Sharon Alroy-Preis of Israel‚Äôs health ministry told the FDA panel that after 3.7 million booster doses administered, there‚Äôs no sign the extra shot is any riskier ‚Äî despite an intense investigation into heart inflammation. In the U.S., scientists are divided about exactly who needs boosters and their purpose ‚Äî whether they‚Äôre needed mostly for people at risk of severe disease or whether they should be used to try to reduce milder infections, too. While Pfizer‚Äôs boosters are only for certain high-risk groups of Americans, Israeli officials credit wider booster use in their country to stemming the delta surge. ‚ÄúThere is no question in my mind that the break of the curve was due to the booster dose,‚Äù Alroy-Preis said in response to FDA advisers who noted that other countries have seen a lowering of delta cases without widespread booster use. As Thursday‚Äôs deliberations began, FDA‚Äôs advisers highlighted one confusing issue: People with severely weakened immune systems already can get a third full dose of the Moderna vaccine soon after the initial vaccinations ‚Äî so a question is whether they should be eligible for a booster, too, which would be their fourth dose.
