headline: Veteran Charged With Fraudulently Obtaining $1M By Allegedly Falsely Claiming To Be Paraplegic
summary: A U.S. Army veteran from Windsor Mill was arrested Thursday for allegedly fraudulently obtaining more than $1 million in Veterans and Social Security Administration benefits by falsely claiming he was a paraplegic, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Maryland.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A U.S. Army veteran from Windsor Mill was arrested Thursday for allegedly fraudulently obtaining more than $1 million in Veterans and Social Security Administration benefits by falsely claiming he was a paraplegic, according to the U.S. Attorney‚Äôs Office for the District of Maryland. William Rich, 41, allegedly misrepresented his physical condition in Veterans Administration disability compensation claims, in communications with the VA and during medical examinations while seeking VA disability benefits by claiming he is paralyzed and unable to walk, according to a statement from the office. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Rich received $800,000 in VA benefits and more than $240,000 in Social Security Disability Insurance Benefits, the statement alleges. Rich served in the U.S. Army from September 1998 to February 2007 and was injured on Aug. 23, 2005, while serving in Baqubah, Iraq. The VA in October 2005 determined Rich was completely disabled and awarded special monthly compensation for his paraplegia, as well as allowances for a caregiver and Social Security Disability Insurance Benefits payments. But six weeks after his injuries, Rich made substantial progress toward recovery and no longer was paralyzed, according to the statement. An MRI in August 2005 revealed no spinal cord impingement and that he could move his lower extremities. A doctor conducting an exam in October 2007 determined Rich was paralyzed, but said he didn‚Äôt have access to Rich‚Äôs complete claims file, so he couldn‚Äôt review the earlier report. Rich then received permanent disability from the VA. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The VA‚Äôs Office of the Inspector General audited claims in 2018 and learned Rich‚Äôs alleged conduct was inconsistent with his purported condition, according to the statement. Special Agents for two years conducted surveillance and saw him walking, going up and down stairs, getting into and out of vehicles, lifting, bending, and carrying items ‚Äì all without visible limitations or assistance of a medical device, such as a wheelchair, the statement alleges. The affidavit further alleges the only time the agents saw Rich use a wheelchair was in connection with his medical appointments, particularly five between March 2019 and February 2021. The agents reported seeing Rich load the wheelchair into the trunk of his car before or after a VA medical appointment, using the wheelchair at the appointments or wheeling himself to his car, then loading the wheelchair into the car. Rich‚Äôs social media accounts feature photos of him standing in front of a mirror at a gym and videos of him lifting weights, according to the statement. The affidavit alleges he used money earmarked for ‚Äúautomobile and adaptive equipment‚Äù and ‚Äúspecially adapted housing‚Äù to buy a BMW 645ci coupe. If Rich is convicted, he faces a maximum sentence of 20 years in federal prison for wire fraud and a maximum of 10 years in federal prison for theft of government property. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: ‚ÄòTactless Finger Pointing‚Äô: Baltimore Officials Push Back On Hogan‚Äôs Criticisms Of The City During ‚ÄòRe-Fund The Police‚Äô Announcement
summary: Baltimore City officials did not take the Gov. Larry Hogan's criticism lightly, with some arguing that more police officers are not the solution to the city's crime woes. Here's a rundown of some of the responses.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Blasting Baltimore City as a ‚Äúposter child for the basic failure to stop lawlessness,‚Äù Gov. Larry Hogan on Friday  proposed directing an additional $150 million  to law enforcement agencies in a counter to the ‚Äúdefund the police‚Äù movement. The money would go toward pay raises and bonuses for officers, police department recruitment programs, body cameras and de-escalation training, victims‚Äô services and other initiatives. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúThinking that you can improve law enforcement by defunding the police is like saying that you want to improve education by defunding the schools,‚Äù Hogan said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs absurd and ridiculous.‚Äù The Baltimore Police Department‚Äôs budget rose by $28 million this year. Without calling them out by name, Hogan also criticized City Councilman Ryan Dorsey, who  recently suggested  disbanding and abolishing the department entirely, and Baltimore City State‚Äôs Attorney Marilyn Mosby, who the governor said ‚Äúrefuses to prosecute crime.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre on pace to surpass 300 homicides again this year,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe Baltimore Police Department is short-staffed by more than 300 officers.‚Äù Baltimore City officials pushed back on Hogan‚Äôs remarks, with some arguing that hiring more police officers doesn‚Äôt address the root causes of the city‚Äôs high crime. Here‚Äôs a rundown of some of the responses. Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott called Hogan‚Äôs remarks ‚Äútactless finger pointing‚Äù and said the Baltimore Police Department has cleared 220 violent crime cases in the last 90 days. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúSimply dispensing money will not solve anything unless that investment is met with real leadership, accountability, and the willingness to make tough decisions,‚Äù he said.   My statement on  @GovLarryHogan 's announcement.  pic.twitter.com/IRsqbHKjnp   ‚Äî Brandon M. Scott (@MayorBMScott)  October 15, 2021 Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson, who lives in Baltimore, suggested ‚Äúimproving public safety isn‚Äôt about just writing a bigger check,‚Äù and said a broader strategy would recognize that ‚Äúpoverty and opportunity shape the outcome of individuals.‚Äù   Nothing is more important than ensuring public safety throughout the State. Enhancing law enforcement trust and effectiveness is an important objective to create that safety. We have and we will continue to support investments that enhance trust and safety.   ‚Äî Bill Ferguson (@SenBillFerg)  October 15, 2021 Baltimore City Councilman Kristerfer Burnett told WJZ that adding more officers doesn‚Äôt address the root causes of crime. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs often economic issues that people are facing, addiction issues that people are facing, housing insecurity ‚Äî I mean, there‚Äôs any number of issues that we could be investing hundreds of millions of dollars into,‚Äù he said. Del. Stephanie Smith, who represents the 45th District, slammed Hogan‚Äôs proposals as ‚Äúperformative hand-wringing about the devastating impacts of violent crime‚Äù and said the governor hasn‚Äôt adequately invested in public transportation and education, ‚Äúthe things that create & connect people to opportunity.‚Äù   For 6+ years,  @GovLarryHogan  has failed to adequately fund state public safety staff. Recidivism is linked to this intentional de-funding of the professionals needed to prepare justice impacted individuals for a productive tax paying existence upon their return to communities. 1/   ‚Äî Stephanie M. Smith (@Smith4Delegate)  October 15, 2021 City Councilman Antonio Glover started out by defining the ‚Äúdefund the police‚Äù movement, saying it is ‚Äúall about divesting the overinflated police budget and investing that money in other sectors. This will allow the police to do actual police work, and not that of mental health specialists and social service workers.‚Äù Glover also tied the city‚Äôs levels of violence to a lack of high-paying jobs and disinvestment in local infrastructure.   Councilman Glover‚Äôs statement on Governor Hogan‚Äôs press conference  pic.twitter.com/wdalkWHLVP   ‚Äî Councilman Antonio Glover (@Team_Glover13)  October 15, 2021 MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Dorsey suggested a different type of refund.   I heard refund police and thought it meant giving people a refund on the billions of dollars spent on the lie that police would make anything better.   ‚Äî Ryan Dorsey (@ElectRyanDorsey)  October 15, 2021

headline: Slamming Baltimore, Gov. Hogan Lays Out $150 Million ‚ÄòRe-fund The Police‚Äô Plan
summary: Lashing out at the "defund the police" movement, Gov. Larry Hogan on Friday announced that Maryland will invest an additional $150 million in law enforcement as part of his "re-fund the police" initiative.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Lashing out at the ‚Äúdefund the police‚Äù movement, Gov. Larry Hogan on Friday announced that Maryland will invest an additional $150 million in law enforcement as part of his ‚Äúre-fund the police‚Äù initiative. Hogan said efforts to reduce police funding, inadequate resources and criticism of police, combined with surging violent crime, have made it difficult for law enforcement agencies to recruit and keep qualified police officers. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Instead of diverting police funding to other avenues, the governor said, public officials need to steer more funding to law enforcement to maintain public safety. ‚ÄúThinking that you can improve law enforcement by defunding the police is like saying that you want to improve education by defunding the schools,‚Äù Hogan said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs absurd and ridiculous.‚Äù Efforts to ‚Äúdefund the police‚Äù have grown in popularity nationwide amid unrest in the wake of high-profile police killings of civilians, such as George Floyd. But the name is a misnomer since it means reducing police funding and spending more on programs to address root causes, not eliminating police budgets. Hogan said now‚Äôs the worst time to consider cutting law enforcement funding, saying violent crime afflicting major cities nationwide is driving away recruits and leading officers on the force to quit or retire early. ‚ÄòWe Need More Investment‚Äô The key to improving public safety is not defunding police, the governor said, but rather beefing up police budgets. ‚ÄúTo reverse the tide of rising crime, we need to stop demonizing and sabotaging the dedicated men and women who risk their lives every single day to keep the rest of us safe. Enough is enough. We cannot defund the police. We need to re-fund the police. Instead of less funding, we need more investment in public safety,‚Äù he said. That‚Äôs why, Hogan said, he plans to spend $150 million to shore up law enforcement funding. The governor‚Äôs plan includes:   $50 million for police pay raises and bonuses;   $45 million to help local agencies with recruitment;   $24 million to fund body cameras and de-escalation training;   $14 million would cover victims‚Äô services and resources;   $10 million would pay for neighborhood safety grants;   $6 million for domestic violence and human trafficking victims;   $1 million for the Maryland Chiefs and Sheriffs Association.   ‚ÄúOur $150 million ‚Äòre-fund the police‚Äô initiative will provide a desperately needed shot in the arm to our state and local police agencies and their critical efforts to stop crime,‚Äù Hogan said. ‚ÄòBaltimore Is A Poster Child‚Äô Singling out Baltimore during Friday‚Äôs news conference, Hogan took digs at city officials and said the city‚Äôs violent crime problem is ‚Äúout of control.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre on pace to surpass 300 homicides again this year,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe Baltimore Police Department is short-staffed by more than 300 officers. The city of Baltimore is a poster child for the basic failure to stop lawlessness. There‚Äôs a prosecutor who refuses to prosecute crime. And there‚Äôs a revolving door of repeat offenders who are being let right back onto the streets to shoot people again and again.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Left unsaid during Hogan‚Äôs remarks was that the Baltimore Police Department‚Äôs budget rose by $28 million this year. Figures provided by the police department show he is not wrong about the violent crime rate. The city has seen 265 homicides so far, compared to 262 for the same time last year. There have been 572 non-deadly shootings, down from last year‚Äôs total (586). Though the governor referred to State‚Äôs Attorney Marilyn Mosby and City Councilman Ryan Dorsey, he did not mention either of them by name. Neither could be reached for comment Friday. City & State Leaders React Mayor Brandon Scott pushed back against the governor‚Äôs comments, saying confronting the city‚Äôs violent crime problem requires collaboration among leaders, ‚Äúnot tactless finger pointing.‚Äù Over the last three months, Scott said, the police department has recovered over 550 crime guns and cleared over 220 violent crimes, including murders and shootings. ‚ÄúSimply dispensing money will not solve anything unless that investment is met with real leadership, accountability and the willingness to make tough decisions,‚Äù the mayor said. Baltimore City Councilman Kristerfer Burnett told WJZ tackling violent crime isn‚Äôt a matter of adding police, it‚Äôs also about investing in programs that keep people from falling into a cycle of crime. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs often not necessarily because we need more officers,‚Äù Burnett said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs often economic issues that people are facing, addiction issues that people are facing, housing insecurity ‚Äî I mean, there‚Äôs any number of issues that we could be investing hundreds of millions of dollars into.‚Äù Legislative leaders also weighed in, with House Speaker Adrienne Jones accusing the governor of politicizing the issue and calling his remarks ‚Äúbeneath him and the dignity of his office.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe House stands ready to have an open an honest conversation about improving policing and reducing crime in the State once there are real ideas ‚Äî not rhetoric,‚Äù Jones said. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Added Senate President Bill Ferguson: ‚ÄúA real effort to stop violence and make communities safe requires a coordinated plan that gets executed purposely every day. It also includes strategies that recognize poverty and opportunity shape the outcome of individuals. Divisive rhetoric does not make us safer.‚Äù

headline: FDA Committee Recommends Boosters For Johnson & Johnson, Final Authorization Could Come Next Week
summary: A month after an FDA panel approved a booster for the Pfizer vaccine, that panel late this week unanimously recommended the same for other vaccines--Thursday for Moderna and Friday the Johnson & Johnson single-shot.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî A month after an FDA panel approved a booster for the Pfizer vaccine, that panel late this week unanimously recommended the same for other vaccines‚ÄìThursday for Moderna and Friday the Johnson & Johnson single-shot. If given final authorization, those boosters could be available late next week. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School An FDA committee will decide later this month whether to authorize Pfizer‚Äôs COVID vaccine for kids 5 to 11. The president says there are enough doses already purchased for that age group. ‚ÄúAssuming both of those events go well and you get a positive recommendation out of the FDA and CDC, this should be available almost immediately,‚Äù said former FDA Commissioner Dr. Scott Gottlieb. Gov. Larry Hogan said Friday local health departments are ready to administer to the younger age group once approved. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been working for three or four months to prepare,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe state health department has been working with the state board of ed.‚Äù Entering Friday, more than 700 Marylanders were hospitalized from COVID-19, including seven children. Maryland is pushing 200,000 boosters administered and is on pace to pass that number Friday. Topline metrics continue to drop, including the state‚Äôs positivity and case rates. But Western Maryland counties, with low vaccination numbers, have the state‚Äôs highest case rates. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The CDC says the covid-19 vaccines remain safe and effective.

headline: Baltimore County Public Schools Feeling The Impact Of Nationwide Teacher Shortage
summary: School leaders say because of the size of the district, they‚Äôre always recruiting new workers and that they hire between 600 and 800 teachers a year because of vacancies.
bodytext: TOWSON, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  There is a nationwide teachers shortage and Baltimore County Public Schools is feeling the impact. ‚ÄúThey had larger than normal classes when the school year started. It has gotten better,‚Äù said Teresa Propst, Parent. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Teresa Propst says the demand for virtual learning put a strain on her child‚Äôs class earlier this year. ‚ÄúI feel for the teachers. They are doing the best they can and trying to keep themselves safe and the kids,‚Äù said Propst. This shortage has been impacting schools in our area for some time. Last month, WJZ interviewed the President of the Maryland State Education Association. ‚ÄúWe really see a crisis in teacher shortages and other staffing shortages,‚Äù said Cheryl Bost, Maryland State Education Association President. The president of the Baltimore County Teachers Association echoes that message. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just teachers. It‚Äôs support staff, bus drivers, cafeteria workers, nurses, it‚Äôs across the board,‚Äù said Cindy Sexton, Baltimore County Teachers Association President. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall BCPS tells WJZ that they are not going through a ‚Äúcritical teachers shortage right now.‚Äù School leaders say because of the size of the district, they‚Äôre always recruiting new workers and that they hire between 600 and 800 teachers a year because of vacancies. The district hosts job fairs regularly. Parents told WJZ that the key to getting more teachers is paying them more. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre working with a lot of kids then they should be paid more. They‚Äôre working with the hours after school, they should be paid more,‚Äù said Christina Clay, Parent. Sexton says the real problem is that the profession isn‚Äôt as respected as it used to be and that people are not signing up for the job. ‚ÄúEducation is not always highly respected in our society right now. So, it really is a society problem to have the respect for the profession and really everything that educators do,‚Äù said Sexton. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized School leaders say they work to recruit teachers from all over. They are hosting another job fair on Oct. 29 for retired teachers and professionals.

headline: Baltimore Police Union Advises Officers To Not Disclose Their Vaccination Status Ahead Of City‚Äôs Mandate
summary: It is an attempt to delay the start of this mandate until they can get more clarity on the city‚Äôs policy.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî¬† Beginning Monday, all of Baltimore City‚Äôs 14,000 employees will be required to get a COVID-19 vaccine or face weekly testing. But Baltimore‚Äôs Police Union is pushing back, telling its officers in a letter sent Friday to not disclose their vaccination status. It is an attempt to delay the start of this mandate until they can get more clarity on the city‚Äôs policy. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúProof of vaccination will be required of Baltimore City employees effective Oct. 18, 2021,‚Äù Mayor Brandon Scott announced in September. The letter sent Friday, from Baltimore Police Union president Sergeant Mike Mancuso says the union has been trying to get clarity on the city‚Äôs new vaccination policy for weeks. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all asking those questions and we‚Äôre all not getting answers,‚Äù said Joshua Fannon, Union President of Baltimore Fire Officers Local 964. Fannon said firefighters are just as concerned about this new policy as police are, particularly how it‚Äôs going to be put into practice. ‚ÄúHow is weekly testing how is weekly testing going to work? It‚Äôs supposed to be on duty. If you have multiple people working on a fire engine how do they all get tested while they‚Äôre working cuz it sounds like it might be at different times?‚Äù Fannon asked, all questions he said have gone unanswered by the City but need to be addressed. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall In the letter from the Police Union, Sergeant Mancuso writes in part: ‚ÄúOur attorneys will be filing a court action today, in an attempt to at least delay the implementation of this policy.‚Äù According to the Baltimore Police Department, 64 percent of their entire department has been vaccinated. WJZ reached out to the City Fire Department who said they do not keep track of these numbers but will start doing so once the vaccination policy is in place next week. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot that needs to be ironed out and it hasn‚Äôt been yet,‚Äù said Fannon. ‚ÄúThis is about leading by example protecting the health of our workforce, residents and their loved ones,‚Äù said Mayor Scott. WJZ received this statement from the Mayor‚Äôs Office: MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúLabor Commissioner Deborah Moore-Carter led a productive meeting this afternoon with the Baltimore City Fraternal Order of Police and their attorney, Commissioner Michael Harrison, and representatives from the City‚Äôs Law Department and Human Resources to discuss concerns over the vaccination mandate. We will remain in close contact with the FOP until a solution is reached, and we are hopeful it will.‚Äù

headline: Just Puppies Agrees To Ban, $100K In Fines After Allegedly Selling Dogs From Puppy Mills, AG Frosh Says
summary: Just Puppies, a retail pet store with locations in Towson and Rockville, agreed to a settlement prohibiting the company from selling dogs in Maryland following allegations the business sourced animals from puppy mills, Attorney General Brian Frosh announced on Friday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Just Puppies, a pet shop with locations in Towson and Rockville, agreed to a settlement prohibiting the company from selling dogs in Maryland following allegations the business violated state law by sourcing animals from puppy mills, Attorney General Brian Frosh announced on Friday. Under the settlement, Just Puppies and owner Mitchell Thomson agreed to refund payments for dogs purchased since Jan. 1, 2020 or to cover the cost of treatment of certain medical conditions for dogs bought at the store. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Frosh‚Äôs office levied a $500,000 civil penalty on Just Puppies, but the number can be reduced to $100,000 if the business complies with the other stipulations in the settlement. ‚ÄúThis settlement resolves allegations that Just Puppies and its owner violated laws intended to protect animals from irresponsible breeding and mistreatment,‚Äù said Frosh. ‚ÄúConsumers who were misled by Just Puppies and purchased sick dogs will get their money back or receive compensation to help pay for their pet‚Äôs care.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall In a statement, Jennifer Bevan-Dangel, Maryland state director for the Humane Society of the United States, praised the settlement and encouraged Frosh to go after other companies that source animals from puppy mills. The state passed the No More Puppy-Mills Act in 2018 to ban the sale of puppy mill puppies in pet stores. The legislation, which went into effect at the start of 2020, was designed ‚Äúto protect Maryland consumers from unknowingly purchasing a sick and often behaviorally-challenged puppy from a puppy mill, leading to steep veterinary bills and too often, heartbreak,‚Äù Bevan-Dangel said. Frosh  charged  Just Puppies in June, alleging the company violated the puppy mill law and the Consumer Protection Act when it misled customers about where its puppies were sourced. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Just Puppies also allegedly continued to operate its Rockville location even after the city pulled its pet shop license, Frosh‚Äôs office said.

headline: Capitol Police Officer Told Jan. 6 Rioter To Scrub Evidence, Prosecutors Say
summary: A U.S. Capitol Police officer has been indicted on obstruction of justice charges after prosecutors say he helped to hide evidence of a rioter's involvement in the Jan. 6 insurrection.
bodytext: WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî  A U.S. Capitol Police officer has been indicted on obstruction of justice charges after prosecutors say he helped to hide evidence of a rioter‚Äôs involvement in the Jan. 6 insurrection. The officer, Michael A. Riley, is accused of tipping off someone who participated in the riot by telling them to remove posts from Facebook that had showed the person inside the Capitol during¬†the Jan. 6 attack,¬†according to court documents. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Riley, 50, appeared virtually in federal court in Washington and was released with several conditions, including that he surrender any firearms and not travel outside the U.S. without permission from a judge. He was ordered to return to court later this month. Riley, who responded to a report of a pipe bomb on Jan. 6 and has been a Capitol Police officer for about 25 years, had sent the person a message telling them that he was an officer with the police force who ‚Äúagrees with your political stance,‚Äù an indictment against him says. The indictment spells out how Riley sent dozens of messages to the unidentified person, encouraging them to remove incriminating photos and videos and telling them how the FBI was investigating to identify rioters. Riley‚Äôs attorney did not immediately respond to a reporter‚Äôs message seeking comment. In a statement, U.S. Capitol Police Chief Tom Manger said the department learned of the investigation against Riley several weeks ago and placed him on administrative leave when he was arrested Friday. Manger called the indictment a ‚Äúvery serious allegation‚Äù and said the department‚Äôs Office of Professional Responsibility was also opening an internal investigation. His arrest and the accusation that an active duty Capitol Police officer was trying to obstruct the investigation into the attack is particularly notable because many of his colleagues were brutally beaten in the insurrection. The riot left dozens of police officers bloodied and bruised as the crowd of pro-Trump rioters, some armed with pipes, bats and bear spray, charged into the Capitol, quickly overrunning the overwhelmed police force. One officer was beaten and shocked with a stun gun repeatedly until he had a heart attack; another was foaming at the mouth and screaming for help as rioters crushed him between two doors and bashed him in the head with his own weapon. More than 600 people face charges in the Jan. 6 attack, in which a mob loyal to then-President Donald Trump stormed the Capitol, battled police and tried to stop the certification of the election victory for President Joe Biden. In the days after the attack,¬†scores of rioters flaunted their participation in social media posts that bragged about their ability to get inside the Capitol. But then many started realizing it could be used as evidence and began deleting it. An¬†Associated Press review of court records¬†has found that at least 49 defendants are accused of trying to erase incriminating photos, videos and texts from phones or social media accounts documenting their conduct as the pro-Trump mob stormed Congress and briefly interrupted the certification of Democrat Joe Biden‚Äôs election victory. Experts say the efforts to scrub the social media accounts reveal a desperate willingness to manipulate evidence once these people realized they were in hot water. They say it can serve as powerful proof of people‚Äôs consciousness of guilt and can make it harder to negotiate plea deals and seek leniency at sentencing. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Riley told the rioter that the scene was a ‚Äútotal s‚Äîshow.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you got out of there unscathed. We had over 50 officers hurt, some pretty bad,‚Äù the officer wrote, according to the complaint. When the rioter said through messaging that he didn‚Äôt think he‚Äôd done anything wrong, Riley responded, according to court papers: ‚ÄúThe only thing I can see is if you went into the building and they have proof you will be charged. You could always articulate that you had nowhere to go, but that‚Äôs for court.‚Äù Later in January, after two had discussed their love of fishing, Riley told the man to get off social media. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre arresting dozens of people a day,‚Äù he wrote, according to the posting. ‚ÄúEveryone that was in the building. Engaged in violent acts or destruction of property and they‚Äôre all being charged federally with felonies.‚Äù Making digital content vanish isn‚Äôt as easy as deleting content from phones, removing social media posts or shutting down accounts. Investigators have been able to retrieve the digital content by requesting it from social media companies, even after accounts are shut down. Posts made on Facebook, Instagram and other social media platforms are recoverable for a certain period of time, and authorities routinely ask those companies to preserve the records until they get court orders to view the posts. Despite initial criticism that Capitol police did not do enough to stop the rioters, Riley is the first Capitol police officer to be charged with a crime involving the insurrection. But several current and former police officers were arrested on riot-related charges, including two Virginia police officers who posed for a photo during the attack. In July, authorities arrested an off-duty Drug Enforcement Administration agent accused of posing for photographs in which he flashed his DEA badge and firearm outside the Capitol during the riot. Other law enforcement officers were investigated for their presence at the Capitol that day or at Trump‚Äôs rally before the riot. In January, an Associated Press survey of law enforcement agencies nationwide found that at least 31 officers in 12 states are being scrutinized by their supervisors for their behavior in the District of Columbia or face criminal charges for participating in the riot. In September, Capitol Police said officials¬†had recommended disciplinary action¬†in six cases after an internal review of officer behavior stemming from the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. The department‚Äôs Office of Professional Responsibility had opened 38 internal investigations and was able to identify 26 of the officers involved, police said in a statement at the time. In 20 of the cases, no wrongdoing was found. It isn‚Äôt clear whether Riley was among the officers who were referred for disciplinary action. ___ Associated Press writers Jacques Billeaud in Phoneix and Michael Kunzelman in College Park, Md. contributed to this report. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized (¬©¬† Copyright ¬†2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: David Boreanaz On ‚ÄòSEAL Team‚Äô Becoming A Paramount+ Original: ‚ÄòGet To Invest In Some Deeper Subject Matters, You Really Get The Plus Aspect Of It‚Äô
summary: David Boreanaz discusses season 5 of 'SEAL Team' coming to Paramount+.
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì¬† Season five of  SEAL Team  is underway and the tactical military drama is also now a Paramount+ original. In episode one of season five, ‚ÄúTrust But Verify: Part 1,‚Äù Jason Hayes (David Boreanaz) and Bravo Team underwent a training exercise that turns into a full-blown mission to smuggle a weapons expert out of hostile territory. CBS‚Äô Matt Weiss spoke to Boreanaz about Jason Hayes mental state, moving to  Paramount+  and what‚Äôs in store for viewers with ‚ÄúTrust But Verify: Part 2‚Äù coming up on Sunday night. READ MORE:  David Boreanaz On ‚ÄòSEAL Team‚Äôs Authenticity: ‚ÄòWe Do It In A Way That Is Very Detail Oriented, We Take Pride In That‚Äô MW-  Good to see you again David!  SEAL Team  season five, episode two comes out this Sunday but before we get into that I want to talk about the big switch to becoming a Paramount+ original. How much does this shift change the way you‚Äôre able to create the show? DB-  You know it‚Äôs interesting because the show to begin with is so intense, what we do on the network and how we push the envelope and the level of authenticity for it to begin with. Now with moving over to Paramount+ you really get the plus aspect of it. You get to see a little bit more, you get to invest in some deeper subject matters with the characters. That‚Äôs just the way it is today, streaming is the world and we are happy and proud to be part of that platform. Each  SEAL Team  episode is a thrill ride I say to speak. You get the speed and efficiency of missions and operations and you see the ins and outs of of how these guys operate with weapons and tactical maneuvers and breaching doors. All that stuff is great but you also get the other half which is the mental component. You have all these compelling characters and how they deal with what‚Äôs going on inside the wire AND outside the wire. I‚Äôve always found that that is really the pulse of the show. For my character, Jason Hayes, you see this leader who takes  SEAL Team  into battle but he‚Äôs also got to understand them outside the wire. That really resonates with me and so we‚Äôll see that intensify more on Paramount+. MW-  The show does such a great job of addressing the mental health challenges that these men and women face. That, of course, includes Jason Hayes. It seemed like at the end of season four he was turning a corner for the better but these things don‚Äôt just completely flip over night. Where is Jason at right now with those issues? DB-  Well, we‚Äôll see at the end of episode two, a moment where the TBI starts to creep back into his world. It‚Äôs a simple kind of test that he gives himself and it doesn‚Äôt work out too well for him. That starts a spiral for him. With the people in these situations it‚Äôs almost like they don‚Äôt want to address what‚Äôs going on. They want to continue to operate at full capacity and failure is not an option; even if they‚Äôre not operating a 100%. That‚Äôs a big struggle for Jason and that‚Äôs hard for him; that‚Äôs his life. It‚Äôs what he‚Äôs known to do and we‚Äôll see that unfold. At the end of episode two we have a sad moment which leads us into three which is the 9/11 episode. That mental health topic will continue with all the members throughout the season and in particular with Jason we will see him meet his father, he‚Äôll find the root of his trauma and in episode 12 he takes a big ayahuasca journey, which I‚Äôm really excited to do. When people think of ayahuasca they thing it‚Äôs just to drug out but it‚Äôs used today to help mental capacity and mental health. READ MORE:  ‚ÄòBlue Bloods‚Äô Vanessa Ray And Will Estes Discuss The ‚ÄòTremendous Responsibility‚Äô Of Playing Cops Organic Mushrooms, or whatever you may say, is now actually helping to battle depression and fight these mental distress problems. These men and women are suffering and we‚Äôll dive into that and that‚Äôs exciting for me to play this character and to do those types of things. The journey is going to lead him down to a path of finding the root of his trauma, trying to understand it and become a better person, a better leader overall. MW-  Episode one of season five was called ‚ÄúTrust Buy Verify: Part 1‚Äù and now episode two ‚ÄúTrust But Verify: Part 2.‚Äù That phrase really stuck out to me, is that going to be a theme for the whole season? DB-  Yeah, we always kick things off that way with the first episode setting the tone and I think that‚Äôs a really great thematic took. I think it helps the viewer saying this is what you have in store for the season. MW-  So what‚Äôs in store for part two on Sunday night? DB-  So this mission in North Korea is definitely different It‚Äôs not a capture/kill it‚Äôs a capture/save operation for Bravo team. What‚Äôs unique about that is the intensity is so high that we‚Äôre not going to be able to fire a single weapon. We‚Äôre not going to be going in there weapons blazing, we have to get in and out as fast as we can. Going back to the character development, we‚Äôll also see how TBI is going to play a very big role in this episode and onward for the rest of the season. MW-  Well I love the show so I‚Äôm excited to see how everything unfolds. Thank you for the time today and all the best David! DB-  Thanks Matt, take care! MORE NEWS:  https://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2020/12/02/seal-team-david-boreanaz-season-4-premiere/ SEAL Team  airs this Sunday, October 17th at 10:30PM ET/PT on CBS and is also available to stream with Paramount+. Check your local listings for more information.

headline: COVID-19 In Maryland: 936 New Cases Reported As Key Metrics Still Decline
summary: Maryland reported 936 new COVID-19 cases and 21 new deaths, according to state health department data released Saturday morning.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland reported 936 new COVID-19 cases and 21 new deaths, according to state health department data released Saturday morning. The percentage of people testing positive decreased slightly by 0.1% to 3.69%. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Doctors say the new cases are fueled by dangerous strains targeting the unvaccinated. During an August press conference, Gov. Larry Hogan said the Delta variant, a strain that is reportedly two to four times more contagious than the original virus strain, accounts for nearly every new confirmed case in Maryland. ‚ÄúThe vaccines are without a doubt our single most effective tool to mitigate the threat of COVID-19 and the surging Delta variant, and Maryland‚Äôs vaccination rate continues to outpace the nation,‚Äù Hogan said. More than 3.96 million Maryland adults are fully vaccinated. Hospitalizations decreased by 38 to 691. Of those hospitalized, 514 remain in acute care and 177 are in the ICU. Since the pandemic began, there were 549,679 total confirmed cases and 10,471 deaths. There are 3,960,647 Marylanders fully vaccinated. The state has administered 8,183,809 doses. Of those, 4,016,087 are first doses with 5,081 administered in the past 24 hours. They have given out 3,652,957 second doses, 4,975 in the last day. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of people who have rolled up their sleeves, Maryland continues to be one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan of the eight million milestone mark. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù The state began to administer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine again in April after the CDC and FDA lifted their pause on the vaccine due to a rare blood clot found in some women. A total of 306,694 Marylanders have received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 316 in the last day. On September 24, after the CDC granted final approval for Pfizer‚Äôs booster, Gov. Hogan announced the immediate authorization of the booster shot for Marylanders who have received their second Pfizer shot at least six months ago. Hogan  had already approved use  for vulnerable populations in early September. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The state has administered 181,261 additional or booster vaccine doses, 9,957 in the last day. The state reported 84.7% of all adults in Maryland have received at least one dose of the vaccine. In August, the state launched a post-vaccination infections dashboard that is updated every Wednesday. There have been 25,476 total cases among fully vaccinated Marylanders as of last Wednesday, October 13. Less than 0.71% of fully vaccinated Marylanders have later tested positive. Of those cases, 1,842 vaccinated Marylanders were hospitalized, representing 10.8% of all Covid cases hospitalized in the state. 233 fully vaccinated Marylanders have died, representing 8.36% of lab-confirmed Covid deaths in the state. headline: Ribbon-Cutting Ceremony In Montgomery County Celebrated Reopening Of The Germantown Public Library
summary: The Germantown public library in Montgomery County reopened Saturday with a ribbon-cutting ceremony and celebration.
bodytext: MONTGOMERY COUNTY, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî¬† The Germantown public library in Montgomery County reopened Saturday with a ribbon-cutting ceremony and celebration. The branch was closed for renovations and this event marked the official reopening. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúI am pleased the Germantown Library has now reopened its doors to the community,‚Äù said County Executive Elrich. ‚ÄúThe entire facility has a more spacious, modern look while maintaining the warm, welcoming feel of a community library. The MCPL Refresh Program allows the branches to be refurbished and be updated at less cost and downtime than building new libraries. Come stop by and see the new look!‚Äù Some of the new changes that came to the library when it was closed include new ergonomic sit-stand circulation and information desks, renovation of the new public restrooms, upgraded lighting and a new shelving area. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúIt is a pleasure to cut the ribbon for this newly refreshed Germantown Branch,‚Äù said Anita Vassallo, Director of Public Libraries. ‚ÄúOur library staff has worked hard to get the library ready, and the Department of General Services staff have done an outstanding job on the capital project improvements. The library looks great, and I know the Germantown area residents are going to enjoy the enhanced features.‚Äù The Germantown refurbishment cost $1.1 million. ‚ÄúThe Department of General Services is pleased to return this refreshed library to its dedicated patrons who will enjoy this improved, updated building,‚Äù said David Dise, Department of General Services Director. ‚ÄúThe ‚ÄòLibrary Refresh‚Äô program keeps our branches modernized and in good repair while saving our residents tens of thousands of dollars.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The library was made available to the public following the ceremony. For more information about the changes made to the library go to¬† Germantown Library Refurbishment (montgomerycountymd.gov) .

headline: Baltimore County Urges People To Get Vaccinated With Super Weekend Flu Clinic
summary: The flu season is fast approaching and health officials are warning of a possible "Twindemic" of both COVID-19 and the flu, especially during the winter months, making vaccination against both diseases more important than ever.
bodytext: BALTIMORE COUNTY, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  The flu season is fast approaching, and health officials are warning of a possible ‚ÄúTwindemic‚Äù of both COVID-19 and the flu, especially during the winter months, making vaccination against both diseases more important than ever. It‚Äôs why Baltimore County is holding its annual Super Weekend flu vaccination clinic. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúWe need to get our vaccines, not only for COVID but for our flu shots because we do not want a twindemic,‚Äù said Dr. Gregory Branch, Director of Health & Human Services for Baltimore County. The County hosted four clinics on Saturday and on Sunday, Oct. 17, clinics are scheduled at the Drumcastle Government Center, Lansdowne Middle School, Middle River Middle School and Pikesville Middle School, from 9 a.m. until noon. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in all the different neighborhoods, I‚Äôm quite sure we‚Äôre in a neighborhood closest to you,‚Äù Dr. Branch said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall At Drumcastle Government Center Saturday, 97-year-old Doris Hawkins was there to get her flu shot, just like every year. Her daughter, Janic Green, drove her. Green said her mother looks forward to her shot and seeing the nurse who gives it, Colleen. ‚ÄúColleen looks forward to us and we look forward to seeing her,‚Äù Green said. And as the flu season approaches, Doctor Branch said it‚Äôs important to remember the flu fact; ‚Äúfrequently wash your hands, always get your vaccination, cover your cough, take time off of work and school if you are sick and if you don‚Äôt get better, seek additional help,‚Äù he listed. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Although walk-ins are welcome, appointments are recommended to get a flu shot. Residents can book a slot by visiting  baltimorecountymd.gov/flu ¬†or calling the Department of Health at 410-887-3816.

headline: A Dad Who Traveled 1,200 Miles For Covid-19 Care Is Finally Going Home. Here‚Äôs What He Wants You To Know
summary: Robby Walker is alive -- a feat some doctors didn't expect two months ago. And while the 52-year-old struggles to speak long sentences, he's now using his voice to try to prevent others from suffering the way he did.
bodytext: ¬†(CNN) ‚Äî  These days, brushing his teeth while standing up is a major accomplishment. But Robby Walker is alive ‚Äî a feat some doctors didn‚Äôt expect two months ago. And while the 52-year-old struggles to speak long sentences, he‚Äôs now using his voice to try to prevent others from suffering the way he did. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The Florida father of six was unvaccinated and gravely ill as Covid-19 pneumonia ravaged both his lungs in August. ‚ÄúHe is in dire need of an¬† ECMO ¬†treatment, which is not available at the hospital that he is in,‚Äù his wife Susan Walker told CNN at the time. ECMO treatment uses an¬†external machine that can function as the body‚Äôs heart and lungs. It can be used for¬†organ transplant¬†patients, victims of ¬†severe heart attacks ¬†and seriously ill Covid-19 patients ‚Äî¬†including young adults. Family members¬†called 169 hospitals¬†in several states, but there was no ECMO availability for Robby. ‚ÄúAll the beds are taken up by Covid victims also getting ECMO treatment,‚Äù Susan said in a CNN interview. Then a doctor¬†in Connecticut saw Susan‚Äôs emotional interview¬†and decided to help. Now, after three weeks on ECMO and a month learning how to walk again, Robby returned to Florida this week ‚Äî with a new mission. ¬† A different life after Covid-19 ¬† Before Robby fell ill in July, he was a strong and sturdy construction business owner who worked out at the gym and ran 5 miles every day. ‚ÄúFifty-two years, I‚Äôve done pretty much whatever I wanted,‚Äù Robby told CNN. ‚ÄúNow, I‚Äôm very limited.‚Äù Scarred lungs and reduced lung capacity means he can only speak in short, choppy sentences before having to catch his breath. He also lost more than 50 pounds while hospitalized as his muscles eroded. Even brushing his teeth is now a struggle. ‚ÄúSitting in a chair, it‚Äôs probably a 5- or 6-minute ordeal,‚Äù Robby said. ‚ÄúIf I stand, then I have to take a break between. So it‚Äôs a little longer,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt takes a lot more energy to hold yourself up. I can go from sitting in a chair to standing, and my heart rate will jump 20, 30 beats a minute.‚Äù After his ECMO treatment at Connecticut‚Äôs Saint Francis Hospital, Robby spent a month in physical therapy at Gaylord Speciality Healthcare about 30 miles away. He relearned how to walk and practiced basic self-care with the help of an assistant. But he still needs a walker to move around, and small tasks can be draining ‚Äî even after taking a break. ‚ÄúOnce your heart rate comes down and your breathing gets straight, you‚Äôre still just exhausted,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPhysically. It just takes a lot of energy to do.‚Äù But the fact he‚Äôs even alive is worth celebrating. ¬† ‚ÄòThey told me he was dying‚Äô ¬† Robby called his wife on July 25 from his hospital bed in Florida and told her he had made a gut-wrenching decision. ‚ÄúHe had signed the papers to be intubated,‚Äù Susan said. Some Covid-19 patients who get put on ventilators don‚Äôt survive the disease. Their final calls to their families before intubation are their last. ‚ÄúHe cried and just told me how regretful he was of not getting the shot,‚Äù Susan said. ‚ÄúAnd he begged me to go get vaccinated.‚Äù She did. But it was too late to protect her husband, whose condition kept deteriorating. ‚ÄúThey told me he was dying,‚Äù Susan said. And the ECMO treatment Robby needed wasn‚Äôt available. Susan told her story to CNN in August. Hours later, a doctor 1,200 miles away was checking his Facebook feed and saw a CNN post with a video clip of Susan‚Äôs interview. ‚ÄúI just clicked on it and watched it and ‚Ä¶ it was pretty compelling,‚Äù said Dr. Robert Gallagher, chief of cardiothoracic surgery at Trinity Health of New England. Cardiothoracic surgeons operate on diseases in the chest, including in the heart and lungs. By the time Covid-19 patients reach Gallagher, they‚Äôre usually in dire condition ‚Äî and often in need of ECMO. He forwarded Susan‚Äôs interview to the chief¬† perfusionist , who runs the ECMO machines. And she immediately wanted to help. ‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòOK, how are we going to find this family?'‚Äù Angela Sakal, the chief perfusionist at Saint Francis Hospital in Connecticut, told CNN. She contacted a friend in Florida who‚Äôs savvy on social media. ‚ÄúAnd within a couple of hours, she had Susan‚Äôs phone number,‚Äù Sakal said. Within two days, Susan hired a medical evacuation team to fly Robby from Florida to Connecticut ‚Äî intubated, sedated and near death. When Sakal first saw Robby, she wasn‚Äôt sure he would survive. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt guarantee you an outcome,‚Äù she recalled telling Susan. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what the future is going to be. But I can promise you that we‚Äôre going to do the best that we can for him.‚Äù ECMO is sometimes used as a last resort for critically ill Covid-19 patients with failing lungs. It removes blood from the body, eliminates carbon dioxide and adds oxygen to the blood, then pumps the blood back into the body so the lungs might have a chance to recover. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Gallagher inserted the ECMO tubes in Robby‚Äôs neck. And over the next 22 days, Sakal oversaw Robby‚Äôs ECMO treatment. ¬† Younger Covid-19 patients are needing ECMO ¬† Robby isn‚Äôt the only previously healthy Covid-19 patient Sakal has seen needing ECMO. With the rise of the Delta variant, Sakal said some ECMO patients have been in their 20s. ‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre finding is our Covid patients ‚Äî even the young ones ‚Äî are single organ failure (and) previously healthy,‚Äù Sakal said. ‚ÄúAnd the Covid is just destroying their lungs.‚Äù Not everyone who goes on ECMO survives. But after three weeks of getting his blood extracted and returned, Robby‚Äôs lungs had recovered enough to support him again. He was discharged from Saint Francis in mid-September and started a month of inpatient rehabilitation at Gaylord Specialty Healthcare. ‚ÄúMy lungs have gotten a little bit better, (but) my heart rate still races a little bit,‚Äù Robby said this week. ‚ÄúI can walk by myself ‚Äî somebody‚Äôs there just kind of making sure I‚Äôm staying straight. But I use a roller/walker, and I‚Äôm able to walk a decent distance,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI mean, I‚Äôm not going to the mall or going shopping. But I‚Äôm able to walk some now. So it‚Äôs been a big improvement.‚Äù After a month of difficult work relearning basic skills, Robby was released from rehab Wednesday. Most of his ECMO team from Saint Francis Hospital traveled to Gaylord to see him off to Florida. Sakal was there. She fought back tears as she visited her former patient. ‚ÄúI remember when he first got here,‚Äù she said Wednesday. ‚ÄúAnd I watched him today, standing up and talking and walking. It was amazing. It was just awesome.‚Äù ¬† A new life filled with uncertainty and lessons learned ¬† Robby‚Äôs two brothers rented an RV and drove up to Connecticut to bring him and Susan home. The drive would take more than 24 hours. As he traveled back to Florida to restart his life, Robby said the first thing he wanted was his wife‚Äôs homemade chicken pot pie. But many other aspects of his former life will be different. It‚Äôs not clear when Robby might be able to go to work again, as he still needs months more of rehabilitation. The family also has no idea how much of the $1.5 million in medical bills racked up so far in Florida and Connecticut they will owe ‚Äî or how exactly they will pay it. A family friend set up¬† a GoFundMe account to help with Robby‚Äôs medical expenses . And Robby doesn‚Äôt know whether he‚Äôll be able to return to all the activities he loved. ‚ÄúMy goal is to get hopefully 80% or 90% to where I was,‚Äù he said. But ‚Äúthey just don‚Äôt know enough about this to give any kind of definitive answers.‚Äù For now, he won‚Äôt be able to go fishing or work out at the gym every day. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a lot of strength,‚Äù he said, joking about fishing: ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt want anything to pull me over the reel.‚Äù But what he lacks in physical ability, he‚Äôs gained in new wisdom ‚Äî especially when it comes to Covid-19 and vaccines. Robby‚Äôs ordeal has inspired more than 100 friends, relatives and acquaintances to get vaccinated ‚Äî¬†including some who were extremely hesitant, Susan said. Robby said the reason he and Susan didn‚Äôt get vaccinated earlier was due to ‚Äúa lack of education on our part.‚Äù With countless rumors and claims spread on social media, ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt know what to believe anymore,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúA lot of that was ignorance on our part, for not doing more research.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe thought that the vaccine was something that was created in a year or two. So we felt like there wasn‚Äôt enough information,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut through this journey that I‚Äôve had, we‚Äôve discovered that (mRNA vaccine research)¬†has actually been around for 20-plus years.‚Äù He also wrongly assumed that he wouldn‚Äôt get severely sick. ‚ÄúI just thought it would be like a flu. I thought that it was something that affected people with underlying conditions. I had none,‚Äù Robby said. ‚ÄúBut for whatever reason, it affected me differently. And if I had to do it over again, I would have gotten my vaccination when it was available to me.‚Äù After he left the hospital, Robby received his first dose of the Moderna vaccine. He had some side effects for a day, he said, but they weren‚Äôt nearly as bad as his Covid-19 symptoms. ‚ÄúThere was a little fever ‚Ä¶ my first few days of Covid, I had a bigger fever than that,‚Äù Robby said. ‚ÄúI just had no energy. I did run a fever for probably a day, day and a half. But nothing horrible compared to everything else I‚Äôve gone through.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The-CNN-Wire  ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2021 Cable News Network, Inc., a WarnerMedia Company. All rights reserved.

headline: Lamar Jackson‚Äôs No. 8 Retired At The University Of Louisville
summary: Lamar Jackson thought today was going to be another meeting with the media, but he was overjoyed and emotional when he realized his college number was getting retired.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Lamar Jackson thought today was going to be another meeting with the media, but he was overjoyed when he realized his college number was getting retired.     ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs unreal. You can‚Äôt really put that in words.‚Äù    ‚ÄúI ain‚Äôt gonna cry on camera though.‚Äù üòÇ @Lj_Era8  was emotional when he found out  @UofLFootball  was retiring his jersey number.  @GoCards   pic.twitter.com/FRuEb1l3DI   ‚Äî Baltimore Ravens (@Ravens)  October 16, 2021     During his time in college, Jackson broke a number of records. One of these includes being the youngest player to win the Heisman trophy in 2016 at the age of 19 and 337 days.  According to ESPN , he was also the first player to win the trophy with at least 30 touchdown passes and at least 21 rushing touchdowns.   Jackson set or tied 42-single game records during his three years in Louisville.   Nov. 13 is the day the number will be officially retired at the University of Louisville. Jackson is expected to attend as the Ravens play the Miami Dolphins that week.

headline: American Airlines Plane Blows Tires On Runway Leaving Flights Diverted And Runways Closed At Regan National
summary: Passengers were inconvenienced at American Airlines after a plane blew tires. Passengers had to be bussed to a terminal at Ronald Regan Washington National Airport according to a Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî¬† Passengers were inconvenienced at American Airlines after a plane blew tires. Passengers had to be bussed to a terminal at Ronald Regan Washington National Airport according to a Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority. Two runways were shut down and flights were diverted as a result. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Around 4 p.m. on Saturday, American Airlines flight 4965 arriving from Memphis, Tennessee, stopped on the runway, causing a response from Airports Authority Fire and Rescue. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Before the tires blew out, the plane landed safely at Regan National according to a spokesperson. No injuries were reported. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The spokesperson added that passengers were moved from the plane to the terminal, and two of the airport‚Äôs three runways were temporarily closed by Air Traffic Control as crews assessed the situation.   ‚ÄúAmerican Eagle flight 4965, operated by Republic Airways‚Ä¶ experienced a mechanical issue upon landing at DCA,‚Äù American Airlines said in a statement. ‚ÄúAll passengers were bussed to the terminal.‚Äù   Many flights will be diverted to Dulles International Airport and Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport.

headline: COVID-19 In Maryland: More Than 800 New Cases & 5 Deaths Reported Sunday
summary: Maryland reported 871 new COVID-19 cases and 5 new deaths, according to state health department data released Sunday morning.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland reported 871 new COVID-19 cases and 5 new deaths, according to state health department data released Sunday morning. The percentage of people testing positive decreased slightly by 0.25% to 3.44%. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Doctors say the new cases are fueled by dangerous strains targeting the unvaccinated. During an August press conference, Gov. Larry Hogan said the Delta variant, a strain that is reportedly two to four times more contagious than the original virus strain, accounts for nearly every new confirmed case in Maryland. ‚ÄúThe vaccines are without a doubt our single most effective tool to mitigate the threat of COVID-19 and the surging Delta variant, and Maryland‚Äôs vaccination rate continues to outpace the nation,‚Äù Hogan said. More than 3.96 million Maryland adults are fully vaccinated. Hospitalizations decreased by 10 to 681. Of those hospitalized, 500 remain in acute care and 181 are in the ICU. Since the pandemic began, there were 550,550 total confirmed cases and 10,476 deaths. There are 3,964,072 Marylanders fully vaccinated. The state has administered 8,196,251 doses. Of those, 4,017,857 are first doses with 1,770 administered in the past 24 hours. They have given out 3,656,119 second doses, 3,162 in the last day. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of people who have rolled up their sleeves, Maryland continues to be one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan of the eight million milestone mark. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù The state began to administer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine again in April after the CDC and FDA lifted their pause on the vaccine due to a rare blood clot found in some women. A total of 307,953 Marylanders have received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 263 in the last day. On September 24, after the CDC granted final approval for Pfizer‚Äôs booster, Gov. Hogan announced the immediate authorization of the booster shot for Marylanders who have received their second Pfizer shot at least six months ago. Hogan  had already approved use  for vulnerable populations in early September. The state has administered 214,322 additional or booster vaccine doses, 7,247 in the last day. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The state reported 85.2% of all adults in Maryland have received at least one dose of the vaccine. In August, the state launched a post-vaccination infections dashboard that is updated every Wednesday. There have been 25,476 total cases among fully vaccinated Marylanders as of last Wednesday, October 13. Less than 0.71% of fully vaccinated Marylanders have later tested positive. Of those cases, 1,842 vaccinated Marylanders were hospitalized, representing 10.8% of all Covid cases hospitalized in the state. 233 fully vaccinated Marylanders have died, representing 8.36% of lab-confirmed Covid deaths in the state. headline: Man Shot, Killed In A Timonium Bowling Alley
summary: Baltimore County detectives are investigating a homicide that took place shortly after 11 p.m. on October 15.
bodytext: TIMONIUM, Md. (WJZ)‚Äì¬†  Baltimore County detectives are investigating a homicide that took place shortly after 11 p.m. on October 15.¬†¬†Officers responded to calls from Bowlero in the 2100 block of York Road, Timonium.   Upon arrival, officers discovered 48-year-old Anthony Cooper suffering from at least one gunshot wound to his upper body. ¬†Cooper was pronounced dead at the scene. ¬†Witnesses have told police that there was a dispute between Cooper and other subjects at the bowling alley before shots were fired.¬†¬†At least one suspect fled the scene prior to police arrival.   As Baltimore County homicide detectives continue their investigation surrounding this murder, they are asking anyone with information on the incident to contact them by calling  410-307-2020 . ¬†Callers may remain anonymous.   Follow  @WJZ  on Twitter and like  WJZ-TV | CBS Baltimore  on Facebook

headline: Ravens Shut Down Herbert, Chargers In 34-6 Victory
summary: Lamar Jackson threw for 167 yards and a touchdown, and the Baltimore Ravens frustrated Justin Herbert and the Los Angeles Chargers in a 34-6 victory Sunday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (AP)  ‚Äî Lamar Jackson threw for 167 yards and a touchdown, and the Baltimore Ravens frustrated Justin Herbert and the Los Angeles Chargers in a 34-6 victory Sunday. A week after scoring 47 points in a win over Cleveland, the Chargers (4-2) came up empty on their first five possessions and were held under 16 points for only the second time since drafting Herbert before last season. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The Ravens completely controlled this matchup of division leaders. Each of Baltimore‚Äôs three veteran running backs ‚Äî Latavius Murray, Le‚ÄôVeon Bell and Devonta Freeman ‚Äî scored a touchdown. Jackson went 19 of 27 with two interceptions. Herbert was 22 of 39 for 195 yards with a touchdown and an interception. Although the much-anticipated clash between these two talented quarterbacks didn‚Äôt live up to expectations, Baltimore won with a total team effort. The Ravens set the tone on their first possession, driving 90 yards on 12 plays in 6:39 and taking the lead on a 14-yard run by Murray. The Chargers entered the game with the NFL‚Äôs worst run defense, and Baltimore finished with 187 yards on the ground ‚Äî a week after the Ravens had their record-tying streak of 43 straight 100-yard rushing games snapped. Bell‚Äôs 2-yard scoring run early in the second quarter put Baltimore up 14-0. Los Angeles punted on its first three possessions, then turned the ball over on downs. Then Herbert was intercepted for the first time since Week 2. He‚Äôd thrown 11 touchdown passes over the previous three games, while the Chargers totaled 105 points. Jackson threw an interception immediately after Herbert‚Äôs, and only then ‚Äî after taking over on the Baltimore 27 ‚Äî did the Chargers score. Herbert‚Äôs 1-yard touchdown pass to Jared Cook made it 17-6. The Ravens got the ball first in the second half, and after a long kickoff return, they went 52 yards in 12 plays, using up nearly half of the third quarter and going ahead 24-6 on Jackson‚Äôs 9-yard touchdown pass to Mark Andrews. The Ravens‚Äô methodical approach ‚Äî and the Chargers‚Äô difficulty stopping the run ‚Äî led to a significant gap in time of possession. Baltimore held the ball for just over 38 minutes. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Los Angeles was 7 of 8 on fourth-down attempts entering the game, but when Chargers rookie coach Brandon Staley tried to be aggressive against Baltimore, it backfired. Los Angeles went for it on fourth-and-3 from its own 39 in the second quarter, then on fourth-and-1 from its own 19 in the third. Herbert threw incomplete both times, leading to two Baltimore field goals. Freeman scored on a 9-yard run at the start of the fourth to make it 34-6. INJURIES Murray left in the third quarter with an ankle injury, and Ravens center Bradley Bozeman left with a back injury on the first drive of the second half. UP NEXT Chargers: Los Angeles has next weekend off before hosting New England on Oct. 31. The Chargers lost 45-0 to the Patriots last season. Ravens: Baltimore hosts Cincinnati next Sunday before its bye week. headline: Baltimore Man, 23, Identified As Victim Of Deadly Annapolis Shooting
summary: Police have identified the victim of Thursday's deadly shooting in Annapolis as a Baltimore man, authorities said Friday.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police have identified the victim of  Thursday‚Äôs deadly shooting in Annapolis  as a Baltimore man, authorities said Friday. Cornell Young, 23, was found shot about 1 p.m. by officers investigating a report of a shooting in the unit block of Pleasant Street, according to the Annapolis Police Department. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Young was taken to an area hospital but did not survive, police said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall There‚Äôs no word yet on a suspect or motive in the deadly shooting. Those who wish to remain anonymous can call Metro Crime Stoppers at 1-866-7LOCKUP.

headline: Court Delays Detention Hearing In Annapolis Couple‚Äôs Espionage Case
summary: A detention hearing for the Annapolis couple facing espionage charges related to a plot to sell military secrets to a foreign intelligence away has been postponed until next week.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A detention hearing for the  Annapolis couple facing espionage charges  related to a plot to sell military secrets to a foreign intelligence away has been postponed until next week. Jonathan Toebbe, 42, a Navy nuclear engineer, and his wife, Diana, 45, were set to appear Friday in federal court in West Virginia to determine whether they would go free while awaiting trial or remain in custody because they present a flight risk. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School According to court records, the detention hearing has been pushed back until Wednesday afternoon. That hearing will now coincide with a preliminary hearing to decide if probable cause exists for the charges the couple face. The Toebbes are each charged with communication of restricted data and conspiracy to commit restricted data, violations of the Atomic Energy Act. Jonathan Toebbe is accused of trading sensitive data on nuclear submarine design to someone he thought was a foreign intelligence asset but was actually an undercover federal agent. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Toebbe spent several months dropping off memory cards containing that data at ‚Äúdead drop‚Äù sites in Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia, at times accompanied by his wife who acted as a lookout, according to charging documents. Authorities say he was paid $100,000 in cryptocurrency during the course of the FBI sting operation, a fraction of the $5 million sum he was allegedly seeking in return for the military data. The Toebbes were arrested Saturday in West Virginia, where they‚Äôve been held in federal custody while awaiting court proceedings in the case. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Each of the charges carries a maximum sentence of life in prison, a $100,000 fine and a five-year term of supervised release.

headline: Vaccine Policy For Baltimore City Employees Begins Monday
summary: It's the latest stringent approach to fighting the COVID-19 pandemic and reaching the vaccine-hesitant population.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)‚Äì  It‚Äôs the latest stringent approach to fighting the COVID-19 pandemic and reaching the vaccine-hesitant population.     ‚ÄúThis is about leading by example, protecting the health of our workforce,‚Äù said Mayor Brandon Scott.     Starting Monday, anyone employed by the city must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or face weekly testing.     ‚ÄúI‚Äôm all for it, I‚Äôve been vaccinated. I work in education,‚Äù said Todd Evans, Baltimore City resident.     A move supported by some city employees like Evans.     ‚ÄúI think mandates are.. it seems like the only way to try to get people to do this because people just aren‚Äôt for whatever reason have decided it‚Äôs not the way out,‚Äù said Evans.     But has also received pushback from Baltimore‚Äôs Fire and Police Union.     ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs weekly testing going to work?‚Äù It‚Äôs supposed to be on duty, if you have multiple people working on a fire engine, how do they all get tested while working,‚Äù said Joshua Fannon, Union President of Baltimore Fire Officers Local 964.     This comes as Maryland‚Äôs key COVID metrics are declining. Sunday, the state reported 871 new COVID-19 cases and five deaths.     The statewide positivity rate dropped slightly to 3.44 percent.     ‚ÄúI understand we need to get to herd immunity so people need to be careful when they are inside and they need to get the vaccine,‚Äù said Bart Stocksdale, Baltimore City resident.     ‚ÄúThe 18 to 29‚Äôs, in general, are sort of on the lower end of getting the vaccine if we think about vaccination coverage in the United States,‚Äù said Rupali Limaye, Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.     Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health is continuing its work to reach vaccine-hesitant young adults.     ‚ÄúOne of the things that‚Äôs really important is who are the messengers? People are less trusting official sources, they trust their friends and family,‚Äù said Caleb Hellerman, medical journalist and documentary filmmaker.     Leaders are focusing on different strategies to communicate and empower the younger population who have not yet received a COVID-19 vaccine.     ‚ÄúGet the vaccine so you can be safe to see your family,‚Äù said Nick Moran, Associate Director of Audience Development, Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.     ‚ÄúShowing empathy to people and understanding the place their coming from, ¬†if they are mistrusting of information I think is really critical,‚Äù said Hellerman.     Right now, data shows nearly 85 percent of all adults in Maryland have received at least one dose of the shot. And nearly 3.9 million eligible Marylanders are fully vaccinated.
