headline: BARCS Seeking Blanket Donations For Cats & Dogs
summary: BARCS Animal Shelter is asking for the public to help their rescued animals by donating new blankets and comforters.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  BARCS Animal Shelter is asking for the public to help their rescued animals by donating new blankets and comforters.   The shelter took to Facebook on Monday asking for:     Baby-sized blankets or swaddled   Comforters (no feather-stuffed)   Bath size towels   Fleece blankets   Cotton blankets   Woven blankets       Donations  can be dropped off or mailed to their adoption center. Drop off times are from 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday through Friday and Saturday and Sunday from 8:30 a.m. until 4:30 p.m.   ¬†

headline: MVA To Provide Birth Certificates At Select Branches
summary: Those visiting the Baltimore City or Essex branches can request a certified copy of their birth certificate and have it printed onsite to provide as proof of identity to acquire a REAL ID ahead of the May 3, 2023 deadline.
bodytext: GLEN BURNIE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Officials announced Monday a new partnership between the Maryland Department of Transportation Motor Vehicle Administration and the Maryland Department of Health Division of Vital Records that will allow Maryland-born customers visiting select branches to request a certified copy of their birth certificate and have it printed onsite to provide as proof of identity to acquire a REAL ID. Those visiting the Baltimore City or Essex branches can request a certified copy of their birth certificate and have it printed onsite to provide as proof of identity to acquire a REAL ID ahead of the May 3, 2023 deadline. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúWe are always looking for opportunities to work with other state agencies to eliminate challenges for our customers,‚Äù said MDOT MVA Administrator Chrissy Nizer. ‚ÄúMarylanders are leading the nation in completing the federal REAL ID requirement, with more than 82% of residents already compliant. For those who still need to present documents, we hope this service will provide additional access and convenience.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The birth certificate pilot program began in 2021 at the Baltimore City location. Since its launch, more than 950 customers at that location and 61 customers in Essex have benefited from this partnership officials said. They added that the goal is to add other branch offices throughout the state. Birth certificate copies are $10 ‚ÄúThis partnership between MDH and MDOT will help provide Marylanders with the tools they need to meet REAL ID compliance by enhancing and maximizing convenience,‚Äù said MDH Assistant Secretary for Customer Experience Tara Hargadon. ‚ÄúBeing able to print and receive certified birth certificates in-house at MVA locations means individuals will have easier access to the documents they need, all in one location.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Howard County‚Äôs Body-Worn Camera Program Takes Step Forward
summary: Howard County is one step closer to equipping its police department with body-worn cameras.
bodytext: ELLICOTT CITY, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Howard County is one step closer to equipping its police department with body-worn cameras. Howard County Executive Calvin Ball announced Monday he has signed a budget amendment releasing nearly $500,000 needed to pay for the program, which was greenlit Oct. 4 by the County Council. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The nearly $500,000, combined with $1 million previously set aside by the county and $1.6 million in American Rescue Plan (ARP) funds, will pay for the county‚Äôs adoption of the estimated $3.1 million program. ‚ÄúI am pleased that the County Council unanimously approved my budget amendment to release these much needed public safety funds out of contingency,‚Äù Ball said. ‚ÄúThe use of County and American Rescue Plan funds will ensure that the body-worn camera program can be fully implemented before the end of the 2022 fiscal year. When this program is fully implemented, Howard County‚Äôs officers and our community will have another vital tool that helps uphold security, transparency, and justice for all.‚Äù RELATED:  Ball Announces Plans To Fund Body-Worn Cameras For Howard County Police Under the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, the Howard County Police Department is  one of four law enforcement agencies in the state that must have body cameras in place  by July 1, 2023. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The $3.1 million will be used to hire 26 positions within the police department, Howard County Sheriff‚Äôs Department and the State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs Office and to buy 600 body-worn cameras for the police department‚Äôs 300 officers. In addition, the funding will cover the costs of purchasing new storage capacity and software required for the body-worn camera program, as well as equipment for sheriff‚Äôs deputies. Some of that funding is expected to address findings identified during Howard County‚Äôs year-long pilot program, which found that a lack of funding, storage space and personnel were the chief barriers keeping the county from adopting body-worn cameras. Howard County Police Chief Lisa Meyers said body-worn cameras will add a layer of transparency and accountability for officers and citizens during their interactions. ‚ÄúThis program is the culmination of years of research and planning by many of our HCPD sworn and civilian staff,‚Äù Chief Meyers said. ‚ÄúWe are ready to hit the ground running, ordering and installing equipment, training officers, hiring administrative staff and tackling many other tasks to prepare for implementation in the months ahead.‚Äù Added Sheriff Marcus Harris: ‚ÄúProviding transparency and building trust with our community are two of my main objectives as a law enforcement leader. Body Worn Cameras are a tool in meeting those objectives. The Sheriff‚Äôs Office is ready to get the ball rolling by hiring new personnel, purchasing the required equipment and providing the necessary training for our deputies.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The county expects to purchase its body-worn cameras from Axon, the same vendor used during its pilot program.

headline: Tractor-Trailer Driver Arrested For Fleeing Police, Traveling In Wrong Direction On I-95
summary: Maryland State Police announced Monday that a tractor-trailer driver has been arrested after he traveled in the wrong direction while fleeing from police on I-95.
bodytext: EDGEWOOD, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland State Police announced Monday that a tractor-trailer driver has been arrested after he traveled in the wrong direction while fleeing from police on I-95. Maurice Cooper, 37, of Haverhill, Florida was taken into custody without incident. He faces attempted second-degree murder, first and second-degree assault, assault of a law enforcement officer, theft and other related traffic charges. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Officials said just before 12:30 p.m., troopers responded to the Maryland House Travel Plaza for a reported theft. There, they found a victim who told police his jacket and keys were stolen while he was inside the travel plaza. The victim notified police the suspect was the driver of a specific tractor-trailer. Police were advised of a tractor exiting the travel plaza on the wrong side. The vehicle was traveling south in the northbound lanes of I-95, driving against traffic. Troopers began to follow the tractor-trailer in an attempt to stop the driver while calling the barrack to request additional assistance. Officials said after nearly three miles, the driver stopped on the fast shoulder in an active work zone where several highway workers were working. According to authorities, through an open passenger side window, the trooper made several verbal requests for the driver to shift the truck into park and hand over his keys. The driver instead accelerated into the northbound lanes of I-95, again traveling south against northbound traffic. As the driver continued to accelerate after failing to listen to commands, the trooper was thrown from the truck onto the highway. He suffered minor injuries and refused medical treatment at the scene. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Preliminary information shows the driver continued to drive against traffic for nearly four more miles and crossed all lanes of northbound I-95 to the slow shoulder into a construction zone where he made a U-turn and continued north on I-95. An off-duty police officer, aware of the ongoing incident, followed the tractor-trailer as it exited off of I-95. A helicopter from the Baltimore County Police Department responded to assist and found the tractor-trailer as it pulled into a motel parking lot in¬† Edgewood. The driver then fled on foot into a wooded area behind the motel, according to witnesses. During the search of the area, police along with a K-9 from the Harford County Sheriff‚Äôs Office tracked the suspect. The suspect was found along the wood line and taken into custody. There were no reported crashes due to the tractor-trailer driving against traffic nor were any injuries sustained during the incident. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Cooper is currently awaiting an initial appearance before a court commissioner in Harford County.

headline: Maryland State Treasurer Nancy Kopp To Step Down After 50 Years Of Public Service
summary: Maryland State Nancy K. Kopp announced Monday that she plans to resign, after a 50-year career in public service, by the end of this year.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland State Nancy K. Kopp announced Monday that she plans to resign by the end of this year after a 50-year career in public service. Kopp is the second longest-serving state treasurer in Maryland and the second woman to serve in the role. She was first elected in Feb. 2002 and has been re-elected to five full four-year terms. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúServing as Maryland‚Äôs Treasurer has been a great privilege, as well as a terrific challenge. I have cherished the opportunity to serve and believe that, working together, we have made a real contribution to the benefit of our state and fellow citizens. Maryland is strong; a model of good, prudent fiscal management and investment,‚Äù said Treasurer Kopp. ‚ÄúWe have invested in our collective future ‚Äî in public education, great universities, a sound human and physical infrastructure, and in the many other ways in which we work to assure strong communities and decent lives for all Marylanders.‚Äù Following 50 years of public service, Kopp says she hopes to spend more time with her family and travel extensively. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Gov. Larry Hogan released a statement regarding Kopp‚Äôs resignation: ‚ÄúIt is difficult to imagine chairing a Board of Public Works meeting without Nancy Kopp. With the second-longest tenure of any treasurer in state history, Nancy will leave an incredible legacy of strong financial stewardship, which has helped assure our coveted AAA bond rating year after year. We have enjoyed a very cordial relationship, and I have always admired her commitment to the people of Maryland. On behalf of all Marylanders, I want to express my profound gratitude to Nancy Kopp for her decades of distinguished service and wish her well in retirement.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Maryland State law requires the Senate President and House Speaker to appoint a committee to review candidates for the opening. The process will begin in the coming weeks.   This afternoon, my longtime friend and colleague, Treasurer Nancy Kopp, met with me to share the news of her intention to step down as state treasurer. 1/4  pic.twitter.com/snzZjSZ4P1   ‚Äî Comptroller Peter Franchot (@peterfranchot)  October 18, 2021

headline: 14-Year-Old Alesha Henry Found Safe, Police Say
summary: Police said Alesha Henry was found safe.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police said Alesha Henry was found safe.   Cancel the lookout for Alesha Henry.  She has been located and is safe  https://t.co/pBXYZcAe3J   ‚Äî Baltimore Police (@BaltimorePolice)  October 19, 2021 ¬† READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School **ORIGINAL POST, 10/18/21 5:31 P.M.** BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Baltimore Police are searching for missing 14-year-old Alesha Henry. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Henry was last seen on Saturday, Oct. 16 in the 4000 block of Ardely Ave. She is described as 5 feet 2 inches tall weighing about 100 pounds. Loved ones are concerned about her well-being. Anyone with information regarding the whereabouts of Henry is asked to call 443-984-7385 or 911. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Those who wish to remain anonymous can utilize the Metro Crime Stoppers tip line, at 1-866-7LOCKUP. You can also submit an online text tip.

headline: Maryland‚Äôs Leaders & Residents React To Colin Powell‚Äôs Death
summary: Tributes from throughout Maryland poured in Monday for late Gen. Colin Powell.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Tributes from throughout Maryland poured in Monday for the late Gen. Colin Powell. Powell, the first Black U.S. Secretary of State,  died Monday morning of complications resulting from COVID-19 , his family announced on Facebook. He was 84. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The news came as a shock to everyone, from Baltimore residents to  elected officials. ‚Äú(I‚Äôm) totally surprised,‚Äù city resident Rod Robinson said. ‚ÄúTotally surprised. Just got the news.‚Äù The retired four-star general was fully vaccinated against COVID-19, but his immune system was compromised by a form of blood cancer. People who spoke with WJZ said Powell will be remembered for the legacy he leaves behind. ‚ÄúI was overwhelmed, heartbroken,‚Äù one resident said. ‚ÄúBecause he‚Äôs a very powerful man.‚Äù Powell, who served as national security adviser and chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff during several presidential administrations, made history in 2001 when President George W. Bush named him Secretary of State. The late general is being remembered for having great influence over U.S. foreign policy during his career in public service. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still trying to get over it,‚Äù Robinson told WJZ. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know him personally, but I know him because of who he was and what kind of role he played in the world.‚Äù Congressman Kweisi Mfume and Senator Ben Cardin both shared their sadness over the loss of Powell. ‚ÄúWith the passing of Colin L. Powell, America lost a great leader and public servant,‚Äù Mfume said. ‚Äù ‚Ä¶ He won bipartisan respect at home and around the globe because of his integrity.‚Äù Said Cardin: ‚ÄúSecretary Powell was an incredible soldier, diplomat and leader of our nation. ‚Ä¶ He took his experience as a soldier and used it as a strategist to transition our military to meet the current threats of America.‚Äù Baltimore has its own unique way of remembering Powell. A wax figure of him is on display at the National Great Blacks in Wax Museum, which Powell visited in 1996. ‚ÄúA man that served well and now leaves here because of COVID,‚Äù Robinson said. ‚ÄúGod bless his family.‚Äù In a tweet paying tribute to Powell, former Baltimore Health Commissioner Dr. Leana Wen said the late general‚Äôs death was a reminder that while vaccines offer protection against COVID-19, they‚Äôre not all-powerful. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúRest In Peace, General Colin Powell. Thank you for your leadership, service, and being an inspiration to so many,‚Äù Dr. Wen said. ‚Äú A reminder that the unvaccinated are 11 times more likely to die from  #covid19  than the vaccinated. Vaccines are very protective, but virtually nothing is 100%.‚Äù

headline: ‚ÄòEverything Has Gone Sky High‚Äô: From Groceries To Gas, Prices Skyrocketing And Could Get Worse
summary: The price increases have hit certain industries particularly hard over the last year.
bodytext: WALTHAM, MASSACHUSETTS (CBS) ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe meat is above and beyond all right?‚Äù Fadia Chamoun of Lexington, Massachusetts lamented as she packed her trunk full of groceries. ‚ÄúIt has gone sky high. Everything has gone sky high and it‚Äôs extremely sad.‚Äù If it feels like lately everything is more expensive, that‚Äôs because it is. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúThe government [just] released that prices over the past 12 months have increased 5.4% and that marks the fifth month in a row of over 5% price increases,‚Äù Boston University Questrom School of Business professor Jay Zagorsky explained. ‚ÄúThat means that roughly every 14 or 15 years, all prices double. Everything is twice as expensive if this keeps up.‚Äù The price increases have hit certain industries particularly hard over the last year. Used car prices are up about 24 percent. The cost of meat has gone up 12 percent in 12 months. Home heating oil is up an estimated 43 percent. Another area on the top of many commuters‚Äô minds: gas prices, which have risen by more than $1 a gallon. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúNow that many people are going shopping again, many people are going traveling again, we want to spend that money,‚Äù Zagorsky explained. ‚ÄúBut the items just aren‚Äôt there.‚Äù Experts credit the price increases to residual effects of the pandemic: labor and supply shortages. In essence, manufacturing is trying to catch up to skyrocketing demand, which leads to skyrocketing prices. So, what can be done to lower the cost of living while we wait for supply to catch up? ‚ÄúThe Federal Reserve might have to start raising interest rates,‚Äù Zagorsky explained. ‚ÄúRaising interest rates will reduce inflationary pressures, but it also means the party‚Äôs over‚Ä¶there‚Äôs just not going to be many people bidding on homes once interest rates go up.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs sort of a balance here,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúThe balance is that the government has some control over inflation, but there are no easy choices.‚Äù

headline: Amazon Plans To Hire 150,000 Temporary Workers For The Holidays
summary: Amazon plans to add 150,000 temporary workers in the United States for the holiday shopping rush, a 50% increase from the company's holiday hiring push a year ago.
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî  Amazon plans to add 150,000 temporary workers in the United States for the holiday shopping rush, a 50% increase from the company‚Äôs holiday hiring push a year ago. Amazon, like many retailers and logistics companies, is facing challenges hiring workers and is raising pay, dangling bonuses, and expanding benefits in response to the pressures. The company‚Äôs holiday jobs this year have an average starting pay of $18 an hour ‚Äî higher than Amazon‚Äôs $15 minimum wage‚Äî sign-on bonuses up to $3,000 and an additional $3 an hour in pay for certain shifts in some locations, Amazon said in an announcement Monday. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Amazon‚Äôs temporary positions for the holidays include picking, scanning and packing items at warehouses and loading boxes onto trucks. Amazon‚Äôs business has surged during the pandemic as many shoppers, spending more time at home, increased their online purchases. Amazon has added more than 450,000 workers in the United States since the beginning of the pandemic and now has upwards of 950,000 US workers. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very competitive labor market out there. And certainly, the biggest contributor to inflationary pressures that we‚Äôre seeing in the business,‚Äù Brian Olsavsky, Amazon‚Äôs chief financial officer, said in July. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre spending a lot of money on signing and incentives.‚Äù Amazon last month said it planned to hire 125,000 permanent workers ahead of the holidays. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Other chains are adding temporary and permanent workers at stores and warehouses to meet demand from holiday shoppers. Walmart plans to hire around 150,000 employees, most of them in permanent, full-time positions, while Target is aiming to bring on 100,000 seasonal workers and 30,000 permanent supply chain employees. UPS, Kohl‚Äôs, Nordstrom, Macy‚Äôs and others are also adding workers for the holidays. Some are offering sign-on bonuses this year for new hires and other incentives. There are signs, however, that interest in holiday work for some has dwindled. The share of job seeker searches for seasonal work during the seven days ending September 22 was down 1.5% compared with the same time last year and 39% from 2019, jobs site Indeed said in a report last month. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The-CNN-Wire  ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2021 Cable News Network, Inc., a WarnerMedia Company. All rights reserved.

headline: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm Going To Donate It All‚Äô: 5-Year-Old Sells His Pumpkins To Raise Money For Others
summary: A pumpkin harvest is proving there is plenty of hope for our future. Meet a young man named Emmitt Cox whose giant gourds are no match for the size of his heart.
bodytext: MINNEAPOLIS (WCCO) ‚Äì¬† A pumpkin harvest in central Minnesota proves there is plenty of hope for our future.¬†WCCO-TV in Minneapolis met a young man named Emmitt Cox and found his giant gourds are no match for the size of his heart. ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs a big one,‚Äù Emmitt showed the TV cameras, pointing to his pumpkins.¬†‚ÄúThis is the biggest one.‚Äù¬†Like any good country boy, 5-year-old Emmitt is proud of his crops.¬†He can even tell you how much one costs to take home. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúThis one is four,‚Äù he said, holding up four fingers. But what began as some father and son bonding last year has grown into something more.¬†‚ÄúHim and his father are both farm boys, any excuse to get out on the tractor and in the dirt,‚Äù Emmitt‚Äôs mother, Anna Cox, said. Their patch last season produced some 200 pumpkins, so many they weren‚Äôt sure what to do with them all.‚ÄúWe thought this would be a good opportunity for Emmitt to learn how to make his own money and manage funds. So we said, ‚ÄòEmmitt if you want to try to sell some we‚Äôd be more than happy to help you with that,‚Äô‚Äù Anna said. An honor system they set up on the side of the road.¬†‚ÄúEvery night he was excited to check the box and put the money in his jar,‚Äù she said. After earning $400 and some teaching at home about how money can be used to help others, Emmitt made his decision.¬†‚ÄúHe mentioned his pumpkin money and [we] said, ‚Äòif you want to donate some of it that‚Äôs totally fine,‚Äô and he said, ‚Äònope I‚Äôm going to donate it all,‚Äô‚Äù Anna said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall And Emmitt did just that donating his profits to Toys For Tots.¬†‚ÄúHe got to do a little bit of a shopping spree and fill this cart to the top,‚Äù she said. Ardis Strommen is one of the Coxs‚Äô neighbors.¬†‚ÄúFor a 5-year-old to be that anxious to help people, it‚Äôs amazing,‚Äù Strommen said. Friends and community members were back again this fall to pitch in, even when the crop wasn‚Äôt as plentiful.¬†‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt get much this year,‚Äù Emmitt said.¬†‚ÄúSome of the seeds did not grow. Not much rain.‚Äù Still, it was a successful harvest where it mattered most.¬†‚ÄúI hope that‚Äôs the lesson people can really get from this, is that [if] a 5-year-old can put others before himself, maybe we all can,‚Äù Anna said. All of Emmitt‚Äôs pumpkins are spoken for this year and he plans to donate the $100 he‚Äôs raised this season to build a new playground at his church.¬†His brother, Paul, is just one and will someday be Emmitt‚Äôs pumpkin partner. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized When asked how long he plans to sell his pumpkins Emmitt said for at least the next 60 years.

headline: First African American To Lead The Maryland National Guard Was Honored After 38-Years Of Service
summary: Major General, retired Linda Signh, the 29th adjutant general of Maryland and the first African American and the first woman to lead the Maryland national guard had her official portrait unveiled at the brand new readiness center in Sykesville.
bodytext: SYKESVILLE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî¬† Honoring 38 years of history-making service.     Major General, retired Linda Singh, the 29th adjutant general of Maryland and the first African American and the first woman to lead the Maryland national guard had her official portrait unveiled at the brand new readiness center in Sykesville.     ‚ÄúBut it is her incredible legacy of service and the transformative things that Gen. Singh did with her command that truly sets her apart,‚Äù said Gov. Larry Hogan.     Singh served in multiple overseas combat deployments, led the national guard during the 2015 civil unrest in Baltimore, and created an all-women leadership team.     ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do it was just because they were women, one because they were qualified, but two it gave permission for the rest of the country to say this is ok,‚Äù said Singh.     Brigadier General Janeen Birckhead was on that team.     ‚ÄúDemonstrates is the word I‚Äôm looking for. Demonstrates really what she talked about today and that being that mentor and everybody fighting for her people and we couldn‚Äôt love her more,‚Äù said Birckhead.     Hogan, who appointed Singh, had one last surprise.     ‚ÄúI will officially introduce a proposal to officially rename this freedom readiness center as the Maj. Gen. Linda Singh Readiness Center,‚Äù said Hogan.     ‚ÄúIt really is an honor, every time I drive past it I‚Äôm going to be looking at it, and my family will get to share in that. And I don‚Äôt really know what else to say about it. It‚Äôs just amazing,‚Äù said Singh.     She officially retired in 2019 but has no plans of slowing down.     ‚ÄúI want to thank you for this honor, I want to thank you because I‚Äôm going to keep serving until the day I die. I‚Äôm going to continue to fight for our rights in my own fashionable way,‚Äù said the National Guard.

headline: Vaccine Mandate Creates Friction Between Baltimore And Its Police & Fire Unions
summary: Everyone who works for the city of Baltimore must now provide proof they‚Äôve been vaccinated against COVID-19, or else they‚Äôll be required to undergo routine testing under a new city policy.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Everyone who works for the city of Baltimore must now provide proof they‚Äôve been vaccinated against COVID-19, or else they‚Äôll be required to undergo routine testing under a new city policy. The  COVID-19 vaccine mandate took effect Monday and covers all 14,000 city employees . READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School But after raising concerns about the policy‚Äôs implications, unions representing the city‚Äôs firefighters and  police officers are calling for the deadline to be pushed back  until they get answers to their lingering questions. ‚ÄúWe just want to know how they‚Äôre going to do this,‚Äù said Rich Langford, who serves as president of Baltimore Firefighters IAFF Local 734, a firefighters and paramedics union. The  policy was announced in late August by Mayor Brandon Scott . It calls for all city employees, including part-time staff and contractors, to prove they‚Äôre vaccinated or be subject to weekly testing. Since the policy was announced, Langford said, the union has tried unsuccessfully to get details about the mandate. He cited problems that have arisen from ‚Äúnot completely thought out‚Äù policy changes in the past. Specifically, he said, his union‚Äôs members want to know how testing for unvaccinated employees will be carried out ‚Äì and how it could affect the fire department‚Äôs ability to serve the community. ‚ÄúOne of the biggest things our members need to know is exactly how this testing is going to be implemented,‚Äù Langford told WJZ. ‚ÄúWe have no idea. We‚Äôve been told it‚Äôs going to be done on duty, but that also brings in a lot of logistical problems.‚Äù One potential problem, he said, could involve putting fire engines, fire trucks and rescue units out of service while their crews get tested for COVID-19. That‚Äôs a risk they‚Äôre not willing to overlook. Similar concerns have been raised by the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 3, which represents the city‚Äôs police. In a letter to members Friday, union president Mike Mancuso said attempts to discuss the policy with the city have been met with delays. As a result, Mancuso wrote, the union filed an unfair labor practice complaint with the Office of the Labor Commissioner. He said the union also filed court paperwork to keep the policy from being enforced until wrinkles are ironed out. ‚ÄúFOP3 believes that there are multiple collective bargaining issues that surround the city‚Äôs vaccination policy,‚Äù Mancuso wrote. ‚ÄúWe have made multiple attempts to sit down and discuss these issues to no avail.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall It‚Äôs because of those delays and the collective bargaining issues at stake that Mancuso  advised union members not to disclose their vaccination status to the city . ‚ÄúUntil the city responds to our right to bargain these issues, or the courts intervene, I suggest you do nothing in regard to revealing your vaccination status as it is outlined in the city‚Äôs policy,‚Äù the letter stated. At last check, figures provided by the Baltimore Police Department showed nearly two-thirds of its employees had gotten at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. That‚Äôs significantly lower than the general population. State health officials estimate 85 percent of adults in Maryland are at least partially vaccinated. The mayor‚Äôs communications director, Cal Harris, released a statement Monday saying the city met with police union officials Friday to discuss their concerns about the mandate. ‚ÄúLabor Commissioner Deborah Moore-Carter led a productive meeting Friday afternoon with the Baltimore City Fraternal Order of Police and their attorney, Commissioner Michael Harrison, and representatives from the City‚Äôs Law Department and Human Resources to discuss concerns over the vaccination mandate. We will remain in close contact with the FOP until a solution is reached, and we are hopeful it will,‚Äù Harris said. In response to questions from WJZ about the details of the testing policy, Harris‚Äô deputy, Stefanie Mavronis, said details will be released later this week. Mavronis said the testing plan will be based on what the data shows, specifically ‚Äúwho is unvaccinated and where they work.‚Äù Some city residents said they believe the mandate is a good idea. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs great,‚Äù said Duane Dennis. ‚ÄúI think the safer we can be, the better we are.‚Äù Added Brian Holmes: ‚ÄúThey said, ‚ÄòDo it,‚Äô so I did it. You go to the doctor, they tell you to take these pills, you take them.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: ‚ÄòThought It Was My Body, My Choice‚Äô: Northrop Grumman Employees Protest Vaccine Mandate
summary: Starting December 8, more than 100 million federal employees and contractors are subject to the vaccine requirement ordered by the president.
bodytext: HANOVER, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Fighting for medical freedom, dozens¬†of demonstrators lined up outside Northrop Grumman‚Äôs BWI location Monday morning with American flags in hand to protest against the company‚Äôs vaccine mandate. ‚ÄúI feel mandates in general upon free citizens of this country is unconstitutional and if it starts here, when does it end?‚Äù said Michael Drodes. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúThought it was my body, my choice. Lets go,‚Äù said Oliva Ravadge. This comes a week after the company said all workers need to be fully vaccinated by Dec. 8 in line with the federal vaccine mandate. ‚ÄúWe should not be forced to put something in our body that we don‚Äôt want to and we‚Äôre going to stand behind that,‚Äù said Ravadge. If workers don‚Äôt get vaccinated, they could lose their jobs and that‚Äôs not sitting well with some. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not anti-vax. We‚Äôre not anti-Northup Grumman. We‚Äôre just pro-choice,‚Äù said Garth Bonbargen. Protestors say they just want their voices to be heard and to terminate the mandate. ‚ÄúWe hope that this mandate gets lifted and it turns into our choice as it should have been from the beginning,‚Äù said Ravadge. ‚ÄúWe should not be forced, it should be our choice from the very beginning and our jobs should not be on the line because of it.‚Äù A spokesman for Northrop Grumman‚Äôs told WJZ, ‚Äúthe company remains committed to continuous operations to ensure they deliver on their commitments to its customers.‚Äù Another protest is scheduled for next Monday, Oct. 25 near the Sykesville Northrop Grumman location. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Biden To Participate In CNN Town Hall In Baltimore On Thursday
summary: President Joe Biden will participate in a town hall on Thursday in Baltimore, where he'll take questions as his administration continues to sell his ambitious legislative agenda to members of Congress and the nation.
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî  President Joe Biden will participate in a CNN town hall on Thursday in Baltimore, where he‚Äôll take questions as his administration continues to sell his ambitious legislative agenda to members of Congress and the nation. CNN anchor Anderson Cooper will moderate the live broadcast event, which will air at 8 p.m. ET on CNN and last 90 minutes. A CNN spokesperson said an invitation-only audience will be present at the town hall and the network will follow all local and state Covid-19 guidance and regulations to ensure a safe event. The town hall‚Äôs location will be announced in the coming days. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Biden‚Äôs town hall comes at a critical time for his administration. The President has spent months delivering speeches across the country trying to sell the public on his infrastructure plans. And this week, Biden is meeting with lawmakers to negotiate both aspects of his infrastructure proposals ‚Äî a sweeping economic package to expand the social safety net and a $1.2 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill. On Thursday, the day Biden takes part in the town hall, Vice President Kamala Harris will be campaigning for gubernatorial candidate Terry McAuliffe in neighboring Virginia, a source familiar with Harris‚Äô event told CNN. The long slog of congressional negotiations is expected to loom over the upcoming November elections, which are just weeks away. Although Democrats have confidence in Congress‚Äô ability to pass the bills in some form, the possibility for those bills to pass before the November elections ‚Äî acting as a boon for Democratic candidates ‚Äî is becoming less likely as each day passes. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall McAuliffe‚Äôs race is of concern for Democrats, given that his state is acutely attune to the federal government‚Äôs actions in neighboring Washington. There‚Äôs support among Republicans and Democrats for the infrastructure proposals. A CNN Poll conducted by SSRS earlier this month found that support for an economic bill that enacts all the proposed social safety net and climate change policies is broadest among liberal Democrats (84%), but two-thirds of moderates and conservatives in the party share that view (67%). In that same poll, Americans were divided over the President‚Äôs approval rating. Fifty percent of individuals polled approved, while 49% disapproved ‚Äî largely unchanged from a CNN poll conducted in August and September. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The-CNN-Wire  ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2021 Cable News Network, Inc., a WarnerMedia Company. All rights reserved.

headline: Colin Powell, Military Leader And First Black US Secretary Of State, Dies After Complications From COVID-19
summary: He was 84.
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî   Colin Powell , the first Black US secretary of state whose leadership in several Republican administrations helped shape American foreign policy in the last years of the 20th century and the early years of the 21st, has died from complications from Covid-19, his family said on Facebook. He was 84. ‚ÄúGeneral Colin L. Powell, former U.S. Secretary of State and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, passed away this morning due to complications from Covid 19,‚Äù the Powell family wrote on Facebook. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúWe have lost a remarkable and loving husband, father, grandfather and a great American,‚Äù they said, noting he was fully vaccinated. Powell was a distinguished and trailblazing professional soldier whose career took him from combat duty in Vietnam to becoming the first Black national security adviser during the end of Ronald Reagan‚Äôs presidency and the youngest and first African American chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under President George H.W. Bush. His national popularity soared in the aftermath of the US-led coalition victory during the Gulf War, and for a time in the mid-90s, he was considered a leading contender to become the first Black President of the United States. But his reputation would be forever stained when, as George W. Bush‚Äôs first secretary of state, he pushed faulty intelligence before the United Nations to advocate for the Iraq War, which he would later call a ‚Äúblot‚Äù on his record. Though he never mounted a White House bid, when Powell was sworn in as Bush‚Äôs secretary of state in 2001, he became the highest-ranking Black public official to date in the country, standing fourth in the presidential line of succession. ‚ÄúI think it shows to the world what is possible in this country,‚Äù Powell  said  of his history-making nomination during his Senate confirmation hearing. ‚ÄúIt shows to the world that: Follow our model, and over a period of time from our beginning, if you believe in the values that espouse, you can see things as miraculous as me sitting before you to receive your approval.‚Äù Later in his public life, he would grow disillusioned with the Republican Party‚Äôs rightward lurch and would use his political capital to help elect Democrats to the White House, most notably Barack Obama, the first Black president whom Powell endorsed in the final weeks of the 2008 campaign. The announcement was seen as a significant boost for Obama‚Äôs candidacy due to Powell‚Äôs widespread popular appeal and stature as one of the  most prominent and successful Black Americans  in public life. Powell is survived by his wife, Alma Vivian (Johnson) Powell, whom he married in 1962, as well as three children. Professional soldier Colin Luther Powell was born April 5, 1937, in Harlem, New York, to Jamaican immigrants. After growing up in the South Bronx, Powell attended school at the City College of New York, where he participated in ROTC, leading the precision drill team and attaining the top rank offered by the corps, cadet colonel. ‚ÄúI liked the structure and the discipline of the military,‚Äù Powell said, according to  a CNN profile of him in the early 2000s . ‚ÄúI felt somewhat distinctive wearing a uniform. I hadn‚Äôt been distinctive in much else.‚Äù He entered the US Army after graduating in 1958, and later served two tours in South Vietnam during the 1960s, where he was wounded twice, including during a helicopter crash in which he rescued two soldiers. He stayed in the Army after returning home, attending the National War College and rising in leadership. He was promoted to brigadier general in 1979, appointed as Reagan‚Äôs final national security adviser in 1987 and was tapped by the elder Bush in 1989 to head the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Powell‚Äôs tenure in the elder Bush‚Äôs administration was marked by his involvement in some of the most notable American military actions of the late 20th century, including the 1989 Panama operation, the 1991 Gulf War and the US humanitarian intervention in Somalia, though he  retired  from the Army days before the disastrous  Battle of Mogadishu . Although Powell was initially reluctant to commit US troops when Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, he became one of the administration‚Äôs most trusted spokesmen when the assault on Saddam Hussein‚Äôs army finally came. ‚ÄúFirst we‚Äôre going to cut it off. Then we‚Äôre going to kill it,‚Äù Powell famously said at a news conference at the time, referring to the Iraqi army. Following the assault, Powell became something of a  national hero , enjoying a 71% favorability rating in the first few year years after the war. His efforts during the war also earned him two prominent awards: a Congressional Gold Medal in March 1991 ‚Äúin recognition of his exemplary performance in planning and coordinating‚Äù the US response to Iraq‚Äôs invasion, and a Presidential Medal of Freedom. As the elder Bush presented Powell with the award at a White House ceremony in 1991, he said the general‚Äôs ‚Äúdeep compassion for every one of the thousands of men and women under (his) command will always be remembered.‚Äù During Powell‚Äôs time in the military, which lasted until 1993, he also received a number of other notable awards, including the Bronze Star and two Purple Hearts. He received his fourth star in 1989, becoming the second African American to rise to that rank. In addition to the military awards, Powell also received the President‚Äôs Citizens Medal, the Secretary of State Distinguished Service Medal, and the Secretary of Energy Distinguished Service Medal, as well as a second Presidential Medal of Freedom, awarded with distinction, from President Bill Clinton. Top diplomat during turbulent time With a prominent national profile, Powell was floated as a potential presidential candidate in the 1996 election. But in a highly anticipated decision, he declined to participate in the race, citing a lack of ‚Äúpassion‚Äù for electoral politics. ‚ÄúSuch a life requires a calling that I do not yet hear,‚Äù he  told reporters in 1995 . ‚ÄúAnd for me to pretend otherwise would not be honest to myself, it would not be honest to the American people.‚Äù Powell was again encouraged to run in the 2000 presidential election, but rebuffed calls for him to mount a bid. He instead endorsed George W. Bush, delivering a  speech  at the Republican National Convention in which he argued that the then-governor of Texas would ‚Äúhelp bridge our racial divides.‚Äù He was Bush‚Äôs  first Cabinet selection  when he was announced as the 43rd President‚Äôs nomination for secretary of state, and with his  expertise  in foreign policy and widespread popularity, he was unanimously confirmed by the Senate. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall He shared Bush‚Äôs reluctance to project military strength across the globe, a view that was quickly displaced by the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. As Bush‚Äôs top diplomat, he was tasked with building international support for the War on Terror, including the Afghanistan War, but it was his involvement in the administration‚Äôs push for intervention in Iraq, over the concerns of many of America‚Äôs longtime allies, for which his tenure at State would become best known. In February 2003, Powell delivered a  speech  before the United Nations in which he presented evidence that the US intelligence community said proved Iraq had misled inspectors and hid weapons of mass destruction. ‚ÄúThere can be no doubt,‚Äù Powell  warned , ‚Äúthat Saddam Hussein has biological weapons and the capability to rapidly produce more, many more.‚Äù Inspectors, however, later found no such weaponry in Iraq, and two years after Powell‚Äôs UN speech, a government report said the intelligence community was ‚Äúdead wrong‚Äù in its assessments of Iraq‚Äôs weapons of mass destruction capabilities before the US invasion. But the damage was already done ‚Äî to both Iraq, which the US went to war with just six weeks after Powell‚Äôs speech, and to the reputation of the once highly popular statesman, who was  reportedly  told by then-Vice President Dick Cheney before the UN speech: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got high poll ratings; you can afford to lose a few points.‚Äù Powell, who left the State Department in early 2005 after submitting his resignation to Bush the previous year, later called his UN speech a ‚Äúblot‚Äù that will forever be on his record. ‚ÄúI regret it now because the information was wrong ‚Äî of course I do,‚Äù he  told  CNN‚Äôs Larry King in 2010. ‚ÄúBut I will always be seen as the one who made the case before the international community.‚Äù ‚ÄúI swayed public opinion, there‚Äôs no question about it,‚Äù he added, referring to how influential his speech was on public support for the invasion. In his 2012 memoir, ‚ÄúIt Worked for Me,‚Äù Powell again acknowledged the speech, writing that his account of it in the book would likely be the last he publicly made. ‚ÄúI am mad mostly at myself for not having smelled the problem. My instincts failed me,‚Äù he wrote, referring to the report he used that contained faulty evidence of supposed Iraqi WMDs. ‚ÄúIt was by no means my first, but it was one of my most momentous failures, the one with the widest-ranging impact.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe event will earn a prominent paragraph in my obituary,‚Äù Powell wrote. Shifting politics After leaving the Bush administration, Powell returned to private life. He  joined  the renowned venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins in 2005, where he worked as a strategic adviser until his death. For a time, he gave speeches at ‚ÄúGet Motivated!‚Äù business seminars, and he authored the 2012 memoir. Though the large majority of Powell‚Äôs time as a public servant was spent in Republican administrations, the later years of his life saw him supporting Democratic presidential candidates and harshly criticizing top Republican leaders. By 2008, the longtime Republican‚Äôs coveted presidential  endorsement  went to another party when he announced his support for Obama‚Äôs White House bid. At the time, he touted Obama‚Äôs ‚Äúability to inspire‚Äù and the ‚Äúinclusive nature of his campaign,‚Äù while criticizing attacks on the Illinois senator by Republican presidential nominee John McCain‚Äôs campaign as ‚Äúinappropriate.‚Äù He was later named an honorary co-chair of Obama‚Äôs inauguration and endorsed him again in 2012. Powell went on to vote for Hillary Clinton in 2016 over Donald Trump, whom he had strongly condemned as a ‚Äúnational disgrace and an international pariah.‚Äù In an extraordinary move that year, three presidential electors in Washington state  cast votes  for Powell rather than Clinton, resulting in state fines that were later upheld by the Supreme Court. He again snubbed Trump in 2020 during the President‚Äôs second campaign,  announcing  his support for Joe Biden in June of that year while blasting Trump‚Äôs presidency. ‚ÄúWe have a Constitution. And we have to follow that Constitution. And the President has drifted away from it,‚Äù  he told CNN , adding that he ‚Äúcertainly cannot in any way support President Trump this year.‚Äù The retired general later delivered an address in support of Biden during the Democratic National Convention. And after Trump incited a deadly insurrection at the US Capitol in early January 2021, Powell told CNN that he no longer considered himself a Republican, with the longtime grandee of the GOP saying he was now simply watching events unfold in a country he long served. ‚ÄúI can no longer call myself a fellow Republican. I‚Äôm not a fellow of anything right now,‚Äù he told CNN‚Äôs Fareed Zakaria on ‚ÄúGPS.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just a citizen who has voted Republican, voted Democrat throughout my entire career. And right now, I‚Äôm just watching my country and not concerned with parties.‚Äù This story has been updated with additional information. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The-CNN-Wire  ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2021 Cable News Network, Inc., a WarnerMedia Company. All rights reserved.

headline: Maryland Lawmakers Introduce New Legislation To Better Protect Witnesses, Reduce Intimidation
summary: Maryland Lawmakers introduced new legislation Monday in an effort to reduce witness intimidation and better protect those who testify in court.
bodytext: ELLICOTT CITY, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland Lawmakers introduced new legislation Monday in an effort to reduce witness intimidation and better protect those who testify in court. The Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act would establish and strengthen witness protection programs through competitive grants to local and state jurisdictions. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The proposed legislation would authorize the U.S. Attorney General to distribute $150 million in grants over five years for national programs to protect witnesses in violent felony cases. Read the bill below: READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ¬† ¬† MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Boy, 16, Charged In Murder Of 15-Year-Old Ja‚ÄôNyi Weeden, Police Say
summary: Police have made an arrest in the murder of Ja'Nyi Weeden, a 15-year-old Baltimore girl who was fatally shot in August.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police have made an arrest in the murder of Ja‚ÄôNyi Weeden, a  15-year-old Baltimore girl who was fatally shot in August . A 16-year-old boy was arrested Friday on a warrant charging him with first-degree murder in Weeden‚Äôs death, the Baltimore Police Department said Monday. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School It wasn‚Äôt immediately clear Monday whether the unnamed teenager would be charged as an adult. The shooting was initially reported about 12:55 a.m. Aug. 10 in the 3700 block of Gelston Drive in Northwest Baltimore. Officers called to the scene that morning found Weeden shot multiple times, including at least once in the head, authorities said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The 15-year-old was rushed to University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center, where she later died of her injuries. As WJZ previously reported, neighbors recalled hearing six to eight gunshots ring out the morning of the shooting. The girl‚Äôs death galvanized the community ‚Äî with many, including Mayor Brandon Scott, calling for answers. ‚ÄúJa‚ÄôNyi‚Äôs life was taken before she was able to fully reach her potential,‚Äù Scott said at the time. ‚ÄúThere were too many people nearby for no one to not know anything about who killed this young lady.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Stay with WJZ on air and online for updates to this developing story.

headline: Weather Blog: October Has The ‚ÄòHunter‚Äôs Moon‚Äô
summary: Marty's Blog
bodytext: Hi everyone! ¬† Did ya see that almost full moon last night? It looked pretty full to the nekkid eye but in fact, it will not go full until tomorrow midday so we all have another chance to see the ‚ÄúHunters Moon‚Äù again tonight. Yep, the October moon is called the ‚ÄúHunter‚Äôs Moon‚Äù as that recreation season is beginning and the early mornings a lit up brightly by this moon. And this time of the year the almanac‚Äôs description of the fullness tells the story of the season more so than anytime of the year. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ¬†¬†The September mom was the ‚ÄúHarvest Moon‚Äù, Summers over get the crops in. We‚Äôve discussed the October Moon. In December it will be called the ‚ÄúCold Moon‚Äù as Winter starts. And no shock, in the dead of winter, February, it is the ‚ÄúSnow Moon.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ¬† The worst name has to be when the thaw hits and the ground loosens up. That moon is the ‚Äúworm Moon.‚Äù Fitting but come on. ¬†¬†So under clear skies, the moon shadows will dance tonight. And those clear skies will also show us the Fall and Winter constellations, like ‚ÄúOrion‚Äù is their fullness too. Enjoy! headline: Can‚Äôt Spare A Square: Toilet Paper Shortage Fears Lead To More ‚ÄòPanic Buying‚Äô In Parts Of Country
summary: With COVID-19 cases rising, shortages of toilet paper, paper towels and cleaning supplies are returning in many parts of the country as well.
bodytext: ( CBS Detroit ) ‚Äî  Shortages of toilet paper, paper towels and cleaning supplies are starting to show up across the country again. With COVID-19 cases rising, consumers are starting to hoard toilet paper as they did during the first coronavirus wave back in the spring. The situation has yet to reach those levels but could if the health situation worsens and panic rises. Officials at Walmart , the country‚Äôs largest retailer, said earlier this week that  supply chains  have not kept pace with increasing demand, and stocking these goods consistently has grown more challenging with steadily increasing virus case loads.¬†‚ÄúWe do see big differences, depending on the communities that you‚Äôre in,‚Äù Walmart US CEO John Furner said on a call with analysts Tuesday after Walmart reported its quarterly earnings. ‚ÄúThe specific categories where we have the most strain at the present time would be bath tissue and cleaning supplies.‚Äù READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School >>READ:  Stimulus Package Update: Politicians Still Can‚Äôt Agree On Type Of Aid Or How Much To Spend Walmart has not imposed limits on toilet paper purchases yet, but other retailers have. Kroger customers can only buy bath tissue and paper towels two packs at a time. Giant grocery stores in the Northeast recently began limiting purchases of large toilet paper and paper towel packs to one and smaller sizes to four. Christopher Brand , a Giant spokesperson, said that the company was ‚Äúseeing little evidence of stockpiling, and there is no need to create panic.‚Äù But the supply chain ‚Äúremains challenged.‚Äù San Jose, California has seen a new wave of  panic buying  which coincides with new COVID restrictions and a dramatic surge in cases, at what is traditionally the busiest time of year for grocery stores. Fear of a shutdown isn‚Äôt helping. Multiple Targets had empty shelves in the paper product aisles and the cleaning supplies section. Paper towels were also selling out at a Whole Foods in San Francisco. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall >>READ:  Stimulus Package Update: What Will A Biden Administration Mean For More Aid? Retailers have stressed that there is no shortage and  no need to panic .¬†A company spokesperson for Giant Eagle, a grocery store chain in the Pittsburgh area, said each location has been receiving daily deliveries of household and grocery items. The company has been strengthening partnerships with current suppliers and working with new and alternate suppliers to maintain a strong stock position. Some parts of the country aren‚Äôt experiencing the rush on toilet paper and cleaning supplies, at least not yet. Local grocery stores and at least one Costco in Queens, a borough of New York, had full shelves earlier this week. Maybe not coincidentally, New York City also has some of the lowest COVID positivity rates in the country. When cases in the city spiked back in the spring, store shelves were empty of toilet paper, paper towels and cleaning supplies. The United States set¬† COVID-19 records  last week for four days in a row, with more than 184,000 cases reported Friday and over 68,000 people hospitalized with the virus. An average of over 1,100 Americans have died of the virus per day last week. Officials across the country continue to announce new, more restrictive¬† measures in response to the surge. The upward trend in cases is expected to continue with cold weather and the holiday season approaching. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized >>READ:  ‚ÄòStimulus Checks Are The Least Important,‚Äô When Drafting Aid Package, Says Economist

headline: Shipping Containers That Spent Weeks Aboard Ships Stuck At Ports Now Being Dumped In Nearby Neighborhoods
summary: Many of the shipping containers that spent weeks onboard ships waiting to be unloaded are now being dumped in nearby neighborhoods once they're emptied.
bodytext: WILMINGTON (CBSLA)  ‚Äî With the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach now running 24/7 operations, a new problem has occurred. Many of the shipping containers that spent weeks onboard ships waiting to be unloaded are now being dumped in nearby neighborhoods once they‚Äôre emptied. Sonia Cervantes lives along Anaheim Street in Wilmington, California, where UCTI Trucking Company is located. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The company‚Äôs lot only has a capacity for 65 containers so the additional containers now line up along Anaheim Street in front of some people‚Äôs homes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bunch of neighbors that are very upset because it‚Äôs a non-stop situation,‚Äù said Cervantes. ‚ÄúI would have to go in at 6:30 a.m. to go to work. There was a trailer already blocking my driveway so I couldn‚Äôt get out. With no driver in the trailer, so we would honk and honk, and it was just crazy.‚Äù ‚ÄúRight now with the ports and everything that‚Äôs going on over there, we‚Äôre stuck with the containers, having to bring them all to the yard, and we only have so much space,‚Äù said UCTI Trucking owner Frank Arrieran. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre sitting in the street for like 15, 20 minutes,‚Äù Cervantes said. ‚ÄúSometimes they just unload the trailer in the street with no front part of it, and they just leave it there.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall CBSLA spoke with U.S. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg on Monday who says the Biden Administration is working on both short and long-term solutions. Last week, President Joe Biden announced that the Port of LA would implement 24/7 operations. ‚ÄúThere are so many pieces to the  supply chain  and most of them are in private hands. But what we found is that the administration can act as an honest broker and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre doing, getting the different players together and securing commitments that are going to make a difference to get these goods flowing,‚Äù Buttigieg said. ‚ÄúThere are $17 billion in port improvements in the President‚Äôs infrastructure bill and they‚Äôre urgently needed. This is one of the reasons why we‚Äôre eager to see congressional action, and I know my department is ready to put those dollars to work,‚Äù Buttigieg said. In the meantime, back in Wilmington, Arrerian said they‚Äôre doing everything they can to ease the congestion on the street. He‚Äôs asking residents for understanding. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been messed with tickets and being harassed,‚Äù Arrerian said. ‚ÄúWe ask the community to help us, because we‚Äôre only in the middle.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Arrieran said he‚Äôs meeting with city officials tomorrow. He hopes they will work with him to get relocated to a bigger yard.

headline: Turkey Farmers Say Shortage Of Workers Will Delay Production
summary: The holidays are right around the corner, but the turkey company Butterball is concerned there may be a shortage in supply this year.
bodytext: CHICAGO (CBS) ‚Äî  The holidays are right around the corner and that means looking for the right turkey for the dinner table. But the turkey company Butterball is concerned there may be a shortage in supply this year. CBS 2‚Äôs Jackie Kostek visited a turkey farm in Dundee, Illinois. They are working very hard to make sure that they can keep up with demand. After speaking to several farmers, they say It‚Äôs not just the labor, it‚Äôs the people it takes to get the turkey from the farm to your table that is the problem. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School For well over a century, Harrison‚Äôs Poultry Farm has been making sure one of Thanksgiving‚Äôs most important guests arrives to the family dinner on time. ‚ÄúEverything that goes into producing turkey has made it harder this year, especially labor.‚Äù Kyle Zimmerman and his brother took over the family business during the pandemic. He says national  supply chain  issues have increased many costs, but he credits long-standing relationships with small farms for not having an issue with supply. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre placing chicken orders every day. Where turkey orders, we get a few deliveries every week throughout the year and then our Thanksgiving order, we have so much time to plan for it and so do the farms,‚Äù Zimmerman said. Robert Kauffman runs Ho-Ka Turkey Farms in Waterman, Illinois. He says the problem isn‚Äôt the turkeys. It‚Äôs having the people to dress them ‚Äì take the feathers off and get them ready to cook. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been real worried about getting temporary help for the dressing season,‚Äù Kauffman said. He says he raises about 60,000 turkeys a year, most of which are sold in November. He usually brings in about 100 temporary workers. Right now, he has seven. ‚ÄúI can dress with a skeleton crew but I don‚Äôt like to. And I won‚Äôt get the numbers I need. If I have a nice full dressing line, we can do maybe 2,500 birds a day. The pace I like to have,‚Äù said Kauffman. So how early is too early to stake claim to a Thanksgiving turkey? ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre taking orders currently and we are noticing that a lot more orders are coming in this year than normal. I do think we will sell out early,‚Äù Zimmerman said. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The owner of the farm in Dundee said turkeys are just a small part of his business but says they‚Äôve already sold out of their presale turkeys; that‚Äôs about 250. He‚Äôll have another couple hundred for resale close to thanksgiving.

headline: Supply Chain Delays Could Soon Leave Wine Glasses Empty
summary: Supply chain delays could soon leave your wine glasses empty, but the problem isn't the grapes, it's the packaging.
bodytext: RANCHO CORDOVA (CBS13) ‚Äî  Supply chain  delays could soon leave your wine glasses empty, but the problem isn‚Äôt the grapes, it‚Äôs the packaging. You may see labels for a local craft beer rolling through the printer, but the owner of Capitol Label in Rancho Cordova sees paper he‚Äôll need to reorder‚Äîand fast. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want to over order and have it sit here too long, but we don‚Äôt want to run short,‚Äù owner Michael Mellon said. Transporation, logistics and weather‚Äîthe same supply chain issues we‚Äôve heard before hit this label business at every step. ‚ÄúAdhesives which have been affected by the Texas freeze and you‚Äôve got paper stuck at the ports,‚Äù Mellon said. The two key components of a label are now harder to come by. When it comes to alcohol, it‚Äôs bigger than the design because ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt be compliant with state laws without a label,‚Äù Mellon said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall It‚Äôs not just the stuff on the outside of the bottle‚Äîshortages impact every part of production. ‚ÄúHe said, we are out of all wine bottles,‚Äù one winemaker said of a recent conversation with his bottle vendor. ‚ÄúI ordered a container from China of the bottles we need. The first container took a month or two longer to arrive in port and cost me 50% more than I was initially quoted because of price increases.‚Äù Both companies rely on goods shipped to the Port of Oakland No surprise, more than 99% of containerized goods in Northern California move through it, either in or out. But right now, a lot of those goods are stuck at the port‚Äîand just not making it there. That forces wineries to get creative. Voluptuary and Lucid Wines is about to pivot to a new supply chain for bottles that look different but are available. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized All eyes are on California ports right now as a solution to the backups. About 40% of all container cargo in the U.S. arrives through western ports, and 30% of the country‚Äôs exports go out this way.

headline: Police Encourage Reports Of Suspicious Activity After Teen Found With BB Gun At Millersville High School

bodytext: MILLERSVILLE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî¬† Anne Arundel County Police said a student‚Äôs report Monday about a possibly armed student at a Millersville high school was ‚Äúa great example of ‚Äòsee something say something.'‚Äù Police said the student told administrators and an officer at Old Mill High School that they may have seen a student armed with a gun a few hours earlier. The student was found in ‚Äúa common area‚Äù of the school and a BB gun was found near him. The student was charged on a juvenile citation. headline: ‚ÄòThis Is Not Just Any Usual Recovery‚Äô: Economist Explains Rash Of Price Hikes, Product Shortages
summary: Shortages and higher prices could remain common, as companies struggle with their supply chains and try to predict post-COVID demand during a surge in spending.
bodytext: ( CBS Baltimore ) ‚Äî  The economic turnaround continues as the country pulls out of the pandemic. But the path to recovery has been far from smooth. Shortages and price hikes across a whole range of products continue to plague consumers, and they‚Äôre likely to persist in the short-term. It‚Äôs yet another side effect of COVID, though one that economists predict should improve with time. The early days of lockdown were marked with widespread scarcity for certain key items. Hand sanitizer, disinfecting wipes and masks topped the list, as people sought protection from the little-understood virus. Toilet paper, being maybe the top panic purchase of all-time, also ran low. Stores couldn‚Äôt keep any of it on the shelves. And then, as suppliers struggled to meet demand, stores couldn‚Äôt get it on the shelves at all. Prices, however, remained fairly stable, at least at major stores. READ MORE:  Stimulus Check Update: Is A Fourth Relief Payment Coming? Demand eventually leveled off, or supply rose to meet the elevated need. Or maybe both. People learned that transmission of the virus happened chiefly through the air rather than from surfaces, lessening the need for sanitizer and wipes. Mask production picked up as the pandemic timeline stretched further and further into the future. And toilet paper returned to shelves once panic buying subsided and stores replenished their supply. Other consumer goods became harder to find as weeks of lockdown turned into months and people adapted to a new reality. Public indoor spaces, like gyms, were off-limits. And social distancing limited capacity when they did reopen. Many people weren‚Äôt comfortable returning regardless, but still wanted to work out. Hand weights became impossible to find for a time. Bicycles did as well, with people seeking a safe outdoor activity. Baking became a popular indoor diversion leading to shortages of flour and yeast. With remote learning the norm for school-age children, inexpensive laptops, specifically Chromebooks, became hard to find in the weeks leading up to the start of the school year and through much of the fall. Higher demand was a big issue. Gartner estimates that Chromebook shipments grew by about  90 percent  year over year in the third quarter of the 2020 and  200 percent  year over year in the fourth quarter. But surging demand wasn‚Äôt the whole problem. Supply couldn‚Äôt keep up. The makers of Chromebooks might have met more of the demand had manufacturers not shut down in the pandemic‚Äôs early days. And then there‚Äôs the complicated  supply chain , which pulls in component parts from various places, assembles them into computers in China and then ships those computers to America and everywhere else. Each of those suppliers likely experienced their own COVID-related slowdowns and shutdowns, crimping supply chains even further. U.S.  government sanctions  on certain Chinese government suppliers made matters more difficult as well. Some version of this supply chain story has played out for countless consumer products across the economy, and will continue to play out until demand evens out and supply catches up. Reports have recently surfaced about shortages and rising prices for everything from  chlorine tablets  for swimming pools to  boba , the tapioca pearls in bubble tea. The pandemic has played a role in both of these cases. Home pool usage in warm-weather locales has increased with people stuck at home. Shipments of boba and the starch used to make it are backlogged, along with many other  shipments from Asia  across a wide variety of industries. It‚Äôs unclear when things will return to normal. Shortages and higher prices are influenced by a range of factors. As Ori Heffetz, Associate Professor of Economics at Cornell University‚Äôs SC Johnson School of Business, explains, ‚ÄúYou need workers, inputs, materials or commodities [to make a product]. And you need capital. And then you need transportation. And above all, you‚Äôre trying to predict demand patterns. Things take time to produce, so you try to be ahead of demand patterns. The short answer is this is a work in progress.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe have bottlenecks in almost each one of these things,‚Äù Heffetz continued. ‚ÄúWorkers, materials, commodities, transportation, and the big one, predicting demand patterns. I can point to issues with each one of them.‚Äù READ MORE:  Child Tax Credit: Parents Will Soon Get A Monthly Check, But For How Much? Some of these issues are broad. Many companies across various industries claim there is a shortage of workers. A recent  disappointing¬† jobs report  for the month of April supports those claims. Employers added 266,000 jobs in the month, far below the 1 million they were expected to add. While 331,000 jobs returned in leisure and hospitality, those gains were countered by losses in temporary help services, transportation and warehousing and the auto sector. Generous unemployment benefits factor into the lag in hiring. Fear of an unsafe work environment, particularly with regard to social distancing and person-to-person contact, also plays a part. A third factor is  relocation friction , changes in the employers‚Äô needs in terms of employee skills and workers‚Äô needs in terms of employment. According to Heffetz, ‚Äúpart of it is the old story of workers not keeping up. Those workers who lost their jobs working in a restaurant will not be very quickly be rehired doing something else. These are things that take time.‚Äù With demand rising across much of the economy, demand for commodities used to make things is also rising. ‚ÄúWhen global demand collapsed a year ago, we saw prices collapsing, and now the world is coming back,‚Äù said Heffetz. ‚ÄúSo strong demand, high commodity prices.‚Äù Rising commodity prices and shortages mean economy-wide difficulties in producers securing what they need to make products. That could translate to boba makers not having enough starch. That could also lead to makers of computers and cars (and smartphones and many other modern devices)  not having enough microchips . Without these inputs, production lines sit idle and workers lose hours. And in the case of cars, that leads to higher car prices and fewer new cars available for sale. Buyers then flock to the used car market, pushing up those prices too. Supply chain difficulties are also affecting restaurants. According to Christina Gonzalez, owner of  Taqueria Los Comales  in Chicago, ‚ÄúNothing ever has been comparable exactly to what we‚Äôve been going through right now.‚Äù ‚ÄúChicken, meats, produce, paper ‚Äì anything that basically has to be transported by fuel has gone up,‚Äù she continued. Pick an industry, and it‚Äôs probably struggling to work out supply chain issues brought on or exacerbated by the pandemic. A recent  Federal Reserve report  summarizing comments received from across the business community cited ‚Äúwidespread supply chain disruptions‚Äù as a major factor influence on current business activity. Companies have to revive and retool their supply chains in the midst of drastic changes in consumer demand patterns. COVID has changed how people consume. And companies have to guess now where demand for their product will be when everything settles in the future. That‚Äôs hard enough in a normal economy. In an economy emerging from a pandemic, it becomes much harder still. MORE NEWS:  American Families Plan: What‚Äôs In It, And How Could It Put Money In Your Pocket? ‚ÄúThis is not just any usual recovery,‚Äù in Heffetz‚Äôs view. ‚ÄúRecovery with perhaps long-term changes in demand patterns. And we still don‚Äôt know which things are here to stay and which things are going away. So on top of the usual things, we‚Äôre having to keep up with the quickly recovering economy, but it‚Äôs not quickly recovering to what it used to be, to the old prices, the old inventories, the old products and patterns. We‚Äôre reemerging into a post-COVID world. This will just take time, some think it will take a long time.‚Äù

headline: Maryland Treasurer Nancy Kopp Stepping Down
summary: Before Kopp became treasurer, she represented the Bethesda area in the House of Delegates for 27 years.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (AP) ‚Äî  Maryland Treasurer Nancy Kopp announced Monday she will step down by the end of the year. Kopp, a Democrat, has been treasurer since 2002. She has been re-elected by the General Assembly to five four-year terms. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The treasurer holds one of three seats on the state‚Äôs powerful Board of Public Works, which oversees a large portion of state procurement contracts. The other two board members are the governor and comptroller. As treasurer, Kopp has served as the state‚Äôs chief representative dealing with bond rating agencies and banking firms, responsible for receiving, depositing, investing, and distributing state funds. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The treasurer also leads several key state boards and financial planning committees, including the Maryland State Retirement and Pension Systems. State law requires the General Assembly‚Äôs Senate president and House speaker to appoint a committee to review candidates for the opening when Kopp steps down. That process will begin in the coming weeks. Before Kopp became treasurer, she represented the Bethesda area in the House of Delegates for 27 years.
