All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: Walters Art Museum Receives  $463K Grant From The National Endowment For The Humanities
summary: The Walters Art Museum received a $463,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to fund new inclusive, community engagement initiatives and continue to provide free exhibits and education classes, the museum announced Tuesday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî The Walters Art Museum received a $463,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to fund new inclusive, community engagement initiatives and continue to provide free exhibits and education classes, the museum announced Tuesday. The money comes from an American Rescue Plan program designed to help cultural institutions emerge from the pandemic. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Museum administrators said the money will fund a new team to engage the community and gather feedback and pay for three new exhibits exploring Asian and Islamic art, North and South American art, and Ethiopian art. ‚ÄúAs we approach a new phase in the life of the museum, we see this moment as an opportunity for growth, innovation, and a redefinition of how we use our humanities-based collections and expand and strengthen our work of bringing art and people together,‚Äù said Julia Marciari-Alexander, the museum‚Äôs director. ‚ÄúWe are aligning our focus on community and want to encapsulate the idea of the museum as a center of civic life and dialogue, which includes critical self-reflection, identifying and building relationships with new audiences, and making our collection more accessible through media and technology.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The first of the three exhibit is scheduled to open in Fall 2022. Over the last year, the Walters has set goals for diversity, equity, access and inclusion, including shows featuring more artists of color, the museum said. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúThis incredible grant from the NEH will allow the Walters to re-imagine how we engage with our public to create space for dialogue and societal growth,‚Äù Marciari-Alexander said. ‚ÄúThe Walters believes in the fundamental role art and history play in shaping a better future. We will strengthen our partnership with our communities through dialogue and accountability.‚Äù

headline: Marcel Spears Says ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs Still Not Real‚Äô Getting To Work With Tichina Arnold On ‚ÄòThe Neighborhood‚Äô
summary: 'The Neighborhood's Marcel Spears discusses a brand new episode tonight at 8:00PM ET/PT on CBS and Paramount+.
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì   The Neighborhood  is back tonight with a brand new episode at 8:00PM ET/PT on CBS and also available to stream with Paramount+. CBS‚Äô Matt Weiss spoke to Marcel Spears, who plays Marty on the show, to discuss tonight‚Äôs new episode and what it‚Äôs like to work with talented co-stars. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School MW-  Hey Marcel, good to see you! Season four of  The Neighborhood  still going strong. How does it feel to be a part of this show with all the success you‚Äôve had as a cast? MS-  That means a lot. One of the really amazing privileges is that I get an opportunity to be a part of something that I feel like talks about who we are, at this time. Where we are and what it‚Äôs like to be just the average American family. I think it‚Äôs one of those things that‚Äôs very nostalgic in that way. It‚Äôs so relatable and it cuts across a lot of cultural divides which I think was the purpose of the show. To get to do that and then to get the longevity to do it for four years now and still counting is really, really exciting. MW-  As a bit of a younger actor on the show, how much does it mean to be able to work with people like Cedric and Tichina and Max and Beth? MS-  It‚Äôs still not real. It‚Äôs still not real, like even today with Tichina. In this episode we don‚Äôt really interact as much, so I was passing by in rehearsal and she was like oh my gosh I haven‚Äôt seen you! I have to pinch myself and be like this is Tichina Arnold, it‚Äôs surreal. It‚Äôs one of those things where I‚Äôm honored that I get to learn from them and work with them as I‚Äôve grown, but also as a fan it makes me just like super excited every day. MW-  As you‚Äôve grown as an actor, how has Marty grown as a character? MS- ¬† The cool thing about Marty is him sort of being the bridge between the two families. He has a foot in both worlds being sort of an outsider amongst the Butler‚Äôs because he‚Äôs a little nerdy and a little corny and relating to Dave in that way. He‚Äôs also still being very much a part of the Butler‚Äôs though and has like a cool balance to sort of hold on to. As we‚Äôve developed his character and his role as young man he‚Äôs sort of finding his individuality and being comfortable in his own skin. He‚Äôs learning about love and life and these tougher life lessons that younger millennials are probably relating to right now. It‚Äôs interesting to watch a character like Marty sort of go through these growing pains and changes in and try find himself. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall MW-  As you‚Äôve flushed out Marty as a character over the years, are there any aspects of yourself you‚Äôve started to bring in? MS-  100%. I would say a good portion of Marty is, is Marcel. I‚Äôm a nerd, I‚Äôm a mama‚Äôs boy, I‚Äôm really big on family. Marty has this genuine love and and almost childlike innocence in the way he approaches things; is something that I have always had. I think those are the things about Marty I really admire and those are the parts of myself that I wish I could go to and live in a little more. MW-  In tonight‚Äôs episode Marty is getting set up by a professional matchmaker, what‚Äôs in store for viewers? MS-  So Marty is really putting himself out there. I think in the past, especially in the past season, he‚Äôs been more reserved and he‚Äôs sort of either had crushes on whoever happened to be next to him even if it wasn‚Äôt an obvious fit. He wants so badly to be with someone and be somebody‚Äôs partner that it kind of influences his decision making. Marty is planning to be more selective now and sort of define what he wants. He‚Äôs at an age now where he‚Äôs starting to think beyond just himself. He has a good job, he‚Äôs got his own place with his brother and now he wants that missing piece. I think a lot of young people are turning to the apps these days and so Marty is trying it the old fashioned way; like the old, old fashioned way [Laughs]. So he is getting a matchmaker to find him some lovely candidates and we‚Äôll see how it unfolds tonight. MW-  Wishing the best for Marty and always a pleasure to speak with you Marcel. All the best and take care! MS- ¬†Thank you, man. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The Neighborhood  airs Mondays at 8:00PM ET/PT on CBS and streaming with  Paramount+ . Check your local listings for more information.

headline: Morgan State University Receives $3M In State Funds For School‚Äôs First Endowed Professorships
summary: Morgan State University received $3 million in state funds to endow three new research professorships, creating new research positions to study the brain health of African Americans, predictive analytics and cybersecurity engineering.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Morgan State University received $3 million in state funds to endow three new research professorships, creating new research positions to study the brain health of African Americans, predictive analytics and cybersecurity engineering. The endowed professorships are the first in the Morgan‚Äôs 154-year history, the university said. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School In a statement, Morgan State University president David K. Wilson said the positions will help the university contribute to developing areas in science, technology, engineering and mathematics, or STEM. ‚ÄúThis is a significant first for our university, placing us in an advantageous position not only to build for our future but to ensure there is a future for others, and we‚Äôre excited about all of the possibilities that await,‚Äù said Wilson. The Maryland Department of Commerce provided $3 million through the Maryland E-Nnovation Initiative, a program designed to boost scientific and technological research at nonprofit colleges and universities in the state. Morgan is providing matching funds with a gift from philanthropist MacKenzie Scott, giving each endowed professorship $2 million. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The Endowed Chair in Brain Science will anchor the new Center for Brain Health Disparities and contribute to research ‚Äúon the brain health of African Americans,‚Äù the university said. The position will be housed in the School of Computer, Mathematical and Natural Sciences. The Endowed Chair in Psychometrics and Predictive Analytics, housed in the James H. Gilliam Jr. College of Liberal Arts, will ‚Äúdevelop and use culturally sensitive and technically appropriate assessment tools‚Äù to study and measure human behavior, the university said. The Eugene M. DeLoatch Endowed Chair in Cybersecurity Engineering, named for for the founding dean of the Clarence M. Mitchell Jr. School of Engineering, will study secure system designs for devices with internet capability and worth with multiple departments at Morgan. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: COVID-19 In Maryland: 543 Cases Reported, 14 New Deaths
summary: Maryland reported 543 new COVID-19 cases and 14 new deaths, according to state health department data released Tuesday morning.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland reported 543 new COVID-19 cases and 14 new deaths, according to state health department data released Tuesday morning. The percentage of people testing positive decreased slightly by 0.06% to 3.44%. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Doctors say the new cases are fueled by dangerous strains targeting the unvaccinated. During an August press conference, Gov. Larry Hogan said the Delta variant, a strain that is reportedly two to four times more contagious than the original virus strain, accounts for nearly every new confirmed case in Maryland. ‚ÄúThe vaccines are without a doubt our single most effective tool to mitigate the threat of COVID-19 and the surging Delta variant, and Maryland‚Äôs vaccination rate continues to outpace the nation,‚Äù Hogan said. More than 3.96 million Maryland adults are fully vaccinated. Hospitalizations increased by 18 to 703. Of those hospitalized, 516 remain in acute care and 178 are in the ICU. Since the pandemic began, there were 551,807 total confirmed cases and 10,504 deaths. There are 3,970,057 Marylanders fully vaccinated. The state has administered 8,218,913 doses. Of those, 4,023,879 are first doses with 4,062 administered in the past 24 hours. They have given out 3,661,853 second doses, 3,768 in the last day. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of people who have rolled up their sleeves, Maryland continues to be one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan of the eight million milestone mark. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù The state began to administer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine again in April after the CDC and FDA lifted their pause on the vaccine due to a rare blood clot found in some women. A total of 308,204 Marylanders have received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 220 in the last day. On September 24, after the CDC granted final approval for Pfizer‚Äôs booster, Gov. Hogan announced the immediate authorization of the booster shot for Marylanders who have received their second Pfizer shot at least six months ago. Hogan  had already approved use  for vulnerable populations in early September. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The state has administered 224,977 additional or booster vaccine doses, 7,979 in the last day. The state reported 85.3% of all adults in Maryland have received at least one dose of the vaccine. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of Marylanders who have rolled up their sleeves over the past 10 months, Maryland is one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù In August, the state launched a post-vaccination infections dashboard that is updated every Wednesday. There have been 25,476 total cases among fully vaccinated Marylanders as of last Wednesday, October 13. Less than 0.71% of fully vaccinated Marylanders have later tested positive. Of those cases, 1,842 vaccinated Marylanders were hospitalized, representing 10.8% of all Covid cases hospitalized in the state. 233 fully vaccinated Marylanders have died, representing 8.36% of lab-confirmed Covid deaths in the state. headline: Instead Of Quarantine For Covid-exposed Students, Some Schools Are Trying Test-to-stay
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is now working with select school districts across the nation to evaluate the practice.
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî  Cars line up before sunrise. Tiny heads stick out of the back seat windows, tightly close their eyes and tilt back as the insides of their noses are swabbed for hints of coronavirus infection. For children who were exposed to someone with Covid-19 in one of Marietta City Schools‚Äô classrooms, early morning testing in a nearby church parking lot has become the routine ‚Äî instead of quarantine. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School If the exposed students test negative and have no symptoms, they can continue going to school in person ‚Äî offering some relief for parents who have been overwhelmed with remote schooling during the pandemic. If the exposed student tests positive, they must isolate at home. This approach is called  test-to-stay , and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is now working with select school districts across the nation to evaluate the practice. Marietta City Schools told CNN that it originally implemented its test-to-stay program on its own; it‚Äôs now one of the school districts in touch with the CDC as part of its evaluation process. ‚ÄúIn Marietta we have been tracking students who are testing positive through test-to-stay, and it‚Äôs 3%,‚Äù Grant Rivera, superintendent of Marietta City Schools in Georgia, told CNN on Monday. ‚ÄúThree percent of our students who participate in test-to-stay test positive, which means we can keep 97% of them in class,‚Äù Rivera said. ‚ÄúThat is a measure of success.‚Äù Under a traditional quarantine program, the 97% of students who tested negative would still stay at home from school. For its  test-to-stay program , any student or staff member who is identified as a school-based close contact of someone with Covid-19 and remains asymptomatic has the option to participate in ‚Äútest-and-stay.‚Äù For example, one week in late September, 318 students and three staff members were eligible for test-to-stay over five days. In that time, 123 tests were performed. Six tests were positive and 117 were negative. ‚ÄúI think for the foreseeable future, we will be out here every morning on a school day making sure that our kids have this option,‚Äù Rivera said about test-to-stay. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre doing this in Marietta not because we have CDC or public health guidance. Quite candidly, we‚Äôre doing it because we saw a model in another state,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo, for me as a superintendent who has been tasked to not only develop these solutions but to lead them, I want more guidance from public health based on today‚Äôs data and today‚Äôs dynamics.‚Äù CDC evaluates test-to-stay Federal public health officials have been meeting with states to discuss a potential ‚Äútest-to-stay‚Äù strategy for schools, CDC Director Dr. Rochelle Walensky said last week during a White House virtual coronavirus briefing. This type of policy would prioritize testing as a way to monitor students who may have been exposed to Covid-19, allowing students to continue to attend classes if they test negative rather than quarantine. But there are still many health experts who agree that  quarantines are still necessary . In an email to CNN, CDC said it views test-to-stay as a ‚Äúpromising practice‚Äù and said it‚Äôs ‚Äúworking with multiple jurisdictions implementing test to stay to evaluate the effectiveness of this strategy.‚Äù But it‚Äôs not clear when that test-to-stay guidance could be available. While there are many different approaches to tracking and containing Covid-19 outbreaks in schools, at least three superintendents ‚Äî Rivera; Michael Karner in Lake County, Illinois and Demetrus Liggins in Fayette County, Kentucky ‚Äî have all adopted some form of test-to-stay programs in their school districts. Lake County, Illinois, has been one of the areas sharing data on test-to-stay programs with the CDC. Michael Karner, the regional superintendent of schools and a parent of two children, told CNN that test-to-stay programs have been successful at keeping kids in school safely, if other mitigation measures, such as wearing masks, are in place. ‚ÄúThis program has allowed us to test for in-school exposures ‚Äî where in the past last year, if you remember, anybody who was a close contact was quarantined. The big things for us is there must be appropriate, layered mitigation, such as social distancing and mask-wearing,‚Äù Karner said. ‚ÄúIf those are not being followed, then the test-to-stay program would not work for those close contacts.‚Äù Data from the test-to-stay program show that for Lake County, fewer than 2% of kids exposed to the coronavirus in classrooms convert to a positive case, Karner said. ‚ÄúLast year we had lots of students ‚Äî hundreds of students ‚Äî quarantine just because they were close contacts. But this year, we found that we‚Äôve been able to keep several hundred individuals that were contacts in schools, and we‚Äôve also been able to get data with regards to exposure,‚Äù Karner said. ‚ÄúBased on all the data that we‚Äôve gotten in Lake County, we found out that exposure in the classroom is not leading to conversion, which means we‚Äôre not having many close contacts in the classroom. Most of the close contact situations that we‚Äôve had with regards to exposure have been on the bus and in the lunchroom,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúOn the bus, they‚Äôre very close. Sometimes kids don‚Äôt wear their masks on the bus. And in the lunchroom, obviously, when students sometimes are sitting closer than the recommended social distancing, that‚Äôs when we found it.‚Äù In Kentucky, Demetrus Liggins said that out of the 402 Covid-19 tests that his school district conducted so far through its test-to-stay pilot program, only four tests yielded positive results. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve also found for us that we‚Äôve had very minimal students that ‚Äî since we began this process on September 27 ‚Äî have tested positive after returning to school on a normal basis. And there also is an opt-in option,‚Äù Liggins said ‚ÄúWe still have some parents that choose to quarantine their students.‚Äù Karner and Liggins both emphasized that their school districts require masking for indoor activities, and that mitigation measure adds to the success of their test-to-stay programs. In a contrast, Rivera of Marietta City Schools recently announced that for his district,  masks now are optional  in school buildings and on school buses. The new masking policy went into effect Saturday. ‚ÄúMarietta recently transitioned to a mask optional approach. The reason for that is several. First of all, we‚Äôre seeing significant decline in community transmission. We‚Äôre also seeing a decrease in community positivity rate. Additionally, we‚Äôre seeing fewer epi-linked cases in our classrooms,‚Äù Rivera said. ‚ÄúSo for us, I don‚Äôt believe that public health protocol should be static. We have to make sure that our protocols evolve with the data.‚Äù The  CDC notes on its website  that test-to-stay may be a practice comprised of regular testing and contact tracing, but that‚Äôs also while ‚Äúmaintaining other layered prevention strategies, such as universal masking, to reduce the spread of Covid-19.‚Äù What the science says As researchers and public health experts continue to examine the data around test-to-stay programs, two studies typically emerge in discussions: one out of Utah and the other out of the United Kingdom. The  study led by researchers at the Utah Department of Health  estimates that a test-to-stay program implemented at 13 high schools in Utah collectively saved 109,752 days of in-person instruction for students who otherwise wouldn‚Äôt have been kept in school. The study,  published by the CDC in May , detailed two state programs in Utah, called test-to-play and test-to-stay. Under test-to-play, students were tested for Covid-19 every two weeks in order to be allowed to continue extracurricular activities. In test-to-stay, school-wide testing was implemented in response to Covid-19 outbreaks, as opposed to a switch to remote instruction. Researchers credited the test-to-play program with preserving 95% of planned athletic events. A separate study conducted in England,  published last month in the journal The Lancet , found similar rates of symptomatic coronavirus infections among students and staff within schools that follow test-to-stay compared with schools that follow traditional quarantines. ‚ÄúThey found no statistically significant difference between the Covid-19 rates in schools which did implement test-to-stay and those which implemented a more traditional quarantine,‚Äù said Dr. Meagan Fitzpatrick, an infectious disease transmission modeler and assistant professor of medicine at the University of Maryland, who was not involved in the study. ‚ÄúThis is also supported by modeling work that my group has done, as well as others have done.‚Äù ‚ÄòIt should be less controversial than it is‚Äô Fitzpatrick acknowledged that test-to-stay is a ‚Äúcontroversial‚Äù approach. ‚ÄúI think, in my expert opinion, that it should be less controversial than it is,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut I definitely understand why people hesitate and why people are looking for a firmer research basis for the test-to-stay program.‚Äù In March, the  US Department of Health and Human Services announced it was funneling $10 billion  to states to help implement coronavirus surveillance testing in K-12 schools across the country. For most of the test-to-stay programs currently underway, schools have received free Covid-19 tests and some test administrators from their state health departments. But even with the funding for tests made available in some places, many schools may not have the necessary personnel ‚Äî such as school nurses or other staff members ‚Äî to organize and coordinate such a large testing operation. As the CDC continues to evaluate test-to-stay programs, the logistics and resources needed to implement such an approach likely will be a serious part of conversations. ‚ÄúThe number-one difficulty that I have heard, when I discuss these test-to-stay programs here in Maryland, is personnel,‚Äù Fitzpatrick said. ‚ÄúWhen these school districts consider the test-to-stay program, what that requires is it requires somebody to keep track of which students have been designated contacts of the first infection. And so it requires to track who those students are, and to track their test results every day, and to cross-check again that they‚Äôre getting their tests before they enter the school,‚Äù Fitzpatrick said. ‚ÄúParticularly the  school nursing staff is already overstretched , and it seems that many of these districts face challenges in getting the additional staff that they would need.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The-CNN-Wire  ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2021 Cable News Network, Inc., a WarnerMedia Company. All rights reserved.

headline: Arrest Made In Murder Of Baltimore Man Killed Over Neighborly Feud
summary: Authorities have made an arrest in the murder of a man fatally shot last month in Southwest Baltimore.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police have made an arrest in the murder of a Baltimore man killed over a feud with his neighbor, authorities said Tuesday. Alejandro Gonzalez, 38, is charged with first-degree murder in the shooting death of Travis Ben-Watkins, according to the Baltimore Police Department. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Ben-Watkins, 26, was found shot multiple times about 8:30 p.m. Sept. 4 by police investigating a shooting reported in the 5000 block of Corley Road. He was taken to an area hospital, where he was pronounced dead. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Homicide detectives later learned that Ben-Watkins had been involved in an ongoing feud with his neighbor that escalated when he was shot. Based on their findings, detectives identified Gonzalez as the shooting suspect and got a warrant for his arrest. The 38-year-old was taken into custody in Georgia and extradited to Baltimore late last month. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Court records show Gonzalez has a preliminary hearing scheduled for Oct. 28.

headline: Magnificent Mile: More Trouble For Area That Was Once A Crown Jewel Of American Retail
summary: Chicago Police have issued a formal warning after continued robberies on and around the city‚Äôs Magnificent Mile, at a time when stores continue to leave while others fight to stay in business after big pandemic hits.
bodytext: CHICAGO (CBS)  ‚Äî Chicago Police have issued a formal warning after continued robberies on and around the city‚Äôs Magnificent Mile, at a time when stores continue to leave while others fight to stay in business after big pandemic hits. CBS 2‚Äôs Tara Molina reports that retail leaders say the problem is so bad, that new business is hesitant to move in. That hesitation stems not only from the continued retail theft and robbery issue here, and across the city, but the perception that the city isn‚Äôt a safe place to be right now. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School A stretch of North Michigan Avenue remains vacant and locked up‚Äìtelling of the struggle on the city‚Äôs Mag Mile. Former tenants like Macy‚Äôs and Disney are gone, and there are no plans for a new tenant for the old Macy‚Äôs space at the Water Tower Place anytime soon. ‚ÄúI think it does not help in terms of the recovery for downtown Chicago,‚Äù said Robb Karr, president and CEO of the Illinois Retail Merchants Association. ‚ÄúThe impression around the nation is that Chicago is not a very safe place to be. And the incidents we saw this morning, over the weekend, the episodes before that, only feed that.‚Äù Karr said the sales tax loss related to these continued crimes hits the city, county, and state of Illinois.¬† With continued robberies in the area, Chicago police have issued a warning about suspects only described as young men, in their teens, robbing items on display. No one is in custody, and the robberies are still under investigation. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a serious problem, and we have to address it,‚Äù said Ald. Brian Hopkins (2nd), adding the impact on the city is much bigger than the police warning because shoppers and visitors aren‚Äôt the only people taking notice. ‚ÄúThe commercial brokers tell us that when they get potential interest from a tenant, that‚Äôs one of the first questions they ask, is what‚Äôs happening in Chicago to stem the tide of retail shoplifting rings that have been operating with impunity downtown? And we don‚Äôt have a good answer right now for that.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hopeful those vacancy rates will continue to decline.‚Äù¬† But it‚Äôs not just continued issues on and around the Mag Mile causing concern. At least three 7-Elevens were hit during the Monday morning commute, by crews of armed robbers downtown. ‚ÄúThe Police Department has to work in closer conjunction with the State‚Äôs Attorneys office, they‚Äôve been very reluctant to prosecute retail theft,‚Äù said Hopkins. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Karr agreed. ‚ÄúI think we have to look at prosecution,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúClearly there‚Äôs a feeling running through the criminal elements that there are no consequences here. We have to look to the courts, and I think we have to just look to all the players in this drama to get Chicago to what it once was.‚Äù Hopkins said Chicago police are trying to take a proactive approach by acting on information from sources. ‚ÄúWe have a tactical plan in place to respond to any intelligence that comes our way about planned retail theft. There was a rumor one of the high end stores on Oak Street was going to get hit, yet again, this weekend,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe were able to deploy a force, including undercover resources. It didn‚Äôt happen, fortunately, but we were ready if it did.‚Äù¬† The Cook County State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs office released the following statement with regard to concerns on the Mag Mile: ‚ÄúWe recognize community concerns around crime, and the impact it can have on one‚Äôs sense of safety as well as the economic stability of a business. We continue to prosecute retail theft cases as misdemeanors and felonies when appropriate to do so based on the facts and evidence.‚Äù The State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs office said this year to date, its prosecutors have reviewed and issued charges for 38 retail theft cases in ZIP code 60611, which includes the Mag Mile and Streeterville. A total of 18 were approved for felony charges, 10 were prosecuted, and convictions were obtained for six. The State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs office also noted that in December 2016, State‚Äôs Attorney Kim Foxx increased the threshold for felony retail theft charges to $1,000, which the office said has allowed the prosecutors to focus on the drivers of violence rather than low-level nonviolent offenses. Prosecutors said misdemeanor charges are issued for some such thefts, but those are not included in the aforementioned data. The State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs office also said this year to date, it has reviewed 82 gun cases in the 60611 ZIP code, approved charges on 70, prosecuted 29, and obtained convictions on 23. Chicago Police did not respond to a request for comment. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Meanwhile, at least one Mag Mile store, Nieman Marcus, says it has no plans to go anywhere ‚Äì despite the fact that the building that houses the store has been sold: ‚ÄúNeiman Marcus Group has no plans to close its Chicago location. Neiman Marcus is currently a tenant in this building, which is owned by the 737 North Michigan Avenue Investors LLC.‚Äù

headline: Edgewood Man, 27, Charged With Manslaughter In Deadly Hit-And-Run
summary: An Edgewood man is under arrest in connection with a hit-and-run crash Monday in Harford County that killed a pedestrian, authorities said Tuesday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  An Edgewood man faces charges in the hit-and-run crash Monday in Harford County that killed a pedestrian, authorities said Tuesday. Anthony Lee Wilson, 27, was booked into the Harford County Detention Center, where he‚Äôs being held without bond on charges of criminal negligent manslaughter by vehicle and negligent manslaughter by vehicle. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The hit-and-run crash happened shortly after noon Monday on Pulaski Highway near Reeds Run Road in Edgewood, according to the Maryland State Police. Troopers said a 31-year-old man was walking on or near the shoulder of Pulaski Highway when he was struck by a vehicle, which drove away afterward. The victim, whose name was not immediately released, was airlifted to University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore, but he did not survive. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Based on a preliminary investigation, investigators identified the vehicle involved as a 2019 Nissan Versa driven by Wilson, troopers said. Authorities made contact with Wilson, who was taken into custody at the MSP‚Äôs Bel Air Barrack. Court records show the 27-year-old has a bail review hearing scheduled for 1:30 p.m. Tuesday. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Troopers said additional charges are pending.

headline: Edgewood Man Charged With Murder In Deadly Harford County Shooting
summary: A Harford County man is accused of killing another man during a dispute in Edgewood early Tuesday morning.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Harford County man is accused of killing another man during a dispute in Edgewood early Tuesday morning. Carl Alexander, 32, of Edgewood, is charged with first-degree murder, second-degree murder, manslaughter, first-degree assault and second-degree assault, among other charges, the Harford County Sheriff‚Äôs Office said. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Alexander is being held without bond at the Harford County Detention Center while awaiting court proceedings in the case. The charges stem a shooting reported about 2 a.m. at an apartment building on Dearwood Court,  the Sheriff‚Äôs Office said . Deputies handling that call found Obrien Butler of Edgewood suffering from a gunshot wound to his upper body. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Butler, 36, was treated at the scene and taken to an area hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Based on their initial investigation, deputies believe Alexander and Butler got into a dispute that escalated when Butler was shot. Alexander, who remained at the shooting scene, was arrested on a list of charges including first-degree murder. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Anyone with information about the case is asked to call detectives at 443-409-3302. Those who wish to stay anonymous can call Metro Crime Stoppers at 1-866-7LOCKUP.

headline: Baltimore Residents Invited To Share Feedback On City‚Äôs Crime Reduction Efforts
summary: Baltimore residents are invited to share their feedback on the city's efforts to rein in violent crime during a series of upcoming meetings.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Baltimore residents are invited to share their feedback on the city‚Äôs efforts to rein in violent crime during a series of upcoming meetings. Starting on Wednesday, the Mayor‚Äôs Office of Neighborhood Safety, the State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs Office and the Baltimore Police Department will host several meetings to discuss the city‚Äôs violence reduction strategy, the mayor‚Äôs office said Tuesday. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Members of the public are invited to join these discussions and weigh in with their input on what the city can do to get violent crime under control. Mayor Brandon Scott said the sessions are designed to give the public a say in how the city deals with violent crime, providing feedback that will help shape the city‚Äôs strategy. ‚Äú(Gun Violence Reduction Strategy) has failed before when it lacked community input. We can not afford to have it fail again,‚Äù Scott said in part. ‚ÄúI urge everyone to participate. It‚Äôs imperative that Baltimore City owns this strategy and is fully invested in its success.‚Äù The meetings come less than a week after  Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan publicly criticized city officials over their handling of Baltimore‚Äôs violent crime problem . READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Gun Violence Reduction Strategy, or GVRS, is a strategy that involves forming groups of community stakeholders to develop long-term tactics to curb violence. According to the city, it has led to 30- 60-percent reductions in homicides in other metro areas. Shantay Jackson, director of the Mayor‚Äôs Office of Neighborhood Safety, said one thing is clear: public safety cannot be achieved through arrests and prosecutions alone. ‚ÄúWe recognize the harm that has been done to our communities,‚Äù Jackson said. ‚ÄúIt is vital that we center our residents in these conversations to ensure that we develop trauma-informed practices.‚Äù The first meeting is scheduled for 6 p.m. Wednesday at the Robert C. Marshall Recreational Center. Upcoming Meetings   Oct. 20, 6-9 p.m., Robert C. Marshall Recreational Center, 1201 Pennsylvania Ave., Baltimore   Oct. 21, 6-9 p.m., Greenmount Recreational Center, 2304 Greenmount Ave., Baltimore   Oct. 27, 6-9 p.m., location to be determined   Nov. 14, 1-4 p.m., Cahill Recreational Center, 4001 Cliffton Ave., Baltimore   Nov. 18, 6-9 p.m., Morrell Park Recreational Center, 2651 Tolley St., Baltimore   Nov. 20, 1-4 p.m., Virtual Meeting   MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Those planning to attend these meetings in person are asked to RSVP by calling 43-901-8355. To learn more,  visit the city‚Äôs website.

headline: Study: Less Than 1% Of Defendants Whose Low-Level Charges Were Dropped By Mosby Went On To Commit More Serious Crimes
summary: The authors of the study say the findings suggest drug- and sex-work-related offenses should be reconsidered as a public health problem rather than a criminal offense.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Baltimore City saw almost no rearrests for serious offenses after the State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs Office stopped prosecuting low-level drug possession and prostitution, according to a new report from Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. The report also found the new policy headed off new arrests for low-level drug possession and prostitution, particularly in Black communities. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School At the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020, Baltimore State‚Äôs Attorney Marilyn Mosby ordered her staff to  drop all pending charges  against people arrested for certain non-violent offenses. The move was initially designed to curb the spread of coronavirus among inmates, but about a year later, her office announced  the policy would remain in place. ‚ÄúThere is no public safety value, and never really was any public safety value, in prosecuting these low-level offenses,‚Äù Mosby said at the time. ‚ÄúIt is wholly counterproductive to continue to prioritize low-level offenses over violent crime.‚Äù A key finding from the Hopkins report, ‚Äú Evaluation of Prosecutorial Drug Policy Reforms in Baltimore, Maryland ,‚Äù was that less than 1% of those who had their charges dropped went on to carry out more serious crimes. Based on an analysis of Maryland Courts Judicial Information System arrest data, of the 741 people whose drug and prostitution charges were dropped under the new policy, only six were later arrested for serious crimes. University researchers said crimes covered by the analysis included: robbery, murder, manslaughter, guns and weapons charges, assault, sex offense, carjacking, home invasion, kidnapping, arson, and drug distribution. Based on an analysis of Baltimore Police Department arrest data, researchers found that an estimated 443 new drug possession and prostitution arrests were avoided. The report said most of those arrests (78%) would‚Äôve impacted the Black community. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The report also suggests that 911 calls about drugs and prostitution ‚Äúdeclined significantly‚Äù after the policy change. The report covered the 14 months following the policy change, from April 2020 to May 2021. The study‚Äôs authors said the findings suggest drug- and prostitution-related offenses should be reclassified as a public health problem, rather than criminal activity. ‚ÄúWe found these results very encouraging on the whole because we know that putting people into the criminal legal system is harmful to their mental and physical health, and it seems that Baltimore has been able to reduce that problem without incurring a significant cost in terms of public safety,‚Äù lead author Saba Rouhani, Ph.D., said. ‚ÄúWe think that the next step is to start a dialogue about providing public health services to these people that are no longer going to be arrested,‚Äù senior author Susan Sherman said. ‚ÄúWe should now be asking, is there a sufficient safety net of harm reduction services, treatment, and social services to meet the needs of people who are no longer arrested?‚Äù The report is part of an ongoing research collaboration between Mosby‚Äôs office and the Bloomberg School of Public Health. Read the full report below: MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized       View this document on Scribd

headline: Maryland Women‚Äôs Basketball Opens Season Ranked No. 4 In AP Poll; Men‚Äôs Team Ranked No. 21
summary: The Maryland women's basketball team is No. 4 in the Associated Press Preseason Poll, the 12th straight year head coach Brenda Frese's squad has opened the season ranked in the Top 25. On Monday, the men's team came in at No. 21
bodytext: COLLEGE PARK, Md. (WJZ)  ‚Äî The Maryland women‚Äôs basketball team is No. 4 in the Associated Press Preseason Poll, making this the 12th straight year head coach Brenda Frese‚Äôs squad has opened the season ranked in the Top 25, the team announced Tuesday. On Monday, the men‚Äôs team came in at No. 21, the fifth time in the past seven seasons Mark Turgeon‚Äôs Terps have been ranked before the first tip-off. Last year‚Äôs team finished the regular season 24-2 and captured the Big Ten title after going 17-1 in conference play, but the Terps were upset in the NCAA Tournament by Texas in the Sweet Sixteen, 64-61. The Terps will face multiple major tests before the start of conference play with three straight games against Top 10 opponents during a seven-day stretch in late November, including a matchup against defending national champion Stanford, ranked No. 3. They‚Äôll also face No. 1 South Carolina in a Dec. 12 road matchup. Four other Big Ten teams are in the AP Preseason Poll: No. 8 Indiana, No. 9 Iowa, No. 11 Michigan and No. 17 Ohio State. Turgeon‚Äôs roster is bolstered by four transfers, headlined by former Georgetown forward Qudus Wahab, who averaged 12.7 points and 8.2 rebounds per game, and Rhode Island point guard Fatts Russell, who averaged 14.7 points and 4.5 assists per game on his way to All-A10 honors. headline: Howard County Awarded $7.7M More In Rental & Utility Aid
summary: Howard County announced Tuesday it has received $7.7 million in federal grants to help residents struggling to pay rent and utility bills.
bodytext: ELLICOTT CITY, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Howard County announced Tuesday it has received $7.7 million in federal grants to help residents struggling to pay rent and utility bills. The Emergency Rental Assistance Program (ERAP) funding is on top of $9.7 million the county received earlier this year, making Howard one of seven counties in Maryland to get a second round of ERAP funds. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School In a statement, County Executive Calvin Ball said the county has already been able to help more than 700 households with the initial round of funding. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ With this additional funding, we can continue to support our neighbors who have significant needs as they manage past-due rents and utilities,‚Äù Ball said in part. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Residents who have lost income, dealt with illness or been forced to care for family because of COVID-19 can apply to receive a share of those funds. The funding can be used to cover past-due rent payments and utility bills for up to 18 months. bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Sheetz is more than doubling the amount of tuition assistance it offers to employees, the convenience store chain said Tuesday. Moving forward, employees enrolled in the company‚Äôs college tuition reimbursement program can get reimbursed up to $5,250 a year, or $2,625 each semester. Stephanie Doliveira, vice president of human resources for Sheetz, said investing in employees‚Äô personal and professional success is a key part of the company‚Äôs culture. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúThrough this tuition reimbursement investment, we hope to lighten the financial burden of attending college for our employees, while also encouraging them to grow their careers with Sheetz,‚Äù Doliveira said. All of Sheetz‚Äôs more than 23,000 employees are eligible to participate in the program, which has seen over 7,000 applications since 2012. An estimated 400 employees are expected to apply this semester. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The company said its tuition reimbursement program was launched nearly three decades ago.

headline: Owings Mills Teen Wins 2021 Congressional Art Contest For Maryland‚Äôs Second District

bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Talk about the opportunity of a lifetime: an Owings Mills teen will have her artwork seen by thousands of people who visit the U.S. Capitol for a year. That‚Äôs because Katelynn Clark, a junior at Carver Center for Arts and Technology in Baltimore, was named the winner Tuesday of the 2021 Congressional Art Contest for Maryland‚Äôs Second District. Congressman Dutch Ruppersberger said he was impressed by all of the contest entries, but Clark‚Äôs graphite artwork stood out from the rest. It was selected by a panel of artists. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúHer piece is a great example of the incredible talent we have in Maryland‚Äôs Second District,‚Äù Ruppersberger said. ‚ÄúI want to thank Katelynn and all of the talented students who participated in the contest this year and wish them much luck in the pursuit of their passion for the arts.‚Äù As the winning entry, Clark‚Äôs artwork will be on display at the U.S. Capitol complex for a year and seen by both visitors and members of Congress. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Over 650,000 high school students have entered the annual contest, which recognizes young and aspiring artists, since its inception in 1982.

headline: Magic Johnson On Unvaccinated NBA Players: ‚ÄòI‚Äôd Never Do That To My Teammates‚Äô
summary: Johnson says that players who go unvaccinated are ‚Äúletting down‚Äù their teammates.
bodytext: LOS ANGELES (CBSLA)  ‚Äì Los Angeles Lakers legend Magic Johnson Monday addressed the situation surrounding NBA players who have refused to get vaccinated against COVID-19.   FILE ‚Äî Magic Johnson speaks to the crowd before the NBA All-Star Game at the United Center on Feb. 16, 2020 in Chicago, Ill. (Getty Images)   READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School In an interview with  CBS News , Johnson said that players who go unvaccinated are ‚Äúletting down‚Äù their teammates. ‚ÄúYou have said to your teammates, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm gonna be there for you,‚Äô‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúWell you can‚Äôt be there if you don‚Äôt get vaccinated. You letting them down. And then that hurts our chances of winning a championship. I would never do that to my teammates. Never.‚Äù The most high-profile case involves Brooklyn Nets star Kyrie Irving. New York City has mandated that players for home teams be vaccinated to play. The Nets announced last week that Irving will not be able to join the team until he is fully vaccinated. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Magic Johnson has been vocal about getting the vaccine. He  was publicly vaccinated  back in March at USC.¬†‚ÄúI got my two shots and made sure I put it out on social media,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúI wanted, especially my community to know, first of all, it‚Äôs safe. And the players, again, people listen to them, they follow them. That‚Äôs very important.‚Äù The entire Lakers franchise is purportedly fully vaccinated. Lakers superstar LeBron James at the start of training camp late last month confirmed  that he has been vaccinated . In March, James said that his decision regarding whether or not to get vaccinated was a private one. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized That silence prompted criticism from another Lakers legend, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who  penned an essay  on the subject earlier this month, in which he wrote, ‚ÄúLeBron is just plain wrong‚Äîand his being wrong could be deadly, especially to the Black community.‚Äù

headline: Mayor Brandon Scott Announces Plans To Reauthorize Three Tax Credits
summary: Mayor Brandon Scott along with the City Council announced Tuesday plans to reauthorize three tax credits set to expire.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Mayor Brandon Scott along with the City Council announced Tuesday plans to reauthorize three tax credits set to expire. The tax credits include the CHAP Tax Credit, the Newly Constructed Dwelling Tax Credit and the High-Performance Market Rate Tax Credit. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Officials said the reauthorization bills associated with the credits were introduced by the City Council Monday evening. They will now begin to move through the council‚Äôs process for approval. Mayor Scott is also set to establish a Tax Credit Review Committee that will evaluate the city‚Äôs existing tax credits and ensure the incentive program sustainably and equitably grows the tax base. ‚ÄúI look forward to working closely with Council President Mosby, Councilman Costello, Shelonda Stokes, and the Tax Credit Review Committee to ensure our incentive structure is fit for today‚Äôs Baltimore, while simultaneously benefiting our residents, homeowners, local business community, and overall strategy for growth,‚Äù said Scott. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúGrowing Baltimore in a responsible and equitable way is paramount, and getting our tax code right plays an important role in achieving that goal and ultimately transforming our city,‚Äù said City Council President Nick J. Mosby. ‚ÄúAs Baltimore‚Äôs leaders, we must always be intentional about developing sustainable solutions that bolster smart and equitable development. I am excited to help establish this review committee and will do all I can to support and extend tax credits that deliver results.‚Äù The reauthorization of these three tax credits would build predictability into the process and aid projects in moving forward.   CHAP Tax Credit incentivizes homeowners and small businesses to make substantive rehabilitation of buildings in historic neighborhoods.   Newly Constructed Dwelling Tax Credit incentivizes construction of new row homes and the substantial rehabilitation of vacant homes.   High-Performance Market Rate Tax Credit incentivizes construction of new apartment buildings and the conversion of vacant commercial properties to apartment buildings.   ‚ÄúThe reauthorization of these credits is critically important to growing our City, creating new jobs, and ensuring opportunity across all neighborhoods,‚Äù said Councilman Eric T. Costello, chairman of the Council‚Äôs Ways and Means Committee. ‚ÄúBy establishing the Tax Credit Review Committee, the Mayor‚Äôs deliberate approach will make sure that we continue to offer credits that have demonstrated results in growing our city and that we act in a fiscally prudent manner to drive economic development in all communities.‚Äù ‚ÄúThese tax credits have fueled development across the city so it‚Äôs important to keep them going while we perform a comprehensive review of what‚Äôs working, what‚Äôs not, and where we have unmet needs,‚Äù said Downtown Partnership President, Shelonda Stokes. ‚ÄúThe process matters moving forward, as we create new tools to stimulate investment, equity, and economic opportunity.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Officials said more information will be announced in the coming weeks.

headline: Mayor Brandon Scott‚Äôs Fall ‚ÄòClean Where You Live‚Äô Scheduled For Saturday, Oct. 23
summary: The citywide day of cleaning encourages residents to clean up loose litter around their homes and alleyways.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Baltimore officials want to remind residents to register for the Mayor‚Äôs Fall Cleanup scheduled for this Saturday, Oct. 23. The citywide day of cleaning encourages residents to clean up loose litter around their homes and alleyways. Officials said more than 100 residents are registered so far. To register, residents can call 311, visit  balt311.baltimorecity.gov,  or sign up using the BALT311 mobile app. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Registered bags will be available for pick-up at DPW‚Äôs Sanitation Yards located at 111 Kane Street from 9:00 a.m. ‚Äì 2:00 p.m. and at 2840 Sisson Street from 9:00 a.m. ‚Äì 5:00 p.m. through October 22, 2021, or until supplies last. Residents must provide the Service Request Number they received when registering before pick-up. Trash and debris must be bagged and placed for pick-up with weekly trash collections.  Residents can also bring bagged trash to DPW‚Äôs Drop-off Centers. Participants who dispose of collected debris at the DPW Drop-off Centers must follow the centers‚Äô guidelines, which do not allow commercial vehicles. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Note:  DPW will not collect bulk trash items and roll-off dumpsters will not be distributed as part of this year‚Äôs Fall Cleanup due to modifications. Stormwater credit applications will also not be distributed.

headline: Racism Declared A Public Health Crisis In New York City
summary: The city's Board of Health passed a resolution recognizing the impact of racism on people's health during the pandemic, which magnified inequities in communities of color.
bodytext: NEW YORK (CBSNewYork)  ‚Äì Racism is now officially a public health crisis in New York City. Monday, the city‚Äôs Board of Health passed a resolution recognizing the impact of racism on people‚Äôs health during the pandemic, which magnified inequities in communities of color.   We must confront racism as a public health crisis. The pandemic magnified inequities, leading to suffering disproportionately borne by communities of color. But these inequities are not inevitable. Today is an historic day for the country‚Äôs oldest Board of Health.  https://t.co/nsAJlUqixG   ‚Äî Commissioner Dave A. Chokshi, MD (@NYCHealthCommr)  October 18, 2021 READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúWe must confront racism as a public health crisis. This pandemic magnified inequities, leading to suffering disproportionately borne by communities of color. But these inequities are not inevitable,‚Äù New York City Health Commissioner Dave Chokshi wrote on Twitter. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The resolution calls on the city‚Äôs Department of Health to find way to make changes as necessary. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The landmark resolution goes into effect immediately.

headline: Hogan Announces Low-Interest Loans Available For Those Impacted By Hurricane Ida
summary: The remnants of Hurricane Ida spawned two confirmed tornados over Anne Arundel County that left significant damage to homes and businesses.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Gov. Larry Hogan on Monday announced federal approval of a disaster declaration that will make low-interest disaster loans available to businesses, nonprofits, and homeowners impacted by Hurricane Ida. The remnants of Hurricane Ida spawned two confirmed tornados over Anne Arundel County that left significant damage to homes and businesses. Torrential rain left behind serious flooding in other areas. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The U.S. Small Business Administration disaster declaration unlocks low-interest loans for impacted areas in Anne Arundel, Cecil, Montgomery, Baltimore, Calvert, Frederick, Harford, Howard, Kent, and Prince George‚Äôs counties and Baltimore City. The Governor‚Äôs Office said the loans include:   Business Physical Disaster Loans:¬† Loans to businesses to repair or replace disaster-damaged property owned by the business, including real estate, inventories, supplies, machinery, and equipment. Businesses of any size are eligible. Private, non-profit organizations such as charities, churches, private universities, etc., are also eligible.   Economic Injury Disaster Loans: ¬†Working capital loans to help small businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, small businesses engaged in aquaculture, and most private, non-profit organizations of all sizes meet their ordinary and necessary financial obligations that cannot be met as a direct result of the disaster. These loans are intended to assist through the disaster recovery period.   Home Disaster Loans : Loans to homeowners or renters to repair or replace disaster-damaged real estate and personal property, including automobiles.   READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúI want to thank the federal administration for acting swiftly on our request for this disaster declaration, which will make more assistance available to businesses and homeowners affected by the storm,‚Äù Gov. Hogan said. ‚ÄúOur administration will continue to work closely with local leaders and do everything we can to help homeowners and businesses recover.‚Äù Last Friday, the governor announced  $4 million in relief  for homeowners and businesses who suffered damages. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Baltimore Man Convicted Of Felony Murder, Gang-Related Charges In Killing Of Bartender Sebastian Dvorak
summary: A jury convicted 21-year-old Malik Mungo of first-degree felony murder, robbery and gang-related charges in the death of Sebastian Dvorak, a popular bartender who was killed in Canton while walking home after celebrating his 27th birthday, Attorney General Brian Frosh said Tuesday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî A jury convicted 21-year-old Malik Mungo of first-degree felony murder, robbery and gang-related charges in the death of Sebastian Dvorak, a popular bartender who was killed four years ago in Canton while walking home after celebrating his 27th birthday, Attorney General Brian Frosh said Tuesday. According to Frosh‚Äôs office, the jury heard testimony that Mungo, who was 16 at the time of the murder, had Dvorak‚Äôs cell phone and Nintendo Switch shortly after Dvorak was  robbed and shot in the chest  in the 2500 block of Boston Street on June 13, 2017. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Under Maryland law, felony murder charges can be brought against defendants who are charged with other crimes, such as robbery, kidnapping, carjacking, arson or rape, that resulted in a killing. ‚ÄúWe hope this outcome brings a measure of solace to the parents and loved ones of Sebastian Dvorak,‚Äù said Frosh. ‚ÄúWe appreciate the cooperation and bravery of witnesses who stepped up and played a crucial role in helping deliver justice in this important case.‚Äù A previous trial of Mungo on murder, gang and gun charges ended  in a mistrial  after four full days of deliberations. His defense said he was not the person who pulled the trigger. Prosecutors said Mungo was a member of the gang 500 L, or simply 500, an affiliate of the Bloods operating out of McElderry Park. The gang sold heroin, fentanyl, cocaine and other drugs and maintained control of their territory with the possession and trafficking of firearms, prosecutors said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúMembers of the 500 L gang used violence as their calling card, flooding the streets with fear as they tried to tear down our neighborhoods and terrorize our communities. We cannot, and will not, let them get away with it. Too many families have suffered because of their cold-blooded actions,‚Äù said Thomas J. Sobocinski, Special Agent in Charge of the FBI Baltimore Field Office. Mungo is one of 13 defendants charged in 2018 with gang, drug and gun offenses following Dvorak‚Äôs murder. All have either pleaded guilty or been convicted in court, Frosh‚Äôs office said. Mungo‚Äôs defense attorney, Mark Van Bavel, said his client will appeal. Maryland‚Äôs gang statute allows prosecutors to charge all crimes committed by a gang in the jurisdiction of any one crime. The attorney general‚Äôs office chose to prosecute Mungo in Baltimore County since some gang members lived in the county and kept drugs there. Sentencing is scheduled for Dec. 10. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The Associated Press contributed to this report.

bodytext: TOWSON, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Baltimore County Executive Johnny Olszewski released a new data dashboard Tuesday to display detailed information about opioid overdose, both fatal and nonfatal, in the county. Officials said the new dashboard is set to expand efforts to provide information to the public and increase transparency. We hope this latest dashboard not only provides residents with access to this critical information but also informs our work and the work of community partners as we continue combatting this deadly epidemic,‚Äù Olszewski said. ‚ÄúMany thanks to our BCSTAT data team, as well as the Baltimore County Health and Police Departments for working together to develop this tool, providing the public with access to this important data and further advancing our administration‚Äôs push for more accessible and open government.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The dashboard was developed by Baltimore County‚Äôs BCSTAT team and shows overdoses reported to police from 2017 through 2021.¬† Data for this year currently reports information on overdoses from Jan. through Sept. Residents who suffer an overdose outside of Baltimore County are not included in this data. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The dashboard is expected to be updated quarterly and can be viewed  here.¬†

headline: Ravens LT Ronnie Stanley To Undergo Season-Ending Ankle Surgery
