bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  For the second year in a row, the Baltimore Ravens will have to do without offensive tackle Ronnie Stanley, who will undergo season-ending ankle surgery. Saying that his ‚Äúankle isn‚Äôt where it should be,‚Äù Stanley announced the decision in a statement released through the franchise‚Äôs Twitter account. He becomes the 17th Ravens player placed on injured reserve. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúThis is the best decision not only for my health, but also for the team long term. I look forward to supporting my team from the sideline this season and coming back fully healthy in 2022,‚Äù Stanley said. It marks the second straight injury shortened season for the All-Pro tackle, who suffered a broken ankle during Baltimore‚Äôs Week 8 game against Pittsburgh last season. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Stanley, 27, is  earning a base salary of $990,000 this season  after signing a five-year, $98.75 million contract extension last year, according to Spotrac. When healthy, the No. 6 overall selection from the 2016 NFL Draft has been productive, earning him All-Pro and Pro Bowl accolades in 2019. The Ravens might have some help waiting in the wings after claiming offensive tackle Brandon Knight off waivers Monday.   We have placed LT Ronnie Stanley on injured reserve.    Statement from  @megatronnie .   https://t.co/NjJmbtGn6P   pic.twitter.com/NcqfEESLWi   ‚Äî Baltimore Ravens (@Ravens)  October 19, 2021 MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Stay with WJZ on air and online for updates to this story.

headline: FDA Expected To Approve J&J, Moderna Covid Booster Shots, ‚ÄòMix and Match‚Äô Doses
summary: The FDA is expected to give the green light this week to booster shots for those already vaccinated with Moderna and Johnson and Johnson‚Äîa huge step in protecting against breakthrough infections and waning immunity.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  The FDA is expected to give the green light this week to booster shots for those already vaccinated with Moderna and Johnson and Johnson‚Äîa huge step in protecting against breakthrough infections and waning immunity. The agency is also expected to allow the mixing and matching of different vaccines. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Dr. Kathy Neuzil is with the University of Maryland School of Medicine, which assisted with a study that showed J&J recipients given a J&J booster dose increased their antibodies by 4 times. Those given a Moderna booster saw their antibodies increase by 76 times after 15 days. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt panic. We are seeing some evidence of waning effectiveness of these vaccines, but it‚Äôs waning relatively slowly and the protection against hospitalization and death is holding strong,‚Äù Dr. Neuzil told WJZ Investigator Mike Hellgren. ‚ÄúThe good news is these vaccines were quite well tolerated‚Äîwhether you give the same type of booster or a different type of booster. We saw local reactions, some arm pain, what you would expect to see but no red flags from the safety standpoint for mixing and matching.‚Äù Some want to receive boosters because of concerns about breakthrough infections among the fully vaccinated. Such breakthrough infections have made up almost 13 percent of cases in Maryland since January. Former Secretary of State Colin Powell died this week in Maryland of Covid-19 complications. He was fully vaccinated but suffered from a rare blood cancer that increased his risk of severe illness. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that the vaccine didn‚Äôt work. His immune system didn‚Äôt work to be able to make him a potent enough immune response to protect him,‚Äù said CBS News Medical Contributor Dr. David Agus. Seventy-year-old Bernard Brown is fully vaccinated and told Hellgren he plans to get the additional dose. ‚ÄúCovid-19 is killing people minute by minute. If there‚Äôs a possibility of some type of extra vaccine that‚Äôs going to keep me alive, I‚Äôm all for it.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The FDA is expected to recommend Moderna and J&J boosters for people 65 and older and those 18 and older with certain jobs or medical conditions that put them at high risk. Local health officials say they are prepared to give out more boosters once the federal government gives the approval. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be ready to provide those as will others. We have the supplies on hand,‚Äù said Anne Arundel County‚Äôs Health Officer Dr. Nilesh Kalyanaraman. Many people in Maryland who have received Pfizer are already eligible for a Pfizer booster. You can read the current guidance  here . Dr. Neuzil said the priority is still convincing the unvaccinated to get the shot. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt forget about the unvaccinated. We need the unvaccinated to get their primary series of vaccines or this virus is going to be able to keep circulating,‚Äù she said. This comes as some local governments are trying to get employees to comply with vaccine mandates.   Vaccination update Baltimore City: ‚ÄúAs of 8AM this morning, 53% of employees have uploaded their proof of vaccination. Yesterday morning we were at 48%.‚Äù  @wjz   pic.twitter.com/WDwFkjmHhn   ‚Äî Mike Hellgren (@HellgrenWJZ)  October 19, 2021 MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Baltimore City‚Äôs mandate went into effect Monday. As of Tuesday morning, 53 percent of employees had uploaded their proof of vaccination.

headline: ‚ÄòPart Of Us Died With Her,‚Äô Ja‚ÄôNyi Weeden‚Äôs Cousin Tells WJZ
summary: A day after police announced an arrest in the murder of Ja'Nyi Weeden, her cousin opens up about a life taken too soon.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Ja‚ÄôNyi Weeden came from a big family and was driven by even bigger dreams. The 15-year-old was an aspiring makeup artist with ambitions of opening her own salon. Those dreams were shattered and her family‚Äôs life was upended Aug. 10 when the teen was fatally shot while with a group of people on Gelston Drive in Northwest Baltimore. She was rushed to the hospital, but she did not survive. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Monday, more than two months after the shooting,  police announced an arrest in her killing . A 16-year-old boy, whose name has not been released, is charged with first-degree murder in connection with her death. Ramond Durant, Ja‚ÄôNyi‚Äôs cousin, opened up to WJZ on Tuesday about the life taken too soon. He said his cousin was universally adored within her family. ‚ÄúShe was an absolute angel. Not perfect, but an angel still,‚Äù Durant told WJZ. Between her talents and her dreams, Durant said, Ja‚ÄôNyi‚Äôs family was convinced she would go far in life. They were all waiting on the day that things came full circle and she started her own business. ‚ÄúWe were waiting to see her own a salon, her own beauty shop,‚Äù Durant said. ‚ÄúShe was absolutely magnificent.‚Äù Instead, the teen‚Äôs life was snuffed out far too soon. A senseless killing in a city afflicted by violent crime ‚Äî Baltimore has seen 268 homicides this year, a 1.5-percent increase over the same time last year. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall And while news of the arrest provided the family with a measure of closure, there are some wounds that never fully heal, no matter how much time passes. ‚ÄúA part of us died with her,‚Äù Durant said. ‚ÄúWe really didn‚Äôt have a full experience with her, and it‚Äôs devastating.‚Äù Ja‚ÄôNyi‚Äôs family isn‚Äôt alone. Families throughout Baltimore have been torn apart by violence, whether their loved ones are the victims or the perpetrators. Earlier this month, 16-year-old Delmonte Keels was shot in the same neighborhood as Ja‚ÄôNyi was. His killing remains under investigation. That young people haven‚Äôt been immune to violence isn‚Äôt lost on Durant, who said more needs to be done to help the city‚Äôs youth ‚Äî before it‚Äôs too late. ‚ÄúIf you look at it, the age is getting younger and younger,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúOur perpetrators are getting younger and youbnge, and they are getting more lost, day by day.‚Äù The Keels family has set up a GoFundMe to help them with final expenses.  Click here to learn more or make a donation. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized

headline: Baltimore County Police Investigating Series Of Attempted ATM Thefts
summary: Baltimore County Police are investigating¬† a series of attempted ATM thefts. The latest one happened early Tuesday morning.
bodytext: COCKEYSVILLE, Md. (WJZ)  ‚Äî Baltimore County Police are investigating a series of attempted ATM thefts. The latest one happened early Tuesday morning. Baltimore County Police are looking into whether all of the cases are related. Three suspects READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School There have been four ATMs targeted in Baltimore County in the last 10 days. ‚ÄúHow are you going to open it up?‚Äù Middle River resident Freddie Bullock asked. ‚ÄúHow are you going to get the money out? Unless you got dynamite.‚Äù Just after midnight on Tuesday, one was ripped from the wall of the WesBanco Banking Center in Cockeysville. The suspects were not successful. ‚ÄúThere is a lot of traffic right here, through York Road and especially Scott Adam [Road],‚Äù Cockeysville resident Ashley Galden said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of communities here. So, it‚Äôs very interesting.‚Äù Baltimore County Police said officers noticed three suspects attempting to steal the ATM. The suspects ran. One of them was arrested. ‚ÄúCraziness,‚Äù Bullock said. ‚ÄúPeople are getting ridiculous out here‚Äìstealing ATMs, robbing banks, robbing you. It‚Äôs not safe out here. You‚Äôve got to be careful.‚Äù This is just the latest ATM targeted in our area, there were two hit in the county last week and a third on Oct 9. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Baltimore City has dealing with the same issue over the last couple months, one was targeted there last week. In some cases, the suspects got away with the machine. Baltimore County Police said at least seven ATMs have been stolen this year, down from 37 stolen last year. We asked police if these cases are connected. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs certainly something that our detectives are investigating, but as far as making any connection at this point, we‚Äôre not there yet,‚Äù Baltimore County Police Director of Public Affairs Joy Stewart said. Police have been offering security surveys for businesses to help prevent them from being targeted. A woman who owns a business near where the latest attempted theft happened is concerned. ‚ÄúNext to us, like, literally next to us, and it just really worried me. And then,  Should I stay here?   Should I leave in the future? ‚Äù said Shala Barfar, owner of Shala‚Äôs Holistic Wellness. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Police are searching for the two other suspects they believe were involved with the attempted theft here last night.

headline: Unemployed Workers Union Continue Push For Unpaid Benefits
summary: The Unemployed Workers Union is continuing its push for the payment of unemployment benefits that they say have not been provided to thousands of Marylanders.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  The Unemployed Workers Union said it will continue its fight to get unemployment benefits for people who have not received them. The group filed a class-action lawsuit in July against the state and Maryland Labor Secretary Tiffany Robinson, to address the unpaid claims. READ MORE:  Unemployed Workers Union Files Class Action Lawsuit In Hopes That A Federal Judge Will Reinstate Enhanced Benefits On Tuesday, the attorney for the Unemployed Workers Union Alec Summerfield said that its request for information and documents related to the case was denied. ‚ÄúThey responded objecting to everything. Really hiding behind technicalities like ‚ÄòOh, it‚Äôs beyond the scope or just answering a question that we didn‚Äôt ask,‚Äù said Summerfield. He added that they plan to file a motion to compel discovery to get the information. READ MORE:  Unemployed Workers Rally, Demanding To Know When They Will Get Their Money ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to keep going. We‚Äôre going to keep fighting until we win,‚Äù said Sharon Black, an organizer for the Unemployed Workers Union. In response, Governor Larry Hogan‚Äôs spokesperson Mike Ricci released a statement about the latest update in the case: ‚ÄúThe plaintiffs‚Äô claims in this matter have previously been resolved, so these activists‚Äô requests and questions are irrelevant. We also remain fully committed to ensuring the Attorney General bears the costs of litigation. Overall, 97.9% of all claims have been processed, and more than $14.1 billion in benefits have been paid out.‚Äù A hearing is scheduled for Monday, Oct. 25 after the Maryland Department of Labor motioned to dismiss the suit. MORE NEWS:  Unemployed Workers Union File Class Action Lawsuit To Prevent End Of Federal Benefits Summerfield said that he plans to appeal if the case is dismissed.

headline: Jimmie, Possibly The Oldest Living Male Giraffe In The World, In ‚ÄòHospice Care‚Äô At Plumpton Park Zoo
summary: This 3,000 pound animal has earned the love of many over his 26 years of life, 25 of them right here at the zoo in Cecil County.
bodytext: RISING SUN, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  The Plumpton Park Zoo  announced Tuesday  that one of the zoo‚Äôs main attractions, Jimmie the giraffe, is in hospice care. This 3,000 pound animal has earned the love of many over his 26 years of life, 25 of them right here at the zoo in Cecil County. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúHe is the heart of the zoo, everyone who knows Plumpton Park knows Jimmie,‚Äù said zoo director Cheryl Lacovara. When you pull into the zoo parking lot you see a silhouette of Jimmie the giraffe. Jimmie even has his  own Facebook page . Oftentimes animals do live longer in captivity than they do in the wild because of the healthcare and balanced, stable diet they get, but 26 years is still impressive. ‚ÄúJimmie is 26 1/2 years old. May 9 is his birthday, he‚Äôs halfway to 27,‚Äù said Lacovara. ‚ÄúTypically, male giraffes live to be around 20.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall And with that, Jimmie is the oldest living giraffe in the U.S., possibly in the entire world. ‚ÄúWell, that giraffe is older than me, so I mean, I think that‚Äôs pretty cool,‚Äù said zoo visitor Ciara Hohman. Under old management, Jimmie lived alone for 10 years. But once Locavara took over, they got Jimmie a girlfriend and companion, Annabell, and the two hit it off. She even came in to check on him while we visited on Tuesday. ‚ÄúThey have created a nice little bond, so she tries to help him when she can and she comes in and checks on him when he stays inside,‚Äù said Lacovara As Jimmie battles the issues that come with living a long life, the zoo is now doing what they can to make him comfortable. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Jimmie has battled a hoof issue for many years of his life. Right now he sees the vet frequently and has special accommodations where he lives.

headline: Anne Arundel County Public Schools Facing Staffing Shortages
summary: From teachers to food service workers to custodians, Anne Arundel County Public School leaders say the district is struggling to fill open roles.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  From teachers to food service workers to custodians, Anne Arundel County Public School leaders say the district is struggling to fill open roles. ‚ÄúWe are hiring. It has been difficult. Our colleagues, both around the state and around the country, are suffering the same,‚Äù said George Arlotto, AACPS Superintendent of Schools. READ MORE:  Anne Arundel County Board Of Education Approves $7.4M School Bus Driver Plan In particular, those who take students to and from school,  bus drivers . ‚ÄúOn any given single day, we‚Äôve got drivers that are in COVID quarantine or drivers on sick leave or other things. It‚Äôs sort of a very dynamic situation,‚Äù said Alex Szachnowicz, Chief Operating Officer, AACPS. READ MORE:  'It's Terrible': Frustrated Parents In Anne Arundel County React To School Bus Driver Shortages, Officials Say They Are Working To Resolve Problem Right now, Anne Arundel County Public School‚Äôs Chief Operating Officer says the district is short about  60 bus drivers  but, they‚Äôre doing everything they can to stay afloat and address the shortage. They have been consolidating routes, partnering up with the City of Annapolis to use its public transportation buses for students along with recruitment and retention efforts. ‚ÄúDr. Lindsey and a college is partnering with AAWDC to offer CDL classes to get more drivers into the pipeline of course some of which will come to the schools,‚Äù said Szachnowicz. The Anne Arundel County Board of Education recently approved a  $7.4 million budget  for school bus drivers and attendants which has been forwarded to the county executive. MORE NEWS:  School Bus Drivers In Anne Arundel County On Strike, Demanding Better Working Conditions They are set to vote on it in November.

headline: Annapolis Couple Indicted On National Security Charges In West Virginia
summary: Officials announced Tuesday that Jonathan and Diana Toebbe were indicted today by a Grand Jury in Elkins, West Virginia, on national security charges.
bodytext: MARTINSBURG, Wv. (WJZ/AP) ‚Äî  Officials announced Tuesday that Jonathan and Diana Toebbe were indicted today by a Grand Jury in Elkins, West Virginia, on national security charges. Forty-two-year-old Jonathan Toebbe and 45-year-old Diana Toebbe were both charged with one count of conspiracy to communicate restricted data and two counts of communication of restricted data. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The Toebbe‚Äôs are due in court Wednesday for a detention hearing in Martinsburg, West Virginia. The FBI says the scheme began in April 2020 when Jonathan Toebbe sent a package of Navy documents to a foreign government and wrote that he was interested in selling to that country operations manuals, performance reports and other sensitive information. Authorities say he also provided instructions for how to conduct the furtive relationship, with a letter that said: ‚ÄúI apologize for this poor translation into your language. Please forward this letter to your military intelligence agency. I believe this information will be of great value to your nation. This is not a hoax.‚Äù That package, which had a return address in Pittsburgh, was obtained by the FBI last December through its legal attache office in the unspecified foreign country. The court documents don‚Äôt explain how the FBI came to receive the package or from whom. In any event, the FBI used Toebbe‚Äôs outreach as the launching pad for a monthslong undercover operation in which an agent posing as a representative of a foreign contact made contact with Toebbe and agreed to pay thousands of dollars in cryptocurrency for the information that Toebbe was offering. After weeks of back and forth over email, the undercover agent in June sent Toebbe about $10,000 in cryptocurrency, describing it as a sign of good faith and trust, the FBI says. Weeks later, federal agents watched as the Toebbes arrived at an agreed-upon location in West Virginia for the exchange, with Diana Toebbe appearing to serve as a lookout for her husband during a dead-drop operation for which the FBI paid $20,000. The FBI recovered a blue memory card wrapped in plastic and placed between two slices of bread on a half of a peanut butter sandwich, court documents say. The records on the memory card included design elements and performance characteristics of Virginia-class submarine reactors. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The Justice Department describes those submarines as ‚Äúcruise missile fast-attack submarines, which incorporate the latest in stealth, intelligence gathering, and weapons systems technology.‚Äù The memory card also included a typed message that said, in part: ‚ÄúI hope your experts are very happy with the sample provided and I understand the importance of a small exchange to grow our trust.‚Äù The FBI conducted similar dead-drop exchanges over the next several months, including one in August in eastern Virginia for which Toebbe was paid roughly $70,000. In that instance, prosecutors say, he concealed in a chewing gum package a memory card that contained schematic designs for the Virginia-class submarine. The complaint alleges violations of the Atomic Energy Act, which restricts the disclosure of information related to atomic weapons or nuclear materials. The Toebbes had their initial court appearances Tuesday in Martinsburg, West Virginia. Jonathan Toebbe has worked for the U.S. government since 2012, holding a top-secret security clearance and specializing in naval nuclear propulsion, the FBI says. He has also been assigned to a government-owned laboratory in the Pittsburgh area that officials say works on nuclear power for the U.S. Navy. No one answered at the Toebbe residence on Sunday afternoon in a waterside Annapolis community by the South River. An outside light was on above the door of their home, and a dog barked inside. John Cooley, who lives across the street from the Toebbes, said he counted more than 30 FBI agents on his block on Saturday from about 2:30 p.m. until after dark. He said agents went inside the home. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized (¬© Copyright 2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: Weather Blog: A Near Perfect Fall Afternoon
summary: Marty's Blog
bodytext: Hi Everyone! ¬† It never gets boring talking about another sunny, mild, and darn near perfect Fall afternoon. But I also need to point out that this is another day with no rain in the forecast. As will be tomorrow and for the very most part Friday too. Other than a couple of light sprinkles early Saturday morning, and some light showers on Monday we do not have a lot of rain in the outlook. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ¬†¬†This month has been very dry. Normally we receive a few inches of rain. So far this month the number is 0.24‚Äù, down 1.98‚Äù from normal.¬† And that can be summed up in one word, dry. No make that 2 words, very dry. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ¬† I have mentioned earlier this month that some good old rain helps kick off the colors. I know Western Maryland is starting to have that beautiful hue, but locally not so much. And rain is a part of the deal.¬† But where I am going with this is brush fires. While not like the horrible fires this year out West, we do get brush fires here. Firefighters know how to get them under control quickly but the danger is real. So dealing with any kind of fire outdoors be careful. Cool nights and firepits come to mind immediately by the way. (We won‚Äôt even¬† go to cigarette butts.) ¬† Enjoy this day, enjoy a high of 77¬∞, and be safe,‚Ä¶. on all counts. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† MB!

headline: Loyola University Elevates Senior Vice President Terrence Sawyer To Presidency
summary: Loyola University Maryland on Wednesday announced the school's board of trustees unanimously selected senior vice president Terrence M. Sawyer to become the 25th president, replacing Rev. Brian F. Linnane, who announced his retirement in February.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Loyola University Maryland on Wednesday announced the school‚Äôs board of trustees unanimously selected senior vice president Terrence M. Sawyer to become the 25th president, replacing Rev. Brian F. Linnane, who announced his retirement in February. A resident of Towson, Sawyer is the first layperson to lead the university, with the previous 24 presidents all being ordained Jesuit priests, the school said. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School He assumes the office on Jan. 1, 2022. ‚ÄúLoyola is blessed to have an incredibly talented and dedicated community. I look forward to working alongside my colleagues across the University in meeting the moment and leading Loyola in this next chapter of its long and illustrious history,‚Äù Sawyer said. ‚ÄúThe extraordinary Jesuit, Catholic liberal arts education Loyola delivers to its students is unparalleled. In this moment, we can lean into the richness of our values and tradition, while enhancing Loyola in innovative ways for the future. Loyola‚Äôs future is bright, and I feel honored to be a part of it.‚Äù Located near Baltimore‚Äôs Guilford and Homeland neighborhoods, Loyola University Maryland has 3,813 undergraduate students and offers 43 majors, according to The College Board. Sawyer first joined Loyola in 1998 as special assistant to the president for government and community relations. After a stint as vice president for administration, he was named vice president for advancement in 2015, and two years later was promoted to his current role. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The university said Sawyer led Loyola‚Äôs response to the pandemic and developed plans to safely reopen the campus. Loyola also credits Sawyer with raising $100 million in the Bright Minds, Bold Hearts campaign, growing the university‚Äôs endowment and allowing for more scholarship offers. He also helped raise funds for capital projects, such as the recently opened Miguel B. Fernandez Family Center for Innovation and Collaborative Learning, the university said. ‚ÄúTerry values Jesuit, liberal arts education, knows Loyola‚Äôs strengths and challenges, and has a compelling, foundational vision for defining and shaping Loyola in the years ahead,‚Äù said James Forbes, chair of Loyola‚Äôs Board of Trustees. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a critical thinker with a sound business sense and an appreciation for intellectual inquiry. He‚Äôs also a relationship builder who is ready to help Loyola achieve still greater success with a deep commitment to its Jesuit identity, academic success, and diversity, equity, and inclusion.‚Äù Originally from New Jersey, Sawyer went to undergrad at the University of Maryland, College Park and earned his law degree at Widener University. He‚Äôs also a graduate of Harvard Graduate School of Education‚Äôs Institute for Educational Management program and the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities‚Äô Ignatian Colleagues Program. Prior to Loyola, Sawyer was a lawyer for the Maryland Department of Business and Economic Development. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized He is still a member of the Maryland State Bar, the university said.

headline: Baltimore To Invest $80M In American Rescue Plan Funding In COVID-19 Response
summary: Mayor Scott made the announcement in front of the Health and Services building at Coppin State University, where the city was holding a free vaccine clinic.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott on Wednesday announced the city will invest $80 million into the city‚Äôs health department over the next four years. The investment will finance and expand the department‚Äôs ongoing response to the coronavirus pandemic. The move is the first in a series of investment announcements for the city‚Äôs $641 million in American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) funding. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The mayor said the investment will provide:   COVID-19 testing expansion:  Funding for tens of thousands of at-home tests and dedicated testing staff;   Personal Protective Equipment:  Funding for the purchase, management and storage of PPE;   Telehealth infrastructure:  Funding to help modernize ‚Äúmuch outdated‚Äù systems of Baltimore City healthcare clinics;   Contact Tracing:  Support for 120 contact tracers and supervisors;   Expand Vaccination Effort:¬† Funding for an immunization office to coordinate and increase vaccination rates in vulnerable communities and for a mobile vaccination team of 24 to reach all areas of the city;   Elder Care:  Funding for additional caseworkers and social workers to protect senior citizens from violence and abuse that has been exacerbated by the pandemic.   Combatting Food Insecurity:  Funding to support home delivery boxes and grab-and-go meals to keep seniors, people with disabilities, and vulnerable residents fed during the pandemic   ‚ÄúAs we continue to navigate the COVID-19 pandemic, the public health of Baltimore residents is my top priority,‚Äù Mayor Scott said. ‚ÄúIncreasing testing, vaccinations, and telehealth services to Baltimoreans, particularly in our neighborhoods that need them most, will allow us to continue to keep our residents safe, healthy, and alive.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Mayor Scott made the announcement in front of the Health and Services building at Coppin State University, where the city was holding a free vaccine clinic.   For more information, visit the Mayor‚Äôs Office of Recovery Programs website at  arp.baltimorecity.gov . This page will be updated frequently with the latest information.   ¬† MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Local Woman To Digitally Archive Black Lives Matter Memorial At Enoch Pratt Free Library
summary: After standing for months, the wall was taken down earlier this year but now, Nadine Seiler, wants to make sure those messages live on.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A fence that stood outside the White House after the death of George Floyd became a place to express some of the messages Black Lives Matter protesters wanted to send. ‚ÄúPeople said ‚Äòoh you‚Äôre going to put up a fence to try to keep us out‚Äô ok well, we are going to tell you what we feel about it so all those signs came from all different protests were occurring,‚Äù said Nadine Seiler, Accidental Curator of Black Lives Matter Memorial. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School After standing for months, the wall was taken down earlier this year but now, Nadine Seiler, wants to make sure those messages live on. ‚ÄúThese are the stories, the angst, the history, the love, all the stuff that went into it, the people, their frustrations that they put on this fence to say you know, do better,‚Äù said Seiler. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall She is now storing the signs and artwork that were on the fence and taking trips from Waldorf, Maryland to the Enoch Pratt Free Library in Baltimore to digitally archive each and every one of them. The library has a unique scanner that can process the more than 700 items from the memorial. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúWe have the capability to scan the signs without damaging the signs and without damaging equipment,‚Äù said Jodi Hoover, Digital Resources Manager at Enoch Pratt Free Library. It will take months to transport and scan the items from the memorial but eventually, they will be available for anyone to view online on both the DC Public Library‚Äôs web portal, Dig DC, and Digital Maryland.   It is an effort that Seiler never expected but is very thankful for.   ‚ÄúNobody set out to do anything,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAll we were doing is taking it down from the fence and trying to not have it destroyed. Not in my wildest imagination did I think it was going to be preserved.‚Äù     Leaders with the Enoch Pratt Free Library said that the signs will be digitally available at a date that will be announced later. They are expecting to be scanning the signs throughout much of 2022.   Seiler is also working to get each sign to different organizations that will preserve them.   If you are interested in obtaining a sign, e-mail BLMMemorialFence@gmail.com or contact Seiler through  Facebook.

headline: ‚ÄòI Can‚Äôt Live With Myself Sometimes‚Äô: Chilling Apology From Parkland School Shooter Nikolas Cruz To Victims‚Äô Families After Guilty Plea
summary: "I love you. And I know you don't believe me. But I have to live with this every day. And it brings me nightmares. And I can't live with myself sometimes," Cruz said in court.
bodytext: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (CBSMiami) ‚Äì ¬†Nikolas Cruz, the gunman behind the deadliest high school shooting in U.S. history, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to the 2018 massacre at  Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School ¬†in Parkland, Florida. Afterwards, Cruz issued an apology to the victims‚Äô families. Standing before Broward County Circuit Judge Elizabeth Scherer, and in front of several family members of those who died, Cruz lowered his mask and said, ‚ÄúI am very sorry for what I did. And I have to live with it every day. And that if I were to get a second chance, I will do everything in my power to try to help others.‚Äù READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School He spoke nervously, adding, ‚ÄúI am doing this for you. And I do not care if you do not believe me. And I love you. And I know you don‚Äôt believe me. But I have to live with this every day. And it brings me nightmares. And I can‚Äôt live with myself sometimes. But I tried to push through, because I know that‚Äôs what you guys would want me to do.‚Äù Cruz‚Äô apology came moments after he  pled guilty  to 17 counts of premeditated murder and 17 counts of attempted murder. WATCH: Nikolaus Cruz plead guilty to all 34 counts   READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall During his apology, he said he wants the families of the victims to decide if he lives or or gets the death penalty, not a jury. ‚ÄúI hate drugs, and I believe this country would do better if everyone will stop smoking marijuana and doing all these drugs and causing racism and violence out in the streets. I‚Äôm sorry, and I can‚Äôt even watch TV anymore. And I‚Äôm trying my best to maintain my composure and I just want you to know I‚Äôm really sorry. And I hope you give me a chance to try to help others if we if I believe it‚Äôs your decision to decide where I go. Whether I live or die, is not the jury‚Äôs, I believe is your decision. I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù Despite his plea, by law, it will be a jury that decides whether he gets a life sentence without parole or the death penalty. Defense attorneys are hoping to avoid the death penalty and will likely present Cruz‚Äôs history of mental illness to jurors, attempting to argue for a life sentence instead. By having Cruz plead guilty, his attorneys will be able to argue during the penalty hearing that he took responsibility for his actions. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Given the case‚Äôs notoriety, Scherer plans to screen thousands of prospective jurors. Hearings are scheduled throughout November and December, with a goal to start testimony in January.

headline: Essex Man Gets Life In Death Of Girlfriend‚Äôs 2-Year-Old Son
summary: An Essex man was sentenced Monday to life in prison in the death of his girlfriend's two-year-old son, authorities said.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  An Essex man was sentenced Monday to life in prison in the death of his girlfriend‚Äôs two-year-old son, authorities said. David Marvin Haas, 31, was previously convicted in late July of first-degree child abuse resulting in death, according to the Baltimore County State‚Äôs Attorney‚Äôs Office. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The young victim was found unresponsive in June 2019 by paramedics answering a call for service at an apartment in Essex. After multiple attempts to resuscitate the boy, authorities determined the child had been dead for some time. An autopsy later found numerous injuries to the child‚Äôs body, including blunt force trauma that left the child‚Äôs pancreas torn in half. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The child‚Äôs death was ruled a homicide. Authorities found Haas‚Äô story about the boy drowning in the bathtub didn‚Äôt match up with the nature or extent of the child‚Äôs injuries. In a statement, State‚Äôs Attorney Scott Shellenberger praised Baltimore County Circuit Judge Keith Truffer for handing down a sentence that would deter child abusers. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúI want to thank Judge Truffer for imposing a completely appropriate sentence and my thoughts are with all the people who loved this little boy and to all who will never be able to know him.‚Äù

bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Know someone who goes above and beyond to make a difference in the community? Here‚Äôs your chance to score them some recognition for their good deeds. Rowe Price and the NFL Foundation ‚Äî is awarded to individuals who have shown a commitment to bettering the community. Applications can be submitted through the Community Programs portal on the Ravens‚Äô website. Recipients of the award will be recognized at the Ravens-Rams game on Jan. 2, 2022, where they‚Äôll receive some Ravens merchandise and grant funding for the nonprofit of their choice. headline: COVID-19 In Maryland: 717 New Cases Confirmed, 22 New Deaths
summary: Maryland reported 543 new COVID-19 cases and 14 new deaths, according to state health department data released Wednesday morning.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland reported 717 new COVID-19 cases and 22 new deaths, according to state health department data released Wednesday morning. The percentage of people testing positive decreased slightly by 0.08% to 3.36%. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Doctors say the new cases are fueled by dangerous strains targeting the unvaccinated. During an August press conference, Gov. Larry Hogan said the Delta variant, a strain that is reportedly two to four times more contagious than the original virus strain, accounts for nearly every new confirmed case in Maryland. ‚ÄúThe vaccines are without a doubt our single most effective tool to mitigate the threat of COVID-19 and the surging Delta variant, and Maryland‚Äôs vaccination rate continues to outpace the nation,‚Äù Hogan said. More than 3.96 million Maryland adults are fully vaccinated. Hospitalizations increased by 18 to 703. Of those hospitalized, 516 remain in acute care and 178 are in the ICU. Since the pandemic began, there were 551,807 total confirmed cases and 10,504 deaths. There are 3,970,057 Marylanders fully vaccinated. The state has administered 8,218,913 doses. Of those, 4,023,879 are first doses with 4,062 administered in the past 24 hours. They have given out 3,661,853 second doses, 3,768 in the last day. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of people who have rolled up their sleeves, Maryland continues to be one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan of the eight million milestone mark. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù The state began to administer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine again in April after the CDC and FDA lifted their pause on the vaccine due to a rare blood clot found in some women. A total of 308,204 Marylanders have received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 220 in the last day. On September 24, after the CDC granted final approval for Pfizer‚Äôs booster, Gov. Hogan announced the immediate authorization of the booster shot for Marylanders who have received their second Pfizer shot at least six months ago. Hogan  had already approved use  for vulnerable populations in early September. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The state has administered 224,977 additional or booster vaccine doses, 7,979 in the last day. The state reported 85.3% of all adults in Maryland have received at least one dose of the vaccine. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of Marylanders who have rolled up their sleeves over the past 10 months, Maryland is one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù In August, the state launched a post-vaccination infections dashboard that is updated every Wednesday. There have been 27,420 total cases among fully vaccinated Marylanders as of last Wednesday, October 20. Less than 0.76% of fully vaccinated Marylanders have later tested positive. Of those cases, 1,995 vaccinated Marylanders were hospitalized, representing 11.3% of all Covid cases hospitalized in the state. 261 fully vaccinated Marylanders have died, representing 11.8% of lab-confirmed Covid deaths in the state. headline: Man Seriously Injured In Edgewater House Fire
summary: The cause of the fire is under investigation. The department said there were no working smoke alarms in the home.
bodytext: EDGEWATER, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A man was seriously injured in a fire at his Edgewater home early Wednesday morning, Anne Arundel County Fire and Rescue said. A firefighter also sustained minor injuries. Around 3 a.m. Wednesday, units responded to the 200 block of Beverly Avenue, where they found a fire coming from a second-floor window of the two-story home. The fire was extinguished within 20 minutes. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School   Credit: Woodland Beach Volunteer Fire Department.   A 51-year-old man was transported by helicopter to a burn center for smoke inhalation and burns to his hands and feet. Officials say he is in serious condition, but is expected to live. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The firefighter injured was transported to the Burn Center at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center. The two displaced occupants from the home are being assisted by the Red Cross. The estimated cost of the damage is $75,000. The cause of the fire is under investigation. The department said there were no working smoke alarms in the home. headline: Driver Killed In Multiple-Car Crash On I-695 Near Pikesville, Police Say
summary: Police said four cars were involved in the crash
bodytext: PIKESVILLE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  The driver of a car involved in a serious crash on I-695 Tuesday died from their injuries, Maryland State Police said Wednesday.   Units responded around 3:30 p.m. to the crash on the inner loop of I-695 between exits 21 and 22 near Pikesville. Police said four cars were involved in the crash and roads were closed for about three hours.   The crash remains under investigation.

headline: Nikolas Cruz, Gunman In Parkland School Shooting, Pleads Guilty To All Counts In 2018 Massacre
summary: It's a day many in the Parkland community and across South Florida have been waiting for.
bodytext: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (CBSMiami) ‚Äì  It‚Äôs a day many in the Parkland community and across South Florida have been waiting for.¬†On Wednesday, Parkland school shooter Nikolas Cruz pleaded guilty to 17 counts of premeditated murder and 17 counts of attempted murder stemming from the¬†February 2018 massacre¬†at  Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School  ‚Äî the deadliest high school shooting in¬†US history. Cruz entered the courtroom just before 9:30 a.m. looking calm and wearing a blue sweater over a gray shirt. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Also in the courtroom were victims and family members of those who died including Anthony Borges, who survived after being shot; Tony Montalto, whose daughter Gina was killed; Gena and Tom Hoyer, whose son Luke was killed; and Debi Hixson, whose husband Chris was killed. Wednesday‚Äôs hearing started with Judge Scherer asking him several questions to assess his competency. She then explained to him what a life sentence meant. She explained that counts 1-17 carried a life sentence and asked if he understood. He replied yes to her questions. She then explained the prison requirements of counts 18-34 and asked if he understood. He replied yes. She then asked if he understood that by entering a guilty plea to the counts that he would be waiving his rights to appeal. He replied yes. Judge Scherer then read each of the counts and asked how he wished to plea. Cruz replied ‚Äòguilty‚Äô to each one. WATCH: Nikolaus Cruz plead guilty to all 34 counts   Judge Scherer then accepted Cruz‚Äôs plea. ‚ÄúI find that you are alert and intelligent, that you have made an informed decision with the advice of counsel. I find that you have made this decison after going over and understanding all of your rights and that you are knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently waiving each and every one of the rights that I went over with you today,‚Äù said Judge Scherer. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The defense then made a statement detailing the day of the shooting and those who were shot. Cruz then apologized to the victims‚Äô families. WATCH: Nikolas Cruz apology for Parkland massacre   ‚ÄúI am very sorry for what I did and I have to live with it every day. If I were to get a second chance I would do everything in my power to help others and I am doing this for you and I do not care if you do not believe me. I love you and I know that you do not believe me. I have to live with this every day and it brings me nightmares. I can‚Äôt live with myself sometimes but I try to push through because I know that is what you guys would want me to do,‚Äù he said. WATCH: Emotional day in court for the victims‚Äô families   The case will now move to the penalty phase. Defense attorneys are hoping to avoid the death penalty and will likely present Cruz‚Äôs history of mental illness to jurors, attempting to argue for a life sentence instead. Cruz said the victims‚Äô families and not a jury should be the ones to decide if he lives or dies. He said he understood his stance was in contradiction to the law. Given the case‚Äôs notoriety, Judge Scherer plans to screen thousands of prospective jurors for the penalty phase. Hearings are scheduled throughout November and December, with a goal to start testimony in January. Last week, Cruz stood before Broward County Circuit Judge Elizabeth Scherer and  pleaded guilty to attempted aggravated battery  on a law enforcement officer, and three other charges in the case of the jailhouse beating of a Broward Sheriff‚Äôs deputy, nine months after the school shootings. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized At the Wednesday hearing, Judge Scherer said she accepted guilty pleas. He was sentenced to 25 years in prison minus time served plus a year in jail.

headline: Paula Newsome On Playing Max Roby On ‚ÄòCSI: Vegas‚Äô: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs An Amazing Opportunity‚Äô
summary: 'CSI: Vegas' star Paula Newsome discusses her role as Max Roby.
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì¬† CSI: Vegas  returns with their third episode tonight at 10:00PM ET/PT on CBS and also available to stream with Paramount+. Paula Newsome stars as the new head of the CSI Crime Lab in this new series that takes the franchise back to its Las Vegas roots. CBS‚Äô Matt Weiss spoke to Newsome about the show‚Äôs early success and what‚Äôs in store for viewers tonight. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School MW-  Paula, good to see you! How are you? PN-  I‚Äôm good, thank you very much. How are you? MW-  I‚Äôm doing well over here, excited to talk to you today! Right off the bat what does it mean to you to be a part of the  CSI  franchise? PN-  You know it‚Äôs one of the things that you never imagined happening. You imagine getting all kinds of phone calls but you don‚Äôt imagine getting cold calls to be a lead on the next  CSI  reboot. I‚Äôm just very, very grateful. It‚Äôs an amazing opportunity. MW-  But you did get that call, what was your reaction in that moment? PN-  You know, I took a picture of myself because I was so shocked. I just took a picture of my expression and I looked like that little kid from  Home Alone . MW-  Hands on the face and everything? PN-  Exactly. [Laughs] READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall MW-   CSI: Vegas  has the benefit of having a few cast members from  CSI: Crime Scene Investigation.  How much of a help has it been to lean on those folks who have been through this before? PN-  So very, very helpful. They bring such a wealth of expertise from many years and it‚Äôs amazing. MW-  What‚Äôs the reception like been from fans who have been waiting for this series to return? PN-  I was a little nervous but I will tell you they have been so excited and so welcoming. People are very excited that the shows back and now to have Max as the head of the lab is awesome. MW-  What are some of your favorite things about Max as a character? PN-  She‚Äôs a good person. My belief is that she decided to be head of the lab because the science that they do is so very important to her. At heart she‚Äôs a scientist. that‚Äôs who she is at heart. Taking on this responsibility to be the head of the lab is about Maxine just wanting to put her big wings around an organization. MW-  We‚Äôre all very excited to see that continue to unfold tonight. Paula, it‚Äôs been great to speak with you, thank you so much for the time and all the best moving forward! PN-  Thank you so much, take care. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized CSI: Vegas  airs Wednesday nights at 10:00PM ET/PT on CBS and available to stream with  Paramount+ . Check your local listings for more information.

headline: Booster Shots Could Soon Be Recommended For People As Young As 40, Source Says
summary: Booster protection could soon expand to a much broader population, as a source says the US government likely will soon recommend additional doses to people as young as 40 who received a Moderna or Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine.
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî  Booster protection could soon expand to a much broader population, as a source says the US government likely will soon recommend additional doses to people as young as 40 who received a Moderna or Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine. ‚ÄúI believe it will happen,‚Äù the source familiar with the plan told CNN‚Äôs Elizabeth Cohen. There is ‚Äúgrowing concern within the FDA‚Äù that US data is beginning to show more hospitalizations among people under age 65 who have been fully vaccinated, the source said. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Still, Americans who haven‚Äôt been vaccinated are 18 times more likely to end up hospitalized with Covid-19 than those who are vaccinated, said Dr. Rochelle Walensky, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Unvaccinated people are also 11 times more likely to die from Covid-19 compared to vaccinated people, Walensky said Wednesday. They were also six times more likely to test positive for Covid-19. ‚ÄúIn August, as we were experiencing the peak of the Delta surge, 16 jurisdictions provided data on cases and deaths stratified by vaccination status. Unvaccinated people had 6.1 times greater risk of testing positive for Covid-19,‚Äù the CDC director said. Getting younger kids vaccinated will ‚Äòplay a major role‚Äô in slowing Covid-19 spread, Fauci says  About 28 million children ages 5 to 11 might soon be able to get pediatric doses of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine if the US Food and Drug Administration authorizes shots for that age group and if the CDC recommends it. Getting most children vaccinated against Covid-19 will ‚Äúplay a major role‚Äù in slowing the spread of disease, Dr. Anthony Fauci said Wednesday. ‚ÄúIn the era of Delta, children get infected as readily as adults do. And they transmit the infection as readily as adults do,‚Äù said Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. ‚ÄúIf we can get the overwhelming majority of those 28 million children vaccinated, I think that would play a major role in diminishing the spread of infection,‚Äù Fauci said at a White House Covid-19 briefing. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one of the reasons why we want to do as best as we can to get those children from 5 to 11 vaccinated.‚Äù More news on booster shots expected soon  The FDA last month authorized Pfizer booster shots for people in certain high-risk groups who got their second dose of the Pfizer vaccine at least six months ago. That includes people age 65 and older; adults with health conditions that put them at high risk for severe Covid-19; and adults who live or work in places that put them at high risk of contracting Covid-19. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Advisers to the FDA recently recommended people in those same high-risk groups who got the Moderna vaccine instead of Pfizer‚Äôs should also be able to get a booster dose. But the FDA has not yet authorized Moderna booster shots for those groups. As for those who got the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, FDA advisers recommended all adults who got the single-shot vaccine get a booster dose at least two months after the first shot. The FDA is considering that recommendation. Schools try testing instead of isolating exposed students  While some schools have enforced strict quarantine and isolation policies for children who are exposed to the virus, the CDC is working with select school districts to evaluate test-to-stay programs. Such programs first involve testing ‚Äî not quarantining ‚Äî students who may have been exposed to Covid-19 at school. If the exposed students test negative and have no symptoms, they can continue going to school in person. If they test positive, they must isolate at home. ‚ÄúIn Marietta, we have been tracking students who are testing positive through test-to-stay, and it‚Äôs 3%,‚Äù Grant Rivera, superintendent of Marietta City Schools in Georgia, told CNN this week. ‚ÄúThree percent of our students who participate in test-to-stay test positive, which means we can keep 97% of them in class,‚Äù Rivera said. ‚ÄúThat is a measure of success.‚Äù Under a traditional quarantine program, the 97% of students who tested negative would still stay at home from school. ‚ÄúI think for the foreseeable future, we will be out here every morning on a school day making sure that our kids have this option,‚Äù Rivera said about test-to-stay. The CDC notes on its website that test-to-stay may be a practice comprised of regular testing and contact tracing, but that‚Äôs also while ‚Äúmaintaining other layered prevention strategies, such as universal masking, to reduce the spread of Covid-19.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized The-CNN-Wire  ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2021 Cable News Network, Inc., a WarnerMedia Company. All rights reserved.
