headline: 41-Year-Old Man Arrested And Charged With First-Degree Murder In March Fatal Stabbing
summary: A 41-year-old Baltimore man was arrested earlier this month and charged in the March fatal stabbing of 54 year-old John Werrell, the Baltimore Police Department said Wednesday.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî A 41-year-old Baltimore man was arrested earlier this month and charged in the March fatal stabbing of 54-year-old John Werrell, the Baltimore Police Department said Wednesday. Police said they arrested Barnett Harper on Oct. 9. According to court records, Harper is charged with first-degree murder, second-degree murder and using a dangerous weapon with intent to injure. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School On March 21 around 1:42 a.m., officers responded to the 500 block of Radnor Avenue for a reported assault and found blood and Werrell suffering from multiple stab wounds, police said. Harper was still at the scene and talked with officers. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Medics took Werrell to Johns Hopkins Hospital, where he later died. Detectives learned Harper and Werrell had been in a dispute before the stabbing, police said. Harper lives in the same block where the stabbing occurred, according to court records. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized A preliminary hearing is scheduled for Nov. 3 in¬†Baltimore District Court.

headline: Eastbound Span Of Bay Bridge Closing On Halloween For Run
summary: If you're planning to travel on the Bay Bridge on Halloween, be ready for significant delays.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  If you‚Äôre planning to travel on the Bay Bridge on Oct. 31, Halloween, be ready for significant delays. The Maryland Transportation Authority said the eastbound span of the bridge will be closed from 12:01 a.m. to 2 p.m. that Sunday for the annual Bay Bridge Run. The westbound span will have two-way traffic operations in place, with the center lane closed. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The MDTA said there will also be multiple detours on the Eastern Shore:     The off-ramp from eastbound US 50 to MD 8 will be closed. A detour will be in place to direct motorists to the next exit at Thompson Creek Road. From there, motorists will travel westbound on MD 835 to the signal at MD 8.   The on-ramp from MD 8 to westbound US 50 will be closed. Traffic attempting to access westbound US 50 will be directed to MD 18 to the roundabout at Castle Marina Road and onto westbound US 50. Additionally, residents wishing to travel west on US 50 are advised to approach the highway from either Duke Street or Castle Marina Road.   MD 18 between Main Street and Love Point Road will be closed. All traffic will be detoured through Stevensville on Love Point Road and Main Street.     READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The MDTA advised travelers to move either before 6 a.m. or after 6 p.m. to avoid the traffic. For live Bay Bridge traffic information call 1-877-BAYSPAN (1-877-229-7726) or visit  baybridge.com.  For more information on the run,  visit its website. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Hello Beautiful Looks To Join Elite Company With Third Maryland Million Day Win
summary: With a win at Saturday's Maryland Million Day, 4-year-old filly Hello Beautiful would join some elite company in the state's horse racing history.
bodytext: LAUREL, Md. (WJZ)  ‚Äî With a win at Saturday‚Äôs Maryland Million Day, 4-year-old filly Hello Beautiful would join some elite company in the state‚Äôs horse racing history. A first-place finish in the Maryland Million Distaff would be Hello Beautiful‚Äôs third victory in the annual showcase of Maryland racing at Laurel Park, making her only the seventh horse to win three of the event‚Äôs races since it began in 1986, the Maryland Jockey Club said. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Hello Beautiful previously finished first in the 2020 Maryland Million Distaff Handicap and the 2019 Maryland Million Lassie Stakes. The most recent horse to accomplish the feat was Eighttofasttocatch, winner of three Maryland Million Classics between 2011 and 2014. The others are Ben‚Äôs Cat, Countus In, Docent, Mz. Zill Bear and Safely Kept, according to the Maryland Jockey Club. In her last time out, the dark bay filly by Golden Lad out of Hello Now dominated the field in the Sept. 18 Weathervane Stakes at Laurel Park, winning by 10 1/4-lengths with jockey Jevian Toledo aboard. Hello Beautiful has won three of her five starts in 2021, finishing fifth in the Grade 3 Runhappy Barbara Fritchie Stakes at Laurel Park in February and second in the Shine Again Stakes at Pimlico Race Course in June. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs had a good year, anyway. I like to be humble about things,‚Äù trainer Brittany Russell said. ‚ÄúOur filly‚Äôs doing good and I hope she runs her race. Just stay humble and be happy that she‚Äôs healthy.‚Äù In her career, Hello Beautiful has won nine of 17 races and earned $524,610 in prize money. The seven-furlong Maryland Million Distaff is one of eight stakes races on the card for Maryland Million Day, which annually features the offspring of stallions standing in the state. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized First post at Laurel Park on Saturday is 11:30 a.m.

headline: Harford County Executive Proposes Legislation To Extend Outdoor Dining
summary: Harford County Executive Barry Glassman proposed legislation that would extend outdoor dining, officials announced Wednesday.
bodytext: BEL AIR, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Harford County Executive Barry Glassman proposed legislation that would extend outdoor dining, officials announced Wednesday. The proposed legislation would allow outdoor dining by continuing to suspend parking lot requirements and other local regulations on restaurants, breweries and bars. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúOutdoor dining is safer for public health and my proposal will allow this option to continue in the parking lots of area businesses,‚Äù County Executive Glassman said. ‚ÄúThe extra seating will also expand opportunities for local companies that still need our help coming through the pandemic.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Harford County was the first Maryland county to suspend these regulations to assist businesses during the pandemic. The emergency act would extend through the end of 2022. A moratorium on the regulations that was set to expire on December 31, 2021. Parking must still be provided for visitors to commercial establishments and must comply with all fire, life safety, and American Disability Act requirements. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Shelter In Place Lifted At Bethesda Navy Base After Bomb Threat At Walter Reed Hospital
summary: The installation said security is on the scene. All gates are closed to non-emergency traffic.
bodytext: BETHESDA, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Naval Support Activity Bethesda, a Naval base in Bethesda, issued a shelter in place for over four hours Wednesday for a bomb threat at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. The shelter in place, put in effect shortly after 9 a.m., remained in effect for the entire installation for just over three hours. Just after noon, the order was lifted for all locations except for Walter Reed. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The shelter in place for all buildings was lifted at 1:18 p.m. The installation said it received a phone call around 8:45 a.m. from an anonymous source saying there is a bomb at or near the building. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall All gates are closed to incoming traffic, gates one and three are open for outbound traffic. All patient appointments have been canceled at the hospital. There was initially an active shooter threat when the shelter in place was issued around 9 a.m., but that threat was dismissed around 10 a.m. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized According to the Walter Reed‚Äôs website, the facility formerly known as the National Naval Medical Center has cared for every President of the United States over the years, as well as other national leaders.   1/2 ‚Äì 0925, 20OCT21: At approximately 8:45 a.m., the installation received a phone call from an anonymous source stating there is a bomb at or near Building 10. Security personnel have responded to the scene.   ‚Äî Naval Support Activity Bethesda (@nsabethesda)  October 20, 2021

headline: Gov. Larry Hogan Encourages Marylanders To Comment On Draft Legislative & Congressional Maps
summary: The maps are published by the Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission. The independent commission is the first of its kind in state history. It is challenged with drawing fair legislative and congressional maps for the 2022 elections.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Gov. Larry Hogan is encouraging Marylanders to comment on the draft legislative and congressional maps, officials said Wednesday. The maps are published by the Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission. The independent commission is the first of its kind in state history. It is challenged with drawing fair legislative and congressional maps for the 2022 elections. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Officials said members are divided equally between republicans, democrats and those unaffiliated. None of the members are elected officials or candidates for office. Gov. Hogan also has no involvement. ‚ÄúAs a mix of Democrats, Republicans, and Independents, our members have embraced our charge to create new district boundaries that are free from political influence and offer the opportunity for free and fair elections in Maryland,‚Äù the Commission stated in a recent update to the governor. ‚ÄúWe are continuing to engage the community and urge their participation in this very open, public, and transparent process. We will finalize our commission‚Äôs map plans and present them to you for your consideration. You can expect these final map recommendations by early November.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The commission is in its third round of public meetings. To date, they have held 32 public meetings and have received more than 80 map submissions from the public. ‚ÄúThis is what real nonpartisan redistricting looks like, fairness, transparency, and accountability,‚Äù said Governor Hogan. ‚ÄúWhile the Citizens Commission has already published draft maps and held dozens of public meetings, the legislature‚Äôs backroom partisan process is run by career politicians, has released no draft maps, and has no map portal for citizen input. I encourage all Marylanders to take part in the process and comment on the independent Commission‚Äôs maps. We want to make sure that this time the people of Maryland are actually drawing these maps‚Äînot the politicians or the party bosses.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized For more information,  click here.¬†

headline: NFL Week 7 NFC West Preview: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm Going 49ers‚Äô In Matchup With Colts, Says CBS San Francisco‚Äôs Vern Glenn
summary: The 49ers return from a bye to face the Colts, with an opportunity to even their record and not fall further behind the undefeated Cardinals.
bodytext: ( CBS San Francisco ) ‚Äî  Back in August and early September, the Arizona Cardinals were not favored to win the NFC West. But they currently lead the division as the NFL‚Äôs only remaining undefeated team. And their 37-14 thrashing of the Cleveland Browns convinced many doubters that this Cardinals team is for real. But can they continue to outpace the Los Angeles Rams? The Rams, behind new quarterback Matthew Stafford, continue to win and impress. They dominated the New York Giants, 38-11, in Week 6. While the San Francisco 49ers enjoyed a bye, the Seattle Seahawks dropped a heartbreaker to the Pittsburgh Steelers. READ MORE:  Bengals Visit Ravens With AFC North Lead On The Line CBS San Francisco sports anchor Vern Glenn looks at the four NFC West matchups in Week 7. All times listed are Eastern. Stream your local NFL On CBS game live on Paramount+. Detroit Lions @ Los Angeles Rams, Sunday, October 24 @ 4:05 p.m. The Lions and Rams traded quarterbacks this past offseason. Jared Goff, who led the Rams to Super Bowl LIII, went to Detroit. And longtime Lions‚Äô signal-caller Matthew Stafford became the starter in Los Angeles. Both QBs needed a change of scenery. The Rams couldn‚Äôt repeat that 2018 season, and it became clear that maybe Goff wasn‚Äôt the best fit in Sean McVay‚Äôs offense. The Lions had been perennially bad, despite Stafford‚Äôs impressive numbers. ‚ÄúThis is the game that I‚Äôm sure Jared Goff has had circled ever since he was traded from the Rams to the Lions.‚Äù Glenn said. ‚ÄúAnd locally here, Jared Goff is our guy. He grew up in Marin County, right outside of San Francisco. So he has been looking forward to this one. It wasn‚Äôt the smoothest transition this trade from the Rams to the Lions for him. But here they come, SoFi stadium. We have all that drama, McVay and Goff.‚Äù The Rams come into Week 7 with a 5-1 record. Stafford remains one of the game‚Äôs best passers, averaging 306.3 yards per game and 9.2 yards per attempt, both among the league‚Äôs top five. The Lions, despite some close calls, continue to look for that elusive first win. Goff‚Äôs numbers ‚Äî 250.8 yards per game, 6.3 yards per attempt ‚Äî pale in comparison to Stafford‚Äôs. He also doesn‚Äôt have the weapons around him that he once did. A dominant Rams defense suggests he‚Äôll have limited success again this Sunday. ‚ÄúBottom line, end zone to end zone, it has to be the Rams‚Äô day,‚Äù Glenn said. ‚ÄúFor as good as Goff is and as much revenge he wants to invoke, he doesn‚Äôt play defense. And then Stafford, in that high-powered Rams offense, they‚Äôre going to go up and down the field. It is a win for the Rams, who I believe are a double-digit favorite to close at home.‚Äù Houston Texans @ Arizona Cardinals, Sunday, October 24 @ 4:25 p.m. The Cardinals are the NFL‚Äôs last remaining undefeated team, as Kyler Murray tossed four touchdown passes in their 37-14 win last week over the Cleveland Browns. Arizona is playing for a Super Bowl, based on all of their offseason moves, though few people saw them as serious contenders going into the season. ‚ÄúI have to come clean with this one,‚Äù Glenn admits. ‚ÄúAt the beginning of the year, I did not give any love to the Arizona Cardinals. I thought this was an organization that, outside of Kyler Murray, this was the organization where a lot of aged NFL veterans would would go and finish up their career. And I‚Äôm citing J.J. Watt as one of them, following along the lines of, say, Emmitt Smith, who ended his career with the Arizona Cardinals. But 6-0 is 6-0.‚Äù READ MORE:  'Happy Halloween, Scooby-Doo!' On The Big Screen At M&T Bank Stadium Tonight There‚Äôs a good chance the Cardinals‚Äô winning streak will continue against Houston. The Texans were clobbered last week, 31-3, by the Indianapolis Colts, leaving them at 1-5. Davis Mills has not looked up to the task at quarterback, except for his 312-yard, three-TD showing against the New England Patriots in Week 5. According to Glenn, ‚Äúthat offensive attack for the Texans [is] just not enough to get it done on the road against Kyler Murray and Arizona, who have been the surprise of the NFL. They have to. Numbers don‚Äôt lie, 6-0 is 6-0. And again double-digit favorites to win at home.‚Äù Indianapolis Colts @ San Francisco 49ers, Sunday, October 24 @ 8:20 p.m. The 49ers are coming off their bye week. Jimmy Garoppolo looks probable for Sunday, though Trey Lance still seems hobbled by a knee injury. Overall, the team should be rested and ready for the Colts. Indianapolis easily knocked off the Texans in Week 6, with Carson Wentz spreading the ball around and looking a little more like he did a few years ago with the Philadelphia Eagles. ‚ÄúThe Niners come in a five-point home favorite,‚Äù Glenn said. ‚ÄúThe 49ers, it doesn‚Äôt matter whether Jimmy Garoppolo or Trey Lance are at quarterback. It‚Äôs not a matter what happens when they‚Äôre in the red zone, because of the 11 trips, they‚Äôve scored 10 times. It‚Äôs getting to the red zone and establishing some kind of rhythm to get there.‚Äù Coach Kyle Shanahan has had two weeks to figure out the consistency issue. But the problems also extend to the other side of the ball. The defense has been solid against the pass, allowing just 216.6 yards per game, but the quarterback pressure hasn‚Äôt been there. They‚Äôve sacked opposing quarterbacks just 11 times all season. ‚ÄúThe Colts are a pretty good football team, I‚Äôll give them that,‚Äù Glenn admits. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre much better than that a lot of people expected. But the 49ers almost have to close it out. It is a Sunday night primetime football game. And I just don‚Äôt believe that Shanahan could go two weeks without preparing for this one, to come out and shine and come out on top. I‚Äôm going 49ers.‚Äù New Orleans Saints @ Seattle Seahawks, Monday, October 25 @ 8:15 p.m. The Saints are also coming out of a bye week. At 3-2, they face the unenviable task of keeping pace with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, who lead the NFC South. New Orleans heads to Seattle to meet the 2-4 Seahawks, who will once again be without Russell Wilson. The team‚Äôs longtime QB is out until at least Week 10 after his recent hand surgery. Geno Smith was 23-32 for 209 yards and a touchdown in the Seahawks‚Äô overtime loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers last week. Smith will have Seattle‚Äôs formidable 12th man behind him this week. Lumen Field is ‚Äú‚Ä¶one of the loudest places to play in the entire NFL,‚Äù Glenn said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve experienced times where I‚Äôve actually tried to have a conversation with someone right next to me, and they could not hear the words coming out of my mouth because it is so, so loud.‚Äù The Saints have been a little hit or miss this season. After dominating the Green Bay Packers in the opener, they fell to the Carolina Panthers and then the New York Giants two weeks after. The Saints dispensed with the Washington Football Team before the break. And the extra rest should help them return some key players from injuries. ‚ÄúThey have four guys that were injured that are going to be able to participate in this game. Especially Michael Thomas, another offensive weapon. They got their left tackle back. They‚Äôve got a linebacker Kwon Alexander back.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Turgeon Still Hoping For Long Postseason Run At Maryland The offense still runs behind Alvin Kamara, who has topped 100 combined yards in his last three outings. Jameis Winston has also picked up his production in his last couple of outings, which included four TD passes in the Saints‚Äô most recent win.

headline: Jones Out For The Season As Terrapins Try To Regroup
summary: Maryland plays at Minnesota this week, and these next two games--against the Golden Gophers and Indiana--are crucial for the Terrapins if they're going to get back on track before another brutal stretch against Penn State, Michigan State and Michigan.
bodytext: COLLEGE PARK, Md. (AP)  ‚Äî Maryland coach Michael Locksley said the goal for his team during the bye week was to get healthy‚Äìmentally and physically. Then he immediately announced two more major injuries. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Receiver Jeshaun Jones and linebacker Durell Nchami are both expected to miss the rest of the season. Locksley said Tuesday that Jones had a lower-leg injury that requires surgery, and he said Nchami had upper-body surgery. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a team that kind of limped into the bye week,‚Äù Locksley said. The Terrapins won their first four games this season. Then their much-anticipated matchups with Iowa and Ohio State went about as badly as possible. Maryland lost standout receiver Dontay Demus to a season-ending injury in the Iowa game, and Jones went down against Ohio State. The Terps also lost both games by a combined score of 117-31. Then the schedule mercifully gave them last weekend off. ‚ÄúWe lost to two of the top teams in our league, again not being with all of our players,‚Äù Locksley said. ‚ÄúIt shows us we still have a ways to go against the elite programs, but I feel very confident that we‚Äôll get there because of the type of kids we have in our program.‚Äù Maryland plays at Minnesota this week, and these next two games‚Äìagainst the Golden Gophers and Indiana‚Äìare crucial for the Terrapins if they‚Äôre going to get back on track before another brutal stretch against Penn State, Michigan State and Michigan. ‚ÄúI think a week off is something we all needed,‚Äù quarterback Taulia Tagovailoa said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The news on injuries wasn‚Äôt all bad. Locksley did say he thinks linebacker Brandon Jennings will be back, and he is hopeful that defensive backs Jakorian Bennett and Kenny Bennett will return as well. And although Demus and Jones have combined for 46 receptions and over 700 yards this season, the Terrapins have other capable pass catchers. Rakim Jarrett has 22 receptions for 319 yards and five touchdowns. Tight end Chigoziem Okonkwo has three TD catches‚Äìas many as he had over his previous two seasons with the Terps. Tagovailoa is averaging 314 yards passing per game, the Big Ten‚Äôs second-best mark. The question is whether he can remain at that level after losing a couple important targets. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never heard me be a guy up here that cries about losing players to injury,‚Äù Locksley said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve recruited a room of receivers that I think are really, really strong.‚Äù Darryl Jones (14 catches for 134 yards this season) and Brian Cobbs (eight catches for 86 yards) are two players who may become more important for the Terps going forward. Each is in his fourth season playing for Maryland. Facing Iowa and Ohio State was a sobering experience for the Terrapins, but they still have a chance to have a successful year relative to preseason expectations. This is a program that hasn‚Äôt had a winning season since 2014, and the next couple weeks could go a long way toward determining how much progress Maryland ultimately makes in Locksley‚Äôs third year at the helm. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúAs I told our team, we sit here 4-2,‚Äù Locksley said. ‚ÄúIf somebody told us at the beginning of the year that we had a chance to be 4-2 at the halfway point, I think every one of us would be pretty happy with it.‚Äù

headline: Baltimore County Hosting Booster Shot Clinics For Seniors
summary: Booster shots are currently only available for the Pfizer vaccine.
bodytext: TOWSON, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  The Baltimore County Department of Health is holding three COVID-19 booster clinics for seniors in the next week. Each clinic will be held at a senior center in the county. Walk-ins are available, but officials said pre-registration is preferred. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Here are the locations, dates and times for each:   Catonsville Senior Center:  Wednesday, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.   Ateaze Senior Center:  Friday, Oct. 15 From 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.   Jacksonville Senior Center:  Oct. 26 from 1 p.m to 5 p.m.   Booster shots are currently only available for the Pfizer vaccine. The department said those who are either 65 or older, between 50- and 64-years-old with an underlying health condition, or 18 or over in a long-term care setting should get the shot. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall To get the booster shot, recipients will need to prove they got a second dose of the Pfizer vaccine over six months ago, and that they have either an underlying health condition or occupational risk. The CDC also advised that those who are 18 or older with an increased risk of contracting the virus at their workplace should get the shot. Those who are immunocompromised are eligible to recieve a third dose of either the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine 28 days after their second dose. ¬† MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Maryland Congressman Says He Prescribes Ivermectin For COVID
summary: A Maryland congressman who is a practicing anesthesiologist said on a radio show that he prescribed a medication typically used to treat parasites in livestock and humans as a treatment for COVID-19.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (AP) ‚Äî  A Maryland congressman who is a practicing anesthesiologist said on a radio show that he prescribed a medication typically used to treat parasites in livestock and humans as a treatment for COVID-19. Republican Rep. Andy Harris, who represents Maryland‚Äôs 1st District, made the comments during a call-in radio program that he and his wife, Nicole, co-hosted last month on WCBM, an AM radio station in the Baltimore area, The Washington Post reported. However, Harris said on the program that he couldn‚Äôt find a pharmacist who would fill it. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gotten bad. ‚Ä¶ The pharmacists are just refusing to fill it,‚Äù Harris said on the ‚ÄúCasey & Company‚Äù show on Sept. 17. He was responding to a call from a 63-year-old man who said he and his 56-year-old wife had opted not to be vaccinated. The caller said he wanted to use ivermectin a couple of times a week to boost his immune system but his doctor objected. ‚ÄúYou can go all the doctor-shopping you want; I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre going to find a pharmacist to fill the prescription. That‚Äôs the problem,‚Äù Harris said, adding that national pharmacy organizations are ‚Äúsaying pharmacies shouldn‚Äôt do it. It‚Äôs ridiculous.‚ÄùThe Food and Drug Administration has not approved ivermectin to treat or prevent COVID-19 and has warned people to avoid the drug. Merck, the manufacturer of ivermectin, has said there is no indication the drug is safe or effective against COVID-19. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Also on the program, Harris expressed opposition to both mask and vaccine mandates, specifically asking ‚Äúwhether masks do anything.‚Äù Earlier this year, Harris was outspoken in support of coronavirus vaccines, even appearing at community centers to administer shots himself. But he subsequently encouraged parents not to allow their children to be vaccinated until the vaccines received full approval for children from the FDA. Harris wrote letters to the University System of Maryland and Republican Gov. Larry Hogan earlier this year asking them to suspend vaccine mandates on campuses, citing concerns about exceedingly rare side effects associated with Moderna and Pfizer vaccines. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized  (¬© Copyright 2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: Baltimore Police Searching For Missing 18-Year-Old
summary: Baltimore Police are searching for missing 18-year-old Ahmad Sawalhi.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Baltimore Police are searching for missing 18-year-old Ahmad Sawalhi. Sawalhi was last seen on Oct. 20 around 2 p.m. in the 4400 block of Grape Vine Way. He is described as 6 feet tall weighing 130 pounds. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Officials said he may be driving a 2011 black Infinity G37X with Maryland tag, IEV0873. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall His loved ones are concerned for his well-being. Anyone with information regarding Sawalhi‚Äôs whereabouts is asked to contact the Missing Person Unit at 443-984-7385. Those who wish to remain anonymous can utilize the Metro Crime Stoppers tip-line, at 1-866-7LOCKUP. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Two Days After Mandate Went Into Effect, The Vaccination Status Of Thousands Of City Employees Remains Unknown
summary: The latest figures from the mayor's office show that as of Wednesday morning, 56% of employees have uploaded proof of vaccination. The status of thousands is still unknown.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ)  ‚Äî Baltimore‚Äôs vaccine mandate for all city employees went into effect this week. Employees are required to show proof of vaccination or conduct weekly COVID-19 testing. The latest figures from the mayor‚Äôs office show that as of Wednesday morning, 56% of employees have uploaded proof of vaccination. That is a 3% increase from the previous day. But that leaves thousands of city employees whose status is still unknown. Of the city‚Äôs approximately 13,600 employees, about 5,900 of them have not provided proof that they have the shot. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Cities like New York and Chicago will put workers on unpaid leave if they don‚Äôt follow the mandate. Mayor Brandon Scott said there could be consequences for city employees who choose not to provide proof of vaccination or conduct weekly COVID-19 testing, but the mayor did not specify what those consequences would be. ‚ÄúWe know that the process it‚Äôs just kicking off and we know that when you don‚Äôt follow rules and regulations there are always possible consequences,‚Äù said Scott. ‚ÄúAs we are just beginning this, the testing and everything is just getting into gear, we‚Äôre going to see where we are and hopefully we don‚Äôt have that [consequences] but we will be ready to respond accordingly.‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall Some union leaders said they haven‚Äôt gotten enough details on the vaccine mandate. Just this week, the fire union president said they were still waiting on information on where testing sites will be located. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt even know who the vendor is that‚Äôs going to be doing this yet, so how are you going to do testing if we don‚Äôt know who the vendor is?‚Äù asked Rich Langford, the president of Baltimore Firefighters local 734. ‚ÄúOne of the biggest things our members need to know is exactly how this testing is going to be implemented,‚Äù Langford told WJZ. ‚ÄúWe have no idea. We‚Äôve been told it‚Äôs going to be done on duty, but that also brings in a lot of logistical problems.‚Äù The mayor said employees will receive the testing information they need. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúWe have spread those sites all across the city to make sure that our workers are able to get to these places that are close to their workplaces, making them a wide range of hours so that we could have the access necessary,‚Äù he said.

headline: ‚ÄòI Think That Is Just Horrible‚Äô: Owner Of Escaped Zebras On The Loose In Prince George‚Äôs County Charged With Three Counts Of Animal Cruelty
summary: The owner of three zebras that escaped their Upper Marlboro farm in August and were seen roaming parts of Prince George's County has been charged with three counts of animal cruelty.
bodytext: UPPER MARLBORO, Md. (WJZ)  ‚Äî Police swarm the home of a Maryland zebra owner after he was charged with three counts of animal cruelty. One by one, dozens of police cars and animal control crews swarmed Jerry Holly‚Äôs property in Prince Georges County with heavy machinery in tow. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúIt looks like somebody is in big trouble, ‚Äú said neighbor, Raynette. With binoculars in hand, Raynette was hoping to catch a glimpse of the exotic animals. ‚ÄúI was hoping to be able to use them to see in case they were off in a distance, ‚Äú said Raynette WJZ cameras were rolling Wednesday night as police shut down Holly‚Äôs driveway and used flashlights to search his property. This all comes just hours after police charged the 76-year-old zebra owner with three counts of animal cruelty. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúI just think that‚Äôs horrible,‚Äù said Raynette. Holly is an exotic animal trader and has about 40 zebras on his property. Three of them escaped back in September and one was found tangled in an illegal snare trap that was set just feet from the fence line. Investigators say they believe the animal died of dehydration after struggling a few days in the trap. Two others are still roaming around town and being cared for by neighbors. ‚ÄúWe can literally see where the zebras are at and when they‚Äôre at, so they‚Äôre still out there and we get video of them every day, and we keep track of where they‚Äôre at and whether they‚Äôre healthy and safe,‚Äù said neighbor, Theodore Mackenzie. Court documents say on Tuesday, police found another zebra dead on the farm giving them enough evidence to file criminal charges. ‚ÄúHopefully they will take the animals and take them to a safe place where they can be better cared for, ‚Äú Raynette added. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized Police on scene say officials will use the equipment to remove the body of the dead zebra, while animal control will search Holly‚Äôs home and the entire area to make sure the other animals are being properly cared for.

headline: FDA OKs Mixing COVID Vaccines; Backs Moderna, J&J Boosters
summary: U.S. regulators on Wednesday signed off on extending COVID-19 boosters to Americans who got the Moderna or Johnson & Johnson vaccine and said anyone eligible for an extra dose can get a brand different from the one they received initially.
bodytext: WASHINGTON (AP)  ‚Äî U.S. regulators on Wednesday signed off on extending COVID-19 boosters to Americans who got the Moderna or Johnson & Johnson vaccine and said anyone eligible for an extra dose can get a brand different from the one they received initially. The Food and Drug Administration‚Äôs decisions mark a big step toward expanding the U.S. booster campaign, which began with extra doses of the Pfizer vaccine last month. But before more people roll up their sleeves, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will consult an expert panel later this week before finalizing official recommendations for who should get boosters and when. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The latest moves would expand by tens of millions the number of Americans eligible for boosters and formally allow ‚Äúmixing and matching‚Äù of shots ‚Äî making it simpler to get another dose, especially for people who had a side effect from one brand but still want the proven protection of vaccination. Specifically, the FDA authorized a third Moderna shot for seniors and others at high risk from COVID-19 because of their health problems, jobs or living conditions ‚Äî six months after their last shot. One big change: Moderna‚Äôs booster will be half the dose that‚Äôs used for the first two shots, based on company data showing that was plenty to rev up immunity again. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall For J&J‚Äôs single-shot vaccine, the FDA said all U.S. recipients should get a second dose at least two months following their initial vaccination. The FDA rulings differ because the vaccines are made differently, with different dosing schedules‚Äìand the J&J vaccine has consistently shown a lower level of effectiveness than either of the two-shot Moderna and Pfizer vaccines. headline: Anne Arundel County Teachers Rally Outside Board Of Education Meeting Over Staff Shortages
summary: Leaders are struggling to fill jobs for teachers as well as for custodians, cafeteria workers and bus drivers.
bodytext: ANNAPOLIS, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  There‚Äôs growing concern over staff shortages in schools, specifically in Anne Arundel County. Teachers gathered Wednesday afternoon in Annapolis outside the Board of Education to voice their concerns. Leaders are struggling to fill jobs for teachers as well as for custodians, cafeteria workers and bus drivers. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ‚ÄúWe are hiring. It has been difficult. Our colleagues, both around the state and around the country, are suffering the same,‚Äù said George Arlotto, AACPS Superintendent of Schools Tuesday. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall School leaders are planning a job fair to help address the issue. The Anne Arundel County Board of Education recently approved a  $7.4 million budget  for school bus drivers and attendants which has been forwarded to the county executive. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized They are set to vote on the budget in November.

headline: ‚ÄòWe Want Good Teachers‚Äô: Local School Leaders Share Impacts Of Nationwide Teacher Shortage
summary: WJZ spoke with the superintendent of Baltimore County Public Schools about the nationwide shortage and how it's impacting the district.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Teacher shortages are impacting  school systems  across the country. WJZ spoke with the superintendent of  Baltimore County Public Schools  about the nationwide shortage and how it‚Äôs impacting the district. READ MORE:  Anne Arundel County Public Schools Facing Staffing Shortages ‚ÄúThis is not a new conversation for all of us, unfortunately,‚Äù Superintendent Dr. Darryl Williams said. ‚ÄúI think the pandemic has exasperated all of this. Folks are concerned. We‚Äôre still concerned. We want good teachers.‚Äù Baltimore County Public School leaders said they‚Äôre not in a critical shortage but continue to recruit teachers because of the large size of their school system. In  Anne Arundel County , school leaders are very concerned about the shortage, especially when it comes to bus drivers. The teacher‚Äôs association president, Russell Leone, worries about overwhelming the staff they already have. READ MORE:  Baltimore County Public Schools Feeling The Impact Of Nationwide Teacher Shortage ‚ÄúWe want to make sure that our teachers really just don‚Äôt burn out because, right now, they‚Äôre working ridiculous amount of hours,‚Äù Leone said. Dr. Williams, who used to be a principal, said that he‚Äôs been worried about teacher shortages for 10 years. The county is working to encourage its students to become teachers one day. ‚ÄúWe have been increasing, just an awareness of, ‚Äòlet‚Äôs become a teacher,‚Äô‚Äù Dr. Williams said. ‚ÄúWe have our Teacher Academy of Maryland program at our high schools. We‚Äôre doing ‚Äògrow your own‚Äô and now I think we‚Äôre starting to see a lot of these conversations and we‚Äôre starting to see the data.‚Äù Parents we spoke with are hoping more qualified candidates step up to the plate.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a difficult job that nobody wants,‚Äù parents Chris Maler said. ‚ÄúIt takes a special heart to do. You have to have that passion for it.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  ‚ÄòWe Really See A Crisis‚Äô Top Maryland Educators Alarmed Over Looming Teacher Shortage Exacerbated By Covid Pandemic Baltimore County Schools leaders are also recruiting future staff members from local universities and host job fairs regularly. The next job fair will be on Oct. 29 for retired teachers and professionals. It will be held at the Loyola University Graduate Center from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m.

headline: State Agencies Say Labor Shortages Are Impacting Processing Times For Unemployment Claims
summary: Thousands of Marylanders are still waiting for unemployment checks and the company assisting the state is working overtime to make it happen. But, the labor shortage is taking its toll on these state agencies.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Thousands of Marylanders are still waiting for unemployment checks and the company assisting the state is working overtime to make it happen. But, the labor shortage is taking its toll on these state agencies. ‚ÄùI anticipate more progress to be made in the coming weeks. I want to answer every call, every day of the week. They are still answering the phone seven days of the week, by the way, my staff is working overtime seven days a week,‚Äù said Tiffany Robinson, Secretary for the Maryland Department of Labor. READ MORE:  Unemployed Workers Union Continue Push For Unpaid Benefits For the next six months, the state will continue working with Alorica. They have processed 844,000 claims, about 97.9 percent, but the 2.1 percent that remains represent thousands of Maryland families. The  Unemployed Workers Union  held a rally Monday expressing their frustration about the backlog. One man said his account is put on hold every few months. READ MORE:  Unemployed Workers Union Files Class Action Lawsuit In Hopes That A Federal Judge Will Reinstate Enhanced Benefits Maryland Comptroller Peter Franchot is begging the Dept of Labor to figure this out soon. ‚ÄúTry to deliver as much as you can, because there is a lot of suffering out there,‚Äù Franchot said. Alorica hopes to hire an additional 675 employees. They said they have struggled to employ half of that with only 250 employees currently. ‚ÄúI hope you know we are doing the best we can and we absolutely will get the benefits to every Marylander who deserves them,‚Äù Robinson added. MORE NEWS:  Unemployed Workers Rally, Demanding To Know When They Will Get Their Money Fraud remains a national problem. The FBI continues to search through legitimate unemployment claims.

headline: White House Details Plans To Vaccinate 28M Children Ages 5-11
summary: Children ages 5 to 11 will soon be able to get a COVID-19 shot at their pediatrician‚Äôs office, local pharmacy and potentially even their school, the White House said Wednesday as it detailed plans for the expected authorization of the Pfizer shot for elementary school youngsters in a matter of weeks.
bodytext: WASHINGTON (AP/WJZ) ‚Äî  Children ages 5 to 11 will soon be able to get a COVID-19 shot at their pediatrician‚Äôs office, local pharmacy and potentially even their school, the White House said Wednesday as it detailed plans for the expected authorization of the Pfizer shot for elementary school youngsters in a matter of weeks. Federal regulators will meet over the next two weeks to weigh the safety and effectiveness of giving low-dose shots to the roughly 28 million children in that age group. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Within hours of formal approval, which is expected after the Food and Drug Administration signs off and a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advisory panel meets on Nov. 2-3, millions of doses will begin going out to providers across the country, along with the smaller needles needed for injecting young children. Within days of that, the vaccine will be ready to go into arms on a wide scale. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre completing the operational planning to ensure vaccinations for kids ages 5 to 11 are available, easy and convenient,‚Äù White House COVID-19 coordinator Jeff Zients said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to be ready, pending the FDA and CDC decision.‚Äù The Pfizer vaccine requires two doses three weeks apart and a two-week wait for full protection to kick in, meaning the first youngsters in line will be fully covered by Christmas. Some parents can hardly wait. Dr. Sterling Ransone said his rural Deltaville, Virginia, office is already getting calls from people asking for appointments for their children and saying, ‚ÄúI want my shot now.‚Äù ‚ÄúJudging by the number of calls, I think we‚Äôre going to be slammed for the first several weeks,‚Äù said Ransone, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians. Justin Shady, a film and TV writer in Chicago, said his 6-year-old daughter, Grey, got nervous when he told her she would be getting the shots soon. But he is bribing her with a trip to Disney World, and ‚Äúshe‚Äôs all in.‚Äù The family likes to travel, ‚Äúwe really just want to get back in the swing of seeing the world,‚Äù Shady said. As for youngsters under 5, Pfizer and Moderna are studying their vaccines in children down to 6 months old, with results expected later in the year. The Biden administration noted that the expansion of shots to children under 12 will not look like the start of the country‚Äôs vaccine rollout 10 months ago, when limited doses and inadequate capacity meant a painstaking wait for many Americans. The country now has ample supplies of the Pfizer shot to vaccinate the children who will soon be eligible, officials said, and they have been working for months to ensure widespread availability of shots. About 15 million doses will be shipped to providers across the U.S. in the first week after approval, the White House said. More than 25,000 pediatricians and primary care providers have already signed on to dispense the vaccine to elementary school children, the White House said, in addition to the tens of thousands of drugstores that are already administering shots to adults. Hundreds of school- and community-based clinics will also be funded and supported by the Federal Emergency Management Agency to help speed the process. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall In addition to doctors‚Äô offices, schools are likely be popular spots for the shots. In Maryland, state officials have offered to help schools set up vaccination clinics. Denver‚Äôs public schools plan to hold mass vaccination events for young children, along with smaller clinics offering shots during the school day and in the evenings. Chicago‚Äôs public health department is working closely with schools, which have already been hosting vaccination events for students age 12 and older and their families. The White House is also preparing a stepped-up campaign to educate parents and children about the safety of the shots and the ease of getting them. As has been the case for adult vaccinations, the administration believes trusted messengers ‚Äî educators, doctors and community leaders ‚Äî will be vital to encouraging vaccinations. Dr. Lisa Reed, medical director for family medicine at MAHEC, a western North Carolina safety net provider that serves patients from rural Appalachia and more urban communities such as the tourist town of Asheville, said it is going to take effort to get some families on board. Reed said she lives ‚Äúin a community that has a lot of vaccine hesitancy, unfortunately.‚Äù ‚ÄúSome have lower health literacy or belong to ethnic groups that are more hesitant in general‚Äù because of a history of mistrust, she said. And Asheville, she said, has a sizeable population of well-educated adults who are longtime vaccine skeptics. While children run a lower risk than older people of getting seriously ill from COVID-19, at least 637 people age 18 or under have died from the virus in the U.S., according to the CDC. Six million U.S. children been infected, 1 million of them since early September amid the spread of the more contagious delta variant, the American Academy of Pediatrics says. Health officials believe that expanding the vaccine drive will not only curb the alarming number of infections in children but also reduce the spread of the virus to vulnerable adults. It could also help schools stay open and youngsters get back on track academically, and contribute to the nation‚Äôs broader recovery from the pandemic. ‚ÄúCOVID has also disrupted our kids‚Äô lives. It‚Äôs made school harder, it‚Äôs disrupted their ability to see friends and family, it‚Äôs made youth sports more challenging,‚Äù U.S. Surgeon General Dr. Vivek Murthy told NBC. ‚ÄúGetting our kids vaccinated, we have the prospect of protecting them, but also getting all of those activities back that are so important to our children.‚Äù Murthy said the administration, which is imposing vaccine mandates for millions of adults, is leaving it up to state and local officials to decide whether to require schoolchildren to get vaccinated. But he said such measures would be ‚Äúa reasonable thing to consider.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also consistent with what we‚Äôve done for other childhood vaccines, like measles, mumps, polio,‚Äù he said. The U.S. has purchased 65 million doses of the Pfizer pediatric shot, which is expected to be one-third the dose given to adults and adolescents, according to officials. They will be shipped in smaller packages of about 100 doses each, so that more providers can deliver them, and they won‚Äôt require the super-cold storage that the adult version did at first. About 219 million Americans age 12 and up, or 66% of the total population, have received a COVID-19 shot, and nearly 190 million are fully vaccinated. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: Jonathan & Diana Toebbe Plead Not Guilty To Espionage Charges
summary: A U.S. Navy nuclear engineer from Annapolis will remain in custody while awaiting trial on espionage charges, but a federal judge has yet to determine if that should be the case for his wife.
bodytext: BALTIMORE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A U.S. Navy nuclear engineer from Annapolis will remain in custody while  awaiting trial on espionage charges , but a federal judge has yet to determine if that should be the case for his wife. Jonathan Toebbe, 42, and his wife, Diana, 45, pleaded not guilty Wednesday when they were arraigned in a West Virginia federal court on a three-count indictment charging them with selling classified data to someone they thought was a foreign intelligence officer but was in fact an undercover FBI agent. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The couple was arrested earlier this month following an FBI sting operation. Authorities say over the course of several months, Toebbe hid memory cards filled with sensitive data inside ordinary items, such as a sandwich or a pack of gum, and dropped them off at sites in Pennsylvania, Virginia, and West Virginia, with his wife acting as a lookout. They were indicted Tuesday on one count of conspiracy to communicate restricted data and two counts of communication of restricted data. Each of those charges carries a maximum sentence of life imprisonment and a $100,000 fine. In court Wednesday, Toebbe waived his right to a detention hearing and was ordered to remain in custody. But attorneys for his wife, who‚Äôs accused of aiding and abetting her husband, maintained their client‚Äôs innocence and contested an effort to keep her behind bars before the case goes to trial. FBI Special Agent Peter Olinits testified about the pains the couple took to maintain a low-profile during the ‚Äúdead drop‚Äù deliveries. He said they wore hiking clothes to blend in, disabled their phones‚Äô location services and parked far enough away from the drop-off sites to check if they were being followed. Olinits said the couple was paid $100,000 in untraceable cryptocurrency, a fraction of the $5 million sum Toebbe allegedly sought. That money, he said, still hasn‚Äôt been recovered. A search of the couple‚Äôs Annapolis home found $11,300 in cash, a specialized wallet for cryptocurrency, and a ‚Äúgo bag‚Äù containing a laptop computer and latex gloves, Olinits said. He said authorities also found a trash bag filled with shredded documents of sensitive data. The agent cited a letter Jonathan Toebbe allegedly wrote in which he expressed a willingness to flee the country at a moment‚Äôs notice. He also pointed to conversations the couple allegedly had over an encrypted messaging app, in which they discussed plans to leave the country. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúI have considered the possible need to leave on short notice,‚Äù read a message left on the memory card at one of the drop-offs. ‚ÄúShould that ever become necessary, I will be forever grateful for your help extracting me and my family.‚Äù The FBI did not name the country that had allegedly been approached by Jonathan Toebbe to buy the documents. Olinits said the agency is looking into whether any other foreign governments may have been sought out to buy the top-secret information. He also said the government has yet to recover all of the classified documents they believe Toebbe allegedly stole. Under cross examination, Olinits acknowledged besides surveillance images of Diana Toebbe at three of four ‚Äúdead drop‚Äù locations, investigators did not have concrete evidence proving that she had access to sensitive data or knew about everything her husband ‚Äúwas up to.‚Äù Federal prosecutors argued that Diana Toebbe was complicit in the plot. If released, they said, she poses a flight risk and has the potential to obstruct justice by altering or destroying evidence. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt have any evidence of this stuff, of her knowing what her husband was up to,‚Äù defense attorney Edward MacMahon said, calling the government‚Äôs arguments ‚Äúpurely speculative.‚Äù MacMahon insisted his client was unaware of what her husband was doing. He said messages the government intercepted about her wanting to leave the country referred to her dislike of then-President Donald Trump and were not about evading law enforcement. The defense proposed freeing their client on bond under the conditions that she is on home detention with active monitoring and that she does not have access to the internet. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not going to flee the United States and leave her children, who need her, here,‚Äù MacMahon said. ‚ÄùThat‚Äôs not going to happen.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized U.S. Magistrate Judge Robert Trumble did not make an immediate decision on Diana Toebbe‚Äôs status Wednesday, saying he would consider the attorneys‚Äô arguments and issue a written ruling later.

headline: Howard Community College Gets Lion‚Äôs Share Of Over $25M In Grant Funding For New Construction
summary: The community college will receive an $18,458,000 grant to replace its existing athletic and fitness center with two new buildings that will house its athletic department and mathematics department.
bodytext: COLUMBIA, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Governor Larry Hogan on Wednesday announced over $25 million in grants to four colleges in Maryland for new construction. Over 70 percent of that funding went to Howard Community College in Columbia. The community college will receive an $18,458,000 grant to replace its existing athletic and fitness center with two new buildings that will house its athletic department and mathematics department. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The second-largest grant went to Cecil College, receiving just over $3.7 million for a new entrance to the campus and to replace its facilities management building. Mount St. Mary‚Äôs University is receiving nearly $3 million for renovations and an addition to the Knott Academic Center, and Carroll Community College is using its $227,000 grant to replace certain building systems on its main campus. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ‚ÄúHigher education plays a critical role in providing opportunities for our students, contributing to our workforce pipeline, and maintaining our quality of life,‚Äù said Governor Hogan. ‚ÄúOur citizens deserve world-class institutions that provide a strong educational foundation, and these investments will help these higher education institutions continue to achieve that goal.‚Äù The grants are administered through the Maryland Department of General Services‚Äô Capital Grants division and the Public Schools & Community Colleges Construction Program. ¬† MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†

headline: Weather Blog: Pull Out The Ravens Hoodie This Weekend
summary: Marty's blog
bodytext: Hi Everyone! ¬† ¬†So we know that the real Fall feel is on the way. Combined with the really MILD temps we have had, and still will have through the end of the week, THAT fact has been a shared headline. But here comes Fall, and just in time for the weekend. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ¬† Behind the cold front coming through Friday night, there will not only be a wind shift but a pressure gradient will set up, and that means breezy conditions. That means with a high of, say, 62¬∞ and a breeze of, say, 15-20 mph, should we start to use the wind chill? I am sure the computer will calculate the real feel down into the mid-50s, and maybe a click or two lower. But are ‚ÄúCHILLS‚Äù in the 50s enough of a shock to the system to include it in a weather broadcast. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ¬† I think for the ‚Äúfirst time‚Äù uniqueness of it, maybe so. And it is the ‚Äúfirst time‚Äù that will really trigger the feel that the north wind, called Boreas by mariners, is taking control. That means before not too long the polar vortex delivered by Boreas will have us dreaming of the southerly humid wind known to boaters as Notus. And that fact is noted! ¬†¬†The Ravens hoodie for sure this weekend! FOR SURE, wind chill graphic or not. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† MB!

headline: Man, Woman Injured In Northwest Baltimore Shooting
summary: Officers responded shortly after 3 a.m. to the 5100 block of Linden Heights for a reported shooting.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A man and woman were injured in a double shooting in Baltimore early Thursday morning, police said.   Officers responded shortly after 3 a.m. to the 5100 block of Linden Heights for a reported shooting. There, they found the victims, a 25-year-old man and a woman.   Both were transported to a hospital. Their condition has not been disclosed.   Detectives are asking anyone with information to contact them at 410-396-2466 or Metro Crime Stoppers at 1-866-7Lockup.

headline: ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Be Shocked By Anything When These Two Teams Get Together‚Äô: CBS Sports‚Äô Rick Neuheisel Previews LSU-#12 Ole Miss And 3 More Games
summary: CBS Sports' Rick Neuheisel breaks down LSU vs. #12 Mississippi and other key college football matchups.
bodytext: (CBS Local Sports) ‚Äî  Another week of college football season means another full schedule of games on CBS and CBS Sports Network. In the SEC, LSU and #12 Ole Miss look to run up the score. #16 Wake Forest tries to sort out Army‚Äôs triple-option offense. In the Mountain West, #22 San Diego State pits its top-flight run defense against Air Force‚Äôs own version of the triple-option. Colorado State faces Utah State. CBS‚Äôs Norm Elrod talked to CBS Sports‚Äô Rick Neuheisel about the matchups. LSU @ #12 Mississippi: October 23, 3:30 p.m. ET on CBS READ MORE:  Bengals Visit Ravens With AFC North Lead On The Line Both offenses have shown they can move the ball. And both defenses don‚Äôt seem capable of slowing anyone down. Do you see this game turning into a shootout? ‚ÄúIt certainly could. Anytime Ole Miss is involved, the number that is expected to be on the scoreboard looks more like a slot machine than a football game. But I do think that we saw some pretty darn spirited defense by Ole Miss last week against Tennessee. And while the numbers didn‚Äôt show it, I think LSU is also capable of playing good defense. So I don‚Äôt necessarily think it‚Äôs going to be an outrageous number, but don‚Äôt be shocked by anything when these two teams get together, especially these two head coaches.‚Äù #16 Wake Forest @ Army: October 23, 12:00 p.m. ET on CBS Sports Network Wake Forest comes in ranked 16th and still undefeated. But they‚Äôll face an Army team that‚Äôs won 13 straight at home and played well against Wisconsin last week. Can Wake Forest handle that triple-option offense of Army? ‚ÄúThe good news for Wake Forest is they had an extra week to get ready for it. They did not play last week. And so when you get a couple of weeks to practice for it, it becomes a little bit less the albatross that it is in just a couple of padded days in practice, because it‚Äôs a very assignment-oriented game when you‚Äôre playing triple-option offense. Your eyes have to be in the right place. And then you have to trust what you see. If your eyes get a little bit lost and you start getting in places where you‚Äôre trying to what I call put on a cape and make plays that aren‚Äôt your plays, you‚Äôre going to get made to look foolish. And that has certainly happened to teams that play triple option. So I like Wake Forest‚Äôs chances, because they‚Äôve had the extra week.‚Äù READ MORE:  'Happy Halloween, Scooby-Doo!' On The Big Screen At M&T Bank Stadium Tonight #22 San Diego State @ Air Force: October 23, 7:00 p.m. ET on CBS Sports Network Over in the Mountain West, San Diego State remains undefeated after getting past San Jose State. San Diego State defends the run well, but Air Force leads the country in average rushing yards per game. How do you see this one playing out? ‚ÄúAgain, triple-option. San Diego State has been fantastic against the run. They lead the country in that department. And they play against themselves, which is primarily a running team. But this is a little bit different, when you try to play all the different nuances that these triple-option service academy teams have. And so, I understand why those in the desert have Air Force as a slight favorite, despite the fact that the Aztecs are undefeated.‚Äù Colorado State @ Utah State: October 22, 9:30 p.m. ET on CBS Sports Network Colorado State has won two straight and is playing well. Utah State just barely slipped by the winless UNLV. But all in all, these teams are pretty close. Can Colorado State win this one on the road? MORE NEWS:  Turgeon Still Hoping For Long Postseason Run At Maryland ‚ÄúThey can. They certainly have played well at times this year. Utah State, when they‚Äôre on all cylinders, is a tough out, especially in Logan. Blake Anderson, their head coach, is a guy that has had great success. It took a little bit of late-game heroics to knock off previously winless UNLV. But sometimes when you find a way to steal one at the end, it can have a lasting impact. And the fact that they‚Äôre going home probably gives the Aggies a little bit of an edge.‚Äù

headline: If You Don‚Äôt Know Where Your Onions Came From, Throw Them Away To Prevent Salmonella, CDC Says
summary: The CDC said 652 people have been infected with salmonella -- and there have been 129 hospitalizations. No deaths have been reported.
bodytext: (CNN) ‚Äî  A  salmonella  outbreak that has sickened more than 600 people in 37 states has been linked to various types of imported onions, federal health officials said Wednesday. ‚ÄúThrow away any unlabeled onions at home. Do not eat, sell, or serve red, white, or yellow onions imported from Mexico and distributed U.S.-wide by ProSource Inc,‚Äù the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)  warned in a tweet . READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The  CDC  said 652 people have been infected with salmonella ‚Äî and there have been 129 hospitalizations. No deaths have been reported. ‚ÄúEpidemiologic and traceback data show that one source of infections in this outbreak are whole red, white, and yellow onions imported from Chihuahua, Mexico, and distributed throughout the United States by ProSource Inc,‚Äù the CDC said in a statement. Multiple people who contracted salmonella ate onions at the same restaurant, according to epidemiological interviews conducted by the CDC. The number of people sick with this salmonella outbreak is likely higher than reported, and it‚Äôs possible the outbreak isn‚Äôt limited to the reported states, the CDC said. ‚ÄúThis is because many people recover without medical care and are not tested for Salmonella,‚Äù the agency said. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall In addition to throwing away onions, people should wash surfaces where there was contact and reach out to a doctor if severe salmonella symptoms develop. Symptoms include bloody diarrhea and a high fever, extensive vomiting and signs of dehydration, which usually begin six hours to six days after infection, according to the  CDC . Federal health officials are investigating to determine whether other onions and suppliers are linked to this outbreak. An estimated 1.35 million Salmonella cases occur annually in the US, with about 420 deaths, according to the  CDC . Infection usually happens by eating foods contaminated with animal feces. Onions last year  were also the cause of a salmonella outbreak that infected 640 people from more than 40 states. Also last year, at least 55 people became sick in 12 different states after a salmonella outbreak was linked to  dried wood ear mushrooms , the CDC said. And  peaches and their products were recalled  in 2020 after 101 people were sickened in 17 states by salmonella poisoning linked to the fruit. headline: Daily Forecast: A Journey Up The Thermometer Today
summary: Here we go toward 79¬∞ today.
bodytext: Hi Everyone! ¬† Here we go toward 79¬∞ today. Simple as that. And the journey up the thermometer will be steady, not slow and steady, ¬†but pretty dramatic. By lunch, we will be within arms reach of 70¬∞. By noon already 5¬∞ above the average daytime high. ¬†By 2:30 squarely in the mid-70s, and still climbing. By 3:30 some thermometers will be at 79¬∞. And what makes this even better is the very gentle slide down the numbers as we head toward evening. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School ¬†¬†Usually, there is a ten-degree difference between being in the sun and shade. But after a high of 79¬∞ by 6 p.m., we will still be in the low 70‚Äôs. This next overnight will be another mild one with city temperatures no lower than the mid 50s. A full 10¬∞ above the average overnight low. The heat pump high to our South is still in control. A fine run he‚Äôs had. Numbers do not lie. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall ¬†¬†And sorry to say breezy highs in the low 60‚Äôs this weekend that could feel like the mid to low 50‚Äôs. Yes, a bit of a wind chill can be calculated over Saturday and Sunday. Another case of the numbers just speaking the truth. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ¬†¬†¬†¬† Marty B!

headline: FBI: Cash, Shredded Papers Seen At Toebbe‚Äôs Annapolis Home In Spy Case
bodytext: WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî  The FBI found a trash bag of shredded documents, thousands of dollars in cash, latex gloves and a ‚Äúgo-bag‚Äù when they searched the home of a Maryland couple¬† accused of trying to sell information about nuclear-powered warships to a foreign country, ¬†an agent testified Wednesday. Jonathan Toebbe, a Navy nuclear engineer, and his wife, Diana, were¬† arrested in West Virginia this month. ¬†Prosecutors allege that Jonathan Toebbe tried to pass secrets about sophisticated and expensive¬† Virginia-class submarines ¬†to someone he thought was a representative of a foreign government but who was actually an undercover FBI agent. The government accuses Diana Toebbe of serving as a lookout for her husband at several ‚Äúdead drop‚Äù locations at which sensitive information was left behind. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School The couple  pleaded not guilty  in federal court in Martinsburg, West Virginia to espionage-related charges that carry life in prison. The Toebbes have been jailed since their arrests. The country to which Toebbe was looking to sell the information has not been identified in court documents and was not disclosed in court during a detention hearing Wednesday. A judge heard arguments but did not immediately rule on whether Diana Toebbe should continue to be locked up. Jonathan Toebbe waived his right to a detention hearing, meaning he continues to be held. Peter Olinits, a Pittsburgh-based agent specializing in counterintelligence investigations, testified in support of the government‚Äôs argument that Diana Toebbe was a potential flight risk and should remain jailed as the case moved forward. He described how agents on the day of the couple‚Äôs arrest found in their home, among other objects, $11,300 in cash, children‚Äôs valid passports and a ‚Äúgo-bag‚Äù containing a USB flash drive and latex gloves. Olinits also cited messages from 2019 and 2020 in which the Toebbes discussed leaving the country, including one in which Diana Toebbe said, ‚ÄúI cannot believe that the two of us wouldn‚Äôt be welcomed and rewarded by a foreign government.‚Äù Months later, in another message, she said, ‚ÄúI think we need to be actively making plans to leave the country,‚Äù according to Olinits. But Diana Toebbe‚Äôs lawyer, Edward MacMahon, raised the possibility that his 45-year-old client, who worked as a teacher at a progressive private school in Annapolis, Maryland, was simply referring to her distress over the prospect of President Donald Trump‚Äôs reelection. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs not the only liberal that‚Äôs wanted to leave the country over politics,‚Äù MacMahon pointed out. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs correct, isn‚Äôt it, sir?‚Äù READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The investigation began in late 2020 after an FBI legal attache office in an unspecified country obtained a package that prosecutors say Jonathan Toebbe had sent that nation. In a letter, he offered to sell confidential U.S. Navy information, according to prosecutors. The letter, sent on April 1, 2020, and bearing a return address in Pittsburgh, says: ‚ÄúIf you do not contact me by December 31, 2020 I will conclude you are uninterested, and will approach other possible buyers,‚Äù according to Olinits‚Äô testimony. After receiving the letter, the FBI began using an undercover agent to communicate with Jonathan Toebbe, arranging for the information to be deposited at ‚Äúdead drop‚Äù locations around the region. Olinits testified that Diana Toebbe accompanied her husband on three of the four missions. To avoid suspicion, Olinits said, the Toebbes would dress as if tourists or hikers and meander around the drop site. Authorities say Jonathan Toebbe left at the locations memory cards containing government secrets, concealing them in objects including a chewing gum wrapper, a Band-Aid wrapper and a peanut butter sandwich. Olinits said the FBI has not been able to locate the roughly $100,000 in cryptocurrency payments that the bureau sent the Toebbes in exchange for the stolen government secrets, and that agents have also not yet recovered all the classified documents. MacMahon, the lawyer for Diana Toebbe, argued that because the FBI did not record any of the couple‚Äôs conversations, agents actually had no proof that his client had any knowledge of her husband‚Äôs activities or what precisely he was doing. He said the couple, who has children, had been planning a family trip, which could explain the bag that agents found and why their passports were being renewed. And he suggested that Diana Toebbe, who has a doctoral degree in anthropology, has no knowledge of nuclear submarines. ‚ÄúDid it occur to you as part of your investigation that maybe Mr. Toebbe was telling her he was up to something other than espionage against the United States?‚Äù MacMahon asked. MORE NEWS:  Vaccinations For Younger Children Could Be Approved Next Month; The Latest On Outbreaks In Maryland Schools As 7 Children Hospitalized ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôd be a difficult thing to sell, but maybe,‚Äù Olinits said.

headline: COVID-19 In Maryland: Over 1,000 New Cases Reported, Key Metrics Decline
summary: Maryland reported 1,069 new COVID-19 cases and 14 new deaths, according to state health department data released Thursday morning.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland reported 1,069 new COVID-19 cases and 14 new deaths, according to state health department data released Thursday morning. The percentage of people testing positive decreased slightly by 0.07% to 3.29%. READ MORE:  Memorial Service Announced For Elijah Gorham At Mervo High School Doctors say the new cases are fueled by dangerous strains targeting the unvaccinated. During an August press conference, Gov. Larry Hogan said the Delta variant, a strain that is reportedly two to four times more contagious than the original virus strain, accounts for nearly every new confirmed case in Maryland. ‚ÄúThe vaccines are without a doubt our single most effective tool to mitigate the threat of COVID-19 and the surging Delta variant, and Maryland‚Äôs vaccination rate continues to outpace the nation,‚Äù Hogan said. More than 3.96 million Maryland adults are fully vaccinated. Hospitalizations decreased by 14 to 668. Of those hospitalized, 494 remain in acute care and 177 are in the ICU. Since the pandemic began, there were 553,593 total confirmed cases and 10,540 deaths. There are 3,979,681 Marylanders fully vaccinated. The state has administered 8,257,802 doses. Of those, 4,033,644 are first doses with 4,062 administered in the past 24 hours. They have given out 3,670,895 second doses, 4,256 in the last day. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of people who have rolled up their sleeves, Maryland continues to be one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan of the eight million milestone mark. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù The state began to administer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine again in April after the CDC and FDA lifted their pause on the vaccine due to a rare blood clot found in some women. A total of 308,786 Marylanders have received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 386 in the last day. On September 24, after the CDC granted final approval for Pfizer‚Äôs booster, Gov. Hogan announced the immediate authorization of the booster shot for Marylanders who have received their second Pfizer shot at least six months ago. Hogan  had already approved use  for vulnerable populations in early September. READ MORE:  President Joe Biden Addresses Several Issues During Thursday Night's Town Hall The state has administered 244,477 additional or booster vaccine doses, 10,667 in the last day. The state reported 85.3% of all adults in Maryland have received at least one dose of the vaccine. ‚ÄúThanks to the millions of Marylanders who have rolled up their sleeves over the past 10 months, Maryland is one of the most vaccinated states in America,‚Äù said Governor Hogan. ‚ÄúWe have achieved these numbers with strong public health outreach, innovative lottery and scholarship promotions, and a relentless focus on equity.‚Äù In August, the state launched a post-vaccination infections dashboard that is updated every Wednesday. There have been 27,420 total cases among fully vaccinated Marylanders as of last Wednesday, October 20. Less than 0.76% of fully vaccinated Marylanders have later tested positive. Of those cases, 1,995 vaccinated Marylanders were hospitalized, representing 11.3% of all Covid cases hospitalized in the state. 261 fully vaccinated Marylanders have died, representing 11.8% of lab-confirmed Covid deaths in the state.
